HEADLINE: 'Junior Partner'? No Way

BYLINE: By Gennadi A. Zyuganov; Gennadi A. Zyuganov is the leader of the Russian Communist Party.

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
It is often said in the American press that Russia's Communists are by definition unfriendly to reform and to the United States. Yet the Communist Party of the Russian Federation was born six years ago precisely as a party of reform in opposition to decades of stagnation and to Mikhail Gorbachev's itch for revolution. While the West sang hallelujahs to perestroika, we knew that revolutions in Russia have always had painful consequences.
We thus called for evolutionary reform consistent with Russian historical traditions and world trends. Unfortunately, we were not listened to, and the Soviet Union collapsed. 
 Boris Yeltsin's regime has thoughtlessly tried to bring the "blessings" of neo-liberalism to Russia, whose economy and character are quite different from those in the West. The results have been disastrous: The gross domestic product and living standards have fallen drastically. Mr. Yeltsin's promises to increase social spending and improve living conditions are merely an electoral maneuver.
Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin are considered friends of the United States. Although we are denied this honor, we will share with you our view of post-Yeltsin relations between the United States and Russia and of Russian foreign policy.
We would restore the might of the Russian state and its status in the world. That would make its policies incomparably more predictable and responsible than they are today.
Our foreign policy priority would be to maintain continuity with the foreign policies of pre-revolutionary Russia and the Soviet Union. We would seek to restore our state's unique role as the pivot and fulcrum of a Eurasian continental bloc -- and its consequent role as a necessary balance between East and West.
We consider the disruption of military and strategic parity caused by the collapse of the Soviet Union dangerously destabilizing. And we see the restoration of the union of the former Soviet peoples -- based on voluntary association -- as a historical necessity dictated by Russia's needs and those of world security. Guided by pragmatism, we would free foreign policy of ideology, which imposes ruinous actions and obligations. We reject fantasies about "world revolution" but also consider the "new world order" no less alien to Russian interests. And we would stringently adhere to universal moral principles and the norms of international law.
Above all, we would concentrate on internal healing and national rebirth. The foreign policy conducive to this effort would be limited to maintaining state security. This rules out being drawn into supranational organizations that claim the right to interfere in others' internal affairs. Thus, we take an extremely negative view of plans to expand NATO into Eastern Europe, up to Russia's border, and we regard the entry of NATO troops into the former Yugoslavia as the first step toward carrying out those dangerous plans.
Several years have passed since the cold war ended, but relations between our countries are far from harmonious. Though it must renounce useless and excessive military spending, Russia never was -- or could be -- a "junior partner." For Americans, too, the burden of being the only superpower is unnecessary and undesirable. Any policy that counts on Russia's remaining in its humiliating position, following in the American wake, is doomed to defeat.
We respect your democratic traditions and outstanding achievements. We are deeply interested in expanding economic cooperation and educational, scientific and cultural exchanges. We are ready to guarantee American investments and to create better conditions for them than now exist.
Recognizing the uniqueness of the American experience, we insist on acknowledgment of our equal right to follow our own path in accordance with our traditions and conditions. The principle of diversity, on which you have successfully based your domestic policy, should extend to foreign policy as well.

HEADLINE: Chicago Gives a Pedestrian Mall the Boot

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 31

 BODY:
There was a time when no place in town was quite so jaunty as State Street on a Saturday night. "On State Street, that great street," sang Frank Sinatra in the song "Chicago," "I just want to say, they do things they don't do on Broadway."
But State Street, in the heart of downtown's Loop, has been struggling for decades, as theater-goers and shoppers have moved to the suburbs and the stores and cinemas have followed. City planners, trying to replicate the success of suburban shopping malls, in 1979 turned a mile-long stretch of State into its own kind of mall, closing the street to traffic, except for buses. But rather than make the street snazzy again, the mall worsened the slump by giving State a quiet, deserted, even dangerous feel. 
 Now, the pedestrian mall is getting what retailers say it has long deserved: jackhammers. The city is going to rip up the broad pedestrian walkways and turn State back into a street, with standard sidewalks and two-way traffic.
"The mall took the excitement out of State Street," said Elizabeth Hollander, who was Chicago's planning commissioner in the 1980's and is now director of a center for urban affairs at DePaul University. "Planners are rethinking these kinds of urban malls. They've learned that cities are different than suburbs. And cities ought to do what cities do best, which is crowd a lot of people together."
More than 200 cities have created pedestrian malls in the last 20 years, according to the American Planning Association. But many cities have reversed course and turned malls back into streets, including Eugene, Ore.; Little Rock, Ark.; Norfolk, Va.; Rockford, Ill., and Oak Park, Ill. Officials in Baltimore are considering doing the same.
"Retailers believe opening the street to traffic means more activity," said Laurie Schwartz, president of the Downtown Partnership of Baltimore, which speaks for business interests. "And it reminds passers-by that stores are open for business."
In Chicago, mall promoters had envisioned a lively alfresco carnival of shoppers and gawkers, with Paris-style curbside cafes. Indeed, outdoor cafes did open. But the street remained open to bus traffic, and the cafe experience did not quite match the ambience of the Left Bank.
"The buses would line up, one after another, like a herd, with their diesel fumes," said Adrian Smith, a partner in the architectural firm Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, which is designing the new State Street, a $24.5 million project that will include special lighting, trees and other improvements.
Planners and architects point out that people like to go where other people are going. It did not help that the vast walkway of the mall gave State an empty look, which, together with the absence of cars, "gave it a deadened feel, like a ghost town," said Craig Wolf, a spokesman for the city's Department of Transportation.
For shopping, State Street has long been a sort of blue-collar cousin to the elegant North Michigan Avenue, which has prospered with upscale attractions like Neiman-Marcus, Saks Fifth Avenue, Burberry's and the Four Seasons Hotel. When affluent suburbanites come to Chicago for a weekend of shopping, it is almost always to North Michigan.
State Street still has the dowager Palmer House hotel, with its elegant lobby. And the street's spectacular Chicago Theater, built as a motion picture palace in the 1920's and styled after the Arc de Triomphe, has attracted the interest of the Walt Disney Company, which has been negotiating with the city on a deal to lease the theater for stage productions.
State Street is also the home address of the venerable Marshall Field department store, which was built in 1868 and then rebuilt after the Great Fire of 1871.
But several other department stores have disappeared from the street since the pedestrian mall was created, including Sears, Montgomery Ward and Goldblatt's.
Still, it is unclear how much the mall can be blamed for State Street's woes, since the economic troubles had started as early as the 1960's.
The stores on State have traditionally catered to middle-income people. And it is that middle-class base that has long been eroding in Chicago, as in many American cities. In the last 40 years, Chicago's population has dropped to 2.7 million, from 3.6 million, while the suburbs continue to grow, reaching deeper into farmland every year.
State Street retailers have long been pushing for the return of cars. Daniel J. Skoda, the president of Marshall Field, said that "bringing back the traffic won't be magic" in boosting sales, "but it's a key."
People on State Street on a recent morning, who were braving temperatures that hovered near zero and a stinging wind that sliced in from Lake Michigan, voiced strong support for bringing back traffic.
"Since people don't drive on State, they forget it's here," said Carmen Rocha, a 24-year-old sales manager who was waiting for a bus at the corner of State and Madison, once said to be the busiest intersection in America. "Hopefully, this will bring the suburbanites and the tourists back into the Loop."
Ann Kramer, a retired telephone operator, who remembers the glory days of State Street a half-century ago and more, said the mall "sounded like a good idea at the time," and added with a laugh, "So do a lot of things."
Mayor Richard M. Daley, who rode one of the jackhammers in a pavement-breaking ceremony on State last week, noted that the mall was so unpopular no one would take credit for its invention.
"As Mayor," Mr. Daley said with a smile, "I have found it difficult to find out whose idea this was in the first place."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Changing the tax system has an allure. But will the fixes work?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
TAX reform is the Republican flavor of the month. The Kemp Commission, recruited by Newt Gingrich to give his party a tonier image on economic issues, is calling for an end to the income tax as we know it. Steve Forbes's tireless pitch for the flat tax has helped him to break away from the pack chasing Bob Dole for the Republican Presidential nomination.
And why not? A makeover of taxes that promises, in the words of the Kemp Commission, to double the rate of economic growth, sure beats abortion or affirmative action as a party-unifying, good-news issue. 
 But most economists aren't buying it. For while it is hard to find a tax specialist who is not charmed by the prospect of starting afresh, virtually all think the Republicans are repackaging green veggies as triple-fudge ice cream.
"It is completely implausible that improving incentives to work, save and invest in a system that has already moved a long way in the right direction would make a significant difference to growth," argues William Gale, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
Nobody has a copyright on the term "tax reform." But for today's Republicans, reform means lower tax brackets and a shift to taxing consumption from savings and investment.
The logic behind lower maximum rates is familiar to anyone who stayed awake in Econ. 101. Income taxes create a wedge between what labor and capital are worth in a competitive market and what workers and capitalists receive as compensation. Make rates high enough, the thinking goes, and Silicon Valley's best and brightest will retire to Aspen. Likewise, economists are intrigued by the flat tax because it would tax the fruit while leaving the orchard to flourish.
So much for theory. How might the changes actually affect growth? There is a near-consensus that the effect would be positive. But with the striking exception of Martin Feldstein of Harvard, number-crunchers doubt that the impact would be visible to the naked eye.
The supply of labor. One way to get faster growth is to induce more people to work longer hours. But the evidence that lower rates make a big difference is underwhelming.
The maximum tax bracket fell from 91 percent to 70 percent in the 1960's under President John F. Kennedy, then to 50 in 1981. The most telling evidence comes, though, from the cut in maximum rates to 28 percent from 50 in 1986.
Randall Mariger, an economist at the Federal Reserve Board, found that rate changes increased the supply of labor by less than 1 percent between 1985 and 1988. Nada Eissa, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, discovered more movement into the labor force among married women with affluent spouses. But since their numbers are small, the overall response was consistent with Mr. Mariger's sobering conclusion.
Mr. Feldstein made a splash last November with the finding that the taxable income of the richest Americans fell by $31 billion after the maximum tax bracket was raised to 42 percent from 31 in 1993. But his research has been sharply challenged: most of the lost income may have been shifted back to 1992 in anticipation of the change. "Labor supply responses to tax rates -- especially tax rates that are already relatively low -- are quite modest," said Joel Slemrod of the University of Michigan Business School.
 
Savings. -- Computer simulations of a change from a tax on all income to a tax only on consumption would increase savings by one-fifth -- a heartening, if not earthshaking, change. But Mr. Gale says that 80 percent of savings is already sheltered in pension accounts. So the impact of sheltering the rest would be proportionately smaller.
Indeed, a switch to a consumption tax might even have perverse results. Without the incentive of tax breaks, Mr. Gale asks, "how many corporations would maintain their pension plans?"
 
Investment. -- Here the picture seems brighter: "I think there would be a substantial increase in investment," Mr. Gale said. But Mr. Slemrod of Michigan is quick to rain on the optimists' parade. For one thing, he says, industrial investment would grow at the expense of housing. For another, taxes on capital are lower than is widely understood, largely because of rapid write-offs allowed by Washington. Hence the potential bang is likely to be smaller than advertised.
It is easy to see why Republicans are flogging tax reform. And it is equally easy to see why many are entranced by the intellectual elegance and simplicity of the flat tax. But as the Kemp Commission's vision of sugar plums suggests, the gap between promise and reality is wide.
"The flat tax is fine in principle," Mr. Gale said. "But could you make it function in the real -- that is, messy -- world of politics?"

HEADLINE: Liberties;
The Faberge Egghead

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: DERRY, N.H.

 BODY:
If George Bush reminded some women of their first husband, Steve Forbes must remind them of their first husband's accountant.
He speaks in a monotone. He shows no emotion, except when he is pleased at some joke he has ventured, and then he looks, for a moment, like a bobbing-head doll in the back of a car: his head goes east to west, his smile goes north to south, and he gives a sort of snort-giggle. His flat-tax monomania makes past New Hampshire oratory, like "Message: I care," seem poetic. (Flat is right.) 
 When Mr. Forbes vows to take the tax code and "scrap it, kill it, drive a stake through its heart and bury it," it plays more Wally Cox than Colin Powell. And he occasionally gets tangled the way Mr. Bush did here with "Nitty Ditty Nitty Gritty Great Bird." Band. At the Nashua Country Club, the 48-year-old publisher lambasted critics of the flat tax as "Chicken Littles -- I don't mean to take Chicken Little's name in vain . . . these fearmongering Washington insider lawyer lobbyists Chicken Roosters or Chicken Littles, whatever they want to call themselves." (I cry fowl.)
Newsweek calls it "geek chic," and voters here like him. The Live-Free-or-Die crowd is not interested in nuance. They want ultimatums.
New Hampshire got fascinated by the unfascinating last time around, too. Paul Tsongas won the '92 Democratic primary with an eat-your-oat-bran economics message that struck many as refreshingly unvarnished. But then it turned out Lowell didn't play in Lubbock, and voters did not really want to sacrifice very much, much less everything, for the next generation.
(St. Paul is still literally wagging his finger at us on the cover of his new book, "Journey of Purpose," and warning that focusing on self "to the exclusion of our progeny" is "violative of basic human instincts.")
But Mr. Forbes's message is sunny -- "Ordinary people can achieve extraordinary deeds" -- and sunny is violative of dourness.
This is Bob Dole's Groundhog Day. In '88, the Dust Bowl Senator lost on the issue of taxes to a Topsidered scion with a goofy smile. At least the last preppie had a padded resume, compliments of his influential friends. This one has no political resume. At least the last one feigned liking pork rinds. This one is basing his whole campaign on a tax plan that would make the rich richer. (Asked by The Boston Globe why he hadn't campaigned in a lower-income area, Mr. Forbes replied that he had talked to Perot voters. "Oh, I have. I went before United We Stand. . . .")
It would be enough to give Bob Dole a dark, fatalistic view of life, except that he already has one. Just as well. Otherwise, how could he get through the spectacle of a Faberge egghead treating himself to a campaign and ending up the dorky darling of the White Mountains?
Mr. Dole got wounded three weeks before the war ended in Europe. He became Republican chairman just as Watergate was about to hit. When he ran on the ticket with Gerald Ford, they lost by two percentage points. He got beaten in New Hampshire in '88 when he did not take the no-new-taxes pledge that George Bush took and later broke.
This time, Mr. Dole signed the pledge and Steve Forbes comes bouncing up out of nowhere with a different angle. Once again, Mr. Dole looks downbeat when he points out that you can't cut everyone's taxes and still balance the budget.
Just when the 72-year-old Mr. Dole should be taking advantage of the Republican tradition of rewarding those who have paid their dues, he finds that the revolutionaries have burned down the clubhouse.
Bill Kristol, the editor of The Standard, who has wooed Colin Powell and raised the Dole age issue, now says: "I hope he can play the lion-in-winter card. There's something moving about the guy's stoicism."
It wasn't pretty yesterday when Mr. Dole showed up at the Nutfield Brewery in Derry for an event his staff had tried to cancel -- inaugurating a beer called Old Man Ale.
What was the symbolism, a reporter called out -- an old man in the White House?
Mr. Dole forced a smile and said the beer tasted "young and fresh." All this time spent waiting to run the country, and he still can't run a photo op?
No wonder Mr. Dole watches Steve Forbes in amazement. It's all geek to him.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off After Rates Are Cut By the Fed and the Bundesbank

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell slightly against most leading currencies yesterday, gaining little support from cuts in interest rates in the United States and Germany.
During trading in Asia yesterday, the dollar continued its recent rally against the German mark and the Japanese yen. But it later fell as traders took profits on the back of a German rate cut. 
 The Federal Reserve announced in the afernoon that it was cutting two interest rates, prompting the dollar to gyrate against the mark and yen in late trading.
The dollar settled slightly higher than the levels it reached just before the Fed announcement.
"There is no major reason to sell the dollar just because the Fed eased," said John Rothfield, an international economist at the Chicago office of Nationsbanc-CRT. "I think there would have been more of a reaction if the Fed hadn't moved."
In late trading, the dollar bought 1.4891 marks, compared with 1.4893 Tuesday. The dollar ended at 107.04 yen, down from 107.25 yen.
Now the markets' attention turns to the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, which is expected to decide today whether it will cut two other important rates.
European officials have been worried about their weakening economies, raising speculation that rates would be reduced to spur spending and lending. Expectations of lower rates have helped to lift the dollar in recent days to highs not seen in two years.
After the dollar continued higher during initial trading yesterday, traders collected profits in anticipation of the cuts and the dollar's value sagged.
Then, as expected, the German central bank allowed its two-week securities repurchase rate to drop and Belgium followed with a rate cut of its own.
Since rate reductions weaken a country's assets and make its currency less attractive, traders sought other currencies, including the Italian lira, the Spanish peseta, the French franc and the Swedish krona.
The Fed's move later was to lower two rates by a quarter point: its official discount rate, to 5 percent, and its target for the Federal funds rate, to 5.25 percent.
The Canadians followed with a quarter-point cut in the overnight lending rate.
Mr. Rothfield of Nationsbanc-CRT said that since the markets anticipated the rate cuts, there was no significant reaction other than the jitters in late trading in the United States.

HEADLINE: This Model Was Too Rough;
Why Economic Forecasting Became a Sideshow

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Want to know what I.B.M.'s in-house economist thinks is in store for the American economy in 1996? You're out of luck: the giant computer maker, which counted more than two dozen economists on its payroll in the early 1970's, no longer employs a single professional to estimate key numbers like interest rates, capital spending and inflation.
And the International Business Machines Corporation has lots of company. Dozens of other big corporations have either slashed or eliminated their forecasting staffs and signed up with commercial services to do their crystal gazing for them. "It's more economical," said Bruce Bunch, a spokesman for the General Electric Company, a conglomerate with $60 billion in annual sales -- and no in-house economist. 
 Actually, the cutbacks have a lot more to do with disillusionment than with dollars. Corporate America's faith in computer-model economic forecasting, already eroded by its failure to signal the stagflation of the late 1970's or the economic turnaround of the early 1980's, has been further shaken by recent research on the complexities of the buying habits of households and businesses.
As a result, most big companies today are giving short shrift to economic forecasting and focusing instead on reducing their exposure to risk. Rather than pouring numbers into computers, they are using financial derivatives to hedge against price and interest rate changes, are minimizing inventories and are employing temporary workers whenever possible.
That means, some people say, that a promising, if flawed, approach to corporate planning has been relegated to an undeserved limbo. If Americans held unrealistic expectations for forecasting in the 1960's -- as they did for so many other things in that optimistic age, from space exploration to big government -- they may now be setting their sights too low, proponents of forecasting say.
"Forecasts do a lot better than Ouija boards," said Stephen McNees, a former vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston who has been keeping track of the forecasters the lasttwo decades.
Academic critics must shoulder some of the blame for the failure of forecasting to live up to its early promise. In effect, they have abandoned the field to business economists with neither the time nor the incentives to break new ground. "Research economists have shown little interest in improving forecasting techniques or testing the models," lamented Ray Fair of Yale University, one of the few academics who still focuses on the field.
"Models" of the economy -- series of statistically estimated equations that describe the determinants of consumption, investment and the like -- were first put together in the 1930's. But most of the credit for developing them goes to Lawrence Klein, whose pioneering efforts in the 1950's later brought him the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science.
The 1960's were a golden era for the model builders, who constructed ever more elaborate edifices to simulate the economy and fed them into the big mainframe computers just coming onto the market. But hopes were dashed in the 1970's, when the models failed to meet the test of predicting the consequences of exploding oil prices.
For example, the President's Council of Economic Advisers' forecast for 1974 overestimated economic growth by a whopping three percentage points and underestimated inflation by the same figure. Most forecasters were also caught off guard by the severity of the 1980-82 recession that was triggered by the Federal Reserve Board's radical tightening of monetary policy and by the speedy turnaround in 1983.
These shortcomings reinforced objections from a new generation of theorists, many of them heavily influenced by the work of Robert Lucas, the Nobel-winning theorist from the University of Chicago. They complained in particular of forecasting's failure to account for the role of expectations in determining how businesses and households respond. For example, the computer models link personal consumption to take-home pay in relatively mechanical ways, while in reality the proportion of income that is spent may turn on expectations about tax and price increases and job security.
As doubts about its accuracy grew in the 1970's, academic interest in forecasting withered. While the Federal Reserve Board and a few universities, notably the University of Michigan, maintained computer models, most of the action shifted to business. "I.B.M. employed 26 Ph.D.'s and near-Ph.D.'s to run their own macro model," recalled Brian O'Connor, one of the 26. Big forecasting firms like Wharton Econometrics (since renamed WEFA) and Data Resources (now DRI/McGraw-Hill) provided retail shopping for companies that could not afford I.B.M.'s wholesale route.
As skepticism spread beyond academia in the 1980's, however, the forecasting industry underwent a shakeout in which corporations reduced or scuttled their forecasting departments and all but a handful of independent services went out of business. I.B.M. retired its entire staff. "Most now work as consultants for the forecasting services," Mr. O'Connor said. His own consulting firm, Ridgewood Economic Associates, sells forecasts to his old employer.
Alan P. Murray, now deputy general manager at Fuji Bank in New York, remembers the 1970's at Citibank, "when the budget was built around the bank's own forecast." Today, Citibank, the principal unit of Citicorp, has virtually abandoned in-house forecasting in favor of risk management. Rather than predicting interest rates and then borrowing and lending accordingly, for example, the bank matches liabilities against assets in ways intended to protect the bottom line no matter what happens to interest rates.
The decline of forecasting by banks, which had been among its most enthusiastic promoters, was hastened by deregulation, according to Robert R. Davis, chief economist for America's Community Banks, a trade association representing 2,000 savings institutions. "When banks were banned from paying interest on checking deposits," he recalled, "they gave away free services, including forecasts, to corporate customers." After the ban was lifted, he added, "depositors took the money."
While the reports generally don't come free today, they come relatively cheap. Most Fortune 500 companies buy forecasts from commercial services and, Mr. O'Connor noted, "For $500 a year, you can get 50-some opinions from Blue Chip Economic Indicators," a newsletter that surveys professional forecasters.
Companies that retain in-house forecasters usually piggyback on the commercial services -- a process facilitated by the revolution in desktop computing. Laurence Meyer & Associates in St. Louis offers a "small" macro model of 350 equations, ready to be plugged into any personal computer and used as a benchmark for specialized forecasts. "We use the Meyer model to test the coherence of our own assumptions and look at how others are thinking," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
The surviving forecasting services have one thing in common: flexibility. DRI/McGraw-Hill sells everything from raw data for the German economy to detailed predictions of computer industry revenues in the Middle Atlantic States along with generous dollops of interpretation. "Clients are saying 'we need you to make the numbers immediately relevant,' " said Roger Brinner, DRI/ McGraw-Hill's chief economist.
Even forecasting's most ardent disciples are quick to point out the limitations of its techniques. "They aren't good at timing issues -- say, predicting which quarter the recession will begin," said Mr. McNees, the former Boston Fed vice president who is now a private consultant. Nor do they accurately predict the impact of big shocks, like wars or energy supply disruptions.
What forecasting can do is improve the odds of accurately gauging trends and save companies -- and taxpayers -- money. Mr. Brinner proudly contends that DRI/McGraw-Hill has predicted auto sales better than any of the auto companies. And he is happy to recall that in 1992 his forecast spared Massachusetts the agony of massive spending cutbacks in response to the state's official projection of a 9 percent fall in revenues. DRI/McGraw-Hill used its more sophisticated resources to forecast virtually unchanged revenues -- a forecast that proved to be right on the nose.
Mr. McNees has looked at the errors made by a sample of private forecasters polled by the American Statistical Association. From 1972 through 1994 the forecasters' one-year-ahead forecasts of gross national product missed by an average of one percentage point, while the forecasts of inflation were off by an average of nine-tenths of a point.
That is roughly half the size of the errors generated by extrapolating from the previous four years. And while the record is mixed, private forecasts incorporating the economic assumptions of the 1960's generally do better than models that ask the computer to search randomly for statistical correlations in recorded data.
What frustrates Mr. Fair at Yale is that the science of forecasting has stalled. One reason, he argues, is that the computer results are always second-guessed by the forecasters before they are published. Even the Federal Reserve, which has a large staff to maintain its forecasting model and faces no competitive pressures, mixes technical rigor with seat-of-the-pants subjectivity. "The results of the model are one of many inputs into the Fed's forecasts," confirmed Janet Yellen, the newest member of the Fed's board of governors.
But the main drag on forecasting is the near-indifference of high-powered academic economists. Macro forecasting got its initial lift on the backs of giants. But only a few top-rank researchers, among them Mr. Fair of Yale and John Taylor of Stanford, remain innovators in the field of economics that is arguably the most important in day-to-day life.
Adding insult to injury, the decline in interest in macroeconomic theory also discouraged attention from statisticians searching for ways to suck more information, more reliably, out of less data. "Most of the forecasting models use statistical techniques dating from the 1950's," Mr. Fair said.
Saul Hymans, director of the University of Michigan's Research Seminar in Quantitative Economics, attributes much of the decline in academic interest to what he calls the "nihilist" disavowal of 1960's economics before more modern theory could be incorporated in forecasting models.
In other words, Mr. Hymans lamented, "We're losing sight of what we're supposed to be doing in economics."

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: REVENUES;
Parking Meters May Be Sold To a Company

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
New York State has sold off a prison and a highway to raise quick cash. Now the city wants to sell off one of its most familiar fixtures -- its parking meters.
In a complicated plan that is still short on detail, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed shifting the maintenance and operation of the city's 68,000 parking meters to a private company. 
 Under the proposal, the city would create a local authority to take control of the meters. That authority would in turn hire a private operator to run them. The authority would sell bonds that would provide as much as $300 million to the city up front. Revenues from the meters would be used to pay off the bonds and supply income to the private company. The city would continue to set the parking rates on the meters.
The Mayor and city budget officials touted the plan as a quick way to raise money while also improving city operations. But fiscal monitors immediately criticized the plan as a gimmick that would provide only temporary relief.
Calling the proposal a "particularly disturbing one-shot" that may eliminate revenue in future years, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said: "The city's excessive reliance on one-shots continues to reflect a lack of adequate planning for adverse developments."
The Mayor argued, however, that the parking meter plan, along with proposals to sell the Brooklyn Army Terminal, a city-run industrial complex in Sunset Park, and about 2,000 city-owned parking lots to private companies, could do more than offer one-time cash infusions. Although the Mayor's plan states that those measures would give the city a $300 million boost next year, Mr. Giuliani said contracts could require the private companies to share future revenues with the city.
"Those items will have recurring value to the city," he said. "If we use the models of other cities, we would be partners in the proceeds and would be able to realize even more revenues than we realize now."
John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for economic development, said selling the Brooklyn Army Terminal and the vacant lots would essentially help get the city out of the business of property management.
"We need to focus down on the essentials of city government," Mr. Dyson said. "Because the city traditionally did too much, I think it's fair to say that it didn't do anything very well. If we did fewer things, we could do the remaining things better."
Although the city has never before privatized parking meters in the way Mr. Giuliani proposes, over the last 30 years the city has tried numerous times to have private contractors handle parking meter collections. But the city created its own Parking Meter Service Unit in 1987, after dozens of employees from private collection companies were charged with large-scale theft from the city.
Mr. Dyson noted, however, that the city has been doing what he characterized as a "less than crisp" job of operating the meters, noting that about 11 percent of the meters are broken at any given time.
The Mayor's plan also recommended a variety of other new sources of money for the city. Among them is a plan to sell one of seven police helicopters, to raise $150,000. And the Mayor proposes to charge a funeral-related fee of $25 to get approval from the Department of Health to carry out a cremation. The city reviews about 7,500 deaths each year solely to grant permission for cremation, and officials estimate that the new fee would bring in about $187,000 a year.
Other proposals include:
*A new $390 fee on civil service exams for police officers to help cover the cost of psychological, medical and drug tests and background investigations. That fee is expected to raise $663,000 for the city.
*Increases in parking fees at Shea and Yankee Stadiums for an additional $435,000 in income. Parking rates would go from $5 to $6 for cars, $12 to $15 for limousines and $15 to $18 for buses.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
It's No Rally, But Bonds Do Move Higher

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved moderately higher yesterday but fell short of the strong rally some traders expected after a cut in short-term rates by the Federal Reserve Board.
The reduction was the third by the Fed in eight months as it has attempted to reignite the economy; the last cut came on Dec. 19. 
 The announcement, following a meeting of the Fed's Federal Open Market Committee, cited "moderating economic expansion" as the reason for the cut. But with the outcome widely anticipated in the market, prices of Government securities eased after an initial surge when the Fed reduced the Federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.25 percent, and the discount rate by a similar amount, to 5 percent.
By late in the day some big banks -- notably Chase Manhattan and NBD Bank in Detroit -- were lowering their prime lending rates to 8.25 percent from 8.50 percent.
Early in the session, data on producer prices and the Chicago purchasing manager's index had a mild impact on trading. December producer prices rose over all by five-tenths of 1 percent, with the closely watched core rates -- excluding the more volatile food and energy sectors -- up only a tenth of 1 percent. The Chicago purchasing managers' index came in at 50.9 for December, below the 53.0 that had been expected, and at 54.8 for November, after a downward revision.
Early rumors suggesting that the Fed would make an early announcement yesterday caused bond prices to trade higher. The March bond futures contract was as high as 121 7/32, with the low price at 120 13/32 before closing at 120 31/32. Still, it is well below the top of the current consolidation range, of between 121 28/32 and 122 10/32, that has held since the beginning of December.
But the Fed played coy in saying it had no idea when the announcment would be made, only to make announce its action when it typically has done so, around 2:15 P.M.
The 30-year bond rose 5/32, to 111 23/32 to yield 6.02 percent, down from 6.04 percent on Tuesday.
The Treasury announced that next week it planned to sell $18.5 billion of three-year notes on Tuesday; $14 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday, and $8 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday, along with $8 billion of seven-day cash management bills. By late in the day, in when-issued trading, the three-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.03 percent, the 10-year note was at 5.57 percent, and the 30-year bond was at 5.97 percent.
P. Christopher Leary, senior vice president and portfolio manager at SunAmerica Asset Management, said that to a certain extent yesterday was a "buy the rumor, sell on the fact type of day."
He added, "I think the more speculative investors were holding out for a 50-basis-point cut on both key rates."
 He did, however, note some significance in the announcement by the Fed. He said that the Fed, for the first time he could recall, mentioned the strength of the economy, and not just inflation, in making its announcement.
"I think this is really a significant week: a lot of data, the F.O.M.C. meeting and the quarterly refunding announcement," Mr. Leary said. "Supply is always an unknown, given the fact that between now and the refunding the high probability is that we get more weak economic data highlighted by the nonfarm payroll data on Friday."

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: THE OVERVIEW;
GIULIANI'S BUDGET CUTS SPENDING 5% AND LOWERS TAXES

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented a preliminary $31 billion budget yesterday that would cut New York City's total spending by nearly 5 percent, continue to reduce taxes and rely heavily on help from Albany and Washington that appears unlikely to come.
As he presented the rough outline of his third budget as Mayor, Mr. Giuliani said the city needed to cut still more to reverse decades of overspending. But this time he couched his austere message in the language of compassion that has marked his oratory in recent weeks. 
 Even as he vowed to protect "the most vulnerable in society," the Mayor accepted the deeper cuts in welfare and Medicaid proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki, a fellow Republican. And he proposed nearly $700 million in cuts to most of the city's agencies, raising the prospect of further erosion of services used by thousands, if not millions, of New Yorkers.
"Balancing the numbers of the budget, however, is the easiest part of it," Mr. Giuliani said, presenting his proposals in the old Board of Estimate Chambers at City Hall. "The most important part of it is that it balance the needs of people, that it balance the needs of society, that it can't be devoted to one priority."
The Mayor's budget would cut spending on the city's public schools by $160 million, or 5 percent, even as the Board of Education faces deeper cuts in aid from the state and Federal governments. It would also cut emergency rent assistance for poor tenants and lunch subsidies for welfare recipients in job training.
The city's recycling program would face new cuts, as would the three library systems, which may have to close some branches an additional day. Now they are open six days a week.
The city's museums and cultural institutions, from the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, also face a 16 percent cut in the city's steadily declining subsidies.
"There are very few people who understand the role of the museums better than the Mayor," said William H. Luers, the president of the Metropolitan, citing the museum's role as a magnet for tourism. "This kind of cut can only show that this is a very bad year. It's going to be very difficult for us to make up this money."
The Mayor's preliminary proposal, the first step in a long march toward a final budget for the fiscal year that begins in July, came under immediate attack from various quarters.
The city's fiscal monitors and bond raters strongly criticized the plan. They dismissed the Mayor's declaration that he had finally begun to untangle the city's fiscal problems and accused him of relying on budgetary gimmicks and unrealistic assumptions to balance the budget.
A major credit rating agency, Moody's Investors Service, said the city's bond rating, already among the lowest of any major city, could fall further. Richard P. Larkin, managing director of Standard & Poor's, the other major rating agency, said the Mayor's budget confirmed the expectations that caused his agency to lower the rating last year.
"It's pretty much what we expected when we lowered the rating," Mr. Larkin said. "The city continues to live year to year."
The city's Democratic elected officials denounced many of the cuts as unacceptable and misguided. The City Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, criticized the Mayor for not having embraced his proposal to use the 12.5 percent surcharge on the city's income tax for a program to rebuild schools, instead of allowing the tax to expire in December as a tax cut.
"It's more pain and no gain," said Mr. Vallone, who will lead negotiations with Mr. Giuliani over the final shape of a budget.
The preliminary budget announced yesterday reflected the Mayor's proposals for closing a projected budget gap of $2 billion for the fiscal year that begins in July. It is almost certain to change in the months ahead.
The gap has arisen despite Mr. Giuliani's two years of cutting, including the reduction of 17,000 municipal employees, because the city's spending continues to rise faster than revenues.
In some ways, the Mayor's proposal represented a departure from the past. For the first time, he proposed cutting the Police Department's $2 billion budget, reducing the police force by 900 from its current level and by 1,500 from the peak of 38,310 last year mandated by the state law known as Safe Streets, Safe City.
In all, the Mayor plans to reduce the payroll by at least 3,000 workers, to 203,000 by the end of the next fiscal year, imposing a strict hiring freeze to cut jobs as workers retire or otherwise leave their jobs.
The proposal also calls for laying off 150 workers at the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, the independent agency that operates the city's 11 hospitals and medical centers. Those would be the first layoffs of unionized workers under Mr. Giuliani, who has so far reduced the work force by attrition and severance packages.
In addition to the cuts in agency spending, the Mayor's budget would rely on $650 million in savings in the city's share of Medicaid and welfare, which the Governor has proposed reducing, as well as $100 million in new state aid for jails, busing for disabled preschoolers and City University of New York. The plan also hopes for $50 million from the Federal Government -- mostly, the Mayor said, in crime-fighting aid.
The Mayor said the largest slice from the state, at $351 million, should come from the $1.3 billion the state hopes to receive from the Federal Government under a new formula for Medicaid. That new formula, however, has languished in the budget impasse in Washington. Even if approved, the Governor has proposed keeping the $1.3 billion to balance the state's budget.
In Albany yesterday, aides to Mr. Pataki and the Republican majority leader of the Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, said it would be difficult for the state to agree to more aid, given its own budget gaps and the uncertainty from Washington. The Governor's spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, suggested that the Mayor should instead do more to support the $955 million in savings Mr. Pataki's budget would give, although city officials have said the savings are exaggerated.
Mr. Giuliani, in keeping with his philosophy, proposed still more tax cuts that would cost the city $349 million in lost revenues next year and $5 billion during the next five years. In addition to the expiration of the personal income tax surcharge, he proposed a reduction in the sales tax on clothing costing less than $500, and a series of smaller cuts in business taxes that the Mayor said would stimulate the economy.
"We don't do tax reductions for the rich or the middle class," the Mayor said. "We do tax reductions based on a different philosophy: Will they produce jobs?"
As proposed, the Mayor's budget would include the largest percentage cut in spending since the Depression, although experience suggests that the scope of the cut will decrease as spending increases through the year. At this time last year, Mr. Giuliani also proposed a cut of the same magnitude, but since then spending has continued to rise so the current budget actually ends up spending more than that of the year before.
Yesterday's proposals also included the Mayor's plan to close a yawning gap of $759 million in the city's current budget with only five months left in the fiscal year. He proposed immediate cuts totaling $207 million, as well as a series of fiscal maneuvers that became the focus of the harshest criticism from the fiscal monitors, from selling the city's television station to auctioning the right to collect unpaid property taxes.
Mr. Giuliani defended such actions, saying they were needed "to ameliorate the burden that could be created by having to do further cuts."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Index of Commodity Prices Soars To Highest Level in Five Years

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Commodity prices rose to their highest levels in more than five years yesterday as frigid temperatures in much of North America threatened crops and lifted demand for heating fuels.
The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities surged 2.05 points, to 247.5, its highest level since May 1990, as the cold weather increased prices for coffee, orange juice, heating oil and natural gas. Gold prices also rose. 
 "The sharp run-up in the C.R.B. index shows we can sustain some commodity inflation," said Bernard Savaiko, a senior metals analyst with the Paine Webber Group in New Jersey.
Cold weather also sent coffee prices soaring to a four-month high. Forecasters said Arctic air descending from Canada into the Midwest could bring freezing temperatures this weekend to coffee-growing areas in Mexico, the world's fourth-largest producer.
Coffee for March delivery rose 9.05 cents, to $1.286 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, its highest level since Nov. 15.
Prospects for a smaller Mexican crop next year come amid mounting concern that Brazil's crop, which is harvested beginning in June, will not fully rebound from two frosts and a drought in 1994. Also, heavy rains wiped out expected increases this year in Mexican and Central American crops.
"The supply situation has caught up with the market," said Luis Berthart, a coffee trader with the Lamborn Futures Group in Miami. "There's not a lot of coffee coming in. The market is tight."
Natural gas and heating oil prices gained on increased demand for heating fuels.
"With this cold weather right now, everyone wants to make sure they have enough supplies," said Dale Wong, a natural gas trader at Nationsbanc-CRT in Houston.
March natural gas soared 15.4 cents, to $2.658, for each 1,000 cubic feet on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Last of Refugees From Cuba In '94 Flight Now Enter U.S.

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 31

 BODY:
After nearly a year and a half of detention at the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Caridad Alonso could have entered the United States two weeks ago. But she wanted to be one of the last Cubans to leave the refugee camps.
"I wanted to stay here for the end," the 44-year-old woman said on Tuesday night, the eve of the last refugees' charter flight to Florida. "I wanted to see the last rafter go." 
 The last 124 Cubans to leave Guantanamo arrived at Homestead Air Force Base here today, and the Government officially closed down the tent cities on the military base. They were erected in the spring and summer of 1994 during the mass exodus of Cubans and Haitians from their homelands by boat and raft. More than 29,000 Cubans and 21,000 Haitians were held in Guantanamo. Most of the Cubans gradually gained entry into the United States and most of the Haitians were sent home. The last contingent of Haitians left in November.
The Cuban exodus, fueled by fears of worsening economic conditions, resulted from the loosening enforcement of border patrols. Haitians were fleeing political violence and poverty at home. The detention policy led to rioting and suicide attempts in the camps, and court cases and protests in the United States. Running the camps for the Haitians and Cubans cost the Government at least $150 million, and the final estimate, when the calculations are completed, could far exceed that.
Clinton Administration officials say that detaining the refugees solved an immigration crisis and deterred others from taking illegally to the seas, often in handmade vessels that were unsafe.
Although Cubans and Haitians are still setting out for Florida -- the Coast Guard intercepted 1,126 Haitian and 114 Cuban migrants in the last three months of 1995 -- the flow of rafts and boats is now a trickle.
Cuban and Administration officials negotiated immigration accords in 1994 to allow Cubans to apply in Havana for 20,000 visas annually, making the influx more orderly.
But critics note that conditions in neither Cuba nor Haiti have changed enough to preclude another mass flight, and that Guantanamo hardly offers a model for a future response.
"It was a successful form of migration management but it was done at the expense of the respect for basic human rights, most specifically the restrictions on liberty under highly militarized circumstances," said Arthur C. Helton, director of migration programs of the Open Society Institute, a New York-based research organization involved in refugee issues. Instead, the institute advocates a coordinated response by countries in the region.
For Cuban exiles, the release of the Guantanamo refugees came at an unprecedented cost -- for the first time the United States withdrew its unconditional welcome to those taking to the sea to escape the Communist rule of Fidel Castro. At least 266 Cubans have been sent back to their country since May, when the Clinton Administration began intercepting Cuban rafters at sea and sending them home.
In Miami, the cradle of the Cuban exile community, hard-line anti-Castro organizations are still reeling from that decision, arguing that the root of the problem is Mr. Castro, not his "victims." But they are a minority in Florida, where a 1980 boatlift brought more than 100,000 Cubans to the state, overwhelming resources. State officials have lobbied for tighter immigration controls for years.
The refugee camps embodied rejection, but a spokesman for the joint military task force that ran the camps said they provided a transition site that made the Cubans "the best-prepared migrant population to reach the shores." While they waited, agonizing about the future, the Cubans, most of them young men, learned English, computer skills or how to balance a checkbook. They worked in clinics, worked on construction projects, including setting up portable restrooms, and spent time writing journals and painting. Help came from private agencies and volunteer groups as well as from the Government.
It was, said Renato Dominguez, a 30-year-old doctor released two months ago, a productive nightmare.
"I polished my English," he said. "I learned to write medical histories like the Americans. I made good contacts. I have job references from all over the United States."
Surveys also show high education levels that make this Cuban wave similar to the early exiles who came in the 1960s, says Juan Clark, a sociologist with Miami-Dade Community College here. He said a sample of 642 refugees showed that 46 percent had studied beyond high school. Ninety percent cited the lack of liberties as the main reason for leaving, he said.
Officials in Florida, where more than 60 percent of the refugees have stayed because they had families and friends there, said the release of the Cubans has not caused major problems because it was gradual, starting in October of 1994 with the old, the sick and families with children. Federal officials have given Florida $18 million in emergency assistance to offset resettlement costs in addition to money for job placement and English training.
Resettlement agencies working with the Cubans say the refugees have found a tight job market because there is high competition for work that does not require fluency in English. Many, including professionals who need to pass exams for licenses, have taken low-paying jobs in restaurants, hotels, stores and at the airport, and some have moved to other states with better prospects despite connections in South Florida.
Dr. Dominguez plans to move to Alabama next week to take a job with a chicken processing plant that pays $5.95 an hour. He has already recruited more than 100 Guantanamo migrants. Among them is Gerardo Mir, 58, an industrial electrician who said a two-month search yielded no jobs.
"We came here to work," said Mr. Mir, whose new job meant leaving his 24-year-old son, another Guantanamo refugee who is already working in a Miami Beach restaurant.
But the area has absorbed many others, and those who stayed here often run into each other as they bicycle to and from appointments or jobs. Even in menial jobs, cramped apartments and cases of sponsors who have reneged on their commitment for financial and other reasons, the refugees still find life in the states a paradise compared to Guantanamo. There, despite generally good relations and even friendships with their keepers, they slept in cots, ate the same food daily and waited suspended in time for months.
Today, the last arrivals from Guantanamo waved happily and smiled broadly as teary-eyed relatives drove them out of Homestead in a caravan.
"I can't believe I'm here," said Osvaldo Espinosa, 24, who spent one year and five months on the base.
"I feel free," said an exuberant Fernando Larduyt, 25, who says he spent 538 days in Guantanamo, and brought an American flag draped around his shoulders. "I can say what I feel. Down with Fidel!"
Back in Guantanamo, the makeshift schools, churches, libraries and recreation centers have been dismantled and life has largely returned to normal for the population of 5,000, including military personnel, their families and contract employees.
Military officials say the cots are going to Atlanta for the Olympics and the wood from hardback tents has been donated to Haiti and Panama for housing. But the base has kept materials to house about 10,000 refugees, in case the need arises again.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ricardo Antunez shed a few tears yesterday on his way to a new life. His journey began in Cuba, moved on to detention at Guantanamo Bay, and was heading for the last leg, the final flight of refugees to Miami. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: White House Wish: Healthy Economy in Election

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's move today to nudge along a sputtering economic expansion highlights the one question that looms over almost every political strategy meeting at the White House these days: What are the chances that President Clinton will run into the kind of economic downturn that killed off George Bush's candidacy four years ago?
The Fed's answer, reading between the lines of its analysis of the economy, is that a pre-election downturn is possible but increasingly unlikely. The Federal Reserve policy makers who approved a modest cut in short-term interest rates seem to be taking the view that resonates through conversations with chief executives and investment bankers. Things are slowing down a bit, the nation's business leaders contend, but nothing like the recession of 1991 and 1992. 
 President Clinton's problem, however, is that the public perception of the economy's direction is very different, and not nearly as optimistic. Poll after poll reveals that many Americans feel more economically insecure than at any time in recent memory, and that they no longer believe that national economic growth translates into personal prosperity.
In fact, for all of the obsessive attention paid to the Federal Reserve -- its mood, its reading of the economic indicators, its internal politics -- in times like this its powers are limited.
"We're stuck with the problem that we've had for the past several years, that the perception is far worse than the reality," one of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers said today. "And that's something the Fed can't really help with."
What the Fed can do is help keep the economy on a relatively even keel. While it takes time for interest rate cuts to work their way through the economy, the Fed is certainly in a position to prevent a slide from getting worse.
But that is only true if the Fed recognizes the problem and acts more decisively than it did in late 1990 and early 1991. In hindsight, the recession of that era was under way well before Fed policy makers and outside analysts realized it and it turned out to be much worse than experts thought at the time.
Most analysts are convinced the Fed has learned its lesson. "This time they did the right thing at the right time," said Allen Sinai, the chief global economist at Lehman Brothers. "There was only one year the Fed didn't do it right in a Presidential election year, and that was 1992. Poor George Bush."
Avoiding a recession, of course, is hardly a guarantee for any incumbent. The economy was strong in November 1994, when the Republicans swept the House and the Senate. But even though robust growth -- annual gains of 3 or 4 percent in the gross domestic product -- is supposed to help the incumbent President, it did little to stop the backlash against President Clinton.
The underlying problem for President Clinton is that even a healthy economy is no cure-all. White House officials are acutely aware that the Fed has only one, fairly blunt weapon at its disposal -- the control of short-term interest rates. And while that weapon can, in Mr. Sinai's phrase, do "magical things to an economy," it may not be very well honed for fighting the kind of pervasive anxieties that preoccupy American workers, consumers and voters.
The polls are fairly unanimous about those worries. In recent months a number of surveys have shown that consumers are not spending much because they are more worried than anytime in recent history about job security and their ability to save. Even those who hold a good job with sound and profitable companies say the endless headlines about cutbacks make them fear that they could lose their jobs.
The worry may be exaggerated, as the White House insists. But the political reality is that perceptions of economic insecurity are far more important than statistics. So Mr. Clinton has already set about trying to persuade the public that the economy is in better shape than it thinks. In his State of the Union address last week, he called the economy "the healthiest it's been in three decades."

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS KEY RATES TO SPUR ECONOMY

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Worried that the economy has slowed and needs a modest spark, the Federal Reserve lowered short-term interest rates today by one-quarter of a point. The move amounts to tossing out a bit of a lifeline at a time when housing and retail sales are flagging and consumer confidence is sinking.
It is the central bank's second rate cut in less than six weeks. The move is expected to ease borrowing costs for consumers and business, and indeed banking companies, including Citicorp and BankAmerica, shaved the lending rates for their best customers today to 8.25 percent from 8.5 percent. 
 The Federal Reserve's most important action, trimming the rate at which banks lend money to each other overnight to 5.25 percent, could also continue to buoy the stock market, which has set records the last three days, partly in anticipation of a rate cut. Stocks rose again today, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 14.09 points.
The Federal Reserve's top rate-setting committee also lowered the discount rate, which it charges on its own loans to banks, to 5 percent from 5.25 percent.
The cuts aprovided a significant symbol of reassurance from Washington -- in contrast to the recent Government shutdowns and budget battles that have left many Americans feeling even more anxious about the future. The moves were welcomed as well by a White House concerned at strategy meetings over the effect a faltering economy could have on the Presidential campaign. [Page D6.]
As large banks cut their prime lending rates, similar reductions are likely to follow in mortgages, home equity loans, small-business loans and some credit card balances, and some economists said they expected the Federal Reserve and private lenders to continue trimming rates over the next several months.
The biggest question, they said, is just how much the economy has slowed -- and whether the central bank has acted quickly and strenuously enough to keep it from stalling.
Only a handful of economists are worried about a recession now. But over the last two weeks, a steady drumbeat of statistics has made it clear that the nation's economic growth rate has fallen sharply.
Most economists estimate that economic growth slid to a rate of about 2 percent in 1995's fourth quarter from a robust 3.2 percent in the previous three months. Many also fear that mounting consumer debt loads and disruptions from snowstorms have pushed it down to about 1 percent so far in 1996.
The slowdown is most evident in consumer spending, which makes up two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Home sales have declined, and retailers reported meager sales gains during the vital holiday shopping season. More ominously, one index this week shows consumer confidence at its lowest level in two years.
Factory orders have also weakened, and new claims for jobless benefits recently hit a six-month high as layoffs continue.
Still, some economists -- and clearly some members of the Federal Reserve's key policy committee -- believe the economy could right itself and resume a steady growth pace without a bigger cut in interest rates. But most economists said they thought more stimulation would be needed, including another round of cuts at the committee's next meeting, set for late March.
"Given the soft economy, the decision to cut interest rates was essential," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers. He said today's cuts "will begin to correct the vicious cycle of slow growth in employment and incomes and anemic consumer demand."
He added that the outlook for the first half of 1996 is "poor in many respects." He also said he thought that the Federal Reserve still needed to lower the Federal funds rate, the key rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans, by another quarter-point, to 5 percent, to ease the debt burden on many consumers.
Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said he also expected to see "multiple rounds of Fed easing in coming months."
And Lawrence Chimerine, an economist at the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington, said he thought that the Federal Reserve "is still behind the curve" on rates.
Mr. Chimerine said that if key economic statistics remained weak for January and February, "That would be very significant, and they wouldn't be able to blame it on winter storms and the Government shutdown."
He said he also thought that the Federal Reserve should quit taking "baby steps" in cutting rates -- and take another half of a percentage point off the funds rate as soon as possible. He said the Federal Reserve's incremental pace was "unnecessarily keeping the risk too high" for a more serious slowdown. He added that it also was "keeping the markets guessing" about what would happen next -- and prompting many consumers to hold off on home refinancings or major purchases out of expectations of lower rates.
But the Federal Reserve has traditionally been more conscious of combating inflation than promoting growth. And one important condition for further rate cuts is clearly that inflation remain "contained," as the Federal Reserve described it in today's statement.
Before the Federal Reserve announced its rate cuts today, the Labor Department reported that producer prices had risen one-half of 1 percent in December. But most analysts discounted that, saying it was caused by quirks in the seasonal adjustment of energy prices. Excluding volatile energy and food prices, producer prices edged up only one-tenth of 1 percent in December. Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for goods they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers.
Similarly, the inflation in consumer prices was running at only a modest 2.6 percent through last November. So far, the Federal Reserve clearly is betting that the slowdown in growth will keep it from rearing up again soon.
But to some economists, the Federal Reserve's recent trend toward lowering rates represents a risky departure from its usual caution and suggests that its chairman, Alan Greenspan, might be keeping a closer eye than normal on political and market pressures.
Indeed, the Federal Reserve's rate-setting board, known as the Federal Open Market Committee, raised the Federal funds rate seven times to keep the brakes on inflation as the economy grew rapidly in 1994 and early 1995, before trimming twice last year. The last cut came on Dec. 19, a day after the stock market fell 101 points and needed support to resume its record-setting climb.
Most analysts said that if the Federal Reserve had not cut rates today, the stock market might well have plunged again. And while President Clinton is widely expected to reappoint Mr. Greenspan, a Reagan Administration appointee, to a third four-year term starting in March, he has not yet formally done so.
Ken Bercuson, an economist at the Swiss Bank in New York, said that in cutting rates, "the Fed is taking on risk on the inflation side that previous incarnations of the F.M.O.C. would not have taken."
Mr. Bercuson said he feared that increases in wages and raw materials could help inflation start inching up again, perhaps even to 4 percent this year.

HEADLINE: The Mayor's Budget Mirage

 BODY:
After two years of tough spending cuts, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is calling for New York City to continue on a steady and stringent budgetary path toward financial health. But the Mayor's latest fiscal plan, outlined yesterday at City Hall, is filled with shaky assumptions that are likely to collapse, thus requiring bolder and more painful budget reductions in the next several months. To his credit, Mr. Giuliani has begun to rethink some of his earlier budget strategies, particularly in the area of police. But several basic causes of the city's insolvency need to be addressed more aggressively.
Mr. Giuliani ran for office promising to change the basic direction of city government, which expanded in size throughout the 1980's far faster than could be justified by economic realities. He has succeeded in cutting the city's work force by 17,000 employees in his first two years. By far the boldest departure in his newest financial plan is his determination to subject the Police Department to the same regimen of fiscal discipline. 
 Until now, City Hall has maintained that it would be risky to reduce the number of police officers from the current level of 38,000. In his latest presentation, the Mayor said that by using civilians to do the administrative chores now done by officers, no less than 10 percent of the uniformed force could be cut without affecting the numbers fighting crime in the streets. He plans to reduce the force by more than 1,600 in the next two years. He also sent a warning to the powerful Patrolmen's Benevolent Association that if it insisted on approval in Albany of a new collective bargaining mechanism that would lead to more generous labor contracts, he would not hesitate to push civilianization and cut the police force even further.
This tough stance toward the police was Mayor Giuliani at his best, reflecting self-confidence in his biggest area of success, the battle against crime. Now he needs to take the same smart approach to the rest of the city's work force, including the other uniformed services, and demand more concessions on work rules and other costly hindrances to the improvement of productivity in delivering city services. One problem with his latest financial plan is that it calls for no more concessions from employees in the next five years, even though wages and fringe benefits account for half the city's budget.
A year ago Mr. Giuliani was demanding huge and destructive cuts in welfare and Medicaid from the State Legislature to balance the city's budget. This year he has softened that approach but has not come up with alternative savings. Instead his budget relies on a mirage of improbable Federal and state aid and money from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He is calculating, for example, that Congress will enact Medicaid formulas allocating hundreds of millions of dollars to New York State, and that Albany will agree to pass these on to New York City rather than keep them for the state budget.
While Mr. Giuliani primarily focused on the budget for next year, he said he would close a $1 billion shortfall in the current year by resorting to one-shot savings like the sale of mortgages, the city radio station WNYC and property taxes, and a refinancing of Municipal Assistance Corporation debt. He deplored the use of such one-shot savings when Mayor David Dinkins used them. Now he is using more of these devices in one year than his predecessor did in all his four years.
Fire sales of property and assets to pay for ongoing expenses is the frantic habit of a city that cannot reach the point where revenues and expenses are in permanent balance. Despite considerable progress in the last two years, Mr. Giuliani cannot yet claim he has taken the city to that point.

HEADLINE: Russian Samples Pastrami Politics

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
There was the historic walk in the woods at the Geneva arms control talks in 1982, and before that, the Cold War kitchen debate. Now, Vice President Al Gore has invented a new method of informal superpower interaction: deli diplomacy.
The vice president made an unscheduled stop yesterday at Katz's Delicatessen on Houston Street to introduce his Russian colleague, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, to the joys of corned beef and pastrami on rye. 
The prime minister, normally a borshcht-and-potatoes man, did not appear to get it at first, and he ordered a frankfurter with mustard and sauerkraut, said the night manager, Faye Weissman. But his entourage prevailed upon him to try true deli, she said, and both dignitaries enjoyed the two-handed sandwiches so much that they took doggie bags with them when they left.
The deli foray came as Mr. Chernomyrdin wound down from Washington meetings at which he reassured American officials that despite a Communist resurgence and Government promises of new social spending, Russia's economic reforms would continue apace. He was also fueling himself for a luncheon speech with the same soothing goal, this time before hundreds of business people at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The pastrami power seemed to work. He delivered a long paean to the improvements in the Russian economy; his diction, which sometimes descends into an indistinct, jowly mumble reminiscent of Marlon Brando in "The Godfather," was clear; his tone calm, confident, almost lilting.
Afterward, he asserted to reporters that "agitation" over doubts about whether the International Monetary Fund would go ahead with a planned $9 billion loan to Russia was vastly exaggerated and premature, and that the loan negotiations were proceeding normally.
He also praised the results of his Washington meetings, which included the announcement of a $1 billion United States loan to Aeroflot, the Russian airline, in an aviation deal that is controversial because it may lead to tougher Russian competition against American companies like Boeing.
In another notable change of schedule in his one-day visit, Mr. Chernomyrdin canceled a trip to the Empire State Building so he could go to Greenwich Village and visit the bier of Joseph Brodsky, the Russian-born poet, who died on Sunday.
But the deli visit seemed the high point of the day. Mr. Chernomyrdin's press secretary, Viktor Konnov, said that when Mr. Gore was asked if he had paid for the food, he said that he had indeed: about $16 for three sandwiches.
Standing around chatting after Mr. Chernomyrdin's luncheon speech, several top-level members of his delegation decided that if they had to choose the headline for the day, it would be "There's no such thing as a free lunch -- especially at Mr. Katz's."
