HEADLINE: Schools Brace for State Aid Fluctuations

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: NUTLEY, N.J., Jan. 31

 BODY:
In a process akin to hearing a mortar shell whining in flight and then bracing for the impact, school superintendents across New Jersey await the state aid figures, wondering which districts will take a hit and which will be spared in the distribution of $4 billion from Trenton's purse.
Until today, Dr. Frank T. Votto, the Superintendent of Schools in Nutley, thought he had reason to be optimistic. State officials said there would not be much change from last year, and last year Nutley's district lost just $72,000. And Gov. Christine Todd Whitman visited last week to lavish praise on the district for keeping costs low and results high. 
 Then came the hit. Aid figures released Tuesday lopped $228,000, or 9 percent, off the annual check from the state. The district had already been making minor adjustments. The business administrator, John C. Sincaglia, faxed a few principals to tell them they could not order new videotapes for certain language programs, for example.
But now the district has about two weeks before it is to present its budget, and must decide which big ticket items to skip. Should it avoid replacing a roof for another year? Should the $30,000 allocated for a new lacrosse program in the sports department be sacrificed? And how much money should it seek in new property taxes?
"Every year we all wait with bated breath for the state aid figures," Dr. Votto said. "It is a very difficult process and it creates great anxiety all around."
This year is more or less slated to be the year of education spending in New Jersey, which already dispenses more dollars per student than any other state. The state is under court order to come up with a plan by September to equalize spending between its richest and poorest districts.
School officials hope that the plan will ultimately put a measure of predictability in the process. And there is a lot at stake for Governor Whitman. Although poll takers say she remains very popular, local taxpayers tend to blame her administration when the gap in state aid is closed with money from their wallets.
Most other states have legal formulas for school financing that allow administrators to anticipate a certain level of state aid and then plan accordingly. But this is the fourth year that the New Jersey budget has been done largely on an ad hoc basis, with overall state grants to school districts flat and various factors combined in a different formula each year to divide up the pie. In previous years, for example, increases or decreases in enrollment were ignored, whereas this year they were one of the factors used to determine state aid.
Even holding overall spending steady is a form of cutting the education budget because inflation means a certain erosion in buying power. Overall, the dollars allocated to education went from $3.938 billion last year to $3.985 billion this year. The only large increases were $60 million distributed among 21 of the poorest districts, plus about $10 million for technology, divided among districts strictly by enrollment, at about $8.50 per pupil.
Under a ruling by the New Jersey Supreme Court in July 1994, the state has until the fall of 1997 to close an estimated $450 million disparity in spending between the richest and poorest districts. So far only about $186 million has been invested.
"We have had very little movement this year and there is no indication of movement next year, so we will be faced with a balloon payment the first year of the required new statute," said Steve Block, a spokesman for the Education Law Center, which filed the lawsuit seeking education parity. "So the state is really backing itself into a corner."
But the state said its new formula is not going to be driven by money. The Commissioner of Education, Dr. Leo F. Klagholz, will next week issue recommendations for statewide curriculum guidelines. Once adopted, the state will decide the cost of the guidelines and allocate money to the districts accordingly. Asked what future aid levels might be, Dr. Klagholz said, "It depends what kind of solution we come up with."
That is cold comfort for most district superintendents, who find themselves caught between local taxpayer fatigue and Mrs. Whitman's pledge to cut state taxes and spending.
Asked how Glen Ridge in Essex County lost more than 13 percent in state school financing, Superintendent Stacy Holmes said, "That is a great question for the governor, not for me. It is a political choice among the districts."
Districts also criticized the state for indicating that some districts were getting what appeared to be large jumps in aid, complaining that those figures represent bookkeeping alterations from last year's budget rather than new money.
In Nutley, Dr. Votto, the superintendent, and Mr. Sincaglia, the business administrator, started poring over their proposed $31.2 million budget today line by line, looking for places to cut further.
They wondered aloud how much of a property tax increase they would have to ask from Nutley residents, who pay an average tax bill for schools of $2,700, Mr. Sincaglia said. They think voters are getting a little fed up with hearing on the one hand that they have an efficient school district where 94 percent of the students who took the high school test needed to graduate passed it on the first round. Then they are asked to pay even higher taxes.
"There is a resentment when you have done a good job in terms of efficiency and the results are good and then there is not really a reward," Dr. Votto said. "At least if we just knew the ground rules it would assist us in terms of planning."

HEADLINE: Fed's Decision to Lower Rates Advances Dow to 5,395.30

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market continued to demonstrate its strength yesterday after the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point -- its third reduction since last July.
Stocks generally sold off in the morning, but turned upward once the Fed made its widely expected announcement around 2:15 P.M. The Dow Jones industrial average even spurted past the 5,400 level, just two days after reaching the 5,300 mark, before easing off to close at still another high of 5,395.30, up 14.09 points. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index followed up the previous session's record by advancing 5.87 points, to 636.02. The American Stock Exchange market value index gained 3.14, to 554.10, surpassing its earlier record of 553.58 set on Sept. 12. The Nasdaq composite index did not set a record, though it increased 8.49 points, to 1,059.79.
"The market confirmed a bullish scenario," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer of the John Hancock Funds in Boston. "It was a good rally across-the-board."
Just as they had on Tuesday, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange about doubled decliners; 1,560 stocks were up, and 804 stocks were down. Big Board volume amounted to 475.2 million shares, compared with 464.7 million shares the prior day.
Having already discounted much of the Fed's rate cut, bond yields edged slightly downward. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond slipped to 6.02 percent from 6.04 percent on Tuesday.
Banks, which usually benefit from lower rates, climbed yesterday. Citicorp rose 1 1/4, to 73 7/8; Wells Fargo increased 5 1/8, to 234 5/8; Mellon added 7/8, to 52 3/4, and BankAmerica advanced 2 1/4, to 67 3/8.
Insurance company stocks advanced amid a rise in premiums and a lessening of competition. AIG closed at 96 7/8, up 3 7/8; General Re closed at 53, up 5, and American General closed at 37 3/4, up 1.
With traders expecting greater economic growth in the months ahead, transportation issues rallied, pushing the Dow transportation average up 37.07 points, to 1,946.74. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, surged 2 3/8, to 161; AMR, the parent of American Airlines, increased 2 1/2, to 76; Delta Air Lines gained 1, to 68 3/8, and Northwest rose 2 3/16, to 45 1/8.
Tobacco stocks slumped at the end of the session, after a Florida court upheld the status of a liability action against cigarette manufacturers. RJR Nabisco fell 1 1/8, to 32 1/2, and Philip Morris dropped 2 1/4, to 92 3/4, even though it reported fourth-quarter profits above analysts' projections.
A number of special situations also finished on the down side. Datron Systems, which suffered from the cancellation of an $8.8 million order that forced it to restate its fiscal second-quarter profits, fell 3, to 13 1/2. Case, which was downgraded by Smith Barney, declined 1 3/8, to 47 3/8. Applied Digital Access, which said that its fourth-quarter net income dropped below analysts' estimates, gave up 1 1/4, to 14. And Jabil Circuit, which said that canceled orders would have a substantial effect on second-half earnings, plunged 3 1/4, to 6 3/8.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China's Move On News Flow Worries U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Two weeks after China announced a broad plan to restrict the flow of news and economic information into China, the Clinton Administration said today that it would raise the subject in trade talks next week, the first indication that China's efforts to control Western news operations may soon become a new source of friction between the two countries.
"This is, of course, an issue of free speech and censorship, but it is also at the heart of our trade relationship," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. "We don't know how China plans to implement its restrictions, but clearly it is a step in the wrong direction." 
 While the Administration has chosen to treat China's restrictions, announced on Jan. 16, as an impediment to trade, Beijing clearly regards it as an issue of national security. The order was directed at the Reuters and Dow Jones news services, which are selling economic information and political news in China. They are now required to be supervised by the official New China News Agency, which will have control over the content of its news reports. The agency will also control their marketing to Chinese customers, which creates another trade problem: Dow Jones and Reuters are competing with the state press agency's own products.
Mr. Kantor said today that the wording of the restriction was so broad that American officials were uncertain how they would be applied. The announcement of the new regulations included the warning that "foreign economic information providers will be punished in accordance with the law if their released information to Chinese users contains anything forbidden by Chinese laws and regulations, or slanders or jeopardizes the national interests of China."
China regards all sorts of economic statistics as property of the state, and it has periodically prosecuted Chinese reporters for revealing classified economic data -- usually statistics considered routine in Japan, the United States and Europe. But it has never tried to do the same with foreign news organizations.
China's usual model in controlling information -- and other economic machinery -- is Singapore, the tightly controlled city-state whose economy, led by ethnic Chinese, has been one of the wonders of Asia. But even in Singapore, Western news is usually filtered for sexual or political content, not financial data.
Mr. Kantor said the restrictions would be raised next week in Beijing by Lee Sands, who directs the China desk of the trade representative's office. Putting the issue at Mr. Sands's level, a State Department official said today, "keeps this from getting too political, too ideological. By treating it as a trade barrier, we hope to keep the issue somewhat contained." Mr. Sands's chief mission is to press China for compliance with an agreement signed last year to protect American software, movies and videos from piracy.
The financial information business has been a booming one in China, with several news organizations attempting for the first time to sell data to Chinese securities houses, businesses and semigovernmental agencies. Some American officials have argued that the Chinese Government's restrictions will collapse of their own weight, once Chinese businesses begin to fall behind, because they cannot get up-to-date information on economic conditions.
But in the short term it could greatly limit trade with China, and it is particularly a threat to Hong Kong, over which China will regain control in July 1997. uHong Kong has always been the financial information center of Southeast Asia, and it is unclear whether the new Chinese restriction will apply there after it reverts to China's control.

HEADLINE: Toyota Plans Kentucky Site

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 1

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation will centralize supervision of its North American manufacturing operations at a new site in northern Kentucky, company and state officials said today.
The Kentucky Economic Development Finance Authority approved an incentive package that could be worth up to $13.3 million in tax credits for the company in the coming decade. 
 A Toyota spokeswoman, Frances Champion, said Toyota would centralize supervision of purchasing, engineering and administration in northern Kentucky. She said sales, marketing and research would remain separate.
Reports here estimate that 500 or more employees will eventually work at the headquarters, which will be in the northern Kentucky suburbs of Cincinnati. An exact site has not yet been chosen.
Toyota makes passenger cars in Georgetown, Ky., and Cambridge, Ontario. It has a joint venture auto plant in Fremont, Calif., with General Motors.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
A Self-Effacing Avowal Of Geometry's Power

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
Given the space requirements of Sol LeWitt's wall drawings, New York probably will not see a full-scale survey of these cornerstones of Conceptualism any time soon. In the interim, the retrospective of the artist's prints at the Museum of Modern Art gives a superb if rather miniaturized account of his achievement and the remarkable way his art has unfolded over the last 25 years.
Mr. LeWitt belongs to that strain of 20th-century artist who has assiduously separated artistic value and beauty from material value. It includes predecessors like Kurt Schwitters, who worked with bits of twine and paper found in the street, and successors like Felix Gonzalez-Torres, who specialized in glittering piles of candy that were free for the taking. 
 Mr. LeWitt's contribution lies in a self-effacing brilliance: in the hazy beauty of his temporary wall drawings with their myriad lines and marks; in his refusal, in any medium, to value his hand over the hands of his assistants, and above all, in consistently giving ideas precedence over form in what is nonetheless a highly formal art.
Significantly, he can't lay any real claim to these ideas: the horizontal, the vertical and diagonal lines so basic to his work, for example, are simply geometry's first principles. Mr. LeWitt does little more than show that by repeating them carefully and in various combinations he can create visual edifices as complex as they are understandable. It is the direct line between cause and effect, between idea and action, that gives his art its power.
Mr. LeWitt realized early on that anything drawn on a wall could be condensed onto paper and that the refinement possible in different print media could yield a translation unusually accurate in scale and effect, with the paper forming a little wall of its own. For years he has given his wall motifs a second life in prints, investigating the special qualities of etching, aquatint and lithograph and figuring out ways, with his characteristic economy, to get the most out of each plate or stone.
In a suite of lithographs from 1971, for example, a squared-off mass of 10,000 freehand lines is multiplied by simply printing the stone four times, rotating it a quarter-turn for each impression to guarantee a maximum distributian of the marks.
The show, which includes some 200 prints from 1970 to the present, begins with the relatively simple configurations that characterized Mr. LeWitt's first wall drawings: repeating expanses of horizontal, vertical and diagonal lines, first in black and then in color, that the artist knit and reknit into grainy bands and blocks of texture and light.
By the mid-1970's the lines gained a life of their own, being freehand or often broken into short irregular marks. As in the wall drawings of the same period, the instructions determining a configuration often gave the draftsman certain formal choices, stressing the implicit collaborative nature of Mr. LeWitt's art. Or these instructions might become part of the image itself, as in a series of etching aquatints whose irregular star bursts consist of tilting lines piggybacked by the written directions determining their angle and length.
By the early 1980's, threa basic geometric shapes -- circle, square and cone -- often edged out the lines, and Mr. LeWitt adopted a subtle Mediterranean palette of rich rusts, blues and golds inspired by extended visits to Italy. (His wall drawings, now rendered in ink, became commensurately fresco-like.) In these works he introduced an extended family of often eccentric isometric forms, many of them derived from cubes, as certain prints reveal. In other images, the lines don't so much disappear as fatten into broad stripes: alternating bands of color that fill fields or define shapes.
In some of the best prints in recent years, the geometric shapes have shrunk to become the small planes of multifaceted, multicolored forms or, better still, angled fields that run edge to edge. Finally, in the artist's most recent efforts the lines are back, but this time they accumulate into freehand fields. Some have a looseness and dark veil-like quality reminiscent of Abstract Expressionism; others, in black and white, recapitulate the undulating patterns of Op Art.
Mr. LeWitt's motifs often evoke those of other geometrically inclined artists. Mel Bochner, Frank Stella, Robert Mangold and even Matisse come to mind at different points here, as do the more anonymous geometries of emblems, flags and charts. Predetermined and then simply executed by himself or others, Mr. LeWitt frequently ends up in vaguely familiar places, illuminating a complex terrain where form and thought overlap without being the least bit territorial.
 
"Sol LeWitt: Prints, 1970-95" remains at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, through May 7.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A work from "Stars," a series of eight aquatints, by Sol LeWitt. (Museum of Modern Art)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Words Not Spoken

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The Secretary of State worked hard polishing the speech. He wanted it to be his best, to sum up his vision of America's place in the world, particularly Asia.
And it did turn out to be the one speech that will always be associated with his career. It is remembered because of two words he did not speak. 
 On Jan. 12, 1950, Secretary Dean Acheson said that the American defensive perimeter -- plainly the areas where America would draw the line -- "runs along the Aleutians to Japan and then goes to the Ryukyus." The two words he left out were "South Korea" -- an ally constantly threatened by North Korea, a dependency of Communist China.
Six months later the North Koreans attacked the South -- and might have anyway. But American and Asian historians have generally believed that the omission of those two words helped convince the North Koreans that the U.S. would not do much about an attack on the South.
The speech has served for decades as a textbook case of how war can start by sliding over the threat and not stating what the price might be to the aggressor.
Once again, it seems to me, the U.S. is in danger of doing that -- this time about Communist China's maniacal threats of a war against Taiwan, 80 miles across the Straits.
Daily for months now, Beijing has threatened military attack against Taiwan. It says the leaders of Taiwan are plotting to make it independent of China. Beijing knows that top leaders of Taiwan plan no such thing.
But Taiwan did recently carry out the first free national election in the history of the Chinese people, and plans another in March. While not demanding independence, the Taiwan leadership does ask the world to acknowledge it as the separate thriving reality it has become.
For its freedoms and modest international ambitions, Beijing cannot forgive Taiwan, not until it surrenders its mind and future.
Beijing threatens naval blockade, and says missiles will fall every day in Taiwan. Already action has been added to threat -- missile "tests" near Taiwan and menacing amphibious landings opposite Taiwan.
To the U.S., which would inevitably become involved in a Chinese-started war that neither America nor Taiwan wants or incites, China offers the usual contempt. Beijing passes word that the U.S. is more interested in Los Angeles than Taiwan -- nasty nuclear blackmail. No country planning war ever delivered clearer threats than China against Taiwan.
The U.S. does caution Beijing. It says an attack on Taiwan would violate U.S. understandings with China and America's treaty with Taiwan. But it is done privately, without specifics about what the U.S. might do.
Washington believes the Chinese may be bluffing, and in any case will not make a direct land assault. But Beijing can easily carry out other attacks. Beijing and the American people should know what the U.S. might do if Beijing blockaded Taiwan or sank its ships or carried out daily missile raids. Would we reply in military proportion? Would we cut off the trade with China that finances the Chinese Army?
And can Beijing take America's whispered, unspecific cautions seriously if at the same time the U.S. helps strengthen the vast industrial empire of the Chinese Army, not only through trade but something called "defense conversion"?
The Far Eastern Economic Review reports that Defense Secretary Perry's plans for the Chinese to convert their arms and nuclear industries to civilian use have had only one tangible result -- "a lucrative business deal for Perry's friends and a springboard for China's efforts to develop a modern military-communications system." Representative Floyd D. Spence, chairman of the House Committee on National Security, has asked Mr. Perry for a reply.
Like other countries looking for trouble, China puts less credibility in another country's whispered cautions than it does in open statements about the cost to be paid.
So, as long as the U.S. gives neither China nor the American people an idea of what Washington might do to meet military action against Taiwan, it increases the possibility of war.
Giving advance warnings of consequences is not warmongering. As the Secretary of State and America found out 46 years ago, it is wiser and safer to say the words than to pencil them out.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A Paris-based real estate firm that deals in deluxe apartments closes its Manhattan office.

BYLINE: By Tracie Rozhon 

 BODY:
THE New York branch of Jean-Marc Levet, a real estate office that opened five years ago and quickly positioned itself as a seller of deluxe apartments, closed its 20-agent Manhattan operation last week.
At the same time, Brown Harris Stevens, an old-line real estate and property management firm that also prides itself on its top-drawer clients, said the president of Jean-Marc Levet/New York and 11 of its top salespeople would be joining Brown Harris. Brown Harris, which itself was acquired by a group of real estate professionals about a year ago, also said the company had negotiated a referral system with the Paris-based Jean-Marc Levet. 
 Owners of several of Manhattan's best-known real estate companies said they were not surprised by the shutdown. For them it was just another indication that medium-sized brokerage firms here were struggling.
"You have to have the economic muscle to survive," said Clark Halstead, head of the 200-agent company that bears his name. The Halstead Property Company itself acquired Carnegie Hill Properties and Edwards & Company, two smaller real estate companies, in the last four years.
Yet the closing of the Jean-Marc Levet office was notable because the firm specialized in the high end of the market, and the high end is by all accounts booming.
Executives at Jean-Marc Levet and Brown Harris said the problem was not a lack of sales -- 25 Levet closings are still scheduled and will go forward without interruption, they said -- but with the cost of doing business.
"You need the same kind of support systems, a very expensive computer network, a staff person spending all day inputting information into the computer and a receptionist," said Susan Greenfield Merdinger, president of Jean-Marc Levet's New York office. "And then there's the rent."
Ms. Merdinger said she closed out the firm's commercial operations in New York in January 1995, a little more than four years after opening the New York branch. At that time, she said, she hoped to expand the residential brokerage.
But the brokers she wanted to attract -- the top-end, top-selling brokers -- were reluctant to join the firm because she could not provide the advertising budgets and support services she said it would take to lure them. Over the last few years, Ms. Merdinger slashed her annual advertising budget of $130,000 in half.
She also tried to broaden her market, an effort she now says might have been a mistake. As she broadened the price range of apartments, the average selling price declined, from a high of $1.1 million to around $650,000 a week ago.
Ms. Merdinger also tried to renegotiate the $15,000-a-month rent, offering to move to smaller quarters in the firm's Park Avenue location, but she said the landlord had declined her offer.
"The lease ran to 2001," she said grimly. "We had $75,000 in escrow; we were really trapped into it."
She cut staff, laying off four secretarial/administrative people who made from $30,000 to $40,000 a year. Then the winter blahs set in: "In November and December of 1995, we hardly made a deal," she said, adding that the office could have gone on "for a while."
When she finally was told she could get out of her lease -- forfeiting her $75,000 deposit -- she said she decided to wind down the operations at a time when the pending sales would cover the firm's debts.
Ms. Merdinger called Brown Harris Stevens, now owned by a partnership that includes William L. and Arthur Zeckendorf and Kent Swig, scions of well-known real estate families. They recently acquired Brown Harris from the Helmsley Organization and since have been making a number of visible changes -- the move to an Upper East Side building they promptly christened the Brown Harris Stevens Building, for one -- as well as some costly, less visible technical systems changes.
Jean-Marc Levet in Paris and Brown Harris will each pay for referrals as they occur, he said, calling the referral plan a "back and forth" arrangement.
"We could have kept going," Ms. Merdinger said, "but I was tired, just very tired of the balancing act." Her title at Brown Harris is still being negotiated, she said, "but I have my own office, with a window."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gives Back Early Gains As a Key German Rate Isn't Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most leading currencies yesterday, giving back early gains on a day when Germany held its discount rate unchanged and bonds slumped in the United States.
While the Bundesbank did trim a key money-market rate, helping the dollar rise to a 20-week high against the mark in early New York trading, the central bank's decision not to cut its discount rate disappointed some investors. 
 "I think it would have been a sign of a concerted effort to bolster the dollar if they had cut, but they didn't," said Jim Raphael, currency trader at the National Westminster Bank in Jersey City. "We're always an inch away from really popping this thing."
Also, a slide in United States bonds, and caution before the release today of the employment report for January, kept investors from buying dollars aggressively yesterday, analysts said.
In New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.4875 marks, from 1.4891 marks on Wednesday. It finished at 106.75 yen, compared with 107.04 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5186 from $1.5122.
Speculation had mounted that the Bundesbank might cut the German discount rate yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by a quarter-point on Wednesday. Lower rates in Europe often help the dollar by making deposits in the United States more attractive.
The dollar has already risen 3.5 percent against the mark this year after a cut in the German discount rate in December and recent cuts to the 14-day securities repurchase rate, the chief money-market rate.
It may take some fresh news to push the dollar above 1.50 marks, a psychologically important level. On Sept. 14, the dollar briefly pushed through, reaching a seven-month high of 1.5048 marks, before turning lower.
"1.50 is a big psychological level for the dollar to overcome," said Michael Perelstein, who manages $11 billion in global bonds for the MacKay-Shields Financial Corporation.
The dollar held some of its gains against the Swiss franc after the Swiss National Bank director, Jean Zwahlen, said that the Swiss currency was "clearly too high," and that he expected it to depreciate. The Swiss currency has already slid 5.3 percent against the dollar this year.The dollar settled yesterday at 1.2145 Swiss francs, up from 1.2122 Swiss francs on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: The Republican Welfare Trap

 BODY:
House Republicans have a plan to corner President Clinton politically. They want to pass the Senate's welfare reform bill, which is less extreme than the House bill but still nasty. No matter what he does, someone will accuse the President of betraying his promises. If he signs the bill he will, by his staff's estimates, throw more than a million children into poverty and infuriate his party's liberal wing. If he vetoes it, the G.O.P. will accuse him of repudiating not only his campaign promise to reform the welfare system but also his grudging embrace of the Senate bill when it passed by an overwhelming majority in September. That mistake has returned to haunt him. 
 Mr. Clinton's choice -- alienating moderates who were won over by his campaign promises or enraging liberal advocates of the current system -- would be unenviable for any politician, let alone a Democrat running for re-election. His best course of action is the right course. That is to admit that his earlier embrace of the Senate plan, which Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York has justifiably described as "an obscene act of social regression," was wrong. He should then veto it or any other bill that rips holes in the nation's 60-year-old safety net.
The Senate bill would end the system under which Washington guarantees to match state contributions to poor mothers with children. That historic entitlement has not only encouraged states to provide adequate benefits. It has also cushioned economic downturns by pumping cash into needy hands.
In addition, the bill would allow states to opt out of the food stamp program -- the only Federal program that sets a uniform standard of relief for everyone in the country. The measure would cut off legal, taxpaying immigrants from food stamps and other help and fall $12 billion short of the money needed to achieve what the Republicans insist is their ultimate goal -- putting welfare recipients to work. The truth is that finding jobs for welfare mothers requires child care, training and transportation -- expenses that dwarf the cost of sending them a check. The Republicans simply duck the financial realities.
Lost in this catfight is the fact that the nation already has a pretty good welfare law, the Family Support Act of 1988. The major problem is that Congress never put nearly enough money behind the law's welfare-to-work provisions to make them function. Senate Democrats previously proposed doing just that. Mr. Clinton's welfare reform bill went even further -- imposing time limits on welfare, which the Republicans favor, but also providing money for child care, job training and, as a last resort, a public-sector job for parents who try without success to find private-sector work. Once the Republicans took control of Congress, these worthwhile bills were dead.
Mr. Clinton was forced to backtrack. But his rhetorical concessions in September, when the Senate voted 87 to 12 for the Republican bill, went much too far. He was petrified at the prospect of walking into November as a defender of the current welfare system. No Democratic President ought to accept a bill that would tear down the legacy of Franklin Roosevelt.
Fortunately, the mood on Capitol Hill has changed. Newt Gingrich is flying closer to the ground. Voters are dissatisfied with the hard edges of the Republican agenda. There is a fighting chance that Mr. Clinton can keep faith with the traditional liberal base of his party without alienating the middle-class voters who, in 1992, resonated to his promise to "end welfare as we know it." Mr. Clinton can take the risk of vetoing a measure he knows is harsh and punitive.

HEADLINE: The Fate of Colombia's Leader

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 1

 BODY:
This week, in a special session of Congress called by President Ernesto Samper to weigh accusations that he had solicited millions of dollars in drug money for his campaign, many of the politicians who could ultimately impeach him gave Mr. Samper a standing ovation after his opening speech.
The show of support was a vivid reminder that, after a week of denunciations from one-time allies and resignations by diplomats and ministers, Mr. Samper is by no means ready to be written into history. 
 Simply by convening Congress to debate his fate, Mr. Samper knew he was selecting an ethically compromised, and therefore sympathetic, forum, said Rudolf Hommes, rector of Los Andes University and a former Finance Minister. Congress itself has been rife with corruption, and roughly 40 Congressmen from Mr. Samper's Liberal Party are plagued by campaign financing scandals of their own, said Mr. Hommes.
As evidence against him has grown, with Fernando Botero, his former campaign manager, implicating him last week from prison, Mr. Samper quickly shifted the debate to the political arena from the judicial one.
On Tuesday, the first day of the special session and weeks before Congress was expected to even begin hearing evidence from the Chief Prosecutor, Alfonso Valdivieso Sarmiento, the mechanisms to ease the President's worries appeared to be in place.
Heyne Mogollon, whose Committee of Accusations has already cleared the President of any wrongdoing, said he would continue as chairman while the congressional committee studies the new evidence. Mr. Mogollon said the fact that he himself is under investigation by the Supreme Court, accused of neglecting to pursue the evidence the prosecutor presented to the committee, did not disqualify him from considering the case against the President.
The podium largely belongs to Mr. Samper's Liberal Party supporters and a disorganized opposition that includes an essentially silent Conservative Party.
Two Conservative Senators began a hunger strike on Wednesday to demand that a new Committee of Accusations be appointed, but they are acting as individuals, not as part of any organized party effort. In fact, the badly fractured Conservatives have no plans to participate in the political debate in Congress, though individual members of the party said they disagreed with this stance.
Further, Mr. Samper has already shown he may hang on to power despite losing the support of business leaders and the media, once considered vital to his survival.
What the business leaders fear most is losing the economic cooperation that comes with the annual certification of Colombia by the United States Congress as an ally in the fight against drug trafficking. But even the business sector appears to be adjusting to a new equilibrium. This week, in a demonstration of their doubts about Mr. Samper's ability to win over Washington, a group of business leaders flew to Washington to lobby Congress directly for certification.
Decertification would mean Colombia would lose all United States aid that is not tied to fighting drugs.
Last year, the United States Government gave Colombia a special certification based on "national interest," and the business leaders apparently feared Colombia could do far worse this year.
Mr. Samper's hand was also strengthened by a letter signed by several previous presidents of Colombia, who emphasized the importance of the political mandate granted the President upon his election.
And though Mr. Samper himself said he would avoid his own Congress during the time it considered the evidence against him, his Interior Minister, Horacio Serpa, was expected to work energetically to build support for him within Congress.
Enrique Gomez, a Conservative Senator, said he believed Mr. Samper called the special session as a means to fan the threat of instability as the prosecutor prepares to present the case against him and Congress weighs whether or not to recommend prosecution. Because the prosecutor, Mr. Valdivieso, enjoys enormous credibility among Colombians, a recommendation from him that Mr. Samper be prosecuted would be nearly impossible for Congress to disregard.
"The strategy of the Government is to heat up the atmosphere, to polarize the rich against the poor, the gringos against the Colombians, the Conservatives against the Liberals," said Senator Gomez, whose brother, Alvaro Gomez, was assassinated on a Bogota street last fall. "I think this is a very dangerous regime."
"They haven't any moral barriers, and they don't have the national interest at heart," he added.
Senator Hugo Serrano, a Liberal, said he expected strong support for the President, despite rumblings that a group of Liberals would withdraw support for him. "With the evidence we have seen, I think the President will do well with Congress," said Mr. Serrano.
In the face of the Conservatives' above-the-fray position, Mr. Samper's speech to the special session was, some observers said, his most forceful since he was elected. "It was very direct, and it responded to every one of the sectors that have attacked him -- the prosecutor, the business leaders, journalists, other politicians," said Juan Tokatlian, a columnist for El Tiempo.
Manuel Hernandez, a professor at Los Andes University, said that after the speech, he upped his private estimate of Mr. Samper's chances of survival from one in four to one in three. Mr. Hommes, the former Finance Minister, said he believed Mr. Samper had an almost even chance of finishing out his term.
Mr. Samper has managed to fend off aggressive reporting by the media and requests from business leaders that he resign by portraying himself as a populist under siege for his commitment to the poor -- indirectly playing on the fear of chaos that terrifies Colombians, rich and poor.
"I think that last week he was very weak," Mr. Hommes said. "Then he scared the establishment by threatening a class struggle, saying he would get the poor people on his side, and they relaxed the pressure."
"I would expect an acquittal, unless the prosecutor brings overwhelming evidence, but in this type of case most of the evidence is of the hearsay type," said Mr. Hommes. "The question is whether the Colombian public is now convinced whether he should stay or not."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond Down Ahead Of Refunding

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday after the modest rises of Wednesday, when the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates.
Longer-term maturities slumped; the 30-year bond was down 23/32 , to 111, and the yield rose to 6.07 percent, from 6.02 percent on Wednesday. 
 Traders had to deal with conflicting signals. The economic news of the day included a weak manufacturing report and a smaller rise than expected in consumer prices, indicating to traders that the decline in interest rates was far from over. All this was good news for the market, which hopes for further cuts from the Fed.
But investors seemed more concerned about a rise in commodity prices, particularly in gold, which suggest that inflationary pressures are building.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager for Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, takes another view, however. "People looking at commodities and gold as precursors of inflation have too narrow a focus," he said. "Gold is safe haven for lots of investors who don't play the bond market, so there are a lot of reasons it is up, but bonds and the economy are not among them."
Mr. Donne said that yesterday's consumer price report meant that 1995 was "the first time since the mid-60's that we've seen price increases below 3 percent for four straight years."
Everything that should have been supporting the market yesterday did not, including the cut in the Federal funds and discount rates, a tiny rise in the core producer price data and prospects for further Fed easing.
So what was wrong with the market?
Mr. Donne pointed out that this is a political year, and people are still leery of the budget talks. The short end of the market from five-year maturities and down has responded well to the fundamental data, he said, but the long end is influenced by the supply of new issues that will be coming to market the rest of the year. And then, he continued, "there are conflicting signals coming out of the commodities market."
"Beside, people have made a lot of money in last few days," Mr. Donne added, "and with the employment number due tomorrow, some participants would want to take profits."
Yesterday, the Treasury sold $18.75 billion of new one-year bills, at an average rate of 4.64 percent, down from 4.89 percent last month and the lowest since March 1994, when it was 4.30 percent.
Traders said the sale drew strong investor demand, particularly from small investors. Shorter maturities have been in high demand on expectations of more Fed easings.
Next week, the Treasury will hold its quarterly refunding, totaling $44.5 billion, with the sale of three-year notes on Tuesday, 10-year notes on Wednesday and 30-year bonds on Thursday. The Thursday sale will include an additional $8 billion of 7-day cash management bills.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the three-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.02 percent; the 10-year notes, 5.96 percent, and the 30-year bonds, 6 percent.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said the market's tone remained healthy with a background of diminishing inflation pressures. The National Association of Purchasing Management index, which gauges anticipated business activity, fell to 44.2 percent for January. Mr. Alexy said that showed how weak the economy was. He added that over the last 40 years, the index has been that low only eight times. With that weakness, he believes that the quarter-point reduction in short-term rates was not enough.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new one-year bills:

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Buchanan Vows an America-First Policy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 1

 BODY:
Battling for third place in New Hampshire's Republican Presidential primary, Patrick J. Buchanan promised an America-first policy today, vowing to make sure the "new world order comes crashing down."
In a spirited speech to the New Hampshire Legislature, Mr. Buchanan railed against the United Nations, the World Bank and the World Trade Organization for usurping the United States' sovereignty. 
 "I give my word. I know that those folks in Tokyo, New York, Paris, Bonn, Brussels -- they love this idea of world government. But if I am elected President of the United States, the minute I raise my hand to take that oath of office that new world order comes crashing down," he said.
Mr. Buchanan said that the polls showed that New Hampshire was "wide open," and he is intent on being the most conservative in the field.
While he still trails Senator Bob Dole and Steve Forbes in polls here, Mr. Buchanan broke into double digits this week and now appears to lead the rest of the pack.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;
Lugar Struggles to Revive Campaign

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: HAWARDEN, Iowa, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The small group of voters gathered in the library of the local high school listened respectfully but seemingly without great enthusiasm as Senator Richard G. Lugar outlined his views on a tax overhaul, gun control, illegal immigration and abortion. But when the subject changed to agriculture, things perked up.
Jokes and barbs were exchanged as Mr. Lugar and his audience discussed target prices for grain, pork exports to Asia, corn futures and Mr. Lugar's own 604-acre farm in Indiana. 
 "It's not a hobby farm," Mr. Lugar said with pride. "We make money every year. We take it very seriously."
Accounting for about 20 percent of Iowa's employment, farmers and workers in farm-related industries are a major force in the state's economy as well as in its politics. And, as was evident in a recent campaign swing through Des Moines and northwest Iowa, including this small town and Sioux City, Mr. Lugar is hoping to tap into the farm vote to help lift his flagging campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination.
While Congress this week is debating a farm bill that would gradually eliminate many of the Government's agriculture subsidy programs, few of the Republican candidates, with the exception of Mr. Lugar and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, have had much to say about farm issues.
When asked why agriculture issues have taken a back seat in this year's campaign, Mr. Lugar said in an interview: "None of the other candidates even have a slight familiarity with the issues. Agriculture issues are very complex, and farmers here are very sophisticated people. They understand better than most all the complexities. I supposed the other candidates would be reduced to saying, Let the free market work or I'm against controls or some other bromide of that variety."
Mr. Lugar is chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, and his role in setting farm policy will be on display this week as he pushes the farm bill, which is scheduled for a Senate vote this week. The bill would end most farm subsidies over seven years, would allow farmers to plant more acres and would give them more of a choice of what they can plant. It is very popular among most farm groups in Iowa.
But as has been the case for much of the Senator's campaign, whatever his views and accomplishments might be on agriculture, Mr. Lugar's message is being drowned out in a sea of television commercials promoting other candidates, most notably Steve Forbes and his plan for a flat tax.
"I still have that fundamental problem," Mr. Lugar said. "They need to know that we're there."
Even on tax issues, Mr. Lugar's message is not reaching much of an audience. He has proposed a plan that is much more radical than Mr. Forbes's flat tax: replacing the current income tax system with a national sales tax. But given Mr. Forbes's lavish advertising campaign, Mr. Lugar's idea has not been part of the debate.
"For $10 million to $20 million, I could popularize my idea, too," Mr. Lugar said on Tuesday at the Iowa Pork Producers convention in Des Moines. "The reason the flat tax is generally more popular is that it's been marketed with extraordinary multiples of any other policy that I have seen in the campaign."

HEADLINE: Audit Says U.S. Capital Remains in Deep Fiscal Crisis Despite Drop in Deficit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
In a city where people wait endlessly for snowplows to clear their streets, police officers sell baked goods to raise money for office supplies, and more than half of the city's 16 firetrucks are out of commission, another reminder of economic tough times was hardly needed. But today, residents of the nation's capital learned just how bleak the city had become.
An audit for the 1995 fiscal year showed that while Washington had substantially reduced its deficit spending, it remains a city in deep fiscal crisis, with its tax base shrinking as thousands of residents move to the suburbs. The audit showed that the city's deficit had reached more than $378.5 million and was expected to grow by as much as $260 million in the 1996 fiscal year. 
 Further, the report found that sloppy and illegal management practices were rampant in the city's agencies. The auditors said that at least four agencies, including schools and human services, had violated a Federal law that prohibits an agency from exceeding its appropriated budget.
"We significantly reduced the deficit for one year," Mayor Barry said at a news conference, focusing on the one encouraging result of the audit, a drop to $54.5 million in deficit spending for 1995 from $335.4 million in the previous year. "It might not seem like any progress to some, but to us it seems like a great deal of progress in the trend of government."
While the Mayor pointed to the declining deficit as proof that city officials are responding to the dictates of the Republican-controlled Congress and a financial control board appointed last year by President Clinton, the audit showed that Mr. Barry's administration still had far to go to achieve a balanced budget by 1999, as required by law.
Chief among what the Mayor called the report's "disturbing news" was evidence that tax revenue in the District of Columbia declined by more than $11 million last year, a drop reflecting not only a reduction in property tax rates but also the steady exodus of people annoyed with poor public services and questionable public safety. Last month the Census Bureau said 13,000 people moved out of Washington in 1995, reducing the population to 554,000, its lowest in 66 years.
The audit showed that the city had assets of $890 million and liabilities of $1.3 billion; thus, more than $400 million in bills could not be paid.
Mr. Barry blamed the decline in the size of the Federal Government, the city's largest employer, for part of the disparity. But with Congress resistent to the idea of a commuter tax, he offered no ideas of how to increase revenue.
While many city agencies heeded calls to cut spending and the number of employees, the report showed that some agencies, including the schools, moved in the opposite direction. The school system, which is cited by many former District residents as their reason for leaving, exceeded its budget by almost $13.2 million.
"The city has been dragging its feet in all areas," said Stephen D. Harlan, vice chairman of the control board, expressing the board's view that the city has not made enough cuts. "They can't go through denial anymore. It's time to say, 'We have a problem; let's fix the problem.' "
The other disturbing aspect of the report was the finding that some city employees had violated laws and regulations. Auditors found six cases in which checks were written to city contractors who had Internal Revenue Service liens against them, 42 instances in which court mandates were violated and six cases of "contract splitting" to evade regulations.
The auditors detailed cases in which city employees violated environmental regulations and made $60 million in purchases without the full amount of the contract being recorded.
They also cited examples of outmoded computer systems, inadequate security for the systems, redundant data entry by different agencies and shoddy maintenance. Describing computer centers at D.C. General Hospital, the auditors said they found one area where computers were kept in a condemned building where "water leaks into the room, causing ceiling tile and wall plaster to fall on the equipment."
Mr. Barry brushed such examples aside, saying, "All those things have been known about." He said he was appointing a panel to study the concerns raised by the audit and to offer some solutions within 30 days.
Instead, he saved his criticism for the control board, which has not approved his proposal for cutting an additional $150 million from the city's $4.99 billion budget for 1996 because it has been caught up in the overall budget impasse in Congress.
Mr. Harlan, who called the plan "absolutely senseless" because it included not paying $100 million in old Medicare bills, said the board's alternative approach would be ready soon.
"I've done all I can to work with the board," Mayor Barry said, showing his reluctance to cut the number of city employees any more. "But it's not as reciprocal as it should be."

HEADLINE: China, Vying With Taiwan, Explores Public Relations

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Last November, representatives from the communications firm of Robinson Lerer Sawyer Miller were invited to the Chinese Embassy to present an ambitious three-year public-relations strategy for Beijing.
Focus on "hot-button issues" like human rights and weapons sales, the Chinese were told, according to people familiar with the day-long presentation. Put on a road show of Chinese athletes during the summer Olympics. Create a "command center" to handle crises. Set up a news bureau with television links and an on-line information system. The firm boasted that it operated "well behind the scenes" and represented corporate giants like Microsoft and Chrysler and the Governments of countries like the Philippines, Columbia, Chile and Indonesia. 
 The Chinese listened politely and thanked their guests. Officials at the firm say they have not heard back since.
Given China's historic suspicion of outside interference, the encounter was highly unusual, as were China's tentative overtures to other American lobbying firms. The search for a hired gun was part of an awkward effort to defeat Taiwan -- not with a missile attack across the Taiwan Strait, but with a public relations campaign in the United States.
On this battlefield, however, even a nuclear power of 1.2 billion people and the fastest-growing economy in the world is no match for a small island of 20 million inhabitants that has assiduously worked Washington for decades.
"It's hard to think of anybody who does this kind of thing worse," said Stanley Roth, director of studies at the U.S. Institute for Peace, who was the senior Asia specialist at the White House until last month. "The Chinese come in and tell you what they want to do and you're supposed to say 'good.' They are not willing to compete in the realm of ideas nor do they recognize that the key to lobbying is education over time."
But ever since the Clinton Administration bent to Congressional pressure and allowed President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan to visit the United States last summer, the Chinese have seemed determined to sell their message better.
President Jiang Zemin has admitted the need for China to develop its skills in dealing with other nations, telling U.S. News and World report last year: "We have not developed the practice of picking up the phone and saying 'hello' to President Clinton. I think we need to improve this. We certainly haven't done enough lobbying of the U.S. Congress."
Late last year, according to press reports, the Chinese created an entity called the "Central Leading Working Group on the U.S. Congress," which reports indirectly to Mr. Jiang and whose mandate is to study and understand Capitol Hill. But the group is either so low-profile or so new that even China specialists at the Central Intelligence Agency and James Sasser, the newly confirmed American Ambassador to China, know nothing about it.
To help burnish their image, the Chinese are pressing members of Congress to visit and treating them like heads of state when they come.
Last month, when three Democratic senators -- Diane Feinstein of California, John Glenn of Ohio and Sam Nunn of Georgia -- visited Beijing, President Jiang showed them Mao's bedroom, billard room and indoor swimming pool, telling them that they were the first foreigners to step foot in that part of the palace since the Chinese leader died.
But when it came to the tough policy issues that divide the two countries -- like Taiwan, human rights and missile sales to Pakistan -- Mr. Jiang and his subordinates turned tone deaf, Senator Glenn said.
When Deputy Foreign Minister Liu Huaqiu, China's top specialist on the United States, suggested during one meeting that Congress not bring up anything negative about the relationship between the two countries during the election year, the Senator lost his patience.
"I told him 'You just don't understand our form of government if you think anybody could tell a particular Congressmen or Senator not to bring up something about China,' " Senator Glenn said. "We're not that kind of country. China has a few top leaders who decide what the country is going to do and it happens. In our country, every individual is a king."
That exchange underscores why China experts, businessmen and lawmakers like Senator Feinstein, who has emerged as a chief defender of China on Capitol Hill, have begun to urge the Chinese to look to Taiwan as an example of how to mold American public opinion.
Even though the United States Government considers Taiwan part of China (its diplomats cannot even enter the State Department), its lobbying efforts have led 24 states to pass resolutions to treat Taiwan like any other country.
Taiwan has 13 regional offices to push cultural and trade ties; it buys good will with donations to universities and first-class trips to Taiwan for Congressional staff members, rotary clubs, state legislators and veterans groups. As Governor of Arkansas, Bill Clinton visited Taiwan four times; he has never visited the People's Republic of China.
The Chinese are well aware that Taiwan is paying $4.5 million over three years to the Washington lobbying firm of Cassidy & Associates, which helped get President Lee a visa last year.
"I say to the Chinese you have a lot to learn here," said Robert Kapp, president of the U.S.-China Business Council. "I say to them, 'America is not a mystery.' I say to them, 'If you're going to talk to Congress, you have to talk the talk and walk the walk.' "
Among his specific advice is for the Chinese to assign younger people with strong language skills to reach out to Congress, state legislatures and the American people.
Although China's Ambassador, Li Daoyu, gives an occasional speech and makes an occasional trip to Capitol Hill, his embassy keeps an exceptionally low profile. The only time many American journalists step foot inside the embassy is trick-or-treating with their children at Halloween.
When Lu Wenxiang, the ever-polite embassy spokesman, was asked to comment on China's efforts to reach out, he said he would call back. He did not.
The Chinese can expect to get some help with Congress from Ambassador Sasser, who spent 18 years in the Senate and pledged during his confirmation hearings last October to have "as many senators as possible" visit him in Beijing.
"Part of my role is going to be -- how should I say it -- to more fully inform the Chinese of the importance of good relations with the U.S. Congress and of the way our Government functions," said Mr. Sasser, who leaves for Beijing on Saturday.
A few months ago, China sent out tentative feelers to several leading public relations and lobbying firms, but has yet to proceed with serious negotiations, a number of China specialists said.
One of those approached was Fleischman-Hillard, Inc., whose clients include Sony and MasterCard and the governments of Angola and Turkey, and which already has a trade office in Beijing. The company had presented the Chinese with a plan to promote American trade and investment, and has talked to independent China experts about developing a public-relations proposal for Beijing, according to people familiar with the company's activities.
For now, the single best lobbyist on behalf of China is probably former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, who is not paid by China but who advises American companies doing business there. Mr. Kissinger's meetings with Speaker Newt Gingrich last year led him to back off his call for Taiwan's independence.
But even Mr. Kissinger's efforts have not been enough to make Mr. Gingrich a friend of China.
Just last Saturday, in a town meeting outside of Atlanta, Mr. Gingrich warned of a future nuclear threat from "China or Iran or Korea or some place like that," adding that an angry China might some day decide to launch a missile at Los Angeles.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Crisis or Not, Shadow of 70's Haunts Budget

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
HANG onto your old Bee Gees records. Don't throw out those Annie Hall clothes. It may be time to brush up on Watergate trivia and to dust off that copy of "Shogun."
The 1970's are back. 
 Even though that may not be readily apparent in pop culture, it is growing hard to escape that notion after a glance at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's latest budget plan. There is an old expression for the present state of municipal finances, and it comes straight out of the 1970's: fiscal crisis.
Shhh! They don't want to hear that at City Hall. Crisis? What crisis?
Officials there describe the big imbalance between expenses and revenues as an opportunity to "reinvent government" and to do so without inflicting serious pain on the public. Any comparison with the crisis of two decades ago is out of line, the officials say. They do have a point. In the mid-1970's, the city teetered close to bankruptcy and could not borrow money, ultimately turning control over its finances to an assortment of outside monitors. Nothing now is that bad.
But no word leaps to mind faster than "crisis" in a city that now finds, even after several years of retrenchment, that it has five months to close holes totaling $2.8 billion in the budget. In three years, the gap is expected to exceed $4 billion. A billion here and a billion there, and, as Everett M. Dirksen used to say, pretty soon you're talking about real money.
"The crisis is definitely there and hitting us again," said Robert R. Kiley, president of the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce. "It could still come back in the form that it did 20 years ago, with ratings agencies telling the city that it's no longer credit worthy."
Stephen R. Berger, who was one of those outside monitors in the 1970's, adds that "structural changes" were never made that would keep New York solvent for good, and not just for months at a time. "What we didn't do on that in 1975 is coming back to haunt us," Mr. Berger said, noting parenthetically that he objects to the word "crisis" because it suggests an aberration while the city's money troubles are "a permanent condition."
In presenting his preliminary budget on Wednesday in a colonnaded hearing room at City Hall, Mr. Giuliani was remarkably upbeat for a man with a financial plan that may have more holes than the Jets' offensive line. He spoke with confidence, even occasional humor. There was something reassuring about this manner. Who wants a leader with the dank air of panic about him?
But that brave front did not erase doubts about his gap-closing suggestions, notably their reliance on one-shot measures like the sale of WNYC-TV and revenue assumptions that are far from bankable -- $244 million in airport rent from the Port Authority, to name one. And despite the Mayor's observations about how the New York economy is bouncing back, the revival is far from solid enough to keep his budget balanced without some legerdemain.
IN fact, the way he accentuated the positive brought a faint reminder of (shades of the '70's again) former Gov. Hugh L. Carey. In his day, Mr. Carey liked to get up in public and belt out the signature song from "Annie." Mr. Giuliani seems too restrained for such a display. But it might do him some good once in a while to offer up a resounding chorus of "The sun will come out tomorrow." Who knows? The sun just might come out.
More likely, the fiscal darkness will linger, deepened by a further closing of the city's favorite cash-dispensing machines, better known as Washington and Albany. Even if the Mayor's fellow Republicans capture the White House along with Congress, it is hard to see much fiscal good in it for New York, especially if Bob Dole wins. Mr. Giuliani has not embraced the Senate leader's candidacy, and one can imagine a recasting of a Daily News headline that became an instant classic in the mid-1970's. The new version:
DOLE TO CITY: DROP DEAD
Still, if the next few months really go wrong, the Mayor has a way out. He could almost balance the budget simply by abandoning his proposed tax cuts. He would resist that step, of course. Tax reductions are a pillar of his philosophy of governance.
But his hands may be tied. In opposition to Mr. Giuliani, the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, already insists on retaining a 12.5 percent income-tax surcharge to finance a school-rebuilding program.
On Wednesday, someone asked Mr. Vallone how he hoped to persuade the Mayor to go along.
"We'll make him an offer he can't refuse," the Speaker replied with a smile.
There's that echo of the 1970's again. Maybe it's time, too, to start humming the theme from "The Godfather."

HEADLINE: Prices in 1995 Up 2.5%, a 5th Subdued Year

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Signaling that inflation has been vanquished to a degree not seen since the early 1960's, the Labor Department reported today that consumer prices rose only 2.5 percent for all of 1995, the lowest rate in nearly a decade and the fifth consecutive year that inflation held to about 3 percent or less.
Most economists toasted the news, saying that they expected the inflation rate to remain just as low in 1996 or to dip further. They said that this period of price stability, one of the longest since World War II, would give the Federal Reserve enough room to keep cutting interest rates, as it did on Wednesday, to spark a slowing economy. 
 For cautious Fed governors, the latest inflation figure was "certainly music to their ears," said David Orr, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
But a few other economists warned that wage increases and other pressures could start to rekindle inflation this year, should the Fed continue to lower interest rates.
"The day that the central bank declares victory over inflation is the day that the forces of reinflation commence," Steven S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley, said.
Still, Government figures show clearly that inflation has not been so tame for so long since the Administration of John F. Kennedy and into the early years of Lyndon B. Johnson's Presidency, when it averaged 1.3 percent from 1961 through 1965.
Moreover, there are no wars or economic shocks on the horizon like the oil-supply cutbacks of the 1970's. Even health costs, a nemesis to inflation fighters in the 1980's and early 1990's, rose in 1995 at just 3.9 percent, the slowest rate in 23 years, the report showed.
The overall inflation rate of 2.5 percent last year followed 2.7 percent in both 1994 and 1993, 2.9 percent in 1992 and 3.1 percent in 1991.
It was also the lowest overall rate since the 1.1 percent recorded when oil prices plunged in 1986, the only other year since the mid-1960's in which inflation fell to less than 3 percent.
Given that many economists believe that the Government's index of consumer prices tends to overstate true inflation by anywhere from half a percentage point to a whole point, "essentially no inflation is showing up now," said Allen Sinai, chief global economist at Lehman Brothers.
Mr. Sinai noted that consumer prices rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in December despite a temporary jump in energy prices. He also said it was remarkable that the overall rate could be so low nearly five years into a period of expansion, which, in economists' terms, began in March 1991.
Mr. Sinai said he thought that the inflation rate would remain at 2.5 percent this year, or even to dip a bit lower. If that is the case, he said, the Federal Reserve should have enough maneuvering room to trim short-term interest rates by perhaps another half a percentage point in the next several months.
Led by the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Open Market Committee -- made up of the Federal Reserve Board's five governors and some of its regional bank presidents -- lowered the Federal funds rate, the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans, by a quarter-point on Wednesday, to 5.25 percent. It also lowered the discount rate, which the Fed charges on its own loans to banks, by a quarter-point, to 5 percent. In a statement, the central bank said it was responding to "moderating economic expansion."
The Fed's key committee also said that the slowdown in the economy had "reduced potential inflationary pressures going forward." Its statement described inflation as being "already subdued" and "contained."
But it made clear that Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues still felt that they had to maintain a delicate balance: nudging the economy along without letting inflation get out of control.
Adding to the difficulty, some economists say, is that it is not clear just how much the economy has slowed in recent months, or how much stimulation it can absorb without increasing inflation.
Nearly every indicator released in recent weeks has showed that the economy is weakening, and a report released today by the National Association of Purchasing Management reinforced the concerns.
That group's composite index, which measures the strength of manufacturing industries, fell in January for the sixth straight month, to a reading of 44.2 from 46 in December. Economists normally regard readings of less than 50 as evidence that the economy could be headed for a recession.
Most economists estimate that growth slid to a rate of about 2 percent in 1995's fourth quarter from a robust 3.2 percent in the previous quarter. Many fear that mounting consumer debts and disruptions from recent snowstorms have pushed economic growth as low as an annualized 1 percent so far in 1996, and some say that the Fed may ultimately have to cut the Federal funds rate to as low as 4 percent to stave off a recession.
But other economists doubt that the growth rate has dropped that far. Some, like Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley, think that the economy remains healthy enough for growth to rebound as high as an annual 2.5 percent to 3 percent by the second half of 1996 without further interest-rate cuts.
In the end, though, what happens with inflation could hinge, as usual, on the economy's ability to create jobs.
The national unemployment rate held steady at the end of last year at 5.6 percent. Most economists expect that to edge up to 5.7 percent, in a report scheduled to be released on Friday.
The number of people filing first-time claims for unemployment insurance recently reached a six-month high of 413,000 people, though the Labor Department reported today that the total had dropped by 25,000 last week.
But to inflation hawks like Mr. Roach, if the Fed continues to cut interest rates to keep unemployment from worsening, "we may look back on this period as having been the low point in the inflationary cycle."
He said that pressures from wage increases were slowly mounting and that recent rises on commodities markets suggested that food prices could increase much more than the scant one-tenth of 1 percent reported in December.
As a result, Mr. Roach said he thought that consumer prices could rise by as much as 3.25 percent in 1996.
"That would still be a terrific inflation result for the United States," he said. But he noted, "I am concerned that the Fed could be adding fuel to an economy that could be doing a lot better right now than it seems to be."
