HEADLINE: Bronx Election Pits 2 Families;
Outcome Could Establish A New Political Dynasty

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
The two candidates have a striking amount in common. Both are young -- 22 years old -- and pursuing college degrees. Both are politically ambitious. Both have fathers who gained prominence in Hispanic politics in New York City.
But what is drawing keen interest in political circles about the Feb. 15 special election for a vacant State Assembly seat in the South Bronx is that both candidates have the potential to establish something new to the city's political landscape: a Puerto Rican political dynasty. 
 When Assemblyman Hector Diaz announced last month that he would step down to become the new Bronx County Clerk, several candidates stepped forward. But the field has since narrowed to two: Pedro Gautier Espada, the son of State Senator Pedro Espada Jr., and Ruben Diaz Jr., the son of the Rev. Ruben Diaz, the Pentecostal minister and three-time political candidate.
Throughout New York City's political history, there has never been a shortage of family dynasties, from the Wagners of Manhattan and O'Dwyers of Brooklyn to the Molinaris of Staten Island. In more recent years, black politicians have started to take part, with the Patersons in Harlem and the Townses in Brooklyn.
So many politicians contend that the race for the Assembly seat, a race widely nicknamed the Battle of the Juniors, symbolizes not only the changing face of politics in the Bronx but also a coming of age of sorts for Hispanic political life in New York.
"In New York, we have seen other immigrant groups going through generations of people running for office," said Luis A. Miranda Jr., president of the Hispanic Federation of New York City, an umbrella organization of 58 service groups. "Now, we are seeing the same phenomenon among Puerto Ricans. The second and third generations are growing up and gaining a foothold in politics in New York."
Symbolism notwithstanding, this is widely viewed as a bare-knuckles political bout with both candidates tapping some formidable resources. Mr. Espada comes with the backing of the Bronx Democratic Party, with endorsements from Representative Jose E. Serrano and Borough President Fernando Ferrer, as well as the counsel of Roberto Ramirez, the Democratic leader in the Bronx.
Mr. Diaz is a Democratic district leader who, after failing to receive his party's endorsement, is running on the Independent and Liberal lines. He is endorsed by Herman Badillo, who was the nation's first Puerto Rican Congressman and is a close adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. He is also supported by Ramon S. Velez, a Bronx political baron who oversees antipoverty programs.
But for both candidates, the weight of the fathers has been critically important, both in image and in resources. Mr. Diaz's father, who ran unsuccessfully for City Council, State Assembly and State Senate, runs three nonprofit centers for the elderly and heads an association of Hispanic ministers. An army of campaign workers brought in by the minister has been making telephone calls and filling the streets with placards.
Mr. Espada's father has built a political career on the strength of his social-services enterprises, which include seven health-care centers that employ more than 400 people in the Bronx. The younger Mr. Espada has retained Luis R. Sepulveda, a lawyer who ran his father's State Senate campaign in 1994. Mr. Espada's campaign is expected to use Senator Espada's network of political volunteers.
Both candidates say they are running to give an emerging group of young citizens a voice in the 75th District, a largely Puerto Rican area marred by high unemployment. The two candidates say they want to dispel the myths about political apathy among Hispanic youth.
"This race represents a new generation of leadership," Mr. Espada said. "I want to emphasize how important the voice of youth is."
Similarly, Mr. Diaz said, "I want to make changes that will have an impact on the problems of the district, especially for the youth."
Both describe an adolescence filled with the minutiae of their fathers' campaigns and say running for office was a consequence of doing every imaginable job for them.
"Many people look at my youth," Mr. Espada said. "But I feel I've been preparing for this all of my life."
Each young candidate went to work after high school.
Mr. Espada formed a marketing company that handles advertising and promotional events for small businesses. He is also pursuing a degree in business from Fordham University.
Mr. Diaz worked at odd jobs and later as a staff member for the City Council. He became active in the Democratic Party in the Bronx as a district leader and campaigned for the 1994 statewide ticket led by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. He administers examinations for the staff of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission and is studying liberal arts at La Guardia Community College.
The two do not seem to disagree much on issues. Both oppose the death penalty, for instance, and support making changes in the structure of the school system.
But the short campaign has already produced some sparks. Mr. Diaz said yesterday that he plans a court challenge on Monday to remove Mr. Espada from the ballot, charging that he has not lived in the district for the one year required by state law. Mr. Espada denied the charge.
Mr. Ramirez, the Democratic county leader, said the decision on an endorsement in the race was "perhaps the hardest I have had to make." But he added that he decided on Mr. Espada because "he offers the best chance of winning."
Some politicians, however, suggested that Mr. Ramirez was acting to distance the Bronx Democratic Party from the controversy around Mr. Diaz's father. The older Mr. Diaz, who has run in the past on the Conservative and Right to Life tickets, has been a target of gay rights groups in recent years. They have accused him of being homophobic and ill suited for his position as a member of the Civilian Complaint Review Board, which reviews allegations of police brutality citywide.
"Espada, the father, is a sitting State Senator, and Ruben Diaz Sr. doesn't get along with Freddy Ferrer or Roberto Ramirez," said Israel Ruiz Jr., a Democratic City Councilman from the Bronx. "So for the Democrats, the question was: why deal with Ruben Diaz Sr. if you don't have to, even though the son is a decent young guy?"
Another consideration, Democratic officials contend, was mayoral politics. Many politicians reason that Mr. Ramirez's efforts to unify the long-fractured Bronx Democrats -- and elect Mr. Ferrer as Mayor next year -- would more likely benefit by solidifying his relationship with the Espadas. Senator Espada joined Representative Serrano two years ago in forming a splinter group of Democrats annoyed about not having influence in the party. But he recently mended fences with Mr. Ramirez and Mr. Ferrer, returning to active participation in the party and raising nearly $20,000 for Mr. Ferrer.
Mr. Espada and Mr. Diaz contend that their political views are strongly independent from their fathers. While Mr. Diaz strongly opposes the death penalty, his father supports it. His father opposes abortion, but he considers it a matter for women to decide individually.
"I love my father, but we disagree on some things," he said.
Similarly, Mr. Espada said: "Anyone who knows me knows that my father and I have very different points of view. I'm proud to be my father's son, but like any son, I have to stand on my own two feet."

HEADLINE: Auto Sales for January Increased by 4.7%

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 1

 BODY:
New vehicle sales over all rose 4.7 percent for most auto makers in January compared with the comparable 1995 period as buyers snapped up brawny pickups, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans but passed over passenger cars, according to sales data released today by nearly a dozen auto companies.
"January was a pretty strong month," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto analyst with Lehman Brothers. The total number of vehicles sold was 656,980, up from 627,694 in January 1995. 
 The vehicle sales strength suggested that the economy might not be teetering as close to the edge of recession as some economists had feared in recent weeks based on other economic statistics, such as weak retail sales in December. The Federal Reserve cited moderation in the pace of economic growth in its decision to lower short-term interest rates on Tuesday by a quarter of a percentage point.
General Motors sold 334,958 vehicles in January, barely up from 329,515 a year earlier; the daily sales rate was off 2.3 percent because dealerships were open 26 days last month and only 25 days in January 1995.
Sales of G.M.'s light trucks -- mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles -- rose 2.2 percent. But the company's car sales dropped 5.7 percent.
Chrysler sold 165,595 vehicles last month, up from 148,638 a year earlier, and the company's daily sales rate rose 7.1 percent. Chrysler's light trucks were popular, with sales up 21 percent. Car sales, however, dropped 13 percent.
The Ford Motor Company is scheduled to report its sales on Monday, but said it expected they would be below January 1995 levels. Joel H. Pitcoff, Ford's market analysis manager, said sales "will be down somewhat, because of the weather and because we had a very good month a year ago."
James W. Bush, an auto industry analyst at Ward's Automotive Reports, estimated that in January, Ford sold 264,000 vehicles -- 120,000 cars and 144,000 light trucks.
The sales results reported today also did not include Toyota, which will report them later. The data did include Honda and Nissan. Honda sales climbed 1.4 percent to, 48,967 vehicles, while Nissan sales jumped 19.1 percent, to 49,652 vehicles, including its Infinity models.
The industry as a whole is doing better than some had expected -- particularly because much of the East Coast's commerce was shut down in the January blizzard.
"I was surprised to see how well things came back toward the end of the month," said David M. Garrity, who follows the auto industry for Smith Barney Inc. "The real strength seems to be domestic truck sales," Mr. Garrity said, forecasting a 14.5 million seasonally adjusted annual rate for January sales.
Mr. Bush of Ward was more bullish, predicting that when all auto makers' January sales figures are in, they will show that last month the industry sold vehicles at an annual rate of between 14.8 and 14.9 million. "We're kind of back on trend," he said.
Mr. Phillippi of Lehman Brothers attributed the gains in part to the rising stock market, which made customers feel they could afford new cars. Also, falling interest rates on adjustable-rate mortgages and other loans made cars seem more affordable, he said, and that trend should be helped by the Federal Reserve's most recent interest rate cut. Interest rates should drop almost immediately for auto loans, lowering buyers' monthly car payments.
Indeed, auto makers are counting on the Fed to spur sales by lowering rates further. Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chief executive, said last week that unless the Federal Reserve cut the main rate for overnight bank borrowing to 5 percent by mid-April, the auto industry's forecast of selling 15 million vehicles this year might not come true. After Wednesday's cut, that rate stood at 5.25 percent.
Analysts said today that they were most impressed with Chrysler, the smallest of the Big Three.
"The market certainly is going to go to the low-cost producer," Mr. Garrity said. "Right now that seems to be Chrysler."

HEADLINE: Hart of the Arts

 BODY:
Kitty Carlisle Hart, who recently resigned as head of the New York State Council on the Arts, which distributes grants to cultural groups throughout the state, fit her job as precisely as a shell fits an egg. In the 20 years since her appointment by Gov. Hugh Carey, there was hardly a cultural institution in the state that she did not visit or a legislator she did not buttonhole. If the Arts Council's grants have usually been sagacious and wide-ranging, much of the credit is due to her determination to expose its members to everything that was going on in the state's cultural community. Her high profile helped compensate for the Council's low budget -- now $28.9 million after a series of drastic budget cuts during the Cuomo years. Gov. George Pataki will find her hard to replace.
To listen to New York's cultural community is to believe that the best successor to Kitty Carlisle Hart would be her clone. "The person who succeeds her," says Schuyler Chapin, New York's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, "has to have her skill at dealing with the State Legislature. Also that person must really know the field, and be able to act as a full-time chairman. It could be someone who, like Kitty, was an actor. Or an artist. Or who came out of academe or the foundations. You want somebody deeply committed to the arts and preferably with a high profile -- somebody like Jane Alexander at the National Endowment for the Arts." 
 Agnes Gund, president of the Museum of Modern Art, also spoke of the Council's statewide scope and the Hart-like energy needed to head it: "This is one of the nation's leading arts organizations, and it really needs someone who can do the job."
"The reason you hear such positive things about Kitty Carlisle Hart," said Lynne Meadow, artistic director of the Manhattan Theatre Club, "is because she is a lover of all the arts."
"What you want in the Arts Council role," said Andre Bishop, artistic director of the Lincoln Center Theater, "is a publicly recognized personality who is afraid neither of politics nor politicians and can really talk up the importance of the arts."
The qualifications described by these arts professionals make sense, and Governor Pataki should pay attention to them. There is widespread private concern among cultural leaders in New York City about reports that Mr. Pataki wants to appoint a prominent contributor, Earle I. Mack, to this important post. Mr. Mack, a real estate developer and former chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, is on the board of both the Dance Theater of Harlem and the New York City Ballet. He has been involved as a producer and director in two well-regarded films about ballet -- "The Children of Theater Street," about Leningrad's Kirov Ballet School, and "She Dances Alone," a portrait of Nijinsky's daughter Kyra.
But when the Governor has all of New York State to choose from, these credentials are simply not weighty enough to make Mr. Mack the first choice for this job. The ideal candidate should have a strong record in the performing arts or an extended history of service in the major cultural institutions. He or she should also have a grasp of the funding needs of the arts community in New York City and of cultural institutions in the state. Finally, everyone who knows Mrs. Hart believes that her successor should have some of her talent for charming (and educating) the State Legislature about the importance of arts funding to both the civic and economic health of New York.
With Mrs. Hart probably not leaving her post before March, there is plenty of time for Mr. Pataki to conduct a broader search. It is also vital that the cultural community start lobbying the Governor to let him know that there is a demand for a candidate who seems a stronger bet to fill the void left by Mrs. Hart's retirement.

HEADLINE: Stocks Continue Climbing, With Dow Topping 5,400

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose yet again yesterday, crossing another milestone in response to the Federal Reserve's cut in short-term interest rates on Wednesday.
Just three days after finishing at more than 5,300 points for the first time, the Dow Jones industrial average breached 5,400, with its fifth consecutive increase. The Dow was down almost 25 points at one time during the session, but recovered to close at 5,405.06, up 9.76 points. 
 Among the broader indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also edged higher to a record, rising 2.44 points, to 638.46. And the Nasdaq composite index increased 9.67 points, to 1,069.46.
Advances outnumbered declines on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,382 to 979. Turnover on the Big Board continued to be heavy, with 461.6 million shares traded.
"The stock market is comfortable with slow growth and low inflation," said Robert Froehlich, of Van Kampen/American Capital.
Bond prices were down sharply, in part because of an expected surge in new debt securities next week. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond plunged 23/32 and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.07 percent from 6.02 percent.
Semiconductor stocks led the upturn, after a Bear, Stearns report that greater demand for local area networking propelled sales of companies like LSI Logic. LSI advanced 3 7/8, to 32 1/8; Intel added 11/64 , to 56 1/4; Motorola rose 2, to 56, and Applied Materials increased 2 7/8, to 39 7/8.
Computer issues marched to the same drummer. I.B.M. rose 1/2, to 109; Hewlett-Packard closed at 87, up 2 1/4, and Compaq rose 1/4 to 47 3/8.
With gold jumping $5.20 an ounce, to $413.70, its highest level since August 1990, gold stocks rose for the second consecutive day. Newmont Mining jumped 2 1/8, to 58 1/8; Homestake Mining gained 5/8, to 19 5/8, and Barrick Gold rose 1 1/2, to 30 7/8.
In the oil sector, both Chevron and Texaco climbed after reaching a final agreement to sell their interests in a Japanese venture for $1.87 billion. Chevron was up 1 1/4, to 53 1/8, and Texaco was up 1 7/8 to 82 3/4.

HEADLINE: COMMUNICATIONS RESHAPED: A 'DIGITAL FREE-FOR-ALL';
A Measure's Long Reach

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Even the politicians who wrote the communications law stumble as they try to explain just what it will actually do, reverting to cliches about the "information superhighway" and the 21st century.
But the most concrete measure of its impact is to look at what the bill has already done, long before it was passed by Congress: 
 *It has prompted the AT&T Corporation to voluntarily split into three separate companies, plan to cut 40,000 jobs and write off billions of dollars in failed business -- all in anticipation of competing against the regional Bell companies in both local and long-distance telephone service.
*Persuaded two of the nation's four commercial television networks to merge with other media companies, with CBS being acquired by the Westinghouse Corporation, and Capital Cities/ABC about to complete its sale to the Walt Disney Company.
*Incited anxious merger talks between two of the seven giant Bell companies -- Nynex and Bell Atlantic -- to create a single company that would control local telephone and cellular systems from Virginia to Maine.
*Fostered a bewildering range of new media alliances and joint ventures -- among long-distance carriers, cable television companies, software companies like Microsoft and satellite television operators.
In theory, at least, consumers will benefit from the variety of new choices that communications competition is supposed to bring. In reality, no one, not even the shrewdest and most powerful media moguls, knows exactly what to expect next. But all of these moves were, in large part, pre-emptive strikes in anticipation of free-market warfare that will result from the communications bill.
At its simplest, the bill's core purpose is to unleash a "digital free-for-all," in the words of Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who has been one of the lawmakers pushing for a communications overhaul since the late 1980's. It would knock down decades of regulatory barriers that have prevented local telephone companies, long-distance carriers and cable television companies from attacking each other's markets -- and even allow electric utilities to seek ways to use their networks of wires and right-of-ways to carry communications traffic.
The bill will not, as many Republicans have maintained, simply "de-regulate" the communications industry. So complex is this legislation that it will actually spawn a mountain of new regulations and lucrative fees for lawyers.
Nor is it clear, despite the repeated promises of lawmakers today, that the bill will generate tens of thousands of new jobs. It may well have that effect eventually, but its most immediate impact has been to prompt telephone companies -- both the Bells and AT&T -- to slash their well-paid work forces.
And for all the forecasts of bare-knuckles competition, it also seems clear that the bill has ushered in a new era of industry consolidation, with huge media mergers and "full-service" conglomerates unlike any that have come before.
Will ordinary people be the only ones not to benefit?
Not necessarily. Recent history has shown that most predictions about the course of communications and media turn out to be wrong. The giant Bell companies have stumbled repeatedly in attempts to offer interactive video services over telephone networks, and have now retreated to cautious attempts at mimicking plain-vanilla cable television programming, transmitted over wireless networks.
Similarly, conventional wisdom on Wall Street is that the Bells will now snatch billions of dollars in business away from long-distance carriers. But some analysts argue that any revenue gains the Bells find in long distance may be more than offset by the money that their new rivals will siphon off in the local market.
"The Bells will be facing competition from all sides, and I'm just not convinced they are up to it," said Michael J. Mahoney, portfolio manager for the GT Global Telecommunications Fund, a mutual fund in San Francisco. "I wouldn't buy stock in those companies."
One who takes the long-term view is Vice President Al Gore, who when he was a Senate Democrat from Tennessee was one of the leading Congressional champions of tough cable television price regulations. He now argues that the long-term public benefits of untangling the regulatory thicket will vastly outweigh the disruption caused by new competition.
"If you look at new jobs, in the industries that make up this sector of the economy, the cumulative additions far outnumber the layoffs," he said tonight. "The large layoffs represent a tragedy for those involved, but there is no question that in this sector as a whole many more new jobs are being added than lost."
Although the bill has been a favorite item of business's agenda, it has drawn the support of many liberals as well, including Representative Markey, who said the coming turbulence is worth the price.
"Some companies will be winners and some companies will be losers, but there will be many more winners than losers," he said on the House floor today. "The country will be the big winner."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE LEAD;
Dole Backers See Fight in New Hampshire

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H., Feb. 1

 BODY:
Leading supporters of Senator Bob Dole portrayed his campaign today as faltering and said they feared that he could no longer count on New Hampshire as an inevitable stepping stone toward the Republican Presidential nomination.
In a series of interviews, many of Mr. Dole's most outspoken advocates -- and even some of his top aides -- said his commanding lead over Steve Forbes had dramatically slipped in the last several days, particularly in this state, which in less than three weeks holds the nation's first Presidential primary. 
 While it is common for candidates to try to lower expectations about the outcome of an election, Mr. Dole himself, as well as his own campaign staff, officially remained bullish about his prospects here and discounted the accounts of his problems.
But other Dole associates, speaking both publicly and privately, said that while they had expected the race to tighten, they were not prepared for Mr. Forbes, the publishing magnate, to emerge so quickly as such a formidable competitor.
"This campaign is thoroughly volatile right now -- it's cracking wide open," said Ruth Griffin of Portsmouth, a local office holder, veteran Republican worker and strong backer of Mr. Dole. "I'm telling you there are a lot of people who are out there changing their minds."
John Stabile, the state Republican chairman, who is remaining neutral, said, "There is a horse race here. It's a wake-up call for Dole. Let's see if he wakes up."
Former Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, one of Mr. Dole's closest advisers, praised the Senator's toughness and said Mr. Dole would prevail. But Mr. Rudman, too, seemed stunned at how well Mr. Forbes was doing in the polls.
"It's like someone comes and spends a billion dollars on a new toothpaste that wipes out the competition, even though it tastes terrible," Mr. Rudman said.
Many Republicans, including Mr. Rudman, said they worried that Mr. Dole's troubles were not necessarily caused by Mr. Forbes but by the Senator's failure to energize voters. "It's hard for anyone who's been in public life as long as Bob Dole to inspire much passion, frankly," Mr. Rudman said.
Even Mr. Dole's deputy campaign manager, William B. Lacy, said Mr. Forbes was doing far better than the campaign had expected and was causing voters to move from the Senator to the undecided column. "It's a real change in terms of the dynamics of the campaign," Mr. Lacy said. "Our critical strategic task over the next few days is to remind people why they were for Bob Dole from the beginning."
Reacting to Mr. Forbes's strength, Gov. Stephen Merrill of New Hampshire said today that he would assume a far more active role in campaigning for Mr. Dole. His help is reminiscent of the way then-Gov. John H. Sununu resuscitated George Bush's candidacy here in 1988.
And the Dole campaign is making an all-out assault on Mr. Forbes's signature flat-tax proposal as harmful to the middle class. In a commercial the campaign began broadcasting today, Governor Merrill warns: "Steve Forbes's income tax plan increases the deficit and raises our taxes."
Mr. Dole, in an appearance here today, called the Forbes proposal "snake oil."
The latest evidence of Mr. Dole's troubles is a poll of 400 likely Republican primary voters published today in The Boston Globe, showing that Mr. Forbes had caught up and perhaps overtaken Mr. Dole in New Hampshire. Mr. Forbes had 31 percent; Mr. Dole, 22 percent. The other Republican candidates were in single digits. The poll, conducted Jan. 29 and 30 by KRC Communications Research for The Globe and WBZ-TV, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
Campaigning at an automobile dealership here today, Mr. Dole dismissed the poll, saying: "If I worried about every poll, I'd probably have an Excedrin headache. They're coming so fast now that you get poll fever."
While he brushed aside that poll, Mr. Dole referred, though not by name, to another survey of likely primary voters. But that poll, by the American Research Group, hardly had good news for him: it showed Mr. Dole and Mr. Forbes so close statistically as to be near a dead heat. Mr. Dole had 25 percent and Mr. Forbes 19 percent, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
It also showed that Mr. Dole's support had slipped two points a day for the last five days. As recently as Jan. 27, the American Research poll showed Mr. Dole at 33 percent and Mr. Forbes at 16 percent.
Despite the glum forecasts even among many Dole partisans, voters, particularly in New Hampshire, traditionally make up their minds just days before they go to cast their ballots. Mr. Dole can recall that in 1988, he surged ahead of Mr. Bush in polls in this state, only to lose the primary. In addition, the outcome of the Iowa caucuses on Feb. 12 could have a marked effect on how candidates place in the New Hampshire primary, on Feb. 20.
"It is not Panicsville in the Dole campaign." said Peter Spaulding of Concord, a veteran Republican worker and Dole supporter. Still, Mr. Dole's advisers said Mr. Forbes's strength had caused tensions in the campaign. Don Sipple, the media consultant for the failed Presidential campaign of Gov. Pete Wilson of California, has, for example, taken a larger role in helping Stuart Stevens, who produces the campaign's commercials, devise a message.
In addition, some Dole advisers said they now regretted that the Senator did not spell out his own plan for a flat tax to head off Mr. Forbes. In a speech before the Economic Club of Chicago last September, Mr. Dole had been expected to lay out such a plan but spoke instead in generalities about overhauling the tax code.
Nor does Mr. Dole's campaign have the feel of a smoothly run front-runner's campaign. There is no large entourage, or even a bus to transport reporters. Even "Dole for President" signs are a rare sight around this state.
Trying to put the best face on Mr. Dole's position, some of his supporters said they hoped the tightness of the race would force people to take a closer, more critical, look at the weaknesses of Mr. Forbes.
"If Steve Forbes is really doing well in the polls," Governor Merrill said, "that's a negative for Steve Forbes, because people are now going to take him seriously. They're going to start running the numbers on the flat tax."
Indeed, the Globe poll suggested that support for Mr. Forbes's flat-tax plan had eroded and that Mr. Forbes's appeal was now in his portrayal of himself as a Washington outsider
"The flat tax thing got everybody's attention," State Representative Harold W. Burns, a Dole supporter and Speaker of the New Hampshire House, said. "You could say Forbes is on a roll. But I say it won't last, because when it comes time to vote folks will go with what's tried and true: Dole."

HEADLINE: U.S. Auto Makers Fear Strength Of Dollar Gives Edge to Japan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 1

 BODY:
With rebates spreading and profits threatened, the nation's car makers are now complaining about the strength of the dollar.
When the dollar was falling and the Japanese yen was rising, Japan's auto makers were raising prices regularly and handing the Big Three auto makers the best import-fighter ever: a price advantage. But now Japanese auto makers are skipping some price increases thanks to a round of significant cost-cutting, and the price difference between Japanese and American cars and trucks is shrinking. 
 What is more, Japanese auto makers, who have learned to live with a high yen-weak dollar, are anticipating a potential profit windfall as the dollar strengthens. Now, analysts say the Japanese are on the verge of raising the industry's standard for competitiveness.
By reducing costs, analysts believe, most Japanese car makers can compete profitably at an exchange rate of 100 yen to the dollar and either expand their market shares or reap large profits at today's exchange rate of nearly 107 yen to the dollar, from about 80 yen last April.
"At 80 yen per dollar, those shipments from Japan were losing billions of dollars -- at 107, they are wildly profitable again," said Jay N. Woodworth, an auto industry analyst in Summit, N.J. "The U.S. Big Three do not realize that, and I think that they do not appreciate the dramatic cost cutting the Japanese have done."
Indeed, despite some the most aggressive cost-cutting in the industry's history, Detroit may find it still has significant work to do just to hang on to its share of the auto market.
The chief executives of the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation agreed here today to warn the Clinton Administration about the cost of its strong-dollar policies. The car companies will not ask the Administration to intervene to drive the dollar down, said Andrew H. Card Jr., the president of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association. "I think that's premature," he said. "We're going to express our concern and ask them to be sensitive to the impact it has on our domestic manufacturers."
Mr. Card would not rule out the possibility of seeking intervention, particularly if the dollar reaches 110 yen. "I personally think it should be at 100," he said. "If you just look at the numbers, from 80 to 107, that's billions of dollars" in sales.
Wall Street analysts are only now assessing what the dollar's rise and the yen's fall might mean for the American automobile industry. The combination of a rising dollar and falling Japanese costs represents "sort of a double-edged sword that they're dealing with here, or potentially being whacked with," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an analyst at Lehman Brothers.
Detroit is "wholly vulnerable" to a higher dollar, said Maryann Keller, an analyst at Furman Selz. It forces "us to look again at the basic competitiveness and cost structure" of Detroit, she said.
The dollar's 34 percent rebound to 107 yen has not only allowed the Japanese companies to return to robust profitability but also makes it harder for Detroit to keep raising prices, hold its market share, and continue reporting strong earnings.
The Mazda Motor Corporation has already refrained from any price increases in November, December and January for the first time in at least five years. The Nissan Motor Company is also planning little or no price increases for now.
"If the dollar had not appreciated like it has, we probably would have seen a continuation of the 2 to 3 percent a year price increases," said Robert J. Thomas, the president and chief executive of the Nissan Motor Corporation USA.
Heavy price discounts by Japanese manufacturers, made possible in part by the stronger dollar, pushed up the Japanese share of the United States market by 1.6 percentage points in December from a year earlier. And Japanese car makers announced further sales gains today.
Until recently, Detroit auto executives have said little publicly about the dollar's rise. But Chrysler officials say that the company's chairman and chief executive, Robert Eaton, did tell senior managers at a meeting last September that Toyota's costs to make the Previa mini-van in Japan, when converted from yen into dollars, were $4,870 greater than Chrysler's costs for the Plymouth Grand Voyager mini-van at an exchange rate of 80 yen to the dollar. But Chrysler faces a $2,650 disadvantage if a dollar is worth 110 yen, Mr. Eaton warned.
Auto executives have been more vocal about their concerns this week. David McCammon, Ford's vice president for finance, said recently that foreign exchange losses hit $500 million last year, reflecting the diminished value in dollars of overseas profits earned in foreign currencies.
But Mr. McCammon said the bigger cost of a higher dollar lay in the greater difficulty it poses for American companies as Japanese vehicles become cheaper here. "Mostly we think of it as hurting us in a competitive sense," he said.
American auto makers have a tradition of complaining about an overvalued dollar and may find that their latest worries will be ignored in Washington. And the effects of a rising dollar may not be as noteworthy this time around. Nearly 40 percent of the cars and trucks sold by Japanese companies in the United States last year were made in North America, so much of the manufacturing costs are in dollars, not yen.
American auto executives took pains in interviews to say that they were not complaining about the outcome from currency market trading but that they were concerned that the dollar's current level was partly the result of American and Japanese Government rehetoric and market interventions.
"I don't know if it's so much to complain to the Administration as to make the Administration aware of the effects a stronger dollar has on the auto industry," said Martin B. Zimmerman, Ford's executive director for government relations and corporate economics.
Even if the Administration wanted to brake the dollar's rise, there is no guarantee that the usual combination of rhetoric from top officials and currency market intervention would have much effect. A senior Treasury official said tonight that while the Administration cared about the auto industry, it still believed that "a strong dollar is in our overall national interest."

HEADLINE: A Swerve To the Right In California

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Barely a month after the State Assembly's Republicans, already in the majority for a year, gained real control of the chamber by finally uniting to elect a Republican Speaker, party leaders have begun to push through an ambitious conservative agenda that could bring profound change to California.
Beginning action on what the Republicans call their "contract with California," the Assembly this week has approved a bill that would bar the state, which does not recognize same-sex marriages performed within its borders, from recognizing such marriages performed elsewhere. 
 It has also passed a measure that would allow police and sheriff's departments to issue concealed-weapons permits to almost anyone.
It has approved a two-year limit on welfare payments to able-bodied adults, and a bill allowing farmers the continued use of methyl bromide, a highly toxic insecticide.
It has voted to slash the corporate tax rate by about 20 percent, from 9.3 percent to 7.5.
And it has approved a bill that, for people 21 or over, would repeal the state's five-year-old law requiring all motorcyclists to wear helmets. Although the existing law has been credited by state health officials with reducing motorcycle fatalities by 45 percent, it is described by sponsors of its repeal as an intrusion on personal freedom.
Whether any of this legislation will ever make its way into law is not clear. The State Senate is still controlled by Democrats, many of whom fervently oppose the conservative agenda, and the Republicans there are not counting on much support from their colleagues on the other side of the aisle.
"We're now in the macho stage of kooky ideas, where all of the pent-up energy over the years is now pouring out," the Senate's most powerful Democrat, Bill Lockyer, the President pro tem, told reporters this week. Eventually, he said, the "extremists" will "settle down and try to get some constructive bipartisan proposals in progress rather than just their right-wing social and economic agenda."
But California is the largest of the 17 states where one or both legislative chambers have switched from Democratic to Republican control since 1994. And if the Republicans here should gain control of the Senate this fall -- a prospect at which they are believed to have a genuine chance -- and if, as the cliche goes, California leads the nation in trends, then the conservative Republican resurgence here could prove enormously influential, especially given expectations that state governments, rather than the Federal, will increasingly take the lead in setting social policy.
For their part, Republican leaders in the Assembly are almost giddy over their accomplishments so far. "It's been a joy," said one of them, Larry Bowler. "To finally matter is just exhilarating. We've got 25 years of destruction we're trying to correct as quickly as we can."
Mr. Bowler's remark was a not-so-subtle dig at former Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr., the Democrat who, with almost contemptuous magnanimity, regularly outmaneuvered his Republican colleagues for more than a decade. Indeed, during Mr. Brown's long reign in Sacramento, it would have been virtually unthinkable for most of the proposals that reached the floor this week to have advanced that far.
All this changed a month ago, however, when Mr. Brown, who has since taken office as Mayor of San Francisco, was forced by California's new term-limits law to leave the Assembly after 30 years as a member, the last 14 as its Speaker. In the Speaker's chair now is Curt Pringle, a 36-year-old former drapery salesman from Orange County, a citadel of Republican conservatism. He is the first Speaker in 25 years elected with majority support of Republicans.
The Republicans, who now hold 41 of the Assembly's 80 seats, won their majority in the November 1994 elections. But Mr. Brown deftly exploited division within their ranks to keep Democrats in power, first winning re-election himself as Speaker and then handing the job to a Republican ally, Doris Allen of Orange County. Ms. Allen quit the post, considered second in power only to that of the governor, before she was recalled in a special election in November. Mr. Brown then engineered the short-lived Speakership of another Republican, Brian Sentencich of Fresno.
While Mr. Brown's retirement has certainly energized Assembly Republicans, it is not the only locomotive driving the new legislative agenda. Perhaps of more profound impact, political analysts say, are the new term limits. The Legislature is now stocked with short-termers who, these analysts say, are much more inclined than their predecessors to bow to a public clamoring for tax relief and get-tough measures against crime.
"What's going on in the Assembly now is a miniature version of what went on in Congress after the '94 elections," said Bruce Cain, associate director of the Institute for Government Studies at the University of California at Berkeley. "In previous years, extreme bills have been stopped in the legislative process. But if the Republicans get complete control of the Assembly, the Senate and the governorship, then these bills could be a taste of the future."
So far, Gov. Pete Wilson has taken no official stand on most of the new measures. But the Governor has generally looked with favor on get-tough anti-crime initiatives, and, badly bruised in his failed campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, he has made no secret of his desire to re-establish himself as a national leader. Heading a young and eager pack of right-leaning legislators could be just the vehicle he needs.
Things could also go the other way, of course: if the conservative legislative drive here is ultimately repelled by the Democrats, Republicans in other states may well prove wary of taking the same bold path.
In any event, although Speaker Pringle's ascendancy gives Republicans a better chance of enacting some of their most cherished goals, doing so will be no picnic. For one thing, even some of the bills already passed have riled powerful interests, from civil libertarians to teachers to business. And there are already signs that the Republicans are apt to compromise in the face of sustained criticism.
On Tuesday, for example, the Assembly rejected a bill that would have allowed judges to punish young graffiti vandals by sentencing them to as many as 10 whacks with a hardwood paddle, administered by a bailiff or their parents in open court. The proposal would have allowed the name of vandals to be made available for publication, in the hope that humiliation of either child or parent would be a deterrent. A companion bill would have repealed the state's decade-old ban on corporal punishment in public schools.
Opponents argued that paddling had little proven value in keeping adolescents out of mischief, especially those from poor, already troubled families.
While Democrats are doing all they can to derail the Republicans' social agenda, not a few are quietly pleased with it.
"I'm thrilled this is happening," said Darry Sragow, a Democratic strategist. "This confirms that the Republicans are no better at governing than the Democrats are," he said, adding that issues like school paddling and helmet-law repeal "are fundamentally immaterial."
"Most voters who could vote -- and many don't -- just shake their heads," Mr. Sragow said, "and wonder why they're paying out their hard-earned tax dollars for salaries of the people who are doing this stuff."
Tony Quinn, a veteran Sacramento lobbyist and former Republican legislative aide, also feels that the agenda being pursued by conservatives could backfire. He compares the Assembly's actions to the iconoclastic politics of Berkeley, where the City Council often tilts well to the left on world and national matters.
"The Berkeley City Council," Mr. Quinn said, "has a reputation for being a bunch of nut cakes. Instead of concerning themselves with what's happening on the streets of Berkeley, they're worried about what's going on in El Salvador."
Similarly, issues like punitive paddling and helmet-law repeal, Mr. Quinn said, "are not the issues of concern to the middle class," and by focusing on them, rather than on the economy or the environment, the Assembly Republicans are "making a considerable mistake."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Words Not Spoken

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The Secretary of State worked hard polishing the speech. He wanted it to be his best, to sum up his vision of America's place in the world, particularly Asia.
And it did turn out to be the one speech that will always be associated with his career. It is remembered because of two words he did not speak. 
 On Jan. 12, 1950, Secretary Dean Acheson said that the American defensive perimeter -- plainly the areas where America would draw the line -- "runs along the Aleutians to Japan and then goes to the Ryukyus." The two words he left out were "South Korea" -- an ally constantly threatened by North Korea, a dependency of Communist China.
Six months later the North Koreans attacked the South -- and might have anyway. But American and Asian historians have generally believed that the omission of those two words helped convince the North Koreans that the U.S. would not do much about an attack on the South.
The speech has served for decades as a textbook case of how war can start by sliding over the threat and not stating what the price might be to the aggressor.
Once again, it seems to me, the U.S. is in danger of doing that -- this time about Communist China's maniacal threats of a war against Taiwan, 80 miles across the Straits.
Daily for months now, Beijing has threatened military attack against Taiwan. It says the leaders of Taiwan are plotting to make it independent of China. Beijing knows that top leaders of Taiwan plan no such thing.
But Taiwan did recently carry out the first free national election in the history of the Chinese people, and plans another in March. While not demanding independence, the Taiwan leadership does ask the world to acknowledge it as the separate thriving reality it has become.
For its freedoms and modest international ambitions, Beijing cannot forgive Taiwan, not until it surrenders its mind and future.
Beijing threatens naval blockade, and says missiles will fall every day in Taiwan. Already action has been added to threat -- missile "tests" near Taiwan and menacing amphibious landings opposite Taiwan.
To the U.S., which would inevitably become involved in a Chinese-started war that neither America nor Taiwan wants or incites, China offers the usual contempt. Beijing passes word that the U.S. is more interested in Los Angeles than Taiwan -- nasty nuclear blackmail. No country planning war ever delivered clearer threats than China against Taiwan.
The U.S. does caution Beijing. It says an attack on Taiwan would violate U.S. understandings with China and America's treaty with Taiwan. But it is done privately, without specifics about what the U.S. might do.
Washington believes the Chinese may be bluffing, and in any case will not make a direct land assault. But Beijing can easily carry out other attacks. Beijing and the American people should know what the U.S. might do if Beijing blockaded Taiwan or sank its ships or carried out daily missile raids. Would we reply in military proportion? Would we cut off the trade with China that finances the Chinese Army?
And can Beijing take America's whispered, unspecific cautions seriously if at the same time the U.S. helps strengthen the vast industrial empire of the Chinese Army, not only through trade but something called "defense conversion"?
The Far Eastern Economic Review reports that Defense Secretary Perry's plans for the Chinese to convert their arms and nuclear industries to civilian use have had only one tangible result -- "a lucrative business deal for Perry's friends and a springboard for China's efforts to develop a modern military-communications system." Representative Floyd D. Spence, chairman of the House Committee on National Security, has asked Mr. Perry for a reply.
Like other countries looking for trouble, China puts less credibility in another country's whispered cautions than it does in open statements about the cost to be paid.
So, as long as the U.S. gives neither China nor the American people an idea of what Washington might do to meet military action against Taiwan, it increases the possibility of war.
Giving advance warnings of consequences is not warmongering. As the Secretary of State and America found out 46 years ago, it is wiser and safer to say the words than to pencil them out.

HEADLINE: The Republican Welfare Trap

 BODY:
House Republicans have a plan to corner President Clinton politically. They want to pass the Senate's welfare reform bill, which is less extreme than the House bill but still nasty. No matter what he does, someone will accuse the President of betraying his promises. If he signs the bill he will, by his staff's estimates, throw more than a million children into poverty and infuriate his party's liberal wing. If he vetoes it, the G.O.P. will accuse him of repudiating not only his campaign promise to reform the welfare system but also his grudging embrace of the Senate bill when it passed by an overwhelming majority in September. That mistake has returned to haunt him. 
 Mr. Clinton's choice -- alienating moderates who were won over by his campaign promises or enraging liberal advocates of the current system -- would be unenviable for any politician, let alone a Democrat running for re-election. His best course of action is the right course. That is to admit that his earlier embrace of the Senate plan, which Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York has justifiably described as "an obscene act of social regression," was wrong. He should then veto it or any other bill that rips holes in the nation's 60-year-old safety net.
The Senate bill would end the system under which Washington guarantees to match state contributions to poor mothers with children. That historic entitlement has not only encouraged states to provide adequate benefits. It has also cushioned economic downturns by pumping cash into needy hands.
In addition, the bill would allow states to opt out of the food stamp program -- the only Federal program that sets a uniform standard of relief for everyone in the country. The measure would cut off legal, taxpaying immigrants from food stamps and other help and fall $12 billion short of the money needed to achieve what the Republicans insist is their ultimate goal -- putting welfare recipients to work. The truth is that finding jobs for welfare mothers requires child care, training and transportation -- expenses that dwarf the cost of sending them a check. The Republicans simply duck the financial realities.
Lost in this catfight is the fact that the nation already has a pretty good welfare law, the Family Support Act of 1988. The major problem is that Congress never put nearly enough money behind the law's welfare-to-work provisions to make them function. Senate Democrats previously proposed doing just that. Mr. Clinton's welfare reform bill went even further -- imposing time limits on welfare, which the Republicans favor, but also providing money for child care, job training and, as a last resort, a public-sector job for parents who try without success to find private-sector work. Once the Republicans took control of Congress, these worthwhile bills were dead.
Mr. Clinton was forced to backtrack. But his rhetorical concessions in September, when the Senate voted 87 to 12 for the Republican bill, went much too far. He was petrified at the prospect of walking into November as a defender of the current welfare system. No Democratic President ought to accept a bill that would tear down the legacy of Franklin Roosevelt.
Fortunately, the mood on Capitol Hill has changed. Newt Gingrich is flying closer to the ground. Voters are dissatisfied with the hard edges of the Republican agenda. There is a fighting chance that Mr. Clinton can keep faith with the traditional liberal base of his party without alienating the middle-class voters who, in 1992, resonated to his promise to "end welfare as we know it." Mr. Clinton can take the risk of vetoing a measure he knows is harsh and punitive.

HEADLINE: Hart of the Arts

 BODY:
Kitty Carlisle Hart, who recently resigned as head of the New York State Council on the Arts, which distributes grants to cultural groups throughout the state, fit her job as precisely as a shell fits an egg. In the 20 years since her appointment by Gov. Hugh Carey, there was hardly a cultural institution in the state that she did not visit or a legislator she did not buttonhole. If the Arts Council's grants have usually been sagacious and wide-ranging, much of the credit is due to her determination to expose its members to everything that was going on in the state's cultural community. Her high profile helped compensate for the Council's low budget -- now $28.9 million after a series of drastic budget cuts during the Cuomo years. Gov. George Pataki will find her hard to replace.
To listen to New York's cultural community is to believe that the best successor to Kitty Carlisle Hart would be her clone. "The person who succeeds her," says Schuyler Chapin, New York's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, "has to have her skill at dealing with the State Legislature. Also that person must really know the field, and be able to act as a full-time chairman. It could be someone who, like Kitty, was an actor. Or an artist. Or who came out of academe or the foundations. You want somebody deeply committed to the arts and preferably with a high profile -- somebody like Jane Alexander at the National Endowment for the Arts." 
 Agnes Gund, president of the Museum of Modern Art, also spoke of the Council's statewide scope and the Hart-like energy needed to head it: "This is one of the nation's leading arts organizations, and it really needs someone who can do the job."
"The reason you hear such positive things about Kitty Carlisle Hart," said Lynne Meadow, artistic director of the Manhattan Theatre Club, "is because she is a lover of all the arts."
"What you want in the Arts Council role," said Andre Bishop, artistic director of the Lincoln Center Theater, "is a publicly recognized personality who is afraid neither of politics nor politicians and can really talk up the importance of the arts."
The qualifications described by these arts professionals make sense, and Governor Pataki should pay attention to them. There is widespread private concern among cultural leaders in New York City about reports that Mr. Pataki wants to appoint a prominent contributor, Earle I. Mack, to this important post. Mr. Mack, a real estate developer and former chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, is on the board of both the Dance Theater of Harlem and the New York City Ballet. He has been involved as a producer and director in two well-regarded films about ballet -- "The Children of Theater Street," about Leningrad's Kirov Ballet School, and "She Dances Alone," a portrait of Nijinsky's daughter Kyra.
But when the Governor has all of New York State to choose from, these credentials are simply not weighty enough to make Mr. Mack the first choice for this job. The ideal candidate should have a strong record in the performing arts or an extended history of service in the major cultural institutions. He or she should also have a grasp of the funding needs of the arts community in New York City and of cultural institutions in the state. Finally, everyone who knows Mrs. Hart believes that her successor should have some of her talent for charming (and educating) the State Legislature about the importance of arts funding to both the civic and economic health of New York.
With Mrs. Hart probably not leaving her post before March, there is plenty of time for Mr. Pataki to conduct a broader search. It is also vital that the cultural community start lobbying the Governor to let him know that there is a demand for a candidate who seems a stronger bet to fill the void left by Mrs. Hart's retirement.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETSWeakness in Europe and Japan Fails to Bring a Rally for Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday on profit taking by currency traders disappointed that the dollar did not rally this week despite evidence of slowing European and Japanese economies.
The dollar fell against both the German mark and the Japanese yen after the dollar spent the day rising and falling against both currencies. 
 With the dollar upwardly mobile for the last few months, traders had expected that the weakening economies of Europe and the need to fix Japan's four-year downward tilt would bolster the dollar for some time.
But when the German central bank allowed one of its important interest rates to drop on Wednesday, the dollar did not jump. The Bundesbank also disappointed the markets Thursday when its policy-making committee did not cut official rates.
"It is profit taking and a certain amount of frustration," said Margaret Kudarauskas, senior foreign exchange analyst at the Boston office of Technical Data. That included "the frustration on Wednesday that the dollar did not rally, especially dollar-mark, after the Fed ease," she said.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar traded at 1.4823 marks, compared with 1.4875 on Thursday. It finished at 106.55 yen, compared with 106.75 the day before. The British pound rose to $1.5235 from $1.5186.
In a thin market like yesterday's, small trades can have an exaggerated effect on the market.
The dollar's weakness against the yen was also partly the result of heavy yen buying by hedge funds, which had sold marks after the German currency failed to continue its advance against the yen.
In addition, American stock and bond markets fell yesterday, taking away some of the dollar's support. Gold buyers also hedged their bets, with bullion in Hong Kong jumping $10 and prices in the United States rising "with a vengeance" to a six-year high, Ms. Kudarauskas of Technical Data said.
With German economic data showing weakness, Europe fearful it is entering a recession and the United States looking just that much better, "the market is still buying time" while waiting for more German rate cuts, said David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, an investment advisory firm.

HEADLINE: Martin Kessler, 66, Publisher of Noted Books, Dies

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Martin Kessler, a New York publisher of influential books about contemporary social history, public policy and economics, died on Thursday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 66.
The cause was brain cancer, said his daughter, Elinor Kessler. 
 At his death, Mr. Kessler had his own imprint, Martin Kessler Books/ Free Books. He started his career at Free Press publishers in Manhattan but in 1967 joined Basic Books, where he acquired, edited and published many authors whose ideas and critiques could inspire public discussion for years and shape the viewpoints of readers.
He rejoined The Free Press in 1993 and started his imprint with "The Tyranny of the Majority" by Lani Guinier, who had been nominated by President Clinton to be Assistant Attorney General for civil rights.
It was a book that gave Ms. Guinier a chance to present her views on voting rights to he general public. Opponents of Ms. Guinier had used some of her earlier writings on the subject to derail her nomination.
Mr. Kessler's current books include "The Winner-Take-All Society" by Robert H. Frank and Phillip J. Cook, "The Luck Business" by Robert Goodman and "On the Eve of the Millenium" by Conor Cruise O'Brien.
In his 25 years at Basic Books he edited and published two Pulitzer-Prize winning books, "Godel, Escher, Bach" by Douglas Hofstadter and "The Social Transformation of American Medicine" by Paul Starr.
He shepherded to publication notable books like "Losing Ground" by Charles Murray, "The Zero Sum Society" by Lester Thurow, "The De industrialization of America" by Barry Bluestone and Ben Harrison and "The Evolution of Cooperation" by Robert Axelrod.
Other titles under his care included "Faces at the Bottom of the Well" by Derrick Bell, "Reflections of an Affirmative Action Baby" by Stephen L. Carter, "The Overworked American" by Juliet Schor, "Trading Places" by Clyde V. Prestowitz, and "Poor Support" by David W. Ellwood.
Among the authors he edited were James Q. Wilson, Michael Walzer, Joseph Nye, Sylvia Hewlett, Herbert Simon and Robert Alter. During 14 of his 25 years at Basic Books he served as president and editorial director.
Mr. Kessler was born in Vienna. He immigrated to England in 1939, where he completed high school. After coming to New York in 1946, he graduated from City College with a degree in history and earned an M.A. in political science at New York University.
Beside his daughter, also of the Upper West Side, he is survived by his former wife, Aline Pick Kessler, who lives in Greenwich Village.

HEADLINE: Economic Data Cause Selloff in Long Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were mixed yesterday, with the shorter maturities showing some strength, but with the longer maturities being hammered, as traders reacted uncertainly to the day's employment report.
Traders said the short end of the market was supported by buyers anticipating more cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve on the heels of the overall weak economic reports. 
 The long end of the market would normally stage a rally on weak numbers like yesterday's nonfarm payroll data, which showed a loss of 201,000 jobs last month. Such signs of a slowing economy are taken as indicators that inflation will be weak. The long bonds did not, however, follow the usual script yesterday as the Clinton Administration said that the job market might actually have improved last month but that the numbers failed to show that because the data were skewed by the Northeast blizzard and the partial shutdown of the Government.
Given the vagaries of the weather, the long end of the government securities market seemed to place more emphasis on other factors, like higher commodity prices, that might suggest a rise in inflation and on the looming supply of new debt issues coming to market in the next week.
The 30-year bond dropped 110/32 , to 10922/32 for a yield of 6.16 percent, up from 6.07 percent on Thursday. The two-year note held steady at 4.90 percent.
The Treasury will be selling about $84.9 billion in new debt securities next week, with $44.5 billion of that representing the Government's quarterly refunding, much of it in long maturities.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said, "For some market participants, the weak employment report today may have been skewed by a number of factors including the blizzard on the East Coast, the strike in New York and the temporary Government shutdown." He was referring to the strike by building maintenance workers in New York City.
He also noted as reasons for some of the market's fears, the high daily reading of commodity prices, the stronger-than-expected numbers in a Columbia University inflation index and the surge in hourly earnings.
"Although many market participants reasoned that the loss of many jobs at the low end of the wage structure during the month may have overly boosted the average hourly earnings numbers," Mr. Chan said, "others were not as quick to discount the previous month's strength, which could not be blamed on the same factor."
"In a market which has thrived on the expectation of future Fed easings, most market players quickly realized that if inflation were to accelerate, then bonds would decline," he said.
Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Everen Securities Inc. in Chicago, attributed a good part of the higher bond yields to the coming refunding, particularly given the large amount of longer maturities involved. He also said that all the weakness in the January payroll data could not be explained away by weather conditions.
"So you have a technical condition where buyers are more comfortable buying shorter maturities believing that the Fed is on their side," Mr. Davis said. "Consequently dealers of Treasury securities view the refunding as an opportunity to make money on a setup trade."
Mr. Davis described the weakness in bonds as dealers' positioning themselves to buy the longer maturities next week at yields that would give them the potential for price improvement after the auctions were over.
In when-issued trading, the three-year note to be auctioned on Tuesday was offered at a price to yield 5.02 percent. The 10-year note to be sold on Wednesday was at 5.65 percent and the 30-year bond, set for a Thursday auction, was at 6.09 percent.

HEADLINE: Arnold E. Safer, 59, Analyst and Expert On Energy Markets

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Arnold E. Safer, an economist who was an expert in the world energy markets, died on Jan. 13 in his home in Rockville, Md. He was 59.
The cause was a heart attack. 
 Mr. Safer founded a consulting firm, the Energy Futures Group, which in collaboration with Benjamin Schlesinger & Associates of Bethesda, Md., helped many clients to understand how the gradual deregulation of the natural gas industry in the 1980's would lead to much freer trading of gas and how the emerging spot and futures markets for gas would work.
Benjamin Schlesinger said Mr. Safer had also played a crucial role as adviser to the New York Mercantile Exchange in setting up the trading of futures in heating oil in the late 1970's. Mr. Schlesinger recalled that Mr. Safer predicted as far back as the 1960's that market forces would prevail over rigid cartel pricing in world oil markets. And in the 1970's, he concluded that growing production outside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would weaken the cartel's ability to set prices, which eventually proved to be true.
Mr. Safer was born in Boston, graduated from Brandeis University and received a doctorate in economics from the University of Rochester. He taught at Rice University and was at one time the chief economist with the Irving Trust Company in New York.
He founded his consulting firm in 1981 and helped put together an analysis of how the natural gas industry would change after its planned deregulation in 1985. His clients included the World Bank, the Energy Department and numerous corporations.
He is survived by his wife Roberta and three daughters, Karen of Silver Spring, Md., and Jocelyn and Adina, both of San Francisco.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Where Small Is Beautiful;
For Italy's Family-Owned Weavers, Life Is Good

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: BIELLA, Italy

 BODY:
Because the weavers on the other side of the valley specialize in cashmere, and the nearby Loro Piana company has a two-year monopoly on the supply of vicuna wool, Paolo Ferla is betting his company's future on the highly prized fleece of the baby alpaca.
Mr. Ferla's company, Lanificio Egidio Ferla S.p.A., is just one of 1,800 family-owned textile producers nestled in the hills around this northern Italian town. Together, they employ 28,000 people -- an average of just 16 each. In the era of the global marketplace, where even giant corporations must fight to protect their turf against low-cost third world competitors, such small-scale operators might seem quaint anachronisms, doomed to extinction. 
 They are anything but. Not only has Biella beaten back the onslaught of cheap textiles from the Far East, it has also inundated Japan, Korea and China with its own top-of-the-line fabrics. When Europe emerged from recession last year, Biella was at the forefront of the Continent's export push, helping Italy rack up a $15.8 billion trade surplus in textiles ($20.5 billion when leather goods and other apparel are included). Demand for Biella's cloths is so strong that the regional unemployment rate has sunk to 5 percent, less than half Western Europe's overall jobless rate of 12 percent, and local business owners complain of a shortage of skilled labor.
Few Americans may realize it, but in Europe, as in the United States, small businesses are assuming an increasingly crucial role as engines of economic growth. While the problems of huge industrial conglomerates like Germany's Daimler-Benz A. G. or Italy's Olivetti S.p.A. grab the headlines, thousands of family enterprises are quietly innovating, increasing sales and exports, and creating jobs.
Pockets of small-business dynamism are scattered across the Continent, from machine-building companies around Bologna, Italy, or in the Germany state of Baden-Wurttemberg, to the shoe makers and tile producers of the Catalonia region of Spain, to the perfume manufacturers of Grasse, France. Collectively they are a bright spot in a Europe otherwise mired in slow growth, high unemployment and out-of-control budget deficits that threaten outbursts of social unrest like the strikes that recently swept France.
The family-owned textile companies of Biella sometimes seem almost relentless in their smallness, with even companies of a dozen workers or fewer setting up employees as suppliers. Yet they show remarkable agility at solving problems, in part because their size makes them more nimble, but also because of an unusual willingness to share technology, marketing and manufacturing experience, and sometimes even production capacity with their home-town competitors.
And rather than having to fight off Government antitrust regulators, they actually get encouragement from the 15-nation European Union, so long as their collaboration at home does not translate into monopolistic practices abroad.
"The advantage is that at any time you can easily talk to your bank, your competitors, your suppliers," said Mr. Ferla, 38, whose $12- million-a-year company employs 65 people who produce 400,000 yards of fabric a year. "Biella is perfect for business."
Biella's textile-weaving community is the product of centuries of growth. Riccardo Piacenza still lives in the house his forebears used in 1733 to start a textile business. Over a lunch of boiled beef and vegetables, he described how the industry grew rapidly in the 19th century after textile machines were imported from Belgium and Britain. In time, Biella boasted all layers of textile work, from spinning to weaving to finishing. To supply the textile makers, local textile machine companies sprang up.
The town's peculiar mix of cooperation and competition dates back at least to those days, when textile mills routinely let competitors inspect their latest equipment.
In the 1960's, the local industrialists banded together to finance a training school for textile workers. In the 1970's, they started a joint trade fair to promote Biella's textiles. And in the 1980's, local textile-machinery manufacturers formed a consortium to sell their products in China's newly liberalized market.
Today, the textile companies have gotten so chummy that some economists liken them to the divisions of a large corporation. When floods of orders exceed one manufacturer's capacity, competitors are often called in to help assure deliveries -- and keep customers happy.
At Ing. Loro Piana & C. S.p.A., Sergio Loro Piana leads a visitor through a new $31 million plant, where computer-controlled machines spin cashmere yarns at dizzying speeds. The equipment is so advanced that only a handful of workers are needed to operate it. Yet far from hiding it from other local textile barons, Mr. Piana, who with his brother Pier Luigi runs the $162 million-a-year company that a forebear founded in 1924, said he would invite them all to inspect the new machinery when the plant is formally inaugurated later this year.
Gestures like that make Biella's companies fiercely loyal to one another. Mr. Ferla said his company paid local suppliers up to 10 percent more than the same goods might cost elsewhere just to maintain a longstanding relationship. "We seldom try to struggle with subcontractors," he said. "We don't want to kill anyone. We learned this from our grandfathers. It's very wise in the long run."
Mr. Ferla's company found itself on the receiving end of its neighbors' largess when it made its move into baby alpaca, a rare and extremely delicate wool. Spinning and finishing the fibers was supposed to be all but technically impossible.
But, working with nearby spinning-machine companies and finishing specialists, Mr. Ferla's company found a way. Now, it supplies the lightweight fabric, half the price of cashmere, to American apparel makers like Hickey Freeman and Oxxford Clothing.
The collaboration in Biella has not touched off any inquiries from Italian or European Union antitrust authorities, perhaps because the weavers seem to have a keen sense of where cooperation ends and competition begins. Rival factory owners will sit over a lunch of polenta and chicken at the local tennis-club restaurant discussing the difficulties of spinning some tricky new fiber or procuring wool supplies. But when they go abroad hawking their wares to apparel manufacturers in Japan or the United States, it is usually other Biella manufacturers they are competing against.
The European Union generally encourages cooperative efforts by regional clusters of small businesses, and the idea has stirred international interest. In the United States, banding together to survive outside competitive threats has become more common for localized industries, but there the small-business partnerships tend to get more of a helping hand from state governments. Richard M. Locke, a specialist on industrial districts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management, cited programs in both Massachusetts and Pennsylvania to help their garment and machine-tool industries in the 1980's.
European small businesses are beginning to show signs of wanting the same sort of government attention. Biella's industrialists recently joined 13 other Italian districts to form a lobbying organization that seeks links with similar industrial regions elsewhere in Europe. The goal, according to Enrico Botto Poala, a textile maker who is its first president, is to pressure the European Union to shift industrial policy from a focus on helping backward regions to doing more for regional small-business groups.
One reason for Biella's backscratching is an awareness of its vulnerability. Memories of the 1970's, when a sputtering economy and a flood of cheap Asian imports wiped out half of the region's textile companies, remain vivid.
To respond to that crisis, the Biellese brought out innovative new products, including Loro Piana's light Tasmanian wools. To increase efficiency, many companies spun off some of their operations or helped finance start-ups that specialized in various steps of the textile process like spinning, dyeing or finishing. Biella's weavers also invested heavily in research and technology.
To be sure, many locals fear that the region, which is one-fourth the size of Rhode Island and has a population of 190,000, remains overdependent on a single industry. While it has developed other manufacturing, like valves and bathroom fixtures, it still relies on textiles for one-third of employment. Meantime, the growth of Italian textile exports is slowing, and raw-material prices are rising.
But Biella textile makers are responding to the challenges. Many, for example, have shifted some of their production abroad. Piacenza now spins cashmere yarns in China, the world's principal supplier of cashmere wool. Loro Piana does likewise, and last year formed a joint venture in Outer Mongolia, another cashmere region, and signed an agreement to obtain vicuna after helping Peru rescue the endangered species. Earlier, Loro Piana acquired Warren of Stafford, a textile mill in Stafford Springs, Conn.
Arnaldo Bagnasco, an economist at Turin University, said he believed Biella's textile industry would undoubtedly get more efficient if it could win tax concessions from the Italian Government and economic assistance -- including money for better roads and telecommunications -- from the European Union authorities in Brussels.
Moreover, the textile-mill owners remain confident that the same skills that enabled them to surmount previous crises will steer them through any new troubles. Riccardo Piacenza, a representative of the 13th generation running his family's business, likens Biella's products to Swiss watches that cannot be easily duplicated by would-be competitors.
Mr. Loro Piana is equally upbeat. "There are some very good manufacturers all over the world," he said. "But we don't see, systematically, any other region, any bunch of companies, capable of casting a serious shadow on our district."

HEADLINE: Peddler Testifies In Firebomb Trial

 BODY:
A peddler testified yesterday that about half an hour after a firebomb exploded in a subway train in Manhattan, he saw a badly-burned man drop a pair of singed, gasoline-soaked gloves in the Clark Street subway station in Brooklyn.
The peddler, Ine Kyu Choi, testifying in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, identified the man as Edward J. Leary, a 50-year-old unemployed computer technician from New Jersey who is accused of attempted murder and assault in the 1994 explosion. 
 Mr. Choi, a Korean immigrant who sold hats and other items at the Clark Street station, said Mr. Leary dropped the gloves while making a phone call. A police officer had called for an ambulance and he and a dozen officers did not think to pick up the gloves, Mr. Choi said.
It was an hour later, when Mr. Leary had become a suspect, that two detectives arrived looking for the gloves, Mr. Choi said. He directed them to a trash container where Mr. Leary had thrown them, he said.
The prosecution contended that dropping the gloves was part of a rational plan by Mr. Leary to evade detection but the defense has claimed that Mr. Leary was insane at the time of the explosion and afterward, and did not know what he was doing as a result of taking a mixture of drugs prescribed for depression.
