HEADLINE: Olestra? Quelle Horreur!

BYLINE: By Judith Warner; Judith Warner is a biographer and magazine writer.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
The announcement that the Food and Drug Administration had approved olestra, a fat substitute, provoked great fanfare in the United States. And the manufacturer, Procter & Gamble, is seeking approval in Britain and Canada, too.
But in France there is no such rush for approval. Here, the idea that Americans had found a product that allows them to eat junk without ingesting fat seemed like proof, once again, that when it comes to gastronomy, they have their heads screwed on wrong. 
 French nutrition experts point to the facts: Every year, hundreds of low-fat or nonfat products are introduced into American supermarkets -- more than 1,300 new creations appeared in 1995 alone. Yet, at the same time, the number of overweight people has increased from one in four Americans in 1980 to one in three in 1994.
"It's quite a paradox," says Dr. France Bellisle, an obesity specialist at the Hotel Dieu hospital in Paris. "It's good to cut fats, but fats are obviously just one part of a much larger picture." For Dr. Bellisle and other French doctors, the other part of the picture is quite simple: Americans eat too much.
"It's not just the doughnuts, the hamburgers, the sugary drinks, but the eating between meals," says Serge Renaud, a nutritionist at a scientific research center in Bordeaux. "If people want to lose weight, they should eat three meals a day -- two light and one heavier at dinnertime, which will allow them to appreciate the beauty of their food."
Enjoy the beauty of food? The concept is an ocean away from the world of olestra. The fat substitute has been reported to cause side effects like nausea, diarrhea and intestinal cramping -- not to mention the loss of nutrients. All this for something that tastes terrible, according to Dr. Bellisle, who has sampled food made with olestra.
"For the French, food is primarily about taste, quality and socializing," says Claude Fischler, a researcher at the Centre Nationale de la Recherche Scientifique in Paris, who has studied French and American eating habits.
In fact, the French had their own flirtation with "lite" foods. From 1984 to 1988, sales of light butters tripled. From 1988 to 1989, the consumption of low-fat spreads went up 43 percent. But the tide turned just as quickly. From 1991 to 1994, consumption of light dairy products alone fell about 35 percent.
Economics was one reason these products failed. When the economy went bad in the early 1990's, people were unwilling to pay more for products that offered less. The medical establishment weighed in, too: Two prominent nutritionists spoke out against all things "lite." Given that the French have the second lowest rate of coronary heart disease in the developed world (after Japan), it seemed that, in lean times, to continue eating foie gras and butter in moderation was the wisest thing to do.
The French don't seem to be any the worse for it. In 1988, 21 percent of them said they were on a diet, according to the dairy trade board. Last year, that figure fell to 17 percent, as more and more products on market shelves bragged of their "good whole milk taste." Only 15 percent of the population is overweight.
But the French need to guard against complacency. Dr. Bellisle says that, with their increasingly sedentary habits, the "French paradox" -- remaining thin while eating fatty foods -- may become a thing of the past. "In 10 or 15 years," she warns, "we will be just like you."
But even then, it's probably safe to say, there will be no market for olestra.

HEADLINE: Coup in Africa Frightens Democratic Neighbors

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: NIAMEY, Niger, Feb. 1

 BODY:
In a fragrant courtyard in this desert's-edge capital, a spokesman at army headquarters busies himself explaining how the military will bring about a "march toward democracy."
But less than a week after a coup that overthrew the country's first democratically elected President, the expression of cocky relaxation worn by young soldiers sitting in the shade, idly fingering their automatic weapons, suggests that they are already relishing being in charge. 
 It is a taste acquired through long experience. After only three turbulent years of experimentation with Western-style democracy in 36 years of independence from France, Niger's coup, for many here accustomed to military rule, was above all a return to normal.
Niger's coup, the first in French-speaking Africa since an era of multi-party politics began at the turn of the decade, came on the heels of one in Sierra Leone in January, on the eve of scheduled multiparty elections there.
The takeover in Niger has sent a chill throughout this region, where elected governments are receiving dwindling international support while they face mounting discontent over sinking economic fortunes.
According to the colonel who led the coup, it was justified by an increasingly volatile political stalemate between a president and a prime minister who came from rival political parties and ethnic groups.
"We knew that our intervention would not win us applause internationally," Lieut. Col. Bare Ibrahim Mainassara, the 46-year-old coup leader, in an interview. "It doesn't go with the winds of these times. But we could not watch while our country became another Somalia."
While Washington and Paris condemned the army takeover here and quickly suspended their economic assistance, Niger's new authorities seemed more surprised by the breadth of denunciations that rained down upon them from the immediate region.
In neighboring Mali, one of West Africa's most vibrant democracies, the Government immediately called for "political and diplomatic isolation and a boycott of the putschists." Other countries with less well established democratic practices, from Chad and Togo to Guinea, likewise condemned the coup, perhaps fearing that their armies might be inspired to copy it.
[On Friday, Reuters reported that soldiers in the West African state of Guinea were holding the capital, Conakry, to protest low pay, and President Lansana Conte said they were trying to overthrow him. A shell exploded near the presidential palace, and it was reported to be in flames.]
For foreign powers, especially France, which provides as much as 45 percent of the country's budget, the takeover by Niger's army, which left six dead, represented an embarrassing predicament.
If they do nothing, many diplomats say, other fledgling democracies in West Africa will quickly face similar military challenges. But if they move to freeze out a country that already faces difficulties feeding its population and paying salaries, diplomats here say that the result would be increased hunger and quickening desertification in Niger, and more political unrest.
American diplomats have little discretion over their aid budget of approximately $25 million. United States law requires an immediate end to aid to countries where elected governments are overthrown by force.
Diplomats say that Washington is holding out for a return to office of Niger's elected leaders. In order to maintain pressure toward this goal, the White House said in a statement this week that, in addition to withholding bilateral assistance, Washington would "not support any new programs" in the international financial institutions like the World Bank, which provide critical budgetary support for Niger.
"The U.S. support for democracy is not one that takes into account the problems that might occur along the way," said one Western diplomat. "From the American perspective, conflict in democracy is not something to be dreaded or to be seen as an excuse for military intervention."
If France publicly supports the same goal, however, many here feel that Paris, which is the region's diplomatic powerhouse, is already positioning itself to help the country's new authorities, who today named a new interim government composed entirely of civilians.
"We must, in my view, find some way out of this," said one European diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Already, the Colonel has taken a step forward in naming a new prime minister with serious qualifications. The rest will have to come with time."
For many African diplomats, this kind of nuanced view, in a region where so many governments take their cues directly from Paris, is potentially as dangerous a precedent as the coup itself.
"We had been told only recently that France was committed to defending democratic governments wherever they came under threat or attack within its sphere of influence in Africa," said a senior diplomat from one neighbor of Niger. "Now we seem to be hearing that if things get sticky and you break the impasse by breaking the rules of the democratic game, Paris will settle with you after a decent interval. All you have to do is make the right noises."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lieut. Col. Bare Ibrahim Mainassara speaking in Niamey, Niger, this week. His forces led a takeover of the democratically elected Government on Jan. 27. The unrest has generated fears of insurrection in the region. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: His Accent Just Right, Chirac Plies His Charms

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 2

 BODY:
When the President of France came calling in Chicago today, John Bryan, the head of Sara Lee, praised him for once receiving an unusual but special honor: a certificate of honor from Howard Johnson's "for artistry in making banana splits."
Making banana splits was not all that Jacques Chirac did when he worked as a part-time counterman while studying at Harvard University in the 1950's. Over lunch he told Mr. Bryan and 500 other members of Chicago's business and political elite that Howard Johnson's "also had a very good turkey sandwich, which I did very very well." The audience loved it. 
 When Gloria Scoby, a senior executive with Crain's Publications, presented him with a gift of appreciation, Mr. Chirac kissed both her cheeks, saying, "I'm in the habit, when given a gift by a very nice-looking girl, to kiss her."
And in his toast at a dinner in his honor at the Art Institute of Chicago, Mr. Chirac lauded Chicago as "a city whose nobility and grandeur are the symbol of America which has made us dream and which still makes us dream."
Mr. Chirac may be defined by his right-of-center politics and studiously cultivated air of arrogance both at home and in the corridors of power in Washington, but out in America, he tried to come across as a man of the people. It is all part of his charm offensive, as he uses his slang-tinged English to sell himself and his country to America.
After all, how many world leaders -- or French politicians for that matter -- could go on CNN's "Larry King Live," as Mr. Chirac did during a visit to New York last fall, and reminisce about the time he worked in an Anheuser-Busch factory in St. Louis and the time he produced a French newspaper about the Port of New Orleans?
"The first paper who printed my name was the Times-Picayune," he told his host, long before he became famous back home.
And who would expect the President of France to invite a group of American journalists to dine at a New York steak house, as Mr. Chirac did last fall, order a couple of beers and tell one of his female guests to choose the wines for the table?
Today, Mr. Chirac, who spent 18 years as Mayor of Paris, took his motorcade to Crane High School set in the midst of the housing projects on Chicago's West Side. With Mayor Richard Daley at his side, Mr. Chirac listened intently as educators, parents and students explained how a special training program brings parents and teachers together to nurture inner-city students and teach them how to get jobs.
"Did you have some problems with the teachers when you began to involve the parents?" he asked. "Isn't that a kind of interference?"
He wanted to know how many schools used the training program, how many students were involved, what percentage of students dropped out before graduation and the extent of the drug problem.
At the end of the 75-minute encounter, Laparis Thompson, a parent, said, "If you want to fly us to France, we'll do that, too."
"I'll think about it," Mr. Chirac replied. "It would probably be useful but it would be a hard job to convince our teachers."
But Mr. Chirac's main mission in coming to Chicago a day after his state visit to Washington was to sweet-talk American business executives into buying French.
He was so eager to come that when snow threatened to close down Andrews Air Force Base and doom his mid-morning departure from Washington on Friday, he decided to leave after the formal state dinner at the White House after midnight on Thursday night, arriving at his Chicago hotel at 5:30 A.M.
There was a time in French history when President Charles de Gaulle dismissed a visiting Japanese Prime Minister as a "transistor salesman" when he showed up in Paris and tried to peddle his country's goods.
But that was then, in the days when diplomacy was all about counting warheads, and this is now, when counting profits is what counts.
No matter that France has just suffered the most serious strikes in a decade. No matter that the French Government and the labor unions are headed for another crash.
"Ladies and gentlemen, I have confidence in France and in the winning cards we hold," Mr. Chirac told his audience at lunch. He even boasted that the per-capita growth of exports is higher in France than, mon dieu, the United States or Japan.
Mr. Chirac knows well that the stakes here are much higher than next fall's sales of Beaujolais Nouveau. Franco-American economic competition has become so cutthroat that France felt compelled last year to expel a number of Americans who were accused of spying on its economy. Spying by the Central Intelligence Agency helped the United States beat out France for a billion-dollar satellite and communications system in the Amazon.
So, Mr. Chirac can be excused for reaching the same conclusion that Bill Clinton did early in the Presidency: when consumer spending is down, the only way for a head of state to make his country's economy grow is to transform himself into salesman to the world.
Not everyone in the audience was convinced by Mr. Chirac's pitch. "The impression around the world is that France has rather protectionist policies and is not so anxious to compete with American interests," one man said.
"He's kidding," Mr. Chirac replied, pausing for effect. "I even think he's pulling my leg. No, France is not protectionist. We think the United States is protectionist. And we are right."
So perfect was his timing that the audience laughed in approval.

HEADLINE: THE BOSNIA ACCORD: IN WASHINGTON;
U.S. Denies Aiding Saudis In Arming The Bosnians

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Senior American officials adamantly denied a report today that the United States had collaborated with Saudi Arabia in a secret operation to funnel arms to the Bosnian Government.
An unidentified Saudi official was quoted in The Washington Post today as saying: "It was more than just turning a blind eye to what was going on. . . . It was consent combined with covert cooperation." 
 Senior American officials from the Pentagon to the State Department to the White House dismissed the assertion as untrue. They said the United States neither encouraged nor assisted the Saudi effort. Indeed, several questioned the Saudi official's claim that Saudi Arabia had contributed as much as $300 million in cash and arms to the Bosnian Government over the last three years.
If confirmed, the report would be an embarrassment for the Clinton Administration. For more than a year, British and French officials have insisted that the United States was covertly violating the United Nations arms embargo on shipments to the Bosnian Government. The Administration has repeatedly denied the charges.
Saudi Arabia has an immensely complicated relationship with the United States in which both sidesquietly do favors for each other, and occasionally put pressure on each other to do more. Sometimes that pressure is exerted privately, sometimes through press disclosures.
American officials said they were not aware of any specific point of contention between Washington and Riyadh. One official speculated that the Saudis might be trying to elbow aside the Iranians, who have publicly acknowledged helping the Muslim-led Bosnian Government.
Adel al-Jubeir, a spokesman for Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Ambassador to the United States, said he could neither confirm nor deny reports about covert actions.
The United States and Saudi Arabia have previously cooperated on covert operations. In the 1980's, the Saudis provided billions of dollars to underwrite the Central Intelligence Agency's arming of the Afghan rebels, and at the request of American officials the Saudis spent millions to arm the Nicaraguan rebels in the Iran-contra operation.
In his interview with The Post, the Saudi official likened the Bosnia operation to the covert efforts in Afghanistan. The United States and the Saudis, he said, turned to a "network" of arms dealers and "former this and former that" who could be trusted to arrange deliveries.
American officials emphatically denied this, and said anyone who helped the Saudis smuggle weapons to Bosnia did so without encouragement from any American official.
The question of arming the Bosnian Government arose almost as soon as war broke out in Bosnia in April 1992. The Clinton Administration lobbied unsuccessfully for a lifting of the embargo against arms shipments to the Balkan factions, while various nations -- including Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Iran -- made it clear they would try to help their Muslim brethren. An Iranian jetliner carrying 4,000 rifles and a million rounds of ammunition was intercepted in Zagreb, Croatia, in 1992.
American intelligence agencies gathered detailed information about which countries were smuggling weapons to the Bosnians. But the United States, American officials said, did not press those nations to stop violating the arms embargo. This could have been viewed, an official said, as a "nod and wink."
The United States, several officials said, felt no obligation to enforce the embargo on other countries, and in October 1994 Congress barred the Administration from sharing any intelligence that could be used to interdict arms shipments to the Bosnian Government.
But at the same time it was turning a blind eye to arms shipments to the Bosnian Government, the Administration used all of its diplomatic muscle to shore up the economic embargo against Serbia.
Last year, there were several European press reports about mysterious flights by American-made transport planes into the Tuzla airfield in Bosnian Government territory. Administration officials said the planes were not American and suggested they might have been sent by Turkey, another supporter of the Bosnian Government. American officials said today that the United States did not raise the issue with the Turks.
"This Administration always felt the embargo was unfair," one official said. Washington's argument was that the embargo merely locked in the Bosnian Government's huge disadvantage in heavy weapons.
The United States is now asking Saudi Arabia to contribute to an international effort to arm and train the Bosnian Army. Riyadh, officials said, has been noncommittal.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
After the Magic, Is It Time To Believe in the Knicks?

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen toyed with them before deciding to blow them off their own floor. Now, with Thursday night's shootout victory over Orlando fresh in their minds, they are talking about such foreign concepts as "playing together" and "accepting their roles."
Here come the Knicks again, teasing their following into believing that maybe, just maybe, they have the tools and the heart to go as far as they want in the post-season. 
 The Knicks have only one problem with that thinking: soon enough, they could be in the same boat they were in on Jan. 23, after a demoralizing 99-79 loss to the Chicago Bulls. So they were more than ready to put in perspective their 110-102 victory over the Magic, the defending Eastern Conference champion, at Madison Square Garden on Thursday, even though it was their fourth straight victory.
"It was a good win, but it's nothing to get over-excited about," Charles Smith said. "We needed to play well, win or lose. And we needed everybody to handle their assignments.
"The last time we played the Bulls, it wasn't just the score. Our effort wasn't there. It was a really bad game for us. In my four years here, I can never remember not competing, not even being in the game with them. So, in that sense, it was a wake-up call for us. But to say it's anything beyond that is premature right now."
The Knicks improved to 28-15 heading into their showdown with Indiana 1 P.M. tomorrow at Market Square Arena. Though the Pacers represent the next measuring stick during a week filled with them, there is reason to believe the Knicks are moving in the right direction.
It would be easy to dismiss the victory over the Magic as an anomaly by taking into account that Orlando is not a good road team (it fell to 9-13 and lost for the seventh time in its last nine games away from home). Also, the Magic has been riddled with injuries all season, with Shaquille O'Neal and Horace Grant missing significant chunks of time.
But Orlando came into the game as healthy as it has been since last season. And the Knicks moved the ball more crisply than they had in weeks, which led to seven players scoring in double figures and New York amazingly outscoring the Magic by 18-10 on fast-break points.
The notion that the Knicks could ever come out on the winning side of a run-and-shoot contest with Orlando was preposterous a month ago. It was not just their running game, either. The Knicks made 21 of 23 free throws. They won a battle of 3-point attrition by making an economical 7 of 13. Hubert Davis made five 3-pointers in a game for the second time this season, and all of them seemed to come at the most opportune times.
Though Patrick Ewing did not make a shot in the second half, he had 23 points through two quarters and 15 rebounds for the game. Charles Oakley and Anthony Mason combined for 31 points (Mason had 21), 22 rebounds (Oakley had 14), 6 assists and all the defensive pressure O'Neal and Horace Grant could take inside.
Coach Don Nelson used the same large lineup he used often against Houston earlier this season. Mason defended against O'Neal, frustrating him with every tactic he could; Smith and Oakley tried their bests to contain Dennis Scott and Nick Anderson; Ewing's job was to limit Grant's effectiveness, and Derek Harper shadowed Anfernee Hardaway, who finished only 3 of 15 from the field.
 
 
 
REBOUNDS
 The Knicks are still playing down rumors of any major deal, simply because they have few players who are hot commodities. But there are indications they will do something before the Feb. 22 trading deadline. The team has had conversations in the past 10 days with Toronto, which is interested in DOUG CHRISTIE. Several players from the Raptors' roster have been mentioned, including WILLIE ANDERSON, ED PINCKNEY and VICTOR ALEXANDER, all of whom are in the last year of their contracts.

HEADLINE: Payrolls Fall by 201,000 Jobs; Blizzard in East Is Cited

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The unemployment rate rose and the number of payroll jobs dropped sharply in January, the Government reported today, but analysts said the blizzard that crippled the Northeast made the already sluggish economy appear in worse shape than it really was.
The Labor Department estimated that employers dropped 201,000 people from their payrolls in the biggest decline in nearly five years. Normally, such a huge drop might herald the onset of a recession, but it was impossible to make an accurate determination because the storm closed so many businesses and kept legions of service and factory workers at home. A strike of building maintenance workers in New York City accounted for part of the loss. 
 The unemployment rate, which is based on a separate survey of households, climbed two-tenths of a point, to 5.8 percent, the upper end of the range that has prevailed since late 1994. That survey, which is often out of synch with the payroll numbers, found that more people were working but that the gains were swamped by an unusually large expansion of those seeking jobs.
"The effects of the severe weather, which unfortunately I am unable to quantify with any degree of confidence, make it difficult to determine whether a change has occurred in underlying labor market trends," Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
Financial markets were left just as baffled by the job figures as the experts at the Labor Department. The value of Treasury bonds fell as long-term interest rates rose, contributing to a decline in the stock market from record heights after five consecutive daily gains. Rates on short-term Treasury securities dipped.
The Clinton Administration, for its part, suggested that the job market might have actually improved last month if it had not been for the combined force of the snowstorm and the partial, budget-related Government shutdown.
"We fully expect employment growth to resume and believe that our economy will recover fully from the blow dealt by Mother Nature," Joseph E. Stiglitz, the President's chief economic adviser, said.
The pattern of job losses tended to support the idea that the blizzard -- which covered an area embracing 25 percent of the American work force -- was the chief culprit behind the big drop. The figures for January were published on schedule, but they followed the delayed December figures by just two weeks.
There were heavy job losses in restaurants and bars, retail trade, temporary help and at schools and colleges that normally hire students for such activities as sports events.
Construction jobs rose on strong growth in some areas not affected by the storm and on the diversion of many highway construction crews in the East to snow removal.
But pinpointing the location of the job losses was made more difficult because the Labor Department, suffering from budget cuts, has discontinued publication of the unemployment rates for 11 major industrial states.
The jobless rate for adult women climbed five-tenths of a point, to 5.1 percent, which may have reflected the pressures on women to stay home with children who were kept out of school. Unemployment for adult men was unchanged at 4.9 percent.
Some analysts found more evidence of a deteriorating economy in today's report. "We are flirting with recession," the National Association of Manufacturers said. And economists at Salomon Brothers, the Wall Street investment house, told clients that "fundamental weakness continues to emerge in timely indicators that are unlikely to be distorted by freak weather."
But others said the job figures reported today grossly exaggerated the underlying economic situation. "The question is whether the weakness is cumulating, feeding on itself, or whether we're in for a bounce," said Paul D. Mastroddi of J. P. Morgan. He said the latter was more likely, arguing that recent reports on sales of homes and motor vehicles were not particularly bad and that first-time claims for unemployment insurance had not climbed markedly in recent weeks.
The most telling sign that the dismal January results were caused more by bad weather than a deteriorating economy, Mr. Mastroddi said, "is that jobless claims seem to be holding at about 375,000" through late January.
Analysts also noted that the Labor Department made upward revisions for November and December that added 56,000 jobs to earlier estimates of payroll employment.
Clearly reflecting the storm was a 1.4-hour plunge in the length of the factory workweek that also helped drag the overall private-sector work week down by 36 minutes.
Average hourly earnings, watched closely for indications of wage pressure, climbed a hefty 6 cents an hour last month, to $11.68. But Commissioner Abraham said perhaps half the increase could be attributed to the storm as a larger proportion of lower-earning workers were idled. Analysts also noted the tendency of hourly earnings to rise sharply in the first month of a new quarter.
Regional figures supplied by the Labor Department showed that unemployment fell in the Northeast to 5.8 percent from 6.2 percent while it rose in the West to 6.9 percent from 6.3.
Officials said this divergence from what might be expected in light of the blizzard occurred because the Labor Department, in its survey of households, counts those with jobs as employed even if their business closed or they could not reach their workplace.
There were some 1.57 million such people during last month's survey week, nearly twice as many as in any other January since the mid-1970's and nearly four times the average January.
Unemployment edged down two-tenths of a point, to 5.4 percent, in the South and one-tenth of a point, to 4.6 percent, in the Midwest, today's report also showed.

HEADLINE: Feminists Gather to Affirm Relevancy of Their Movement

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The feminist movement has encountered rough waters of late. Issues that agitated its aging leaders in their youth three decades ago -- marriage and career, abortion rights and political clout -- are taken for granted by younger women. Some social critics have declared the movement irrelevant, out of touch, even dead.
About 3,000 women gathered here today in an effort to dispel those notions. They are participating in Feminist Expo '96, a three-day conference of meetings, displays and networking organized by the Feminist Majority Foundation, a nonprofit group. 
 The event is co-sponsored by 299 groups, including Emily's List, a political fund-raising organization, the United Farm Workers, Women in Film and the Young Women's Christian Association of the U.S.A.
"We want to end this discussion about the death of feminism," said Eleanor Smeal, president of the Feminist Majority Foundation. "We want to reframe the debate for the 21st century."
Ms. Smeal said there was no dearth of issues that women should be concerned about, from debate over the Federal budget to efforts in California and other states to repeal affirmative-action policies. She and other feminist leaders here said a women's movement was needed today more than ever exactly because many young women assumed that rights they took for granted could not be rolled back.
"We've changed the roles of women and men substantially," Ms. Smeal said. But "make no mistake, there is a backlash now exactly because of our success."
Another participant, Gloria Steinem, came to the event fresh from the successful campaign for Ron Wyden, a liberal Oregon Democrat who won the Senate seat left vacant when Bob Packwood resigned in disgrace over accusations of sexual and official misconduct. Feminists had to gear up to fight for affirmative action and "rescue women who have fallen into a river of discrimination," Ms. Steinem said.
As if to confirm her observation, the American Bar Association's Commission on Women in the Profession released a report today asserting that despite the large number of women in law schools, "too many women still experience debilitating gender bias and discrimination in various forms."
At the same time, some of the participants at the conference acknowledge that they have often let their opponents define the debate by, for example, letting conservatives capture the family value issue.
"We get on the defensive and screw it up," said Ms. Smeal, who noted that she was "a Pittsburgh housewife with a baby on her lap" when she first became involved with the movement.
The feminist organizations, largely white middle- and upper-class in the movement's beginning in the 1960's, say they have made efforts to include women of other ethnic and economic groups. Still, the opening day's participants were overwhelmingly white, and if they were casually dressed, it was by choice, not economic necessity.
Vivian Lovell, a 28-year-old office manager of the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund, said she was disappointed that there was not more racial diversity at the gathering. The diversity issue had been brought up in planning sessions for the exposition, Ms. Lovell said, but no efforts were made to reach out to minority women's groups through sororities, churches, colleges and universities and by radio, which minorities use more frequently than newspapers to get their news.
"I give the feminists credit," Ms. Lovell said, "but they're keeping things in a little circle when they ought to broaden it to a big circle."
Prema Mathai-Davis, national executive director of the Y.W.C.A., said the feminist movement had suffered from stereotypes of what types of organizations were feminist.
"The Y.W.C.A. is the largest and oldest women's organization in the country," Ms. Mathai-Davis said. "That is why we're gearing up to collaborate in this fight for affirmative action. We're not against men. This fight helps men, women and children and families."
Though the movement has been less enthusiastically embraced by women in their 20's and 30's, the halls of the Sheraton Washington Hotel where the conference is being held, were swarming with young women, many of college- and high-school age. While many defined themselves as feminists, others were less comfortable with the label.
"Feminist is such a touchy word," said Susan Smith, a 17-year-old high school student from McLean, Va. "A lot of young women don't want to be called feminists because, hey, listen to Rush Limbaugh, and you've heard it all. It's equated with being lesbian, fat, ugly."
Nonetheless, Ms. Smith said she called herself a feminist if it meant "getting buck for buck what every guy makes doing the same job I'm doing, instead of 72 cents on the dollar."

HEADLINE: A Central Fiscal Argument Advanced by Forbes Proves Hard to Confirm

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 2

 BODY:
"Don't take my word for it, just look at the history books," Steve Forbes told the Rotary Club in Nashua this week. "Every time the tax burden is reduced, Government revenues go up, not down."
That is a line Mr. Forbes delivers almost verbatim day after day, speech after speech, as he campaigns for the Republican Presidential nomination. But like many other claims he makes for his flat-tax proposal -- the issue that propelled him out of the pack and into a close race with Senator Bob Dole here in New Hampshire and in Iowa -- the proposition that past tax cuts have caused an increase in Federal revenue is difficult to document. 
 The history books do show that in the years following tax cuts, the Government's tax receipts have almost always gone up. But they have also risen in the years following tax increases. In fact, except for the recession years of 1971 and 1983, Government tax collections have risen annually ever since the 1960 fiscal year.
The reason, almost all economists agree, is that the amount of taxes the Government collects depends much more on the state of the economy than on the tax rate, and normally the American economy grows each year.
So tax receipts did rise after tax rates were lowered in 1963, 1981 and 1986. And as Mr. Forbes point out, income tax revenue was $200 billion higher at the end of the 1980's than at the beginning even though the decade's two tax cuts lowered the top rate to 30 percent from 70 percent.
But Congress increased the top tax rate in 1990 and again in 1993 -- much to the dismay of Mr. Forbes -- and income tax collections in 1994 were $123 billion, or 22 percent, higher than in 1990.
"They can't have it both ways," said C. Eugene Steuerle, a top tax policy official in the Reagan Administration who is now an economist at the Urban Institute in Washington. "If every time you decrease rates it causes taxes to go up, then when rates are increased, taxes should go down. But that is not the case."
On Saturday, Mr. Forbes will hold two town meetings in New Hampshire devoted to the flat tax, a proposal that the other candidates have been forced to address because of his unexpected success with voters. Patrick J. Buchanan, Phil Gramm and Alan Keyes have produced their own versions of a flat tax, differing in varying degrees from Mr. Forbes's. Senator Dole and Lamar Alexander attack the Forbes proposal daily, arguing that it would worsen the budget deficit and raise the taxes of middle-income Americans.
Like almost all other industrialized countries, the United States has a progressive tax system, in which the tax rate increases as income rises. For individuals, the existing tax law has five tax brackets, ranging from 15 percent for most taxpayers to nearly 40 percent for the wealthiest. Most corporations pay a 35 percent tax on their profits.
For most individual taxpayers, tax return preparation is relatively simple. Almost three-quarters of them, for instance, take the standard deduction instead of itemizing their deductions. Their returns are usually no more than a page or two.
But for many others and for many businesses, the tax system can be maddeningly complicated and expensive to comply with. By some estimates, Americans spend more than $100 billion a year for lawyers, accountants and other costs related to preparing tax returns, money that could presumably be put to more productive use.
It would be impossible, Mr. Forbes says in his typical speech, to devise a system "more antifamily, antigrowth, ununderstandable, more corrupting than this monstrosity."
Mr. Forbes would set the rate for individuals and companies at 17 percent and abolish all deductions, including the one individuals are allowed for mortgage interest and the one businesses can take for the cost of their employees' health insurance. He would also end taxation altogether on interest and dividend income, capital gains, inheritances, pensions and Social Security benefits.
The first $13,000 of each individual's income, or $26,000 for a couple, would be exempt from taxes, and families could take a $5,000 exemption for each child. That means that a couple with two children would pay no taxes on income below $36,000. Today, a family of four with income of $36,000 can expect to owe about $3,000 in income taxes.
The Treasury Department has calculated that Mr. Forbes's plan would increase the budget deficit by almost $200 billion a year. To raise the same amount of revenue as the existing system, the Treasury maintains, a flat tax would have to be set at about 20 percent. Mr. Forbes dismisses these calculations as "bogus numbers."
In addition to his contention that his proposal would increase revenue, Mr. Forbes says it would cause savings and investment to grow, leading to an economic boom. Interest rates would fall to such an extent, he says, that homeowners would not miss their mortgage interest deductions. He points to states with low, flat taxes, which, he says, do better than states with high, progressive taxes.
Each of those arguments is subject to challenge.
As for savings and investment, there is little historic data showing that when taxes are low, people save and invest more. Indeed, the lowering of tax rates in the 1980's did not result in more savings. And even if another $50 billion to $100 billion was saved and invested, most economists doubt that it would improve economic growth by more than a small fraction of a percent each year.
On the matter of interest rates, many economists believe that lowering taxes would actually cause rates to rise. The reason, says Benjamin M. Friedman, an economist at Harvard, is that tax cuts tend to stimulate the economy. That could lead either to inflation, which would be followed by higher rates, or to a rate rise by the Federal Reserve in an effort to head off inflation.
And Prof. Michael Wasylenko, an economist at Syracuse University who has written widely about the issue of state taxes and job creation, says he has seen little evidence that state income taxes have anything to do with economic growth.
For instance, Pennsylvania, with a 2.3 percent flat tax on all income, has had a poor economy for decades. And in Minnesota, which has one of the nation's highest and most progressive state income taxes, the economy is as strong as it is almost anywhere else in the country.

HEADLINE: Clinton Order Discouraging Striker Replacement Is Voided

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
In a blow to the nation's labor unions, a Federal appeals court today voided a Presidential order intended to penalize companies that in effect discharge workers who strike.
The decision, issued by a unanimous three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, held that in issuing the order last March, President Clinton violated labor law that the courts have interpreted as permitting employers to replace strikers with permanent nonunion recruits. 
 The President's next step is an appeal to either the entire appeals court or the Supreme Court. In a statement issued while he was campaigning today in New Hampshire, Mr. Clinton said, "I strongly believe that this executive order is economically sound, fair and legal, and accordingly I am instructing my Justice Department to take all appropriate steps to have this decision overturned."
The Presidential order applied to all businesses holding Federal contracts of more than $100,000 -- that is, virtually every large Government contractor, from motel chains to aircraft builders. The order instructed the Labor Department to cancel contracts with companies that permanently replaced striking workers and to bar such companies from future contracts.
Six plaintiffs, led by the United States Chamber of Commerce, sued to have the order voided. But they were rebuffed by a lower court, which held that the President had authority to establish Government procurement policy and that the judiciary therefore had no standing to review Mr. Clinton's directive.
That finding was overturned today by the appeals court's decision, which was issued by Judges Laurence H. Silberman, nominated to the bench by President Ronald Reagan; David B. Sentelle, another Reagan nominee, and A. Raymond Randolph, a nominee of President George Bush.
The appeals panel held that the President's right to set procurement policy did not permit what the judges found to be an effect of Mr. Clinton's order: an undermining of the National Labor Relations Act of 1935, under which, the courts have held, employers may permanently replace strikers.
John J. Sweeney, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, which represents 13 million unionized workers, called the decision "simply wrong."
"This ruling," Mr. Sweeney said in a statement, "serves those employers who want to wage war on workers and hurts the rest of us -- working families, communities, fair employers, our nation."
The plaintiffs were elated. Stephen Bokat, general counsel for the United States Chamber of Commerce, called the decision "a total vindication of our position and a total repudiation of the President's position."
The right to replace striking workers, Mr. Bokat said, "is a key economic weapon in dealing with unions and dealing with strikes."
But Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said there was an important broader issue involved in opposing permanent replacement.
"The President," Mr. Reich said, "has the authority to make sure that taxpayers get the quality of goods and services that they deserve in a timely way from reliable Federal contractors. Strikes involving permanent replacement workers are potentially longer, more bitter and compromise the quality of goods produced. We don't want American service men and women in Bosnia driving around in tires made by replacement workers."
The threat of permanent replacement, a tactic that employers rarely used until the early 1980's, has terrified unions and blunted their ability to use strikes as their principal weapon in labor-management disputes. Strikes involving 1,000 or more workers averaged 352 a year in the 1950's, but the average has plunged to 39 in the 1990's.
Organized labor sees the erosion of its power to strike as a leading cause of a two-decade-long decline in inflation-adjusted wages and an accompanying decline in union membership and union influence in Congress and political campaigns.
Late in 1993, labor almost won legislation prohibiting the use of permanent replacements. But after the bill had been passed by the House of Representatives, it died on the Senate floor in the face of a certain filibuster.
Then, last year, Mr. Clinton issued his executive order. The directive followed a period in which the President had infuriated labor with his support for the North American Free Trade Agreement, and, amid a political climate that unions saw as increasingly threatening, it stood out as a rare Government response to their complaints.
Now, the court decision overturning the order could accelerate a trend among unions in bypassing Congress, the courts and the National Labor Relations Board to press their interests. Many are now resorting to what they call corporate campaigns, putting pressure on employers by demonstrating at their centers around the country and discouraging their suppliers from doing business with them.
And with the election of the militant Mr. Sweeney as A.F.L.-C.I.O. president late last year, labor is also threatening campaigns of civil disobedience. "Progress has mainly been where unions have exercised rights outside normal regulatory procedures," said Jon Hiatt, the labor federation's general counsel. "Decisions like this convince unions to give up on the N.L.R.B. and the courts, and take to the streets."
Mr. Clinton's order never led to the cancellation of a Government contract with any employers, although it is hard to say how many of them refrained from using permanent replacements for fear of losing such contracts.
The Chamber of Commerce was joined in the challenge to the order by two manufacturers, Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. and Mosler Inc.; the American Trucking Associations; the National Association of Manufacturers, and the Labor Policy Association, an employer advocate.

HEADLINE: How Fed Made Decision To Cut Rates in December

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers listed the possibility of an economic slowdown and low inflation as reasons for their decision in December to reduce a key interest rate, minutes of their meeting showed today.
Members of the the Fed's policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, agreed 11 to 0 to reduce the Federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks to a target of 5.5 percent from 5.75 percent at the Dec. 19 meeting. 
 On Wednesday, the Fed policy makers cut the Federal funds another quarter-point, to 5.25 percent. Minutes of that session will not be available for several more weeks.
The full Fed board also voted 5 to 0 this week to lower the more symbolic discount rate on Fed loans to member banks a quarter-point, to 5 percent.
The F.O.M.C. meets eight times a year at intervals of five to eight weeks. Deliberations are secret, although the minutes later outline the reasoning behind the Fed officials' decisions.
The minutes from Dec. 19 released today showed the Fed policy makers concluded that "inflation and inflationary expectations moderated" and that "the downside risks to the expansion appeared to have increased," although there were no outright signs at the time of an economic slowdown.
Some members of the panel would have settled for leaving interest rates unchanged because they saw "little hard evidence" to suggest the inflation rate would slow further, the minutes said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Apple Computer Dismissess Spindler; Names Amelio
Apple Computer dismissed Michael H. Spindler as president and chief executive and replaced him with Gilbert F. Amelio, a board member, who will become chairman and chief executive of the struggling company.
Armas C. ("Mike") Markkula Jr., the company's chairman and a founder, is stepping down to be vice chairman. [Page A1.]
 
Mr. Amelio, who resigned Thursday as president and chief executive of the National Semiconductor Corporation, has a reputation for rebuilding struggling companies. [38.]
 
Apple's investors have been trading in the dark for weeks, despite standards calling for prompt public disclosure. [38.]
 
Long Treasury Bonds Tumble
In the bond market, prices fell for longer maturities as traders reacted to the uncertainty created by the Goverment's report that jobslessness had risen in January to 5.8 percent, but mainly because of the Northeastern blizzard. Traders feared the report masked a stronger economy with inflationary pressures gathering strength. The 30-year bond dropped 110/32 , to 10922/32 for a yield of 6.16 percent. [49.]
 
Blue chip stocks fell, following bonds down. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 31.07 points, to 5,373.99, marking its first falloff in six sessions, but the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index advanced 2.65 points, to a high of 1,072.11. Telecommunications shares fell in response to Thursday's passage of deregulation. [39.]
 
Business Yielding to Greens
Leading business groups, yielding to opposition from environmentalists, are beginning to advise Senator Bob Dole and other Republican leaders in Congress to scale back ambitious proposals to restrict Federal regulatory powers. Some business leaders say they might even settle for merely writing into law an order President Clinton issued in 1993 telling regulatory agencies, including the Environmental Protection Agency, to pay more attention to the costs their regulations impose on business. [1.]
 
Grace Rebuffs Bid by Baxter
W. R. Grace & Company brushed aside a $3.8 billion bid by Baxter International for National Medical Care, Grace's big chain of kidney dialysis centers, hinting that it was considering more lucrative offers. Investors, hoping for a bidding war, drove Grace shares up $7.375, to $69.25. Baxter shares dropped $2.50, to $42.50. [37.]
 
Merry-Go-Round to Liquidate
Merry-Go-Round Enterprises, a retailer that clothed America's teen-agers for more than two decades, said it would liquidate its 536 stores and cease operations. The chain filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code two years ago, but it was never able to reorganize profitably. [37.]
 
A Worrisome S.E.C. Stance
The fine print of the Securities and Exchange Commission's settlement last week of securities fraud charges against Orange County, Calif., is distressing two very different groups. Public officials across the country are anxious that the S.E.C. intends to scrutinize more closely their handling of municipal bond issues, and eight leading Wall Street firms, particularly Merrill Lynch, are worried about a continuing S.E.C. investigation. [D38.]
 
S.E.C. Intensifies Milken Inquiry
The Securities and Exchange Commission has taken took its investigation of Michael R. Milken, the former junk-bond king, to a new level, granting itself full subpoena powers to look into his recent business dealings, say people familiar with the inquiry. But Mr. Milken's lawyer said, "There's nothing new." The S.E.C. is trying to determine whether he has breached an order barring him from the securities industry. [37.]
 
Herbert Haft Awarded Damages
A Washington jury awarded Herbert H. Haft $10.2 million in damages in a dispute with his son Ronald Haft and Donald Bourassa over the management of Combined Properties Inc., a privately held real estate concern. [36.]
 
Fed Saw Possible Slowdown
Federal Reserve policy makers listed the possibility of an economic slowdown and low inflation as reasons for their December decision to cut the Federal funds rate. [36.]
 
Dollar Falls Against Mark
The dollar fell against most major currencies, despite evidence of slowing economies in both Europe and Japan. It traded at 1.4823 marks, compared with 1.4875 on Thursday. [45.]

HEADLINE: Businesses Scaling Back Plans To Defang Federal Regulations

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Leading business groups are beginning to advise allies in Congress to scale back their ambitious proposals if they hope to pass stalled legislation restricting Federal regulatory powers.
Legislation was passed by the House last year as part of the Contract With America, but it died in the Senate when Democrats condemned it as an effort to roll back a generation of environmental progress. Senator Bob Dole, the bill's principal advocate in the Senate, and other Republican leaders have promised to try to revive it. 
 Many backers of restrictions on regulatory agencies concede that the only bill that seems likely to be passed would be a far cry from the radical regulatory overhaul that the Republicans once proposed, with intense support from business groups.
Throughout last year, that coalition, with the support of a few Democrats, pushed a bill that would have changed how all environmental statutes are implemented without amending any of them. The measure would have required elaborate cost-benefit studies of major rules and opened significant new opportunities for industry to challenge regulations in court.
But now, some business leaders say they might even settle for merely writing into law an order President Clinton issued in 1993 telling regulatory agencies, including the Environmental Protection Agency, to pay more attention to how much their regulations cost businesses.
The tactical retreat comes as Democratic opposition to changes in environmental laws is intensifying, the White House is claiming environmental protection as a central election issue, and one poll after another suggests that the public thinks that the Republicans tried to take regulatory changes too far.
"We have certainly trimmed our sails," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers and the main spokesman for the corporate coalition lobbying for regulatory changes. Mr. Jasinowski said the group was urging "more modest changes that could garner bipartisan support."
Industry leaders say their efforts last year were intended to remove unnecessary and burdensome regulation. But they add with dismay that the debate over regulation has left them painted as polluters intent on undoing environmental protections. Like the Republican Congressional leaders, some industry leaders have recently been anguishing over how to recast their environmental messages.
Until new proposals are made public, it is impossible to judge whether industry genuinely wants a compromise or is making a public-relations foray meant to improve its image and its chances of success. Congress is in recess, so no legislative action is expected right away.
An approach that is being widely discussed would be to adopt the terms of an executive order on regulatory practices that was issued in 1993 by Mr. Clinton. The order instructed agencies to balance costs and benefits when writing rules to carry out laws like the Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act, but it did not provide industry with any grounds for legal challenges.
"That executive order was pretty good," said Fred Webber, the head of the Chemical Manufacturers Association, in a news conference this week.
That kind of talk is an abrupt change from last year, when industry groups fought hard against softer alternatives, like a bipartisan bill offered by Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, and Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island.
Now corporate lobbyists are asking themselves how much they can realistically expect to achieve in an election year.
A meeting on Dec. 12 at the American Petroleum Institute, for example, led off with a review of what happened last year, according to notes taken by one participant.
"Industry lost the battle and regulatory reform has become a political football," said the minutes, taken by an American Petroleum Institute consultant, Arnold Moore.
"It may not be addressed again until 1997, if ever," his notes said. "Some attendees concluded that there must be a change in how we think and talk about regulatory reform and the environment."
Mr. Moore's notes fell into the hands of an environmental group, the Natural Resources Defense Council, which provided them to The New York Times. Greg Wetstone, the environmental group's legislative director, described the notes as proof that the industry was discussing "not how to make their proposals less destructive, but how to mislead the American public with better packaging."
The meeting was attended by Charles DiBona, the head of the oil industry trade association; five of its staff members, and supporters from groups like Resources for the Future, a resource organization; the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a pro-business group, and the Center for Risk Analysis at Harvard University, an academic program financed by industry.
Mr. Moore's notes do not disclose who said what, but they describe soul-searching over big business's failure to push through a bill that was among its highest priorities.
"There was a perception that the special interests wrote the bill," the notes said, "and the public was very unhappy about that.
"While industry may not have been seeking a general rollback of environmental regulation, some Republican Congressmen were, and some want to abolish E.P.A."
The notes went on, "It would be great progress if the Administration should offer the 1993 executive order as regulatory reform legislation."
But Administration officials said it all depended on how the legislation was written. The Administration wants to retain the flexibility it is allowed under current law and avoid opening Federal regulations to endless litigation.
That is exactly what some environmentalists say will happen if the executive order becomes law, said Gary Bass, the executive director of O.M.B. Watch, an advocacy group that monitors regulatory affairs.
On the other hand, some advocates of rolling back regulations say they oppose watering down the original Republican bills.
"Something that is not enforceable in the courts and does not impose real accountability on agencies does not accomplish much," said Jonathan Adler, a spokesman for the Competitive Enterprise Institute. "Clinton's executive order is a perfect example."
But Mr. Adler acknowledged that "most industry folks want a bill."
"I get the impression," he added, "that there are a lot of lobbyists in this town who want to say, 'We got a bill -- I earned my keep.' "

HEADLINE: About New York;
Still All Girls, Still Teaching Self-Reliance

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE fetal shark lay split open on the dissecting tray, like a clay toy steeped in formaldehyde. A nearby index card read: "What Sex Am I?"
Liz Kay glanced at it briefly. 
 "I think it's male," she said.
No question, the girls at this school know a lot about sex roles, science labs and plenty of other subjects. And there's no doubt who's in charge.
Miss Kay and her friends attend the Academy of Mount Saint Ursula in the Bronx, which was founded in 1855 and is the state's oldest all-girls Roman Catholic high school. Although it predates the women's suffrage, civil rights and feminist movements, its students think it's hardly anachronistic. They feel that the company of women gives them a sense of confidence that would be lost in a co-ed school where boys vie for the teacher's attention (and the girls' affections).
"I don't have to worry about all the guys taking over," said Christine Balubayan, a senior who helped Miss Kay lead a tour for prospective students on Tuesday. "Girls have all the power to speak here. In co-ed schools, some of the teachers would only pick on the guys. The guys take over and the girls feel intimidated."
Indeed, a 1992 report by the American Association of University Women warned that girls were being "shortchanged" in co-ed schools where teachers paid less attention to them. And while girls start out school on the same footing as boys, they often lag behind them by the end of high school, especially in math and science.
It's an age-old problem. There's an equally old solution, at least if you know about St. Angela Merici, who started the Ursuline order in 1535 when she gathered a group of women to educate them in the faith.
"The value of the education of women has been a strong one, even going back to the 16th century," said Sister Mary Beth Read, the school's principal. "Women originally were not taught to read because nobody thought it was worth it. But St. Angela talked about women's dignity and work."
AT her school, a young woman's place is anywhere she wants to be.
"The studies confirm what we seem to know from instinct," Sister Mary Beth said. "We have a certain gift to give young women that they may not be getting elsewhere. We help them develop leadership ability."
You'd think it would be tough to pitch an all-girls school in an age when even some football teams are co-ed. "It's not hard to sell it to their parents," Miss Balubayan said. "My father jumped for joy when he found out I wanted to go here."
Parents nodded in approval as Miss Kay and Miss Balubayan led them through the school's winding halls, past labs, chapels and classrooms. The Bronx eighth graders listened intently as the seniors talked about traditions, like the annual roller-skate journey to the campus Ring Day ceremony.
Even at their young age, the prospective students spoke clearly of what they could expect in a co-ed high school: more of what they experienced in grammar school.
"If you answer a question wrong, the boys go 'Duh!' " said Jessica Matthew, of the Holy Family parish school. "It's annoying."
It's not the only adolescent ritual to irk them.
"You have less distractions without the boys," said Tara Lozada, who graduates this year from Blessed Sacrament grammar school. "Most of the boys look at the girls and the girls worry about how they look."
No wonder the blue blazer and plaid skirt uniforms appealed to her.
"You don't have to worry about picking out your clothes," she said. "And they're cute uniforms."
THE nuns don't wear their uniforms anymore. Their black and white wimples have long since given way to demure business suits. But they insist on clinging to their all-girl tradition, despite the economic arguments that they could better cover the school's operating costs if they admitted boys. They see a greater cost not found on any balance sheet.
"I can remember 15 or 20 years ago people were saying that schools should go co-ed and many women's colleges did that," Sister Mary Beth said. "There is a danger with us: are the students ready for co-ed colleges and careers where the world is mixed? But our graduates say they have more self-confidence and are not shy about speaking up or asking questions."
The only question left for Miss Kay was where to go to college. She's already applied to "half the Ivy League" and a few other schools. Although some have been around longer, few can match her high school.
"Just the history alone of this school shows that it's not just you," she said. "We have 140 classes of alumni. One hundred and forty classes of people who survived and have gone forward as young women."

HEADLINE: Gene Kelly, Dancer of Vigor and Grace, Dies

BYLINE: By ALBIN KREBS 

 BODY:
Gene Kelly, the dancer, actor, director and choreographer who brought a vigorous athleticism, casual grace and an earthy masculinity to the high romance of lavish Hollywood musicals, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83.
His longtime publicity agent, Warren Cowan, said Mr. Kelly had never fully recovered from strokes he suffered in 1994 and last year. 
 Mr. Kelly's highly developed sense of the possibilities of dance on film invigorated classic musicals like "Anchors Aweigh," "On the Town," "An American in Paris" and "Singin' in the Rain."
A gifted dancer with his own vibrant style, he also flourished as an innovative choreographer and director in the 1940's and 50's, the heyday of the big, splashy Hollywood musical.
Mr. Kelly, who could also put over a song in a high, thin voice, brought to his films an inventive technique that enabled him to create unusual and imaginative dance routines that usually arose directly out of a plot or script situation.
Thus millions of moviegoers remember Mr. Kelly dancing merrily in a downpour in "Singin' in the Rain," hoofing with an animated mouse, Jerry, in "Anchors Aweigh," hopping over garbage cans in a sequence in "It's Always Fair Weather" and, with the aid of special process photography, dancing with himself in the "alter ego" number from "Cover Girl."
In addition to his movies, which included "The Pirate," "Brigadoon" and the drama "Inherit the Wind," Mr. Kelly was also a star on Broadway, where he created the title role of the heel as hero in "Pal Joey," choreographed "Best Foot Forward" and directed Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Flower Drum Song."
"I don't really know why I clicked," Mr. Kelly said many years later. "I didn't want to be a dancer. I just did it to work my way through college. But I was always an athlete and gymnast, so it came naturally.
"In the 1930's, when I started, Martha Graham was the only dancer doing anything modern, but she did it all to classical music. I couldn't see myself doing 'Swan Lake' every night, and I wanted to develop a truly American style. The only dancer in the movies at that time with any success was Fred Astaire, but he did very small, elegant steps in a top hat, white tie and tails. I was too big physically for that kind of dancing, and I looked better in a sweatshirt and loafers anyway. It wasn't elegant, but it was me."
Eugene Curran Kelly was born on Aug. 23, 1912, in Pittsburgh. His mother insisted that all five of the Kelly children take music and dance lessons, and in high school Mr. Kelly continued dance lessons while also playing on the football and hockey teams. His education at Pennsylvania State College was interrupted by the Depression, and his first job was teaching gymnastics at a summer camp for boys.
He was later able to major in economics at the University of Pittsburgh and received a degree in 1933, but jobs were scarce and he went to work for a dancing school partly owned by his mother. Two years later, the school was renamed the Gene Kelly Studio of the Dance and soon a successful branch was opened in Johnstown.
Meanwhile, Mr. Kelly directed plays produced locally and formed a dance act with his brother Fred, with whom he performed in a theater for children at the Chicago World's Fair in 1934. In the mid-1930's Mr. Kelly also redirected vaudeville acts that passed through Pittsburgh.
Mr. Kelly did not decide to try his luck in New York until 1938, when he was 27 years old. His first job was as a Broadway chorus boy in 1938's "Leave It to Me," dancing while Mary Martin sang "My Heart Belongs to Daddy," but the next year he won critical acclaim for his featured role as the comic hoofer in William Saroyan's play "The Time of Your Life."
That success led to his being cast in "Pal Joey," the 1940 Rodgers and Hart musical, in which he played the unscrupulous central character so convincingly that John Martin, a critic for The New York Times, said, "He is not only glib-footed, but he has a feeling for comment and content that give his dancing personal distinction and raise it several notches as a dancing art."
Mr. Kelly's ability to meld singing and dancing with characterization and the demands of the play's plot attracted so much notice that David O. Selznick signed him to an exclusive Hollywood contract. At the time, Mr. Kelly was appearing in "Pal Joey" at night and by day choreographing the Broadway musical hit "Best Foot Forward."
In 1941, he left for Hollywood, where he was to bring a new vitality to dance on film and help change the whole concept of movie musicals.
Mr. Selznick had no musicals planned, however, and lent Mr. Kelly to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the studio most noted for lavish musicals. His first film, in 1942, was "For Me and My Gal," in which he starred as a small-time vaudeville hoofer opposite Judy Garland.
It was a huge success, but MGM, after buying the new star's contract from Mr. Selznick, relegated him to relatively minor parts in "DuBarry Was a Lady," "Thousands Cheer," and the wartime drama "Cross of Lorraine."
In "Cover Girl," co-starring with Rita Hayworth in 1944 on loan to Columbia Pictures, Mr. Kelly's career took off. With the aid of Stanley Donen, with whom he was to direct and choreograph several movies in years to follow, Mr. Kelly developed the celebrated "alter ego" solo dance with his ectoplasmic self, the character's conscience. Photographed separately, then combined on a single strip of film, the two Kelly images seemed to pursue each other up and down flights of steps, to threaten each other and leap over each other's heads.
"For once, a dance on the screen is not merely a specialty but actually develops character and advances plot," wrote a New York Times critic. The alter ego sequence and others in "Cover Girl" significantly advanced the use of movie song-and-dance numbers that evolve naturally from the plot and the action on screen.
Mr. Kelly said later: "In my first picture, I made a startling discovery. Things danced on the screen do not look the way they do on the stage. On the stage, dancing is three-dimensional, but a motion picture is two-dimensional. Also, I felt the dancer in films had never had the opportunity to probe emotional and acting problems adequately. So I tried to do things uniquely cinematic, that you couldn't do on a stage. Call it 'cine-dancing,' or whatever, but I tried to invent the dance to fit the camera and its movements."
Mr. Kelly's choreographic inventiveness was credited with the success of the trail-blazing live-dance-with-animation sequence in "Anchors Aweigh" in 1945. He had a hard time persuading MGM officials that they should spend $100,000 and two months shooting an eight-minute number, in which he would dance with Jerry the mouse from the "Tom and Jerry" cartoon series.
Simple live action and animation went back to silent-film days, but Mr. Kelly's idea involved color and intricate dance steps for himself and the cartoon characters, and required complex laboratory and processing work.
For the charming sequence, Mr. Kelly first danced against a plain blue background, then animators filmed the mouse song-and-dance portion. What audiences saw was a composite picture made from the two separate films, with man and mouse happily dancing and singing. The procedure is common now, even in television commercials, but in the mid-1940's it was hailed as a cinematic breakthrough.
Before joining the Navy in 1944, Mr. Kelly appeared with his friend Fred Astaire for the first time in a single number, Gershwin's "Babbitt and the Bromide" in MGM's opulent, star-studded "Ziegfeld Follies."
"It wasn't a battle of dancers, but our different styles were purposely made apparent," Mr. Kelly said. "My style is strong, wide open; Fred's is intimate, cool, easy. He can give an audience pleasure just by walking across a dance floor."
After the war, Mr. Kelly's first big picture was "The Pirate," a 1948 spoof of swashbuckling adventures in which he again starred with Judy Garland, with whom he sang the rousing "Be a Clown." James Agee, the critic, found Mr. Kelly's performance "very ambitious, painfully misguided, by John Barrymore out of the elder Douglas Fairbanks." In "The Three Musketeers" (1948), Mr. Kelly did not dance, but as D'Artagnan he used his balletic skills to burlesque some fencing scenes.
One of Mr. Kelly's most memorable dance performances came in the seven-minute "Slaughter on 10th Avenue" ballet sequence in "Words and Music," a 1948 movie that was only subliminally based on the lives of Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart. Most critics agreed that about the only thing to cheer about the film was the Rodgers ballet, in which Mr. Kelly was partnered with Vera-Ellen.
In 1949, Mr. Kelly made two films with Frank Sinatra, "Take Me Out to the Ball Game" and one of his all-time hits, "On the Town," which he directed and choreographed with Mr. Donen and filmed mostly on location in New York City. Mr. Kelly, whose co-stars included Betty Garrett, Ann Miller and Vera-Ellen, turned the film into an exhilarating, joyful experience that began with the brassy "New York, New York (It's a Helluva Town)" opening number and never let up in its mood of pervasive effervescence.
"This film was a milestone," he said in 1977. "It was the first musical to be shot on location. We took the musical off the sound stage and showed that it could be realistic. The idea of doing such a thing was anathema to the studio moguls. We shot a lot of it in New York and showed sailors getting off their ship in the Brooklyn Navy Yard and singing and dancing through the streets of New York. You can't imagine how crazy everybody thought this was at the time, but it changed the face of musicals. The picture has dated a bit, but it's the closest to my heart."
But some of Mr. Kelly's most popular and artistically successful films were yet to come. In 1951, "An American in Paris," in which he received sole star billing, won eight Academy Awards, including best picture of the year, and a special Oscar for Mr. Kelly for his contributions to screen choreography.
An integral part of the film was a 17-minute ballet conceived by Mr. Kelly and the director, Vincente Minnelli, as a means of showing the impact Paris has on the hero. Costumes, sets and dance movements for the ballet were borrowed from the styles of such artists as Dufy, Renoir, Utrillo, Rousseau, van Gogh and Toulouse-Lautrec and the music danced to by Mr. Kelly and Leslie Caron was George Gershwin's "American in Paris" suite.
"Singin' in the Rain," released in 1952, was one of the last of the big MGM musicals and it was, said Vincent Canby, film critic of The New York Times, in a 1975 appraisal, "a movie masterpiece." Again teaming with Mr. Donen, Mr. Kelly helped to direct and choreograph the affectionate spoof of the start of the talkies era in movies. The movie made splendid use of such Arthur Freed-Nacio Herb Brown songs as "You Were Meant for Me," "You Are My Lucky Star" and "All I Do Is Dream of You."
In the title number, a love-struck Mr. Kelly, with an umbrella as his principal prop, sang and splashed ecstatically and obliviously through a downpour on an all-but-deserted street. The sequence is widely regarded as a classic piece of cinematic choreography.
Since it was a period piece in the first place, taking place in the Hollywood of the 1920's, when sound was revolutionizing the movie business, "Singin' in the Rain" even today does not seem dated, possibly because, as Mr. Kelly put it, "when you work in a period that was, you have some distance and a better chance to make a picture last."
Debbie Reynolds, who was 18 at the time and had her first major role in "Singin' in the Rain," had never sung or danced before, but she said years later: "I learned a lot from Gene. He is a perfectionist and a disciplinarian: the most exacting director I've worked for. And he has a good temper. Every so often he would yell at me and make me cry. But it took a lot of patience for him to work with someone who had never danced before."
In 1989, "Singin' in the Rain" was among the first 25 films chosen by the Library of Congress for its National Film Registry of significant motion pictures.
Mr. Kelly's last major musicals at MGM were "Brigadoon" (1954), a disappointment, and "It's Always Fair Weather (1955) and "Les Girls" (1957), which were both hits. In the 1950's, he also appeared in "Deep in My Heart," "Marjorie Morningstar" and "The Devil Makes Three," and he produced and directed "The Happy Road," "Tunnel of Love" and other movies.
Generally regarded as an artistic as well as a commercial failure was Mr. Kelly's ambitious project "Invitation to the Dance," a three-part, plotless dance film without dialogue released in 1956. Mr. Kelly starred in the film and directed and choreographed it. "The public wasn't ready for a serious dance film, and besides, by the time it came out, the popularity of film musicals had declined," Mr. Kelly said.
He nevertheless said he believed the public could be taught to appreciate dance, and late in 1958 conceived, wrote, narrated and danced in an NBC-TV special called "Dancing Is a Man's Game," in which he used athletes to demonstrate the sheer physicality and manliness of dance, often viewed by Americans as an effete art. That same year, Mr. Kelly returned to Broadway to direct the hit Rodgers and Hammerstein musical "Flower Drum Song,"
In 1960, Mr. Kelly was invited to write and choreograph for the Paris Opera ballet troupe a zesty modern jazz ballet, which he set to Gershwin's "Concerto in F." He gave the ballet the punning title "Pas de Dieux," and he received 23 curtain calls after its premiere. A pas de deux he created for the San Francisco Ballet in 1982 was not as enthusiastically greeted.
Over the years there were many appearances on television specials by Mr. Kelly, and he also had a weekly series on ABC-TV in 1963 called "Going My Way," in which he was seen as a priest. Mr. Kelly also continued to direct an occasional movie, including "Hello, Dolly!" in 1969 and "The Cheyenne Social Club" in 1970. His last performance on screen was dancing on roller skates in the 1980 movie "Xanadu," with Olivia Newton-John, a reprise of a number he did with his brother, Fred, years earlier. He also reminisced in the 1994 anthology film "That's Entertainment! III."
In 1994, Mr. Kelly was a recipient of the National Medal of Arts, awarded by President Clinton in a ceremony at the White House.
Mr. Kelly's first wife was the actress Betsy Blair, from whom he was divorced in 1957. They had a daughter, Kerry. In 1960, Mr. Kelly married Jeanne Coyne, who had been one of his dance students in Pittsburgh and had worked as his assistant choreographer since 1949. They had two children, Timothy and Bridget. Mrs. Kelly died in 1973. In 1990, he married Patricia Ward.
 
The Hits in Film And Onstage
Gene Kelly first won stardom on Broadway, in the musical "Pal Joey." In Hollywood, he sang, danced, acted, choreographed and directed. Here are some highlights of his career.
