HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
When Theater Turns Out to Be Just a Stage

BYLINE: By ANDY MEISLER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
BY MOST MEASURES, Sheldon Epps has had a sterling career in the American theater and has a very bright future within it.
At 42, he is the visiting associate artistic director of the prestigious Old Globe Theater in San Diego. A member of the executive board of the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, Mr. Epps has directed plays and musicals at many of the country's major theaters, including the Tyrone Guthrie Theater, the Manhattan Theater Club, Playwrights Horizons, the Goodspeed Opera House and the Pasadena Playhouse. 
In 1983, his Broadway production of "Blues in the Night," starring Leslie Uggams, was nominated for a Tony Award as best musical. In 1991, his all-black "Death of a Salesman" at the Guthrie in Minneapolis received highly favorable reviews. "Bring In the Morning," a musical he directed at Manhattan's Variety Arts Theater in 1994, also got good notices. And last year, his Old Globe production of Ibsen's "Hedda Gabler," starring CCH Pounder, had a successful six-week run.
This year, in a major career move, he would like to direct a 22-minute episode of "Sister, Sister," a perky television sitcom concerning the high jinks of twin teen-agers that runs on the fledgling WB Network on Sunday evenings. He recently received a tentative commitment from the show's producers, and this summer, if all goes well, Mr. Epps will, after months of patience and unpaid on-set observation, add this accomplishment to his resume.
If all goes very well, his direction of that one episode, for which he will receive around $10,000, plus residuals, will lead to more five-day directing stints on "Sister, Sister" and on other half-hour comedies. Or perhaps, though the competition is fierce, he will land a coveted contract to direct several, half or even all of the episodes of a long-running comedy series.
That would almost certainly mean a significant change in life style for Mr. Epps: he would earn a salary in the middle six figures, move to Los Angeles and leave the Old Globe and possibly the theater world altogether. It would be a bittersweet step, but it is one he is prepared to make. Two important factors: Mr. Epps's current position at the nonprofit Old Globe is underwritten by a grant from the Pew Charitable Trusts. And Mr. Epps's boss, Jack O'Brien, the Old Globe artistic director, recently directed his first sitcom, an episode of ABC's "Grace Under Fire."
"Everyone in the theater knows that it's tough to make an adult living," said Mr. Epps recently. "You can't live in one place, have a home, make a salary. All of us who've done this for a while are tired of moving around the country, rebuilding their lives every six or seven weeks."
"As a freelance director," he continued, "you have to direct so much, and direct almost everything that comes along. You work so hard, and so often, that you begin to dislike the work. A lot of people now hope that if they get a series, they can pick and choose what they do. Most of the people that I grew up with in the theater are working consistently in television."
Indeed, Mr. Epps's experience is just a small part of a significant but virtually unnoticed displacement of creativity. In the 1950's, when live television drama flourished in New York, a playwright like Paddy Chayevsky could move naturally between mediums, but after that decade, there was no prominent nexus between the theater world and television for many years. In the last decade, the constriction of commercial theater and the cuts in public arts financing changed that: a bridge -- or perhaps an escape ladder -- was built, and it is being used more and more.
FOR THE LAST 10 YEARS, there has been a steady flow of directors, producers and playwrights out of the theater and into television, and not primarily into high-toned PBS series like "American Playhouse" but into mainstream commercial television. And almost all of these people -- unlike actors, for whom the back-and-forth between stage, film and television is easier, and virtually required -- are people who grew up dreaming that they would spend their lives in the theater.
"During the second year of 'Murphy Brown,' I went back to New York to do a show at the Manhattan Theater Club," said Barnet Kellman, an accomplished television comedy director with deep roots in the theater. That was in 1989. "It was amazing to me how many of my friends in the theater world came up to me and said: 'How can I get out of the theater? How can I break into television? Help me, help me.' "
What effect these defections have had on television, which by many accounts has improved in the last 10 years, is difficult to characterize, Mr. Kellman added. But the effect they have had on the struggling world of American theater is clearer. "It can only be described as an absolute brain drain going on in the theater," said Mr. Kellman. "I mean, they used to talk in the old days about actors being grabbed by Hollywood. But look around. How many directors over 40 have you got in the New York theater? You can count them on one hand."
There are certainly talented people who could make the switch but don't, for creative reasons. The playwright Nicky Silver ("The Food Chain") explains such a choice this way: "For the theater, I write something that fascinates me and I shop it around. In television, you're told what to write and then you hope it becomes fascinating." But what is also certain is that behind the scenes, prime time is swarming with theater emigrants.
Mr. Kellman was the first-season director of CBS's "Murphy Brown" and of NBC's "Mad About You." Before that, he directed the original New York productions of "Key Exchange," "Breakfast With Les and Bess" and "Danny and the Deep Blue Sea."
Matt Williams, the creator and producer of ABC's popular "Home Improvement," was a New York playwright who had several of his plays produced Off Broadway before he switched to television.
Since 1986, Craig Anderson, the founder of the Hudson Guild Theater in Manhattan, has been working in Los Angeles, producing network movies and mini-series, including August Wilson's "Piano Lesson" and the recent NBC potboiler "Dead by Sunset."
Still other examples are Theresa Rebeck, the Off Broadway playwright ("Spike Heels," "The Family of Mann"), who is now a staff writer with the rank of co-producer on ABC's "N.Y.P.D. Blue," and David Trainer, a producer and director of ABC's "Maybe This Time," who directed the original Broadway production of "Foxfire" and the Off Broadway production of A. R. Gurney's "Dining Room."
In addition to these people and many others like them, there are numerous costumers, scenic designers and other craft people from the theater who now work primarily in television.
"What I tell people who are interested in joining us is that you have to have a flexible spirit," said Janet Blake, a vice president for writer development and special projects for Walt Disney Television who spends much of her time combing colleges, regional theaters and theater festivals for talent. "You'll have to give up your disdain. And if you stick with it, you'll get a chance next week to do it again."
Over lunch recently in the Sony Studios commissary, near his office on the Culver City movie lot, Mr. Anderson said: "When I was in New York, I looked down my nose tremendously at people who had 'sold out' and gone to L.A. I always thought it was just that, selling out. I'd say: 'Well, there goes another good person. How dare they give the theater up for the commercial crassness of that town!' I thought that way about those people -- that is, until I myself became one. And in hindsight, I probably should have come out here five years earlier."
The 47-year-old Mr. Anderson smiled ruefully. As with most of the theater people who have succeeded in making the transition to television, his journey has been a complicated one. He spoke wistfully about the excitement and challenge of live theater. "The theater is very special," he said. "It's a great training ground."
A Los Angeles native who was a U.C.L.A. theater major, he moved east at 21 and worked at the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn., before starting the Hudson Guild inside a settlement house on West 26th Street in the mid-1970's. "I had a theater in New York," he continued. "And I had the right to fail. I had the right to put on plays and learn from them. We painted the sets, and we focused the lights, and we had a small operation. And the theater grew. It became very successful."
Although most former theater people defend their current work as significant and demanding, few have unalloyed praise for television, with its production-line methods and homogenized writing. Mr. Anderson is no exception. Unlike television, he explains, theater allows for the luxury of sufficient rehearsal time, of harnessing idiosyncratic voices and forms, of giving writers and directors control over their creations.
"And the kinds of plays that I was interested in in New York, the ones that I both produced and directed, were mostly plays about the human condition," said Mr. Anderson, who won a Tony Award as the producer of "Da." "They were plays about growth; they were plays about personal relationships. They could be comedies, but those were no exception. When I came out here, nobody really wanted to know from that. And they still don't, for the most part."
Other theater emigres offer a different sort of backward glance.
"I think the New York theater world -- and that includes the audience, too -- can be smug and elitist," said Ms. Rebeck. "Sometimes I worry that the American theater will evolve into something where the only plays that will be done are by Terrence McNally and Tony Kushner."
Mr. Trainer said: "I once directed 'Painting Churches' at the Long Wharf Theater. I remember going one night to see it. I stood in the back of the house and noticed that everybody in the audience had white hair. I thought: 'I'm spending my life entertaining a generation older than I am. Is that really what I should be doing?' "
But these observations, savvy as they may be, are secondary to the primary force pushing theater people into television: the soul-numbing economics of theater work in contrast with the relatively astronomical sums paid to talented people in the television industry. (An established staff writer for a television series can easily earn $5,000 a week, for instance.) Everyone has a story.
"It took me three years to get my first play produced in New York," said Mr. Williams of "Home Improvement." "My gross profits: $3,800."
Recalling the early 80's, Mr. Kellman said: "While 'Key Exchange,' which I had directed, was running at the Orpheum, I directed different productions with different casts in Dallas and Los Angeles. I'd already done the original production, at the W.P.A. Theater, for nothing. I think we got $200 for carfare. For doing all of that, I made less than $20,000. And that was my red-letter year in the New York theater."
IN THE LAST YEAR, MR. ANDERSON earned more doing television than he did in his 16 years doing stage work put together, he said. In the mid-1980's, he had a plan to earn a viable living in New York: form a syndicate to purchase Town Hall on 43d Street and turn it into two 500-seat live theaters. "We were ready to break ground," he said. "Then the Landmarks Commission stepped in. They turned Town Hall into a landmark, which meant we couldn't change the mildewed carpets or the broken seats without petitioning them."
The plan fell through, and shortly thereafter Mr. Anderson left in frustration for Los Angeles, where he drifted into producing television movies after several feature-movie projects fell through.
There are many routes from theater into television, some rockier than others. Matt Williams made the leap when one of his one-act plays fell into the hands of the television director Jay Sandrich. Mr. Sandrich, who was helping start "The Cosby Show" for NBC, commissioned an episode from Mr. Williams, despite the playwright's protest that he "couldn't write jokes."
Mr. Kellman, who had been "supporting his theater habit," as he puts it, by directing daytime soap operas in New York, was enticed to Los Angeles by James Burrows, the director and producer of "Cheers," to direct the first three episodes of "All Is Forgiven," a short-lived 1986 sitcom. Then came "Murphy Brown" in 1988.
Are the real classics now not theatrical works but popular television shows like "Murphy Brown" and "N.Y.P.D. Blue," shows seen so often by so many people that despite network homogenizing they do have real impact on American society? This is a lively topic of discussion on both sides of the theater-television fence.
"I guess I sound a little self-serving," said one playwright-turned-television-writer, "but my old theater friends who like to turn up their noses at television are martyring themselves for a medium that's almost totally irrelevant."
Still, among many former theater people, there is common longing for the freedom and immediacy of live theater. "I'd rather be making a living in the theater if I could," said a prominent television scriptwriter, after recounting several hair-raising tales of being rejected or totally rewritten. "It would be my own work. I wouldn't have to answer to anyone else."
Some try to take their television bounty and recarve a space in the theater for themselves. Craig Anderson is holding readings for Bill C. Davis's play "Avow," which he would like to produce on the East Coast.
Others, like Barnet Kellman, frame their old theater posters and hang them on their production-office walls. Chances are that Mr. Kellman will spend the rest of his career in Hollywood, but he wants to leave the door to the past ajar.
"When I go to see a good play," Mr. Kellman said in his office at Warner Brothers Television in Burbank, "I say, 'Oh, my God, I miss the theater.' You know something? If someone asked me to direct 'Angels in America' tomorrow, I would drop everything I'm doing, clear my calendar and go do it."

HEADLINE: Women's Work

BYLINE: By Wendy Martin; Wendy Martin, the chairwoman of the English department at the Claremont Graduate School, is the editor of "The Beacon Book of Essays by Contemporary American Women."

 BODY:

Daughters of the Great Depression
Women, Work, and Fiction in the American 1930s.
By Laura Hapke.
Illustrated. 286 pp. Athens:
The University of Georgia Press. $45.
 The Great Depression created immense hardship for millions of Americans, bequeathing a legacy of impoverished expectations that stunted an entire generation. Because masculine identity in the United States is so closely bound to work, this economic cataclysm has been viewed as a crisis that affected male workers. Overlooked, and often erased from history, are the 11 million women -- a quarter of all American women -- who worked outside the home. 
 Ever since the American Revolution, women have encountered enormous opposition in the paid labor force, especially during periods of economic contraction that starkly expose the cultural biases against women workers. In this carefully researched and detailed study, Laura Hapke, a professor of English at Pace University, examines the conflicts and tensions centering on the lives of women wage earners in the Depression.
 Exploring a wide range of texts -- from novels and short stories by Erskine Caldwell, Langston Hughes, Zora Neale Hurston, Sinclair Lewis, Claude McKay, Margaret Mitchell and John Steinbeck to articles in business magazines like Fortune, documentary photographs and films, as well as reports of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor -- Ms. Hapke demonstrates that working women, whether industrial workers or professionals, were scapegoats for the widespread economic and psychological conflicts and tensions felt by women and men alike in an era of hardship and uncertainty.
 In the 1920's, women optimistically ventured to work outside the home, but the collapse of the economy reversed the progress working women had made. Ironically, during the Depression when more women than ever needed to support themselves or their families, female wage earners were often depicted as harridans who were out to steal men's jobs: if not as harpies, harlots or bad mothers, at best as office helpmeets to powerful men. But as Ms. Hapke points out, "In reality, only rarely did women and men compete for the same jobs. Nor did firing women insure men access to jobs; it only contributed to the downfall of households supported by women."
 The vehement debates of the 1930's between the traditionalists who promoted the back-to-the-home movement and the radicals who sought to merge the cause of working women with that of workers in general continue today. The fiction of the Depression era documents the collective guilt associated with women wage earners, whether they were stenographers, teachers, nurses, domestics or workers on an assembly line. Even radical writers like Tillie Olsen, Meridel Le Sueur and Agnes Smedley had difficulty envisioning a woman in command of the material circumstances of her life. Ms. Hapke argues that instead of insisting on equal opportunity and compensation, these champions of the proletariat undercut the needs of women who worked outside the home by portraying them more as overburdened mothers than as workers who deserved respect for their ability to earn a wage.
 The deeply conflicted relationship between women and paid labor during the Great Depression is dramatically illustrated in Dorothea Lange's well-known photograph "Migrant Mother," one of a series taken at a farm camp in Nipomo, Calif. The gaunt, worry-creased face of Lange's subject, 32-year-old Florence Thompson, has become an enduring emblem of privation. Lange has explained that the woman looks harried because she was the sole support of her six children, and the pea fields where she worked had frozen over, forcing her to sell her few possessions for food. However, instead of acknowledging the fact that Thompson is a farm worker whose family depends on her wages, the photograph's label emphasizes her maternal role.
 Similarly, Ms. Hapke observes that in "The Grapes of Wrath," Steinbeck portrays Ma Joad as holding her family together through mother love while he ignores the importance of her long hours of farm labor, however poorly paid.
 In the 1930's, as today, millions of women anesthetized themselves against economic inequity by immersing themselves in pulp fiction and sensational melodrama. A few writers like Josephine Herbst and Tess Slesinger wrote novels out of the conviction that salvation came not from a man but from a good job, yet most fiction of the day dramatized the sentimental dimension of the narrative rather than the physical or intellectual challenges of paid employment.
 IN spite of all of the forces that tended to submerge the working woman, at least one novel with a powerful female protagonist became a best seller. As a resourceful and resilient woman who emerges from social and economic chaos in command of her considerable abilities, Scarlett O'Hara in Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind" helped to subvert the ideology of domestic femininity.
 Set in the Civil War and Reconstruction periods, Mitchell's novel provided a historical distance that allowed readers to identify safely with a heroine who prevails despite epic odds. Ms. Hapke writes that the popularity of "Gone With the Wind," which won the Pulitzer Prize the year after it was published in 1936, signaled the desire of a generation of women to pursue a life that encompassed work as well as love.
 With the onset of World War II and the opportunities for employment in munitions factories, on airplane assembly lines and in shipyards, women entered the work force in unprecedented numbers. As soon as the troops came home, however, women were once again urged to embrace the ideal of domestic femininity. Cultural constructions of gender roles continue to be powerfully affected by economic conditions. Ms. Hapke gives us a probing analysis of the way this process shaped the lives of Depression-era Americans.

82 of 745 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1996 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 4, 1996

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1900 words

HEADLINE: Sweeping the House

BYLINE: By John B. Judis; John B. Judis, a senior editor at The New Republic, is the author of "Grand Illusion: Critics and Champions of the American Century."

 BODY:

Storming the Gates
Protest Politics and the Republican Revival.
By Dan Balz and Ronald Brownstein.
424 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.
The Republican takeover of Congress in November 1994 caught even many of its supporters by surprise, but little more than a year later, it has become common to hear Republican strategists like William Kristol, the editor of The Weekly Standard, a conservative opinion magazine, describe 1994 as a realigning election, similar to the Democratic sweep of 1932. Dan Balz, a reporter for The Washington Post, and Ronald Brownstein, a reporter for The Los Angeles Times, have undertaken the first sober and extensive study of how the Republican takeover occurred and where it might lead. 
 Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein describe how, after the cold war's end, Republican conservatives, led by Newt Gingrich, forged a powerful new coalition among the Christian right, the advocates of term limits and property rights, the foes of gun control and business regulation, and Ross Perot supporters around the "central goal of limiting Federal power." In their view, "opposition to Washington has succeeded opposition to Communism as the unifying focus for the right." In 1994, this new Republican right was able to wrest control of Congress from the Democrats, who were crippled by the missteps of the Clinton Administration and by their own factional divisions.
Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein warn, however, that the Republicans' victory may not lead to a New Deal-style political realignment. For one thing, Republicans face what they call "the gusts of discontent that are billowing demands for new political alternatives." In 1992, Mr. Perot's independent candidacy helped defeat George Bush. In 1994, the Republicans were able to direct these winds against the Democrats, but in 1996 (if Mr. Perot runs) and in future elections, the Republicans could be blown away by them. "The persistent alienation that voters now express about the political system is a force inimical to electoral stability of any sort," the authors write.
In addition, as the Republicans expand their reach in the electorate, they are beginning to suffer from the same quarrels among a "collection of interests" that eventually paralyzed the Democratic Party. Like that of the Democrats, the Republicans' "driving energy" is increasingly lodged outside the party apparatus itself, in activist organizations and movements. The members of these movements narrow the "boundaries of permissible dissent" within the party on issues like abortion and gun control. They also don't necessarily get along with one another. While the members of the Christian Coalition and of Mr. Perot's United We Stand agree about economics, they don't automatically agree about social issues.
Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein chronicle at length the development of this new Republican coalition. Much of what they write, particularly about Mr. Gingrich and the Democrats, has appeared before, but not in one place and in such copious detail. Anyone who wants to understand contemporary American politics will find their book useful. But I have several reservations about their portrayal.
The authors accept the Republicans' description of themselves as "populist" tribunes for the aggrieved middle class. They repeatedly contrast the new Republican conservatism with the older "Wall Street" Republicanism, describing "Gingrich conservatives" as hostile to "Wall Street's influence," symbolized by President Bush's budget director, Richard Darman, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. And except in explaining Republican reluctance to embrace campaign reform, they ignore the central role of business lobbyists in the new coalition.
In fact, Mr. Gingrich, the new House Republicans and many of the key conservative organizations were heavily underwritten and influenced by corporate and Wall Street lobbyists. Mr. Gingrich's main political organization, Gopac, and William Kristol's Project for the Republican Future were both heavily subsidized by members of the Political Club for Growth, a group of financiers based in New York. Gopac, the Cato Institute and lobbies like Citizens for a Sound Economy were also underwritten by businesses that yearned for a Republican takeover of Congress. These included those securities houses and tobacco, defense, insurance and pharmaceutical firms that felt threatened by the Clinton Administration and the Democratic Congress.
Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein portray the Republican freshmen as representatives of populist gun owners and small businessmen, but they were also closely linked to corporate lobbies. Some freshmen were lobbyists themselves. Helen Chenoweth, from Idaho, represented Western timber and mining companies. Others, like David McIntosh, from Indiania, depended on industry lobbies for their campaign money. Mr. McIntosh, the former director of Vice President Dan Quayle's Council on Competitiveness, got at least a quarter of his campaign funds from the kinds of concerns that sought regulatory exceptions from the council.
Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein seem oblivious of this side of Republicanism. They say that a crucial meeting of House Republicans in early 1994 took place "without lobbyists present." They acknowledge that former Representative Tom Tauke was chairman of the Salisbury, Md., retreat, but they describe him as a "corporate executive." Mr. Tauke was then and is now the chief Washington lobbyist for Nynex, which has been a major player in the Republicans' telecommunications legislation.
It's not just a matter of whether the new Republican coalition deserves the term "populist." One can't understand what the Republicans have done in the last year without understanding the critical role that business lobbyists have played in their coalition. While the National Rifle Association and the Christian Coalition won a few token victories, the business lobbies have reaped their rewards in the Republican environmental, health care, defense and tax legislation. And the Republicans' current political problems stem directly from the public's accurate perception of this influence.
In explaining the populist appeal of the new Republicanism, Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein also play down its darker side. They acknowledge that racial division has been important in conservative Republicans' rise in the South, but they insist that Republican "racial appeals" are not the "principal reason" for the Democrats' decline in the South.
That doesn't square with recent history, beginning with Barry Goldwater's 1964 Republican Presidential campaign and George Wallace's defection from the Democrats in 1968. Race has been a crystallizing factor in just about every instance of Republican rise and Democratic decline. It was even central to the rise of the religious right. The authors date the religious right from the rise of the Rev. Jerry Falwell's Moral Majority in 1980, but it really began two years earlier when Mr. Falwell, Robert Billings and other previously apolitical evangelicals got together to lobby with new right activists against the Carter Administration's attempt to deny tax exemption to segregated Christian academies in the South.
A few conservatives like Jack Kemp and Bill Bennett have sought to alter the Republicans' identification as the white people's party, but they have largely failed. Most recently, some conservative intellectuals have even begun to entertain ominous racial theories to justify policies of malign neglect. In "The Bell Curve," Charles Murray, a fellow of the American Enterprise Institute, rooted black crime and lack of economic achievement in racial genetics. Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein once again appear oblivious. They describe Mr. Murray's book as the subject of "controversy," a description that might also apply to the Scarsdale diet or the designated hitter in baseball.
My second reservation about this book may strike some readers as asking more of "Storming the Gates" than its authors promise. When reporters write for their newspapers, they have to limit themselves to reporting facts and evaluating means, not ends. Like other journalists, Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein apply these strictures to their book writing. As a result, their book writing lacks passion and bite. But more important, they deprive the book's readers of their own considered judgments of the value of the Republican program. Only in the last chapter -- and in a timid equivocal manner -- do they attempt to evaluate ends, and not merely means.
This pursuit of objectivity has curious results. When the authors describe the Republican goal of blocking the Clinton health care bill without giving a view on whether doing so benefited Americans, readers may believe that they thought the Republicans were doing the country a favor in killing any chance of universal health insurance. Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein correctly see Mr. Quayle's White House office as a way station in the Republican revival, but, concentrating on its instrumental role, they describe it as one of "the pockets of conservative innovation" for "such ideas as regulatory and legal reform." Conservative innovation? Most of these ideas had been pressed by business lobbyists for years.
Because the authors cannot finally screen out all moral and political judgment, many of their own sentiments are embedded in their use of pejorative descriptions. They describe California's Proposition 187 as being an "anti-immigration ballot initiative." (In fact, it was aimed at illegal immigrants.) They describe Representative Richard Gephardt's trade position in the 1988 Presidential year as "protectionism." (In fact, it reflected a strategy of trade reciprocity.) They write that Mr. Perot's indictment of the two-party system is like a "small-town grocer complaining about the new Safeway," while Bill Bradley "invests the argument with a different kind of credibility." (In fact, Mr. Perot's indictment has proved far more significant, if not credible.) After reading these statements, I got an inkling of where Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein stood on immigration, free trade and Ross Perot, but not why, or what implications these positions had for their view of America's political future.
In the book's last chapter, the authors do cast doubt on whether the Republicans' anti-government agenda, translated into legislation, will have its promised effect of buoying up the economy and quelling social unrest. But rather than taking a firm position, they fall back on the journalist's pose of enlightened skepticism, invoking opposing experts to justify their own lack of resolution: "Some private economists" expected a balanced budget to achieve "dramatic results," while "other economists warn that rapidly reducing the deficit could slow the economy in the near term." This is fine for a newspaper analysis, but not for an extensive study of contemporary politics.
Mr. Balz and Mr. Brownstein have given us a good start toward understanding how conservative Republicans won control of Congress. But we need not only a fuller understanding of that process, including the role of business lobbies, but also a lively evaluation of the ends, or goals, of politics, one that is informed by moral judgment and historical understanding. For the most part, that is missing from this otherwise excellent book.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: Screen Dreams

BYLINE: By Liesl Schillinger; Liesl Schillinger writes about American culture for The London Independent and other publications.

 BODY:

SPIKE, MIKE, SLACKERS & DYKES
A Guided Tour Across a Decade of American Independent Cinema.
By John Pierson.
With the conversational collaboration of Kevin Smith.
Illustrated. 371 pp. New York:
Miramax Books/Hyperion. $22.95.
IT is difficult lately to tell whether Hollywood is trying harder to imitate the independent films or the indies are trying harder to imitate Hollywood. Perhaps no one is more tormented by this than John Pierson, a producer's representative who has given more American independent directors their start in the last 10 years than any other person or agency in the industry, but whose own roots lie in the esoteric world of art films and repertory houses. Idealistic, grudge-holding, visionary and defensive, Mr. Pierson is someone few outside the film industry are aware of. Yet without him Americans would not have heard so soon from Spike Lee, Michael Moore, Richard Linklater and a host of other directors whose unconventional visions brought the lives of blacks, the unemployed, homosexuals, hoop dreamers and other marginalized Americans to the silver screen. 
 In "Spike, Mike, Slackers & Dykes: A Guided Tour Across a Decade of American Independent Cinema," Mr. Pierson races the reader at breakneck speed through mazes of alleyways and up the vertiginous escalators that have led both him and independent films from obscurity to the big time. The book "is not a how to, it's a how come," Mr. Pierson says, and taking himself at his own word, he proceeds to relate every imaginable business detail of the past 10 years, from first meetings to deal making and deal breaking, from contracts and expense sheets to distribution. Somehow the glut of information doesn't slow the book down. The deals, enlivened by the author's brio, never lose their human complexion, even when, using the book as a kind of scrapbook, Mr. Pierson sticks in the actual documents that were the residue of the agreements -- like all four pages of Michael Moore's rights-and-distribution contract for "Roger and Me," or Kevin Smith's hand-scrawled list of the credit card cash advances he used to pay for his film "Clerks."
Mr. Pierson, who has lived, breathed and hunted film for most of his adult life, covers his territory with urgency and conviction, and his single-mindedness is ravishing. When he mentions the Sundance Film Festival of 1991, which occurred simultaneously with the gulf war, he comments blithely: "With so many films to watch and debate, it was difficult to worry about the Middle East." When he tells of years-old grievances and betrayals, you can hear him pounding his desk. When he alludes, in asides, to the misfortunes of his enemies, you can't miss the vengeful cackle in his tone (at Cannes, meeting the Samuel Goldwyn Company's Larry Jackson, who bid insultingly low on "She's Gotta Have It," losing the film and millions for Goldwyn, Mr. Pierson crows, "I mentioned that I could hardly keep track of the zeroes"). But when he tells of the successes of the directors he has nurtured and loved, you can see him smile.
No matter how many millions he's made, Mr. Pierson, now 41, still sides with the underdogs and not with management, still craves to see and understand with a youthful eye. It is telling that his book is broken up by one-on-one interviews between Mr. Pierson and his 24-year-old protg, Kevin Smith -- in which Mr. Pierson asks the questions. In one interlude, Mr. Smith says Mr. Pierson is just a glorified video clerk, like the stars of Mr. Smith's film. "You take something you find that you're really into like 'Clerks' and take it to the people. So in essence you're a very selective, very finicky video clerk." Mr. Pierson is delighted with this impertinence, although he can't help pointing out that he has a college degree.
The pride Mr. Pierson takes in his directors is like the admiration of a parent for a child, or even, disarmingly, like a little brother's respect for an older sibling. Spike Lee is "my hero," Mr. Pierson says at one point, and when he adds, "My life changed when his life changed," it's clear he's not just talking about cash flow.
ALWAYS fast, always personal, Mr. Pierson plows through the years director by director, film by film, child by child (he gets married along the way), dropping in news here and there of the immolations and rebirths of assorted indie studios and Hollywood executives. He's not afraid to acknowledge his own mistakes. In one chapter, titled "Amongst Jerks," Mr. Pierson rails against the director Rob Weiss, whose acquaintance and whose film, "Amongst Friends," he wishes he had never made.
Mr. Pierson is too resilient to let one bad experience keep him down, however, and sure enough, he bounded from Mr. Weiss to the much happier finds of Mr. Smith and the duo of Rose Troche and Guinevere Turner, whose wry, observant lesbian film "Go Fish" came out in 1994. They "made me feel young again," he writes. "Their good fortune was my redemption." Taking advantage of this surge of youthful vigor, Mr. Pierson wraps up the book and the indie film decade with a surprise slam dunk called "Hoop Dreams."
Ironically, Mr. Pierson worries that the increased fame and stature he has helped bring independent films may be their undoing. Ever since Steven Soderbergh's 1989 film, "Sex, Lies and Videotape," showed that indies could not only take Sundance but could take in millions at the box office, Hollywood has courted new film makers heartily. Indeed, ever since "The Crying Game," "The Piano" and "Pulp Fiction" grossed tens of millions of dollars, Hollywood seems intent on crushing the luscious new directorial jailbait with its overeager embrace. Mr. Pierson fears that in the face of such temptation, "the desire to make a film, any film," will replace "the need to express a vision," and he asks if heightened expectations for indies are creating "more opportunities or problems for traditional, smaller debut features." It is, as he writes, a "million-dollar question." Mr. Pierson can hardly be expected to solve it. As he admits early on: "I don't necessarily have all the answers." Nonetheless, it is reassuring to reflect that if this last decade is any sign, he can be counted on to spot the people who will.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1103 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Gauging the Impact on Housing of AT&T's Layoffs

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AT&T's plan to split into three smaller companies and cut up to 7,000 employees in New Jersey is another hard knock for the state's housing industry, which ended 1995 on a downward spiral.
The layoffs are planned over the next three years, with 4,900 of the cuts in 1996. Some 2,650 employees have already accepted voluntary severance packages and about 800 more have received pink slips. The consensus of economic forecasters and realtors is that the ax-wielding at a company that has come to represent stability has pushed a low level of consumer confidence even lower. 
 The question is whether the housing market will take the layoffs in stride or slide into a downturn. Most industry analysts don't expect the worst. "Such corporate downsizings always have some negative impact, but it is never the extent that people think." said Michael T. Robinson, president of the Weichert Relocation Company. This is particularly true in a market as diverse as New Jersey's, he added.
The impact is expected to be strongest on counties like Somerset, Morris, Middlesex, and Union where a concentration of AT&Temployees work. But real estate agents in those areas insist that the layoffs will not flood their markets with homes or depress prices, just as it did not with past job cuts by Johnson & Johnson in Somerset County and Exxon and Allied Signal in Morris County.
"People expect hundreds of homes to go up for sale in Basking Ridge and that is not going to happen," said Sue Humphrey, president of the Somerset County Board of Realtors, referring to the community where AT&T has its world headquarters.
One of those at AT&T who will sell his home is Peter R. McCarthy, vice president of sales, development and operations at the company's microelectronics headquarters in Berkeley Heights. Mr. McCarthy, who has held various positions there for the last 32 years, accepted a voluntary severance package in November, speeding his planned retirement by a few years.
"The package made it financially satisfying to retire now," said Mr. McCarthy, who is 54. He and his wife, Ellen, a tax preparer, plan to sell their single-family home in Madison this spring or summer and move to Maine. But Mr. McCarthy said he was concerned about selling his six-bedroom colonial given today's economic realities. "We are certainly anxious but know the influences on the market can shift the demand picture," he said. "But not so anxious that will we sell at a fire-sale price."
The Economic Advisory Service at the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University in New Brunswick has forecast that the AT&T layoffs will reduce the state's annual employment level by 3,200 jobs this year. Using a multiplier factor, jobs will be reduced by 10,000 in 1997 and by 12,800 in 1998 compared with previous expected levels for those years. As a result there will be a small rise in the unemployment rate and a slower population growth by 1988, and between 1996 and 1998 1.6 percent fewer building permits will be issued than previously expected.
"No one should be crying wolf or whistling by the graveyard about the layoffs," said Norman J. Glickman, director of the research center. "But a lot of people may be downsizing their housing demand."
Ritch Blasi, a spokesman for AT&T, said that "it is important to realize that other parts of the business are hiring" including wireless communications and on-line services. But the real issue, Mr. Glickman and other analysts said, is that the AT&T layoffs come on top of other corporate restructurings like that at Public Service Gas and Electric and amid recent signs that the state economy, like the nation's, has stalled.
Evidence of that was the rise in New Jersey's unemployment rate in December to 7.3 percent from 6.1 percent in the previous month. Unlike the layoffs of 1993 and 1994, the latest round is taking place when job growth is faltering: Only 39,000 new jobs are to be created this year, a 17,000 drop from last year, state figures show.
And a Rutgers report issued two weeks ago showed that the housing market has "reached advanced middle age," and predicted that the number of building permits issued, on a downward trend since the 1950's, would remain sluggish through the 1990's. The report concluded that the number of permits was unlikely to top 30,000 during any of the remaining years of this decade because the state's "painfully slow recovery and the aging baby boom and the advancing baby bust generations have led to a major drop-off in houshold formations."
The last time that happened was during the Depression, according to the report by James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, and Joseph Seneca, an economics professor and vice president of academic affairs at the university.
INDEED, estimates are that the state ended 1995 issuing 7 percent fewer permits than 1994's total of 26,986 permits.
The job cuts by AT&T, Professor Seneca said, put out a cautionary flag to everyone else about their own employment prospects, and another damper on housing demand this year.
All these factors "provide a recipe for a housing trough," Dean Hughes added. For consumers "the economic tug-of-war in 1996 will be low mortgage rates versus the health of the labor market, and what may win out is immobility," he said.
Sales of existing single-family homes fell in the third quarter of 1995 to 38,500 from 39,500 in the comparable 1994 quarter, according to the New Jersey Association of Realtors in Edison. And estimates are that the state will wind up 1995 with 7,000 fewer homes sold than the 145,400 sold 1994, or a total of 138,400 homes.
It is the combination of uncertain state and national economic conditions with a wicked winter season, more than the AT&T layoffs, that has given the market a lethargic sales start for 1996, said Peter Mosca, a spokesman for the association.
Whatever homes do come on the market as a result of the layoffs, he said, will come during the second quarter and be added to an already high level of unsold homes, which he estimates as a six- to nine-month inventory.
Until that backlog is absorbed, he said, house prices will remain flat. The median sale price in the state for 1995 is expected to be $148,000, down from $148,700 in 1994, he added.
"There's always a period of hesitation and people will delay trading up or buying the house of their dreams," added Elenore T. Stone, past president of the Morris County Board.
And the AT&T layoffs will cause housing buyers "to become more cautious, and the market to slow," Dean Hughes said.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 6; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 263 words

HEADLINE: VIEWS;
Of Breweries and Water Wheels in 1890's Essex

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM 

 BODY:
These ordinary scenes, frozen in old photographs from the 1880's or 1890's, capture a sense of Essex County as it struggled and prospered and grew from verdant pastures and meadows into the densely packed urban-suburban environment of Newark and its suburbs in the 20th century.
In their pictorial history "Remembering Essex" (Donning Company, 1995), the historians John T. Cunningham and Charles F. Cummings use 275 photos to compile a record of everyday life in a place of farms and factories, workers and beer barons. Pictures date from the eve of the Civil War -- a family portrait on the steps of a High Street home in Newark -- to a recent contemporary image of the Seton Hall University basketball team. 
 In the sampling here, the authors have chosen to remember and memorialize Essex through its people as well as its achievements. Newark was already flexing its muscles, at the Ballantine brewery as well as in the heart of the downtown business district, where the Fireman's Insurance Company building displayed its Victorian majesty at Broad and Market Streets. Yet in nearby Millburn, even in the age of steam and at the dawn of the age of electricity, Smith's Mill continued to provide water power for a thriving paper company.
The quaint and the modern are everywhere apparent. At the Prudential Insurance Company in Newark, still a keystone of the city's economy, no employer in the county retained a larger female work force. And at an old school in Millburn, the authors seem to invite the reader to find someone without a hat. CHARLES STRUM

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 887 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER 

 BODY:

THE LAST SHOT: City Streets, Basketball Dreams
 By Darcy Frey. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $11.
 A prevalent myth in the American ghetto is that athletic achievement -- particularly in basketball -- will provide a way out of poverty. As the author discovered at a high school in Brooklyn, this belief often helps perpetuate scholastic and professional failure. "This book -- compellingly written, with elegance, economy and just the right amount of outrage -- should be read by every parent who has a child involved in school sports," Brent Staples said here in 1994.

 THE UNUSUAL LIFE OF TRISTAN SMITH
 By Peter Carey. Vintage International, $13.
 The man of the title, deformed at birth, is as crushed by circumstances as his fictional nation, Efica, is by the heavy hand of imperialism. As an adult he travels to Voorstand, the country that has colonized his own, where he encounters a culture in love with its own technology and the pulp creations of its entertainers. Last year our reviewer, Carol Shields, found Voorstand eerily reminiscent of the United States, where the novel's Australian author now lives. "The first two pages are enough to tell us we're in the hands of a master storyteller," she wrote. Vintage International has also restored to print Mr. Carey's first novel, BLISS ($12), published in 1981. The story of an average 39-year-old man who is resuscitated nine minutes after his heart has failed, it presents the near-death experience as less of a moral regeneration than a wake-up call to sin. It is "engagingly unappetizing" and "written with enormous verve and malice," Howard Jacobsen said in these pages in 1985.

 BOB DOLE: The Republicans' Man for All Seasons
 By Jake H. Thompson. Primus/Donald I. Fine, $12.95.
 This biography, recently updated, charts the career path of the Senator who presents the most formidable political challenge to President Clinton. It portrays him as a man whose strength and resolve have consistently enabled him to overcome adversity. The author "provides a glimpse of how complex this man who longs to be President is," Janet Hook wrote in the Book Review in 1994. For another personal look there is BOB DOLE, by Richard Ben Cramer (Vintage, $11), excerpted from the author's 1992 book, "What It Takes: The Way to the White House." Our reviewer of "What It Takes," Laurence I. Barrett, said, "In describing Mr. Dole, Mr. Cramer . . . gets closer to this very private man's core than any other writer has."

 SECOND MARRIAGE
 By Frederick Barthelme. Grove, $11.
 Love isn't necessarily better the second time around, especially for Henry, the narrator, who is trying to patch together a marriage that seems destined for the same end as his first. Set in a stultifying suburbia where passion of any kind is largely absent, Mr. Barthelme's first novel "registers acutely a world in which everything occurs obliquely," Ron Loewinsohn wrote here in 1984. Grove has also restored to print the author's first short-story collection, MOON DELUXE ($12), which features men, middle-class and mostly middle-aged, who tread warily around the edges of sexual relationships. The book is "engaging, observant and at times downright whack-in-the-solar-plexus mean," Margaret Atwood said in the Book Review in 1983.

 PICTURES AT AN EXECUTION
 By Wendy Lesser. Harvard University, $14.95.
 The author's subject is murder: specifically, our endless fascination with it in art and in life. The core of her investigation is a trial in 1991 in which a San Francisco public television station sued over the right to broadcast an execution at San Quentin prison. Her work is "full of shrewd observations . . . and acerbic asides," George Stade wrote here in 1994.

 THE NATURE OF LONGING
 By Alyce Miller. Norton, $10.
 The desire for connection -- between lovers, between races, between any two people who are fundamentally different -- is the theme of these eight stories, which won the Flannery O'Connor Award for Short Fiction in 1994. The collection "convincingly presents a variety of complex characters, all of whom yearn for what they lack," Gardner McFall said in these pages.

 NOW
 By Lauren Bacall. Ballantine, $6.99.
 In a celebrity memoir refreshingly devoid of gossip or rancor, the actress reflects on her life in recent years. Still devoted to her profession, she notes the conflict between her desire for solitude and her emotional dependence on family and friends. "The author is as likable as ever -- honest, funny and appealingly balanced between certainty and insecurity," Judith Viorst wrote in the Book Review in 1994. Another actress's world is evoked in GRACE, by Robert Lacey (Berkley, $6.99), the story of the young American film star who renounced her career to become Princess of Monaco. Its portrait of Grace Kelly is "a definitive biography with a shrewd final verdict," one critic said in 1994.

 SAINT
 By Christine Bell. Norton, $11.
 Susan, nicknamed Rubia by her South American husband, Federico, doesn't mind being a Yankee outsider on the family hacienda until she finds out her husband is having an affair. The first novel by the author of "The Perez Family," this tale of revenge offers "high comedy laced with the lessons of sexual warfare," Sara Vogan said here in 1985. Laurel Graeber

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
New Residential Space Arrives in Lower Manhattan

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
BEFORE the year is over, about 1,000 apartments are expected to be in construction in older office and commercial buildings in lower Manhattan. Developers are taking advantage of relaxed zoning regulations and new tax incentives aimed at assisting economically stagnant properties and bringing in more round-the-clock occupancy.
Some of these projects will be large-scale conversions. But as it happens, the first to begin marketing space after a construction start is a small-scale project that exemplifies the offbeat specimens of mixed residential, office and industrial use that the new incentives may occasionally produce. It will also test the market for large for-rent live-work spaces in the financial district. 
 The property is 47 West Street, close to the entrance to the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel and directly across from Battery Park City. It is actually three buildings on one tax lot. The tallest is the 12-story 47 West Street, named the Crystal Building for the family that once owned it. It is internally connected to 74 Washington Street, which is five floors lower. Combined they create 160,000 square feet of space, with lower floors of 15,200 square feet for printers and other businesses. The small third building is the three-story 50 West Street.
The Crystal Building was 90 percent occupied until about 1989, said Francis Greenburger, principal of Time Equities, the owner, a major co-op converter in the 80's but a commercial owner as well.
"Then one tenant went bust, two moved to Brooklyn and another went out of business," he said. "We had 26,000 square feet of nonresidential loft space vacant for two years." A tenant on the eighth and ninth floors of theWest Street building was moved to the large fifth floor, which runs through to the shorter building on the Washington Street side. That freed two floors for residential conversion.
Now the 8th through the 11th floors of the West Street building are being converted to live-work space, with a sizable 3,000 square feet in each space, two to a floor, and sunlight from four directions. The units will rent for $4,000 a month, or $16 a square foot a year. Residents will share a modest-sized lobby, redecorated in Art Deco fashion, with the commercial tenants. The Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburgh is financing the construction.
The long-term tenant on the 12th floor of 47 West Street is the Superior Group (formerly Superior Reproduction Systems), a copying, microfilm and imaging service that signed a new lease only a year ago.
"I have no heavy presses," said Michael S. Darvin, the chief operating officer. "I have no problem with people living below us as long as the people moving in know we're a functioning business, 24 hours a day."
N OR is Donald Kern dissatisfied. He and his partner, Arthur Baron, run Admiral Communications (formerly Admiral Photo Offset Company), a printing company founded by their fathers in lower Manhattan 50 years ago. Three weeks ago Admiral signed a 15-year, $10-million lease renewal for 49,100 square feet on three-and-a-half low floors. Time Equities agreed to build a new heavy-duty freight elevator for Admiral on the south side of the building, along Joseph P. Ward Street.
Does residential occupancy disturb Admiral? "It doesn't bother me one way or another," Mr. Kern said. "My machines are noisy but they're down in the building, on the Washington Street side."
The live-work units of 47 West Street are a modest precursor of residential projects to come in lower Manhattan. Crescent Heights Investments, a partnership of Bruce A. Menin, Russell Galbut and Sonny Kahn, has gutted the interior of the 500,000-square-foot 1901 building at 25 Broad Street, at Exchange Place, in preparation for construction of a residential building of 345 family-sized high-ceiling apartments. Crescent Heights has developed close to 6,000 apartments in 20 former apartment buildings or hotels, mostly in South Florida.
Another redevelopment candidate is 127 John Street, the 32-story, 550,000-square-foot office building completed only 25 years ago by the Kaufman Organization. It was purchased out of foreclosure last November by Rockrose Development Corporation, a large residential owner-builder. A major tenant, Prudential Securities, moved out of 150,000 square feet three years ago and the space was not rerented.
A few blocks away is the 66-story, 1.4-million-square-foot 40 Wall Street, recently purchased by Donald Trump. Despite speculation that its upper floors might be converted to residential use, Mr. Trump said that it would remain a pure office building. Most of it is vacant, a big reconstruction has started and Cushman & Wakefield has been retained by the Trump Organization as the leasing agent, Mr. Trump said.
Creating an environment that attracts residents requires more than apartments. "The key is to create a restaurant destination that makes people want to be there," said Tony Goldman, principal in Goldman Properties, who said he was prepared to open five of them over the next 24 months. Mr. Goldman owns 70 Broad Street and other nearby property. A brownstone converter, he owns and operates three hotels in the South Beach section of Miami.
The zoning changes that are fueling the residential conversion activity were adopted last summer. They affect pre-1961 buildings below Murray Street west of Broadway, and below the Brooklyn Bridge east of Broadway. One change allows apartments in these buildings to have an average gross square footage of 900. Previous zoning discouraged conversions with a provision that the average apartment size in a large portion of the building had to be 1,800 square feet. Also, developers are now allowed to provide on-site parking for 20 percent of the units, up to 200 spaces.
Another zoning change makes it easier to create live-work space in lower Manhattan by permitting up to 49 percent of the dwelling units to be used for the home occupation. The previous limit was 25 percent. Three employees may work in the space.
S PECIAL tax incentives were also introduced for lower Manhattan conversions. After completion of construction, a 12-year tax exemption is provided. It applies to the assessment established at that time for buildings that are wholly or substantially (more than 75 percent of the total space) converted to residential use. It phases out after the first eight years at a rate of 20 percent a year.
In addition, taxes attributable to the preconstruction assessment are abated for 14 years. The abatement is 100 percent for 10 years, and it phases out over the next. (Landmarked properties get an extra year on both the exemption and the abatement.) The exemption and abatement together let the converted building to start out tax free. Then, until the benefits phase out, it pays taxes only on the portion of subsequent assessments that reflect a rise in value.
To qualify for the full initial tax benefits when less than 75 percent of the property is converted, developers are likely to attempt to establish the residential space as condominiums. Their expectation is that then both the exemption and the abatement would be available. On this principle, the converted floors at 47 West Street are likely to become a condominium.
Other tax incentives in lower Manhattan benefit office and commercial lessees. One runs for three years and applies to new arrivals in pre-1975 buildings in lower Manhattan, or to tenants signing renewal leases renewals in such buildings. This benefit helped Admiral Communications at 47 West Street. Mr. Kern said it would save the business $250,000 over five years, and was a factor in its decision not to move.
Mr. Greenburger said that he got the idea of converting several floors in 47 West Street two years ago when he was visiting a friend at Battery Park City. "I looked out and saw the empty floors in my building, and I thought residential might work," he said. "It took two years to get a bank to agree to finance it."

GRAPHIC: Photos: At 47 West Street, left, the 8th to the 11th floors are becoming live-work space. At right, owners of Admiral Communications, Donald Kern, left, and Arthur Baron, who renewed their lease on lower floors that extend to the Washington Street side of the property. (Photographs by Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
The Governor's Midterm Grades

 BODY:
Governor Whitman is at midterm. How would you grade her performance so far?
 
Attracting Businesses
It seems that she has fulfilled her end of the bargain. I don't really see business leaving New Jersey, I see New York businesses running here.
 
ROBERT W. KULESSA
Toms River
 
Big Losses, Few Gains 
 Governor Whitman has outrageously plundered the state work force, diverted funds from the retirement system, moved state aid from school districts, appropriated millions from the disability insurance fund and raised innumerable licensing and permit fees.
She now proposes to reduce the Department of Environmental Protection, reduce the level of services provided by the state, cut school aid even further, reduce prescription subsidies for seniors and cut state financing for state colleges and universities. All this for a saving of approximately $300 a year for a typical family.
 
PAUL HIRSCH
Somerset
 
A Shrinking Constituency
Governor Whitman's performance has been merely adequate. Her only notable accomplishment has been the rollback of income taxes to something close to, but not quite as low as, the still-high pre-Florio level. The Governor attempts to appeal to Democrats and liberals who will never vote for her while hoping that conservatives stick with her. Soon her constituency will evaporate.
 
EDWARD J. ZOHN
Scotch Plains
 
Listing What's Wrong
An outstanding public relations job has masked these realities:
1. A phony tax program.
2. Devious accounting practices, raiding surpluses of various state trust funds and tampering with public employee pension system.
3. State spending has increased by $700 million.
4. The economy is faltering. . Our unemployment rate is one of the highest in the nation.
 
EDWARD A. FORMAN
Englewood Cliffs
 
Earning an A, and an F
Her promises of an income tax cut and a Howard Stern rest stop were kept. Her politial party controls the Legislature. To those who had such priorities, she earns an A. But for those who still have to pay the highest auto insurance premiums in the nation, or those recently laid off due to continuing budget cuts and corporate downsizings, or those who still object to gimmicrky in budget balancing, she gets an F.
 
JOHN BURY
Kenilworth
 
Shifting the Burden
I am unhappy with the way Governor Whitman has increased the burden on municipalities. Two areas in which I think she did a good job are requiring insurers to cover a 48-hours stay in the hospital after chirldbirth, and her effort in keeping the speed limit at 55 miles an hour.
 
JOYCE JACOBS
Teaneck

HEADLINE: LOYAL OPPOSITION;
A Former Speaker Finds a Kindred Spirit on the Podium

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
BY now, Joseph V. Doria Jr. should be used to playing the part of the loyal opposition in the State Legislature. Mr. Doria, a politician from Hudson County, where Democrats once ruled unchallenged, is starting his fifth year as the leader of the minority party in the Assembly.
Although he acknowledges that the situation can be frustrating, and he knows he had more power in the days when he was Speaker, Mr. Doria says his current role is not entirely unrewarding. 
 "Do I get tired of being in the minority? Sure, everybody gets tired," said Mr. Doria, who will turn 50 in June and has served successive two-year terms in the Assembly since 1980. "But the minority creates a point of debate, and that's important. We have forced a lot of issues, like regulatory reform and state mandate, state pay."
And it is the leader of the minority party who determines the form and substance of that debate.
"The Democrats will be back," he said. "In New Jersey, the pendulum always swings back. It may be two years, or four years, but it will swing."
But Mr. Doria, who is an administrator at St. Peter's College in Jersey City and is working on his doctorate in education at Teachers College of Columbia University, said he had no idea if he would be part of that majority.
Even though he and his longtime running mate, Joseph Charles Jr., defeated their Republican opponents last November by more than 3 to 1, Mr. Doria said, "I take it two years at a time." He added that he hoped to remain involved in issues of public policy and education: he was a sponsor of the 1990 Quality Education Act, one of several unsuccessful attempts to to meet court-imposed guidelines to pay for public schools.
The personalities of the legislative leaders and the Governor often set the tone for dealings in the State House, and state government has seldom seen two more easygoing leaders than Mr. Doria and the new Speaker, Jack Collins, both of whom are educators. Mr. Doria is a big man, and despite a recent weight loss his appearance can make him seem unyielding and unapproachable. But even his political opponents say the impression is misleading.
"He is one of the gentlest legislators I know," said Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Scotch Plains Republican who has led the Senate since 1992 and is widely thought to have gubernatorial ambitions. Coming from Mr. DiFrancesco, who himself has been criticized for being too easygoing and willing to compromise, the description of his political rival is revealing.
"At times, I think he finds it difficult to be partisan," the Senate President said, "and I don't mean that in a negative way. I may disagree with him, but I can't help but like him."
When he has to, Mr. Doria is willing to take on the Republican majority and Governor Whitman, whom he sees as politically inexperienced and inclined to make promises she cannot keep.
"It's easy to cut taxes. It's hard to govern responsibly," Mr. Doria said of Mrs. Whitman's first two years in office. "The Governor's proposed budget is based on gimmicks and on overly optimistic revenue estimates."
What the state should be looking at now, he went on, are ways to guarantee the creation of new jobs; the administration has taken steps in that direction but has not done everything possible, he said.
"We have to put New Jersey in a position where people have psychological and economic security," Mr. Doria said. "Tax collections will be higher only if more people are working."
And reviewing education financing with an eye to providing equal educational opportunities for every child in the state will once again be a priority in the Legislature, he said, echoing the new Speaker, Mr. Collins.
Between his jobs in the Legislature and at St. Peter's College, Mr. Doria says he has very little spare time. His wife of nearly 18 years, the former Maribeth Keselica, who is director of testing in the Bayonne school system, is understanding of his busy schedule but does not participate in many political events.
Despite the demands of the job, Mr. Doria said he would encourage others to take the plunge into politics.
"I'd tell them to realize what they will sacrifice in family life and personal life," he said.
"It's much harder to be a legislator now than when I started, but it's very satisfying. These are more challenging times, but you can have a major impact on people's lives."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph V. Doria Jr. of Bayonne, the Assembly minority leader, at his desk in the lower house. "The Democrats will be back," he said. "In New Jersey, the pendulum always swings back. It may be two years, or four years, but it will swing." (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)
