PUB-DATE: February 4, 1996

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2326 words

HEADLINE: Man of the House

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: ELMER

 BODY:
Jack Collins doesn't claim to be much of a farmer anymore. He no longer has time to milk his cows. The livestock on his small farm here in southern New Jersey share a ramshackle old barn, and sometimes they have to wait until 8:30 at night to get fed.
But when his brood of chicks began to disappear mysteriously last fall, it didn't take long for Mr. Collins to get rid of the culprit, a marauding barn cat. 
 "If you can't get along," he said, "you have to go."
These days, Mr. Collins, a five-term Republican lawmaker from Salem County, has another menagerie to oversee as the new Speaker of the General Assembly. He will not be able to dispose of members who block his agenda as easily as his former cat, but he will be controlling what bills come to the floor and will have a lot to say about whether they become law.
In his new role, Mr. Collins, 50, is the state's third-ranking elected official, after the Governor and the Senate President. He was elected unanimously by the Legislature's Republican majority to continue pressing the party's agenda of slowing government spending and cutting taxes. In the two-year-old administration of Christine Todd Whitman, a woman being watched closely by Republicans nationwide, that is no small burden.
Mr. Collins succeeds Chuck Haytaian, a Republican from Warren County who decided not to run for re-election last fall after an unsuccessful bid to unseat Senator Frank R. Lautenberg. Mr. Haytaian is now the chairman of the state's Republican Party.
Governor Whitman could count on Mr. Haytaian to drive her agenda through a sometimes balky Assembly. But some members of the Legislature say she may not have as easy a time persuading Mr. Collins to go along with her plans.
Mr. Haytaian used hard-fisted tactics to push through the Republican agenda. Mr. Collins is known for putting the concerns of his members first. Affable and easygoing, he prefers consensus over pressure to keep his 80 members -- 50 Republicans and 30 Democrats -- in line.
Yet despite his demeanor, the quick smile and the ready slap on the back, his colleagues caution against underestimating his ability to be tough.
"Anybody who would mistake his affability for being less than a strong leader would be making a mistake," said Assemblyman Gary W. Stuhltrager, a Republican who has represented the same district as Mr. Collins -- Salem County and parts of Gloucester -- since 1985, when they both arrived in the Assembly.
For his part, the new Speaker does not seem to mind being underestimated. "It is a great deal of power," he said one recent morning as he sat at his kitchen table with three mastiffs at his feet. "I've figured that out. I like to play the local yokel for those North Jerseyites. People say, Everybody seems to like Collins, but can he get those 41 votes?. We'll see."
The new Speaker will preside tomorrow over his first routine legislative session, wielding his gavel from the large raised podium in the General Assembly chambers that have been recently refurbished to their 19th-century splendor. The state's lawmakers first met there more than 100 years ago.
And to hear Mr. Collins tell it, the 207th Legislature will be confronting some of the same intractable issues that legislators have been wrestling with for decades.
AT his swearing-in ceremony on a bitterly cold afternoon last month, Mr. Collins said the most important issue facing the Legislature was public education, and he promised that this would be the year for New Jersey to resolve the debate over finding a fair way to pay for schools. He closed his remarks by noting that the last Speaker from Salem County, John W. Davis, had told his members the very same thing 34 years before.
The State Supreme Court has imposed a September deadline on the Legislature and the Whitman administration to come up with a plan to end disparities between the state's wealthiest and poorest school districts. Mrs. Whitman devoted her annual legislative address to education, and said she believed that improving public education would not require additional dollars.
Mr. Collins, who has appointed two new Assembly task forces to examine the issue, said he was waiting to see the Governor's detailed proposal and for his members to report to him with their findings before deciding what course to take.
"We will play a key role," he said. "We are the extension of the people. There is no greater issue touching the people of this state and not just kids. It touches parents, senior citizens, employers, future employers. We are going to be very involved."
The Legislature is facing other volatile issues that will require strong leadership by Mr. Collins and his counterpart, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican from Scotch Plains.
The most pressing issue is replenishing the state's Health Care Subsidy Fund, which helps pay for hospital care for the poor.
The Legislature rejected Mrs. Whitman's proposal to raise cigarette taxes in December, and Mr. Collins and Mr. DiFrancesco are now trying to find other ways to come up with $400 million for charity care -- $300 million to be distributed to 84 hospitals and $100 million for the state's subsidized health insurance program for working families and individuals who are unable to obtain insurance through their employers.
Then there's balancing the state's $16 billion budget in a declining economy, providing cities and towns with property tax relief, coming up with ways to create more jobs as unemployment increases and taking on Mrs. Whitman's proposal to overhaul the state's welfare system.
So how does a nice guy like Jack Collins get at least 41 of his members to give him the majority he needs to reach agreement on these complex issues? How will he get along with Mr. DiFrancesco, the Senate President? And will he push through Mrs. Whitman's agenda as aggressively as Mr. Haytaian did?
To help him, Mr. Collins can draw upon a background that has nothing to do with Trenton politics but lots to do with getting through life, which in some ways may be the same thing: before he arrived in the Assembly, he was a farmer, lawyer, college administrator, basketball coach, graduate-level instructor and father of four.
Mr. DiFrancesco said last week that during the last four years, when Mr. Collins was majority leader, they worked closely and successfully together. "We have a good relationship," he said. "We've been together a lot."
Mr. Haytaian, who chose Mr. Collins as his successor, said he thought the new Speaker would provide strong leadership and continue the Assembly's close relationship with Mrs. Whitman. "He understands what has to be done in working with the Governor and the Senate President," Mr. Haytaian said.
But Mr. Collins, the son of a shipyard worker, is more sympathetic than many Republicans to organized labor and environmental issues.
In the final weeks of the last legislative session, he openly challenged Mrs. Whitman's proposal to change the way municipalities negotiate contracts with police and fire unions. Mr. Collins also publicly questioned the cigarette tax she proposed.
And in contrast to Mr. Haytaian, he is expected to listen more closely and respond more to the needs of his members and put them, in some cases, ahead of the Governor's.
"She's tough and I like her," Mr. Collins said about the Governor. "I don't always agree with her." But he added, "I sure don't think that we're going to go against her."
Governor Whitman said Mr. Collins had always been up-front and honest with her, whether they agreed or disagreed. "And when he said that he was going to do something, he always kept to his word," she said. "I look forward to that kind of relationship."
TO build consensus among Assembly members, Mr. Collins said his strategy was simple. He intends to listen a lot and involve Assembly members in the major issues.
"I think there has to be a lot more communication," he said. "I'm going to spend more time with the members. I want to know what they're thinking. They ought to know where we are."
Even some Democrats, who have been in the minority for the last four years, say they like his open, informal, friendly style and particularly welcome his commitment to involve the Legislature actively in solving the school-financing issue.
"He is saying that we need to be a part of the process," said the minority leader, Joseph V. Doria Jr. of Bayonne, who has a good relationship with Mr. Collins. "We need to play a role, which is important."
Despite his varied personal background, Mr. Collins says that in dealing with the state's problems he doesn't feel qualified to be all things to all people. He points out, for example, that he does not even handle the family's finances and that his wife doles out his allowance once every two weeks.
"And I'm going to be deciding the economic future on the state alone?" he said. "No. We have people who are accomplished individuals who know about things. I am going to ask everybody to have more of a stake in what we're doing. If they don't want to participate then don't be whining later when we go do something."
He said he believed that the chairs of legislative committees should have great power. "They should be able to massage the ideas, to convince their committee people to come together first.
"That lays the groundwork for the next step, which is to have a 41-member majority vote for something. How do you do that? You have to let people be part of the action. They have to be able to put something into it."
Of all of his work experiences, Mr. Collins says his years as a college basketball coach will help him the most in his new role.
Mr. Collins was a basketball star at Gloucester City Catholic High School and scored more than 1,000 points one year as a guard on the Glassboro, now Rowan, State College team. A few years later, as the coach, he guided the team to the division's national championship tournament. He left the job after seven winning seasons because while winning was wonderful, he said, losing became too unbearable for him.
"Part of coaching is knowing who your people are, what you can expect from them, what you can demand of them, what they are able to do," he said. "Then you look at them and try to put them together."
After coaching, Mr. Collins became an administrator at Rowan, earned a law degree at Rutgers in Camden, and now teaches graduate courses on education and the law at the college. He and his wife, Betsy, have owned their three-acre farm in Pittsgrove Township since 1974, when they traded in their Gloucester City row house for the rural life.
They raise pigs, cows, chickens, geese, peacocks and a couple of turkeys. "We will not get the great farming award, but we have fun," he said.
In 1985, Mr. Collins was approached by the state Republican Party to run for the Assembly. Until then, he had never been involved in politics and he thinks he might even have been a Democrat at the time. He beat a longtime incumbent Democrat.
TWO years after arriving in the Assembly, Mr. Collins gained notoriety in the State House during an emotional debate on the Assembly floor over easing the ban on leg-hold traps, an issue important to his constituents in South Jersey. To demonstrate that supporters of the traps also loved animals, he told a story of how he once gave mouth-to-mouth resuscitation to save a piglet's life. His colleagues laughed so hard that a recess was called.
A few legislators predicted the incident would damage Mr. Collins's political career. But two years later, when the Republicans lost control of the Assembly, Mr. Collins was chosen by Mr. Haytaian, then the minority leader, as his deputy.
It became a powerful position when the Republicans regained control of the Assembly and Mr. Haytaian was elected Speaker. Mr. Collins then moved into position as majority leader, ultimately to succeed Mr. Haytaian. He was then elected by the Republican caucus last fall.
Mr. Collins, the first Speaker elected from a mostly rural district in South Jersey in more than three decades, said he did not expect to have trouble understanding the issues that are of special concern to residents of North Jersey. Property taxes, for example, are a much bigger issue in the northern part of the state than in the south. He also objected to the notion that that he might not understand the problems of the urban poor.
"If there is any group in this state that is not understood, it is small urban communities, " he said. "They have all the problems that inner cities have, but no social programs, no public transportation. Poor problems are everywhere."
Now that he's Speaker, he said, he recognizes his responsibility to the entire state. "If you draw a line in the middle of the state, three quarters of the state's population live in the north," he said.
But don't expect to see Mr. Collins at many political fund-raising events or Rotary Club luncheons north of Trenton. He says he has no political ambitions beyond his present role, so he will not be spending much time trying to build statewide political support for some future campaign.
He will be relying heavily, he said, on his majority leader, Paul DiGaetano, a Republican from Rutherford, in Bergen County, to represent the Assembly leadership on many occasions. Unlike Mr. Haytaian and several other former speakers, who used the job as a platform to run for higher office, he says his aspirations end in the Assembly chamber.
As for being Governor someday, Mr. Collins said: "By appointment only."
Nor does he plan to spend every day in his State House office, like Mr. Haytaian. He will be keeping his full teaching schedule at Rowan. And there are all of his animals, waiting to be fed.
"We got phones, we got faxes," he said. Then he paused, as if realizing the extent of his new power. "And I decide when we meet. If I don't show up, no one else can."

HEADLINE: Spoil Dumped in Sound May Be Tainted

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THE Navy may be using contaminat'd spoil to cap 1.2 million cubic yards of toxic-laden material that it dumped into Long Island Sound near Fishers Island, opponents of the project charge.
The dumping, which began in late 1994 and is to be completed early this month, dredged the heavily industrialized Thames River at New London to provide clearance for the Seawolf nuclear submarine at her home port. 
 The opponents, led by the Fishers Island Conservancy, said recent tests that they paid for had showed moderate levels of mercury, traces of dioxin and small amounts of other toxic substances in samples of the capping material used to cover over the spoils that were taken from the river and dumped in the Sound.
They said the results should compel further tests by the Navy before the capping is allowed to continue.
"Any capping material that goes out there should be very clean," the president of the conservancy, John H. Thatcher Jr., said. "This should raise a red flag."
Mr. Thatcher said that if additional contamination was found officials should recap the dump site with spoil that is certified as clean.
The Navy official in charge of the project, Robert K. Ostermueller of the Navy Facilities Engineering Command in Lester, Pa., did not return three calls to his office.
But an assistant commissioner in the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, Arthur J. Rocque Jr., said the capping material was clean and met Federal and state standards for marine projects. Mr. Rocque said recapping would be unnecessary and potentially harmful to the home of the clean material.
Capping, the final step in the project, entails dumping clean dredged material from the Thames on top of the larger volume of contaminated material at the site. In theory, a three-meter-thick cap seals contaminants on the bottom of the Sound.
The one-mile-square site, in use since before World War II, is one and a half miles from Fishers Island, in an area where opponents said strong currents would spread contaminants, particularly if they are in the capping material.
In December the privately hired testers took seven samples from river-bottom areas to be used for capping while Navy observers videotaped from a patrol boat.
Test results showed traces of pesticides and heavy metals. Mercury, one of the most toxic heavy metals, was present in five samples in moderate levels, according to standards set by the New England River Basins Commission. The amounts ranged from 0.2 to 0.6 parts per million.
Mr. Rocque said the results were consistent with Navy findings. He said the moderate classification referred to ground disposal, not to Federal standards for marine disposal. But Mr. Thatcher said the standards were the ones cited in the Navy environmental-impact statement for the dredging.
Although a portion of the disposal site is in New York waters, the Navy, the Army and Connecticut officials have said all dumping has occurred on the Connecticut side.
New York State challenged the project, saying New York permits might be needed because of the potential effects on the New York side. But the New York Attorney General's office dropped the legal action in Federal Court in Albany after Gov. George E. Pataki said in December that the dredging posed no damage.
The president of the 1,000-member Concerned Citizens of Montauk, Rav Freidel, attacked Mr. Pataki for "his support of the U.S. Navy's reckless poisoning of Long Island Sound."
Mr. Freidel said in an interview that the project "was done in the name of national security."
"Give me a break," he said. "Where's the war? I'll tell you where. It's in Long Island Sound, and its the Government against our fish and our fishermen."
Mr. Rocque said Mr. Freidel's assertion that the project had been rushed to completion by dumping seven days a week 24 hours a day since October was "extremely economical with the truth."
"We are very careful about this stuff," he said. "We really are."
But Mr. Thatcher said conservancy members, including himself, had witnessed dumping during high winds and strong tides. "That has been going on from Day 1," he said.
The conservancy and other organizations like the Town of Southold, the Fishers Island Civic Association, the Long Island Sound Lobstermen's Association, the North Shore Baymen's Association and the Concerned Citizens of Montauk sued in Federal District Court in Uniondale in the fall to stop the dumping.
Those groups argued that dumping contaminated material in the Sound violated the Federal Ocean Dumping Act, which now includes the Sound.
The Army, the Navy and the Environmental Protection Agency, the original defendants, argued that the dumping complied with all Federal laws. The Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, at its request, later joined the defendants.
After weeks of hearings Judge Thomas C. Platt ruled that the dumping could proceed. He said the opponents had failed to show that irreparable harm would occur if the dumping continued. By the time of his ruling the work was nearly completed.
The opponents have subpoenaed a Navy report that catalogued contaminants near the Groton submarine base, a Federal Superfund site. Mr. Thatcher said the large report had information about highly toxic conditions in the Thames.
Mr. Rocque said he was familiar with the report. "Reports like that are used to inform us about what we should be looking for," he said. "But if you have a compound in the marine sediment that is chemically bonded to the sediment, the amount of the material is relatively irrelevant."
He said many contaminants were bonded to sediments and remained so even when dredged up and dumped in the Sound.
Opponents have sharply different views. Mr. Thatcher said that the Navy made no tests for dioxin and that the cost of the samples, $2,000, limited the opponents to one test. But he said the tests showed that a number of the compounds were dioxin.
Dioxin is a highly toxic synthetic carcinogen that affects reproduction in fish, birds and mammals. "We found enough to show the Navy should have taken dioxin tests," Mr. Thatcher said. "We should have to pay for this."
He said the groups had spent nearly $100,000 for legal fees and expert testimony in the case in Uniondale.

HEADLINE: School Districts Upset By Pataki Budget Plans

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
AT a time when school districts are experiencing increasing enrollments and decreasing revenues, Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed cuts in the state education budget are expected to compromise the ability of superintendents to maintain instruction and other services at present levels without raising property taxes -- a move that could be restricted by some of the Governor's proposals.
"Under the guise of protecting the local property owner, these proposals are shifting the burden of costs to local property owners," said Dr. Vincent Beni, Superintendent of the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services. "It's disingenuous. It's a very mean-spirited budget." 
 Although the state budget shows increased aid to 18 local districts, that is not quite the entire picture. What is at issue goes beyond a score card of which districts gain or lose in state-aid formulas.
"I could sit here and argue the pros and cons of specific proposals," said Dr. Stanley Toll, Superintendent of the Ardsley school district. "But in my view of the world, the entire package is polluted by two specific proposals: the supermajority requirement to pass a budget beyond the inflation rate, and the increase in aid to private and parochial schools. This is not very subtle. He's trying to turn around the decline in private and parochial schools and force the public schools to self-destruct. The Governor is trying to destroy public education in New York State."
Beyond the reductions in state aid to 22 local school districts for a combined $8.5 million loss, the Governor's proposed cuts in the state education budget, which were announced in mid-December, would affect special education and building aid, make reductions in the reimbursement levels that school districts receive for taking part in Board of Cooperative Educational Services programs, eliminate financing for teachers' centers and technology training and jeopardize others, like preschool education for disabled children and summer school programs for such youngsters.
Some educators estimate that the increased cost to state taxpayers would be at least $300 million.
"We're concerned about the cuts to Boces, special ed and the cap on building aid," said Lesley A. Purdy, district director for the Westchester Parent-Teacher Association. "We're watching what's going on."
During this budget preparation season, districts' energies have lately been focused on combatting those cuts and talking with state legislators. "We have been preoccupied with this for the last two weeks," said Dr. Anthony L. Mazzullo, Superintendent of the Greenburgh Central Seven school district. A community meeting last Wednesday, which was originally scheduled to inform the community on next year's budget projections, was used to discuss how the Governor's proposals would affect the district.
These cuts would lead to difficult choices for superintendents, who would have either to eliminate some programs or raise taxes to compensate for state reductions. Under the Governor's proposals, however, such tax increases would be sharply curtailed. He is seeking a requirement that would hold tax-rate increases to no more than the inflation rate unless a three-fifths majority of the voters approved a change.
"We're held to a rate-of-inflation increase with no accounting for increased enrollment or increased fixed costs," said Dr. Bruce Dennis, Superintendent of the Bedford public schools. "It would lead to an erosion of programs, and it spells bad news for us. Clearly, the effect on public education would be extremely harmful. A consequence would be to make public education less attractive to many people."
This so-called supermajority provision has raised fears among public school advocates that no future budgets could be adopted. Should a budget pass with less than a 60 percent majority, districts would be required to adopt austerity budgets.
"In effect, this gives a minority of voters the ability to block the budget," said Dr. Richard P. Mills, Commissioner of Education for the State of New York. "I disagree with that strategy. Maybe I'm old-fashioned, but I was taught that in a democracy the majority rules."
County education leaders are especially worried about this proposed requirement, given the difficulties many districts already face in gaining voter approval for school budgets.
"To require a 60 percent majority is an extreme requirement," said Dr. Ronald Valenti, Superintendent of the Harrison public schools and president of the Lower Hudson Council of School Superintendents, which represents 80 districts in Westchester, Putnam, Rockland and Dutchess Counties. "I don't know of any other level of government that has that requirement. There's no logic to it. It's difficult to pass budgets in Westchester as it is. This supermajority proposal is unreasonable and the height of hypocrisy."
Dr. Toll said: "There's a paradox that the Governor has created with this proposal. If you do what's good for the kids, a minority of people can reject your budget. And if you do what the naysayers want, you lose your supporters. That's a very, very horrible thing."
Cuts to Board of Cooperative Educational Services aid, for example, do more than simply shift costs back to the districts. "Districts spent money this year, expecting to get aid reimbursement," said Dr. Beni, who observed that Board of Cooperative Educational Services ran its programs at no increase in cost over last year and reduced its administrative expenses to the local districts by 20 percent. "That's a very difficult problem," Dr. Beni said. "Our job is not to keep ourselves in business but to share program quality. There has been a covenant between the state and the districts, where the incentive has been Boces aid. This will make districts very reluctant to participate in a Boces service. If some districts participate and others don't, we lose economies of scale. All the things that Boces does well become very fragile. Without the aid, our costs will start to creep up again."
Dr. Mazzullo said: "What the Governor has done is shift responsibility from the state to the local property owner. If this is a trend, it's the beginning of the end of public education in the state of New York. The script is analogous to what happened in California. I've never seen school districts thrown into such a tailspin.
"We're on an austerity budget this year. We don't want another budget defeat. We have increasing enrollment, increasing certioraris and deteriorating buildings. This is a conservative Republican ideology that shows how draconian these measures are."
Dr. Beni said: "The districts are caught in a three-way squeeze. State aid is being reduced, district enrollments are rising as revenues are falling and then strike three is the supermajority provision."

HEADLINE: Rethinking School Busing In Yonkers

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
FIFTEEN years after a landmark Federal desegregation lawsuit was filed in this racially divided city, the firebrand leader of the local branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has questioned whether busing students across town to achieve a racial balance in classrooms is still worth the time and trouble, to say nothing of the cost.
But the leader, Kenneth W. Jenkins, who has been suspended from his post by the N.A.A.C.P. for publicly challenging busing, is not the sole voice questioning some of the basic tenets of the court-ordered desegregation remedy here. 
 Nor is he the lone rebel who thinks the 87-year-old organization needs to shift at least some of its priorities from the issues that were paramount in the civil rights era to other goals now also important to blacks -- like achieving economic parity with whites.
But it was not just the dissenting nature of what Mr. Jenkins said that troubled fellow members of the N.A.A.C.P. The branch president announced that "busing had outlived its usefulness" less than a month before Election Day last fall in a joint news conference with the city's Mayor Terence M. Zaleski, who was waging a hard-fought and eventually unsuccessful battle for re-election.
"More so than the statement -- although that was not consistent with the organization's policy -- Mr. Jenkins was mixing politics with being president of the branch," said Winston A. Ross, director of the Westchester Region of the New York State Conference of the N.A.A.C.P. "It gave the appearance that he was endorsing a candidate."
Mr. Ross also criticized Mr. Jenkins for "speaking out of turn," because the Yonkers desegregation case is still in litigation.
The second phase of the court-ordered education remedy, to erase vestiges of segregation in the classroom, has yet to be put into effect. The school district is appealing the ruling by Judge Leonard B. Sand of United States District Court, which holds the city -- but not the state also -- financially responsible for carrying out that phase.
Mr. Ross said that Yonkers was a landmark desegregation case and that "any actions taken locally have broad consequences." He added, "Normally, the national organization would not step in on something like this."
A hearing was held by the N.A.A.C.P. on Jan. 26 to examine arguments in the matter and determine whether the branch president should be restored to office, disciplined or ordered to step down.
The national board, which has indicated that it would decide the outcome by next month, could also take over operation of the local branch for a period, said William H. Penn Sr., director of branches for the N.A.A.C.P.
One member of the local branch, Gail Baxter, said that membership is down in Yonkers and that the group is "rife with factions." Accusations against Mr. Jenkins were brought by 11 fellow branch members who signed a petition calling for the president's suspension.
Among them were Ms. Baxter and Herman Keith, a former head of the Yonkers N.A.A.C.P. and a former Westchester County Legislator from the 16th District in southwest Yonkers. Ms. Baxter and others said Mr. Jenkins damaged the organization's credibility by his actions.
But the 34-year-old Mr. Jenkins denies that he spoke without the backing of his executive board or that he was using the press conference for political purposes. He has also not backed down on his position on busing.
He said last week that the money Yonkers now spends to bus more than 17,000 of its 23,000 children to magnet schools around the city would be better spent on upgrading classrooms. The district spends a total of $13 million a year for busing, including transportation for special education and other students.
Mr. Jenkins said his statement on busing was consistent with a 1994 N.A.A.C.P. policy statement proclaiming that the organization is concerned not only with "dismantling the structure of segregation" but also with providing a quality education for all black students.
Noting that more than 70 percent of the student population in the Yonkers schools is so-called minority, he said: "So what if a classroom is all black? Does that mean it's bad? Can't you have excellence coming from that?
"What we really should be worrying about is whether African-American kids are getting the right education and going on to college and jobs."
Although many have taken issue with statements like that, there are those in the black and white communities who support Mr. Jenkins's position.
In New Jersey last fall, another N.A.A.C.P. chapter president rebelled against the national organization's policies by opposing a proposal to desegregate a high school in Englewood.
That official, Robert H. Robinson, president of the Bergen County chapter of the civil rights organization, wrote in a letter to the New Jersey State Board of Education: "Racial balance is not the important factor here, equal and quality education is. There are studies that show that an integrated school does not necessarily provide quality education."
In Yonkers 10 years after the judge ordered the schools integrated, many acknowledge that the effort has not led to improved academic performance by minority students.
Statistics show that black and Hispanic students score nearly two grade levels lower than whites on local standardized tests, with no progress since the early days of desegregation.
The numbers also show that white students receive the overwhelming share of high school Regents diplomas and that black and Hispanic students are suspended at a disproportionately higher rate than whites.
But Joseph M. Pastore Jr., the court-appointed monitor for the desegregation of the Yonkers schools, said studies now under way indicated that other factors are at work in determining test scores. Those studies, he said, show that minority students who have had "a continuous affiliation" with the public school system over the last decade are scoring well.
Conversely, those whose families move often and are new to the school system score poorly on standardized tests and other measurements.
He said the intent of desegregation was not to raise minority students' test scores: "The question of whether desegregation is helping or hurting in this regard is not relevant. The court's interest is a constitutional one."
But Andrea Stewart-Cousins, the newly elected County Legislator from Mr. Keith's old district, said the tenets of desegregation need to be re-evaluated periodically.
"If the doctor gave out a prescription 10 years ago, he would be very remiss not to reassess it every so often," she said. "It is the same thing with this city's desegregation order. It has been in place a decade, and it's time to see if the solution still fits the problem."
Busing, Ms. Stewart-Cousins said, was always just a means to an end -- a way for minorities on the west side to tap in to the better education that was being offered on the city's mostly white east side.
But many middle-class white families have abandoned the school system in Yonkers for private and parochial schools -- what Mr. Ross called the whites' "opportunity to walk because they can afford to." Statistics show that white enrollment in the public schools dropped to 30 percent in the last decade, from about 53 percent.
Ms. Stewart-Cousins, who has two children in the Yonkers school system, said, "So why are we getting our kids up two hours early to take a bus across town to sit next to someone they would have sat next to if they had stayed in our own neighborhood?"
Like others in Yonkers, the newly elected Mayor, John D. Spencer, said he would also like to see busing abandoned. He said that even though Mr. Jenkins made his comments with the former Mayor, "that did not take away from his message."
"Busing in and of itself does not provide for a better education," said Mr. Spencer, who said he met with more than 100 members of the Alliance of African-American Educators of Yonkers last week. The new Mayor said he wants to reunite the school and housing portions of the Federal desegregation order as they were 10 years ago. The two parts were separated when the school district complied immediately with its part of the order but the city resisted complying with its part for five years.
Meanwhile, the conflict over Mr. Jenkins's statements is being closely watched by N.A.A.C.P. members in neighboring communities.
Gerald M. Coleman, president of the Mount Vernon branch, said he empathized with Mr. Jenkins, whom he called "a firebrand like myself."
"What's occurring in the organization is a shift from the post-civil-rights era to a more diversified view -- a re-engineering of the N.A.A.C.P, a redefinition of purpose," Mr. Coleman said. "The old views are being nudged out by a younger group who wants to become part of the political process. Maybe Ken Jenkins picked the wrong time to say what he did, but I understand what he was saying."
In Mount Vernon, Wilhelmena Strong, coordinator of the membership drive in that city's branch of the N.A.A.C.P., said: "I don't see what he said as helping or hurting. Mr. Jenkins is just someone who had an idea and stumbled in a sense."
But, she cautioned: "The organization can't afford to drop anyone. We can't throw any of our young people away."

HEADLINE: VIEWPOINT;
Wrestling the Tax Devil We Know

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE B. GIBBS; Lawrence B. Gibbs is a member of the law firm of Miller & Chevalier in Washington and was Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service from 1986 until 1989. Frances B. Morgan, a lawyer with the firm, assisted in preparation of this article.

 BODY:
TWO hundred twenty years ago, our country went to war in part because of the unfairness of consumption taxes imposed by Britain upon her colonies. One hundred thirty-seven years later, in 1913, Americans went to the extraordinary length of amending the Constitution to replace domestic consumption taxes with the Federal income tax as the principal source of our nation's revenue. Since then, our income tax system has consistently raised the revenue needed to meet the Government's spending decisions. Through two world wars and a worldwide Depression, the income tax system has proven capable, flexible and dependable.
But today a national debate rages over whether we should retain this system or return to a consumption-based tax system. The decision is important and difficult and will affect every citizen and every business in this country. 
 The four proposals most prominently debated today -- the flat tax, the unlimited savings allowance tax, the value-added tax and the national retail sales tax -- have one shared feature (accomplished in different ways). None would tax the savings and investment income of individuals. Consequently, the proposals are variants of a consumption tax.
Proponents of consumption taxes argue that change is necessary because our income tax law has become too complicated, too burdensome, too intrusive as administered by the Internal Revenue Service, and too unfair to our citizenry. It was only nine years ago that I, then Commissioner of Internal Revenue, stood on the South Lawn of the White House to hear President Ronald Reagan proclaim that the newly enacted 1986 Tax Reform Act would make substantial changes in the income tax laws that were needed to restore "fairness, simplicity and economic growth." Now we are being told that our entire tax system must be replaced -- for reasons that do not differ much from the reasons given for the major changes we made over the last 20 years.
To be sure, our present tax law can be incredibly complex. At times, it can also apply unevenly and therefore unfairly among taxpayers. Because of certain biases in the present tax law, it can impede capital formation, encourage borrowing, discourage saving and diminish the competitiveness of American businesses in international markets. The I.R.S. is often its own worst enemy when it is unresponsive to taxpayers or deals with them in a heavy-handed way.
Even those, like the current Administration, who would choose to improve the present income tax system rather than adopt a consumption-based system agree that the structural deficiencies need to be addressed. The wisdom of taking a hard look at the present system is apparent. As a loyal supporter of my former agency, I endorse the view that the I.R.S. can and must improve the way it administers the tax law.
What is of deep concern, however, is that the present discussion of income tax versus consumption tax systems appears driven more by emotional attack and political agenda than by thoughtful analysis. No less disturbing is the recent spate of attacks on the I.R.S. Much of the rhetoric has been harsh, even provocative, like the headline in a weekly national magazine proclaiming "Death to the I.R.S." The Kemp Commission Report issued last month hints that the I.R.S. could be replaced by a "Taxpayer Protection Agency" whose purpose would be to assure that "no one pays more than is owed," but the report fails to explain how to assure that everyone pays what they owe.
To guarantee a reasoned and constructive national debate on the qualities we want in our tax system, it is imperative that all of us -- particularly our nation's leaders -- dispense with inflammatory assaults. Politically motivated attacks on our Government's programs and its agencies may carry an inordinately high price, as last year's Oklahoma City tragedy attests.
Although one would not know it from the rhetoric that speaks of "monstrous" complexity, the present income tax system is not, in fact, particularly complicated for the majority of Americans, especially the nearly three-quarters of taxpayers who claim the standard deduction instead of itemizing. The complexity faced by other individuals and business taxpayers is created primarily by two factors. The most important is the inherent complexity of our diverse, rapidly changing and sophisticated economy. The second is the degree to which Congress annually changes the tax laws to deal with the rising costs of Federal entitlement programs and the ever-higher interest costs of our increasing national debt.
To the extent that the tax law merely mirrors the complexity of our economy, it is doubtful that drastic simplification can be achieved by any tax system. To the extent that the complexity is driven by annual changes, if the United States gets its fiscal house in order, it is much more likely that some degree of the stability and simplification that we desire can be achieved with the present income tax system.
Proponents of consumption taxes are often critical of the so-called social engineering that is a perceived part of the current tax system. Some, for example, point to deductions for home mortgage interest and charitable contributions as unnecessary and inappropriate Government tax subsidies. Yet there is a longstanding public consensus in support of these deductions that suggests their repeal would cause economic dislocation and hardship. Over the last 80 years, the items of income and deduction that comprise the base of our Federal income tax system have become integrated into the United States economy. While some change in the tax base may be possible, a dramatic shift would undoubtedly have repercussions that could be quite damaging.
An example of this integration is the relationship between the Federal income tax system and the tax systems of our states and communities, whose taxes are often based on Federal law. So, too, are tax laws in many other countries, meaning that changes would have international ramifications, particularly for the business community.
It is remarkable that, thus far, the spotlight of public discussion has been focused on the rates of the various consumption tax proposals. But the key question in any comparison of alternative tax systems is not what the tax rate will be but rather what will and won't be taxed. The answer determines what will be included in the tax base, and the rate to be used will generally be a function of how much revenue must be raised.
Detractors of the present system assume that a new, untested tax base could be substituted for the current one and raise the same amount of revenue based on a particular rate schedule, but in the final analysis, this is more likely to be a leap of faith than a plausible revenue estimate.
In truth, we have taken for granted too long and too blithely the capabilities of our present tax system. For all its faults, the United States tax system is the envy of much of the world. We ought not exchange the tax devil we know for one we do not until we are confident that the new system is likely to work at least as well. The devil is in the details of tax base, not tax rates. Sound-bite tax proposals that promise easy solutions to hard problems are not the way to go.

HEADLINE: Neighborhood Report;
The Gritty and the Gentry Battle for a Waterfront's Soul

BYLINE: By MARK FRANCIS COHEN 

 BODY:
Pockets of homes dot the industrially dominated streets of western Red Hook, where ships' men once lived and maritime voyagers slept. Today the link between home and work is gone: most residents work away from the area and the small-business owners largely live outside the neighborhood.
The tension has grown as residents who have moved in over the last five years or so seek to transform the commercial character of the waterfront neighborhood into a mixed-use enclave. What used to be common practices for the existing manufacturing and trucking businesses are now regarded as intolerable by residents, some of whom have started organized campaigns against the businesses. 
 They complain about noise coming from inside the ruddy red-brick walls of the squat warehouses, and pollution emitted by idling trucks. "In the beginning, nobody bothered us," said Archie Blandford, the owner of Blandford Construction, which has been in Red Hook for 10 years. "Now they have started a petition to get me removed."
Many light manufacturers said residents might drive them out by rezoning efforts or harassment. "Every time you make a noise around here, someone is calling a city agency to stop you," said Fred Marckesano, owner of Harbor Side Truck Repair. "It would be better to turn it all commercial and let the residents go through attrition."
Business leaders contend that the fight was formalized last year when residents proposed, and the community board approved, a zoning plan to restrict the commercial sector by making more housing available. The City Planning Commission asked Community Board 6 to revise the plan after business representatives complained at a public hearing.
The plan was started in 1993 under provision 197-a of the 1989 City Charter, authorizing communities to map their own future, and Red Hook became the first to make such a large-scale plan. There was, however, no business representative on the rezoning steering committee.
Frustrated residents said developers had been consulted during the planning and only recently voiced opposition to the proposal. Residents have stopped another plan by business leaders, the creation of a business improvement district.
"They used this BID to try to take over the community," said Susan Peebles, a resident involved in the rezoning. Ms. Peebles said that businesses were welcome, since they kept the area safe during the day, but that many buildings would stay empty unless they could be converted into housing. "You walk around here and say, 'Where are the businesses?' " she said.
Lisa Tennyson, a community development director for the South Brooklyn Economic Development Corporation, says there are more than 300 businesses in Red Hook employing at least 3,000 people. "Buildings look vacant but many aren't," she said. "A lot don't advertise themselves because they don't want to advertise what they have inside."
Still, business operators said they were considering leaving because whatever plan moves ahead, an industrial work environment is inherently inhospitable to residents. "Would you stay where you aren't wanted?" asked Mike DiPierri, the owner of R & S Trucking. "I'll end up moving to New Jersey. Who needs the aggravation?" MARK FRANCIS COHEN

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I'll end up moving to New Jersey," said Mike DiPierri, outside his company, R & S Trucking in Red Hook. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Neighborhood Report;
Bakery Stays In Jamaica

BYLINE: By Mark Francis Cohen 

 BODY:
The future of the Continental Baking plant and its 450 employees was imperiled last July when Interstate Bakeries Corporation took over the South Jamaica company and decided it had one too many baking facilities in the Northeast.
But because of lobbying by the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, officials at Interstate decided instead to close its East Brunswick, N.J., bakery and expand operations at the Jamaica plant, creating 100 more jobs. 
 "It is a significant victory to retain them and to see them expand," said Carlisle Towery, the president of the nonprofit development corporation. "This is particularly delightful since New York is losing manufacturing."
Interstate's South Jamaica plant bakes and distributes Hostess and Wonder Bread products for the New York region. Company officials said they plan to invest $8 million into the plant at 168-23 Douglas Avenue to start producing a new line of rolls. In return, Interstate, the largest wholesale baking corporation in the country, will get at least $2 million in tax credits, because the Jamaica plant is in a state economic development zone.
Mr. Towery said he quickly approached the company, arguing that it should keep the plant running in Jamaica because of its proximity to Long Island, the two New York airports and a labor pool accustomed to working in food industries.
City officials also lobbied the company and said they were pleased that it decided to stay in Jamaica.
"Are you kidding me, 440 jobs?" said Rudy Washington, the commissioner of the city's Department of Business Services. "There was no way were going to let them go." MARK FRANCIS COHEN

HEADLINE: Three Views, No Agreement

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
IS a recession coming? How much will the Fed ease, and what will that do for the stock and bond markets? During a week in which the Fed cut short-term interest rates a bit, and which ended with a surprisingly weak employment report, we put the questions to three leading Wall Street economists -- Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley; Philip Braverman of DKB Securities, a part of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan, and Robert J. Barbera of Capital Investments International. We found big disputes on the past as well as the future, with one panel member saying workers were going to start scoring big wage gains and another arguing that workers had not done that badly in recent years, whatever the statistics say.
 
Q. The European economy seems to be weak. Christmas sales were atrocious in this country. Is there a danger that we're going to have an election-year recession?
ROACH I don't think so. The fears of recession are overblown. I think we're in a long business cycle expansion. I just got back from Europe, and it's weak but it's not falling out of bed. The core of Europe counts for about 14 percent of global G.D.P. The other 86 percent is growing -- it's not booming. Christmas was weak in the U.S., if you talk to the department stores and the specialty retailers. But if you talk to a broad array of other industries that deal in consumer-sensitive demands ranging from home electronics to airlines, business was O.K. This is certainly not a boom, but it's not a bust. And I'm just a believer that expansions do not die a natural death. In the end they are murdered by the Fed, and the Fed is not holding the gun.
BARBERA I agree that expansions don't die a natural death. The Fed murders them. Sometimes, though, I think it's an inadvertent event. In the current environment, you can make the case that the Fed is very tight. The Fed doubled short rates in 1994 and has really given very little of that back.
 
Q. So it's involuntary manslaughter?
BARBERA Well, Alan Greenspan has erred before. To err is human. And to err twice is to run the Fed, I guess. The risk is that the Fed is too tight. I don't think we'll have a recession because I expect more aggressive Fed easing.
BRAVERMAN It's a tough call. We've moved to a disinflationary environment in which business is shifting production to lower-cost labor pools. Consumers have a sense of distrust for the future that they haven't previously experienced. They have very little in the way of income growth in real terms. The consumer, who represents two-thirds of the U.S. economy, is at least holding back, restraining spending. Things are going to be even tougher in 1996, particularly in the first half. We have too much inventory. Consumers are cutting back their spending. We have a decline in mortgage rates, but housing is not improving. We have huge excess capacity, not only here but around the world. So I see one of the mainstays of the expansion thus far, capital investment, slowing up. I see Government cutting back its spending.
Is the economy vulnerable to recession? Yes. Will it actually go into it? It's a tough call, but I think the economy will slow to the extent that we will move to the brink of recession. My view is that in the first half of this year we'll have G.D.P. growth of only about half a percent.
The consumer has increased borrowing as an end run around the absence of income growth. But it appears that option is being foreclosed to a considerable extent.
 
Q. The option is being foreclosed? I still get plenty of offers for new credit cards.
BRAVERMAN I know. But we have an increase in delinquency rates on installment credit and on mortgages. We're beginning to see a rise in consumer bankruptcies. And in the last Fed survey of bank lending patterns there was, for the first time, an indication that they are beginning to be shy about lending to consumers. So there's a combination of factors that have already reduced the pace of borrowing.
ROACH I've got to jump in. This notion that consumers are over extended is overblown. I think we're early in the debt cycle, not late in the debt cycle. The way you measure the burden of leverage on borrowers is not by the volume of debt they have outstanding. You don't pay off your credit card balance each month out of your current income flow. You pay the interest expenses associated with that. Mortgage and installment credit combined are well below the highs of the second half of the 1980's. Consumers are not at the brink.
These are tough times in terms of job and income security, but the system is generating enough in the way of purchasing power growth to enable consumers to deliver a reasonable rate of rise in spending. And I don't share the notion that there's weakness everywhere, either. I think that our export sector, capital spending sector and the housing sector will be reasonably firm in 1996.
BARBERA I think that Steve is right, that it is debt burden, not debt levels that matter. But obviously you affect debt burdens when you change short-term interest rates. And you did have a doubling of short-term interest rates in 1994. It's critically important to provide substantial rate relief to lower those debt burdens and allow consumers to return to putting more of their cash into purchases rather than into debt service.
 
Q. There's another way that consumers can get money besides borrowing it. It's called earning it. The statistics on real income growth have looked bad for years. Will that change soon?
ROACH Yes. We have gone too far in squeezing the worker to boost corporate profitability and competitiveness. I just came back from Asia, where a third of the world is perceived to be toiling for a bowl of rice for a day's wage, and therefore no wage increase is ever going to take place in this environment. But the relatively unskilled, undertrained, inexperienced Chinese worker does not compete with the machinist at Boeing who just successfully held out for a significant increase in real wages for the first time in several years. I think we're going to see more of that in the U.S. economy because pay rates over the past five years have now been squeezed so that they are running below the productivity curve and economic theory suggests that workers should be paid their marginal productivity contribution.
At a time when everybody is cracking out the champagne and celebrating the death of inflation, which is truly the view in the financial markets right now, I think we're going to be surprised that labor may have the final say on that in the years ahead.
BARBERA But your point is that they should get, at a minimum, the wage increase that allows them to benefit from their productivity contribution, which wouldn't generate any inflation.
ROACH If in fact wages were equal to productivity, then real labor cost growth would stay forever at zero. But wages have now gone so far below the productivity curve, I think the risk is, in a fully employed labor market, and, in my view, of an expanding global economy, that we're going to get into a period where wages move back above the productivity curve for a while for some of our more skilled irreplaceable occupations and that will bring the long-dormant wage cycle back to life at a time when no one thinks it can happen.
BARBERA That begs another question, which is where we are in terms of the domestic employment situation. Over the past 12 months we had a substantial slowing in employment growth but no change in the unemployment rate until the January jump we just saw, because there was less participation in the labor force. I find that too convenient to sound right. We saw precisely the same thing in 1989: a sharp slowing in household employment, sharp slowing in labor force participation and no apparent rise in the unemployment rate. There's substantially more slack in the economy today than there was 12 months ago, a consequence of a material slowdown in employment growth, even if you look at January's plunge with a jaundiced eye. Some increase in wages is a very legitimate event in light of the productivity gains that we've seen. But I don't see any rampant wage-generated inflation pressures because a year-plus of very slow growth has, as I see it, raised the de facto slack in the U.S. labor market.
 
Q. Phil, can I hope for a raise?
BRAVERMAN Well, you can hope. But that's about the extent of it. We happen to be somewhere in the middle on labor costs. The Germans are at the top end of the range with probably somewhere in the neighborhood of $23 to $26 an hour. The Japanese are close to $20, Americans, $17 an hour. And the Chinese, 54 cents. Now in between there are a lot of efficient, skilled workers available at $5 an hour in Hong Kong and Korea and Taiwan.
But it is inevitable that Americans, who are competing not only with the Japanese and Germans and are in a favorable position relative to that competition, but an unfavorable position relative to most of the rest of the world, are running nervous and scared and are literally losing jobs as production and services gradually shift away. Yes, we are gaining to some extent from Japanese and German companies. But the general sense of insecurity that is taking place in the hearts and minds of most American workers is a key element in causing this slowdown in spending. It's not, in a recession, the people who are unemployed that cause the reduction in spending as much as it is the people who are employed who fear they may become unemployed that call a halt to the postponable spending. And that's what we're beginning to see now.
BARBERA There is also the issue of what's going on with real wages in the U.S. I have become one of the proponents of the notion that the Consumer Price Index is overstated and that it's gotten substantially worse over the last 10 years. If you believe that a consequence of the big move into high-technology equipment, a big move toward quality improvements rather than quantity, is to substantially overstate the C.P.I. . . .
ROACH How much? Give us a ball park.
BARBERA Leonard Nakamura at the Philly Fed thinks that it's about 2 1/2 to 3 percent.
ROACH A year?
BARBERA At present you essentially have more than a hundred percent of the measured inflation as measurement error.
ROACH So we've been in a period of deflation for how long?
BARBERA He would say that we're right now slightly in deflation.
ROACH Do you actually believe that?
BARBERA I think that inflation is overstated by two percentage points. Do you actually believe that there's been no contribution from technological improvement over the last 15 years?
ROACH I think the technological contribution has just started to click in. To just surmise that we have been riding the crest of this wonderful information age for 15 to 20 years and the productivity benefits have been accruing for all of us for the entire period is wrong.
BARBERA Look at medical care, for instance. Look at the extraordinary advances that have gone on in medical technology, and you realize that all of those advances are measured as inflation. It appears, according to official Government data, that we're spending more and more and more for less medical care due to the methodology that the C.P.I. uses. The reason I bring it up is it's interesting that there has not been any substantial and dramatic saber rattling within the labor markets despite what appears in the official data to be a devastation of real wages. I would submit that's because inflation is overstated significantly and real wages have been rising at about the trend rate that you saw in the previous period.
ROACH I would submit, to the contrary, that Bill Clinton was elected in 1992 under the campaign credo of putting people first and that there is a strong sense of malaise and concern over stagnant real wages in the United States. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has just elected the most militant leader in about 40 years, John Sweeney.
Let's look at a few other facts that I think really underscore the fact that this system is not delivering as we thought it should. The widening of the inequalities of income distribution in the 1990's is without precedent in the post-World War II history of the U.S. economy. The share of national income going to the owners of capital through corporate profits is surging. The share going to compensation is falling. This is not the way a democracy is supposed to work. This is not the way our free-enterprise capital system is supposed to allocate its income. So, a very small slice of America is benefiting from the competitive revival and the new-found prosperity. I think the second half of the 1990's is going to be about shifting the benefits of this productivity recovery to the workers who have made the contribution, and so I think we're going to see more in the way of real wage increases going forward than we have seen in the past decade.
BRAVERMAN The problem is that most economists continue to view the U.S. economy the way they had when we were less exposed to an international competitive threat. We are now part of a global economy. We don't have the control, labor doesn't have the control, management doesn't have the control. The U.S. Government doesn't have the control. We are an open society. Not as much as we may be in some period ahead, but far more than we have been. Over a billion workers have been added to the labor force of the world.
ROACH But what do they do? I mean, do these workers have the same skill set that, say, a machinist does who's assembling aircraft for Boeing? Do the Chinese really compete with Boeing's machinists?
BRAVERMAN You use one of the few areas where the United States or a U.S. company has five years' worth of orders and is one of the premiere producers. Those workers producing for that particular company, in a particular industry, yes, still have a fair amount of clout. But you can't use that, what I view as a pretty isolated case, as a demonstration for the U.S.
ROACH I'll tell you why I can. The process of corporate restructuring, which has been under way since the mid-1980's, is aimed at producing exactly the type of example that we're seeing in Boeing. Boeing is a byproduct of a successful restructuring. And company after company has followed the same model. They're left with a core of workers that they need to deliver into their expanding global marketplace. And they have to pay those workers what those, that core of their workers, are contributing. And that's why management elected to pay the machinists a real wage increase at Boeing for the first time in several years. I think you're going to see more of that down the road.
BRAVERMAN There are spots here and there where highly skilled workers are in relatively short supply in business. But the essence of business is to operate as lean as it possibly can. Companies don't have the ability to pass price increases through. And because they don't have that ability, they are downsizing, outsourcing and cutting fringe benefits and shifting production outside the U.S., if that's efficient. So the employees are more nervous. And because they're more nervous, not experiencing the income growth or the job security, they are holding back on their spending. That makes them very price sensitive. And that creates a virtuous inflation circle.
 
Q. I'm not sure workers find it that virtuous.
BRAVERMAN Well, it's virtuous from the point of view of inflation being an evil. But this deflation can also be an evil.
BARBERA The single best measure indicating that downsizing has only benefited the corporate sector is that real wages have gone nowhere for 15 years. But my contention is that the C.P.I. is meaningfully overstated and therefore the real wage numbers have been substantially better, which means that downsizing is what it was supposed to be in the textbooks -- bad for you in the short run, because you lose your job, good for you in the intermediate term because productivity goes up and real wages go up and living standards go up. Now there is a shift, no question, from wages to profits in terms of share of income. However, we had an extraordinary decline in profits from 1966 to 1982, and we're about two-thirds of the way back to where we were in 1966.
 
Q. Let me ask about a different kind of prices, bond prices. Should I buy bonds?
BRAVERMAN Yes, definitely. I think most of the economic statistics overstate the health of the U.S. economy and overstate inflation. I would say that we are already seeing a C.P.I., if it were properly measured, somewhere in the neighborhood of 2 percent. If you take historical norms over the last 200 years, when inflation wasn't running up the way it did in the 70's and 80's, we only got to current levels of bond yields in the midst of war, and a wartime inflationary environment, or in financial panics. Right now, we are talking about Treasury bond yields at 6 percent, substantially above the median of 4 1/4 percent of that 200-year experience. And if you take the historical relationships to inflation . . .
ROACH What was the average budget deficit share of G.D.P. over the 200-year period?
BRAVERMAN Well, we were running budget deficits in the Civil War, in the War of 1812 and we still got bond yields of only 6 percent, where we are now.
 
Q. Most of that time we also had the dollar anchored to the price of gold.
BRAVERMAN There is no doubt that there were some unique advantages. But inflation, I look to be this year in the neighborhood of 2, 2 1/2 percent. Historical norm would suggest something in the neighborhood of 2 1/2 to at most 3 percent for the real rate, which would give you a 5 to 5 1/2 percent bond yield range this year. So, potentially, a full percentage point under current levels.
ROACH I think that there is one more leg to this rally in bonds as long as the Fed is perceived to be in a fairly aggressive easing mode, as is the case right now. I think that bond yields will fall lower, possibly down to 5 1/2 percent near term. But I would argue that that rally will be short-lived. And that investors should sell into that rally because I think the markets are just too bulled up on the notion that the economy is going to flirt with recession and that inflation is dead and that meaningful deficit reduction is at hand. In all three of those counts the markets are going to end up being disappointed. I see bond yields moving back toward 7 percent in the second half of this year.
BARBERA I'm quite concerned because our bond market bear has them at 5 1/2 percent near term. That gives me pause. The best friend that the bond had, in the second half of last year, was the Fed, which dragged its feet and extended this period of economic weakness. I believe the Fed is going to be a lot more aggressive in its easing in the first half of this year, and as a consequence, I think there's a lot less to the bond rally in the first half of this year than there was in the second half of last. Dare I mention stocks?
 
Q. I haven't heard a number on bonds yet.
BARBERA I'd say, maybe we'll get to 5 3/4 percent on the long bond. In the second half you'll probably have rising rates. Likewise in the equity market in the second half of last year, economically sensitive stocks had a disastrous relative performance. The rise for the stock market masked a sharp signal of cyclical deterioration. I would think with a more aggressive Fed, that trend reverses and in the first half of this year, economically sensitive stocks do substantially better.
 
Q. And the overall market?
BARBERA Modestly up.
 
Q. Anyone else care to forecast stocks?
ROACH We've been bullish on the stock market at Morgan Stanley for about four years, and my colleague Byron Wien is of the view that we've got one more leg to go in this stock rally. But he shares my view that a rise in long-term interest rates, which will occur in the second half of this year, is a distinct negative for stocks. We look for a sharp correction, in excess of 20 percent, in the second half of 1996.
BRAVERMAN Since I think the economy will slow and corporate earnings with it, even though I look for a very substantial decline in interest rates, which has been a positive for stocks, I think that by July the stock market will be hurt by failing expectations for earnings. That will cause a retrenchment in equities, perhaps 5 to 10 percent.
 
Q. The Federal funds rate, which is the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, was cut to 5.25 percent from 5.5 percent last week. How low will it go?
BRAVERMAN I look for the Fed to reduce it to 4 1/2 percent before Labor Day and to cut it further after the election.
ROACH I think the Fed is not going to cut the funds rate even close to what Phil indicated and not as much as what the bond market is clearly expecting. If the economy does O.K. and if wage trends continue to tick up as they have been doing over the last 24 months and if the global economy comes out of this mid-cycle pause, I think the Fed will actually shock the markets by contemplating a tightening in the second half of this year.
BARBERA I guess it comes down to whether you think the U.S. economy in 1995 slowed as a consequence of monetary policy. My sense is a doubling of short rates from 3 to 6 percent on Fed funds is the reason you had a sharp slowing in everything you can measure in the U.S. economy in 1995. And then you've got to erase about half of that to put you back on a firmer trend for real economic growth. So 3 to 6 to slow it down; 6 to 4 1/2 to rev it up some.
 
Q. Thanks. I'm absolutely confident you're not all right.

HEADLINE: Neighborhood Report;
Madison Ave.: Ever Chichi, Soon Safer

BYLINE: By Bruce Lambert 

 BODY:
Madison Avenue ranks among the world's premier shopping streets. Fashionable and famous emporiums like Polo, Armani and Barneys draw the rich and the recognized, as do the avenue's art galleries and restaurants. Rents for retail space are in league with those for stores on Fifth Avenue, 57th Street and the Ginza in Tokyo.
But two years ago the shooting of two customers in a robbery at the exclusive Vera Wang bridal salon, at 77th Street, shocked merchants, moving them to form a business improvement district, the first large one approved by the Council after it lifted a moratorium on new districts so it could study abuses at existing ones and recommend changes. "It is sorely needed to maintain the area's position," said the head of the Madison Avenue Merchants Association, Alexander Kabbaz, who is expected to head the new district when it starts operating in September. 
 Violent crime remains rare on Madison Avenue, so the district's planned 17-member security force will focus on deterring purse snatchings, pickpocketing, shopping-bag theft, car theft, burglaries and shoplifting.
"We're hoping this will make the shopping district more attractive, giving back the services the city used to give us 20 years ago," said Michael Goodrich, owner of Spectra electronics, near 65th Street. And Murray Shapiro, vice president of Zitomer, a pharmacy and specialty store between 75th and 76th Streets, says he is certain the district will make the avenue "cleaner, safer, more visible, more inviting -- and more profitable -- if that's not too gauche to say."

HEADLINE: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
Here's a Way to Diversify, With Training Wheels

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN 

DATELINE: New Canaan, Conn.

 BODY:

Q. I've been hearing a lot about so-called life-style funds that are supposedly well-suited to retirement planning. Are they worth investigating? ALIZANNE FORRESTER 

A. They may be, especially if you're among the millions of United States workers who plan to live off their 401(k) plans after retiring. When you add up your projected expenses and take inflation into account, you may find that the amount you've salted away so far is barely enough to season a large order of french fries.
Not saving enough, of course, is part of the problem. But another big reason is that two-thirds of all 401(k) money is tied up in fixed-income instruments like bonds, money market accounts and guaranteed investment contracts -- safe, yes, but hardly big moneymakers. Once you stop working, you'll probably need a lot more than the payout from a 401(k) loaded with such conservative choices if you want to maintain your current life style.
This nettlesome problem can be addressed with a financial tuneup. For some people, particularly those who don't want to be bothered with financial planning and sophisticated investment choices, life-style funds may offer a limited solution. Also called life-cycle funds, lifepath funds or theme funds, these portfolios are usually well-diversified and specifically matched to an investor's age group, risk tolerance, financial objectives and time horizon.
The idea is simple: different blends of investments for different stages of life. It's basically the same concept as cycle dog food, only for investors, not canines.
Life-style funds put your money to work in more than one type of asset -- stocks and bonds, mostly. The mix is weighted toward stocks for younger and more risk-tolerant investors and toward bonds for older, more conservative ones. Other investors can choose a fund equally divided between stocks and bonds. Some funds gradually shift toward safer, fixed-income securities based on your age or the fund's target date.
The three Time Horizon funds from BankAmerica are intended for people with 10, 20 or 30 years to invest. Others, like Putnam's Lifestage funds, come in growth, balanced and conservative versions so you make your choice based on your risk level rather than simply on your age.
A life-style fund is perhaps best suited for aging baby boomers looking to save for retirement. By putting these investors at least partly into stocks, a life-style fund offers the prospect of healthier returns than could be squeezed from an all-bond portfolio, while the fund's fixed-income component provides a cushion against market volatility. The fund managers also do all the thinking, watch the markets and make the picks -- for a management fee similar to what most any fund would charge. For a novice investor, that can be an advantage.
"The industry is offering what it should have sold all along: an actively managed product targeted toward a time line," said Geoffrey Bobroff, a financial services consultant in East Greenwich, R.I. He predicted that life-style funds would make up as much as a quarter of the equity fund exposure in 401(k) plans within five years.
Much of that growth, if it materializes, will come from inexperienced investors fretting about rock-bottom interest rates on bank certificates of deposit.
Though nervous about gambling, neophytes are often equally concerned that their play-it-safe mentality may keep them from realizing adequate returns. A life-style fund can help them take the plunge -- or at least wade in up to their knees. According to J. Carter Beese Jr., a former member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, life-style funds teach participants the merits of allocating money to different asset classes. "They realize that this is an ongoing process and that there's a difference between saving and investing," Mr. Beese said.
Before investing in a life-style fund, you might keep a few things in mind.
For starters, the funds are too new to have established a meaningful track record, though initial overall performance has been less than stellar. Nor does their mix-and-match approach to investing make it easy to compare them with other funds, or even with one another.
Moreover, for all the talk about matching plans to people, life-style portfolios often reflect a one-size-fits-most approach that can do more harm than good.
Some skeptics question the funds' underlying assumption that the older you are, the more you should tilt toward bonds and away from stocks. Age and risk intolerance are not always synonymous, said Gary Lineberry, vice president of Met Life's defined-contribution group. One 50-year-old investor, for example, may have a substantial retirement account after doing a lot of planning and saving. But another investor of the same age may have accumulated far less because of many job changes and may be eager to make up for lost opportunities in a shorter time.
In addition, some people think it's not such a good idea to relinquish control of your assets to a fund manager. You may be spared the trouble of making your own picks, but you also give up much freedom and flexibility. As long as you're taking the trouble to shop for a life-style fund, this argument goes, you could spend a bit more time to construct a portfolio that is better suited to your needs.
For people who are already comfortable managing their own investments, a life-style fund will seem about as necessary as asking a flight attendant to direct them to seat 4A on a 737. But for novices, it may be a sensible way to make a first venture into the stock market.

HEADLINE: Anarchy in America?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, Jan. 28) suggests that Africa is "a freshman Republican's paradise" because there are no taxpayers to finance a welfare state: that "in Rwanda and Burundi, no one is asked to pay for Head Start," and that, instead, the Tutsi and the Hutu revert to genocide "to grab more resources." 
 Does Mr. Friedman really believe that 8 percent increases in Medicare spending mean civilization in America but that 4 percent increases foretell barbarism?
Does a free-market economy suppose anarchy?
The United States, as Mr. Friedman observes, is a special place. His commentary helps shred that something special to which we are all devoted.
