HEADLINE: Remember 1987 Peak? It's Nearly Doubled

 BODY:
It was during a period of speculative frenzy that the Dow Jones industrial average hit a record of 2,722.42 on a summer day in 1987. Within a few months, after share prices crashed, money managers could be heard muttering they would never again let valuations grow so excessive.
Now, eight and a half years later, the Dow is on the verge of doubling that figure, having topped 5,400 on Thursday. Investors who held on after the crash have long since felt vindicated. Those who bought after the crash are even happier. The Dow is more than three times as high as it was then. 
 Have those gains exceeded rationality, as happened in the summer of 1987? Certainly there has been plenty of good news: Interest rates are down and corporate profits are up. But stock market valuation measures are strained, at best, even though Wall Street has lots of reasons why they don't matter.
In 1987, as shares moved to dizzying heights, there was talk that the bull market could not end quickly, because everyone knew that in the final blowout phase, it is the small speculative stocks that go up the most. And small stocks were lagging badly, as they are now. The Dow was up 3.5 percent last month; the Russell 2,000 index was down a bit.
What happened then, and appears to be happening now, says Steve Leuthold, the Minneapolis value maven, is capitulation by cautious money managers. They are investing the cash they had accumulated, fearing that otherwise they will be left in the performance-derby dust if share prices keep rising. The amount of uninvested cash in mutual funds devoted to American stocks jumped 23 percent, or $15.4 billion, in the final quarter of 1995. Now it is being spent.
When such a buying panic hits, the fastest way to get money to work is to buy stock index futures, which are also nice if you can't find any particular stocks worth buying. Through the magic of program trading and index arbitrage, that buying gets translated into the purchase of big stocks, which then become the best performers.
Mutual fund investing may make it easier to ignore valuation measures. The buyer is looking for past performance, not current fundamentals. Studying those is the job of the manager running the fund. And most of those managers figure that it is their job to invest the money given to them, not to let cash pile up for long.
Mr. Leuthold is an exception. He figures the market is about 5 percent more overvalued now than it was at the 1987 peak, but he has started a mutual fund anyway. The Leuthold Asset Allocation Fund has less than a quarter of its assets in stocks, with the rest in cash and bonds. Its performance will be pitiful if the bull keeps raging.
When will this end? Not until the money stops pouring into the market. The demographic factors are clearly bullish, with retirement worries prompting more and more baby boomers to invest. And with bond yields down and savings accounts paying little, the stock market can look like the only hope for good returns.
Worries about recession traditionally kill bull markets. But in 1990, the stock market did not turn down until the recession had begun, rather than months before. Now there is great faith that the Federal Reserve will do just the right thing to keep the economy growing for many years to come, so no recession is likely. Could the stock market be surprised again?
At these valuation levels, such a surprise could be very painful.

HEADLINE: Neighborhood Report;
Troubled Haven, Now Bankrupt, Still Fighting to Survive

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
In 1972, Joyce Hartwell set up a school on Avenue B to teach carpentry and plumbing to inner-city women. Today, Ms. Hartwell's Lady Carpenter institute has expanded into the All-Craft Center, a sprawling complex of buildings on St. Marks Place offering social services that help, among others, abused children, recovering drug addicts and former prison inmates with AIDS.
But over the years, government officials have criticized All-Craft for sloppy record-keeping, and nearby residents have complained that center clients clog sidewalks and disturb neighbors with late-night noise. 
 Now, after serving thousands of clients in crisis, Ms. Hartwell is facing one of her own: a financial one. Saddled with over $1 million in debt, Ms. Hartwell, 57, nearly lost her buildings last month at a city auction because one of her creditors won a judgment against her organization. Ms. Hartwell was able to stave off the sale at the last minute by filing for bankruptcy protection.
While she may have bought a reprieve, Ms. Hartwell is still trying to keep her agency afloat with her only remaining income source, the $80,000 a year she says is collected from renting out space in her hulking collection of buildings that stretch from 19 to 25 St. Marks Place, between Second and Third Avenues. All-Craft now gets by without a paid staff, and Ms. Hartwell scrimps for light bulbs and toilet paper.
Her buildings are in desperate need of repair: last June, a Civil Court judge sentenced her to 30 days on Rikers Island for neglecting her property. And three tenants she inherited when All-Craft bought the buildings in 1978 stopped paying rent a decade ago to protest what they say are a lack of basic services.
Despite these troubles, Ms. Hartwell is pressing forward with ideas to bring All-Craft to solvency. With the help of an unidentified investment banker, Ms. Hartwell, an interfaith minister, says she will establish a coffee house and a New Age cabaret on the ground floor.
"There are some people who only want us to fail," she said last week, "but if they give us a chance, our businesses will bring enormous economic benefit to the entire neighborhood."
An imposing woman who dresses in flowing black frocks and a clerical collar, Ms. Hartwell faces a chorus of neighborhood critics who call the All-Craft Center is a blight on St. Marks Place.
"All we want is a good neighbor, but every time you try talking to Joyce, she gets defensive and says you're trying to get rid of her," said Kate Walter, chairwoman of the local block association.
Ms. Hartwell dismisses such complaints as racist. "I think people are just afraid because our clients are mostly minority," she said.
Over the years, the government money that kept All-Craft afloat dried up, because of budget cuts or because she failed to maintain the records that agencies require.
"Ms. Hartwell is a people person, not a paper person," said Dan McGill of the state's Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse, which stopped funds for All-Craft in 1993 because of budget constraints and concerns about its fiscal viability.
For the 10 youths and 18 recovering addicts from all parts of the city who live at All-Craft, Ms. Hartwell's money problems are worrisome. Fleeing an abusive father, Nelson Carrion, 19, has lived at the center since he was 10.
"If this place wasn't here, we'd be on the street or in jail," he said. "Joyce keeps us out of trouble." ANDREW JACOBS

HEADLINE: The Magellan Fund Enters Its Next Phase: Cyclical Stocks

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
AMID all the market fascination about whether the Fidelity Magellan fund is buying or selling technology stocks, it's easy to forget that the $54 billion behemoth has anything else in its portfolio.
But by its most recent tally, the Magellan fund had holdings of cyclical stocks -- those of construction companies, manufacturers of industrial machinery and makers of durable goods like textiles, home furnishings and automobiles -- totaling nearly 24 percent of assets, only slightly less than the fund's technology stake. That was at the end of November, and in the last two months of 1995, the fund added substantially to some cyclical stocks, according to regulatory filings. Along the way, it may well have trimmed its technology position even further. 
 So everyone interested in what sector will replace technology as the favorite of Jeffrey N. Vinik, who has made some big sector bets as the manager of Magellan and of previous funds, will want to take a close look at the cyclicals. While some managers fleeing the technology stocks have been turning to drug companies and financial companies -- both of which have had a good run already -- Magellan seems to be leaning toward a basic bet on a strengthening economy. And because it is the nation's largest mutual fund, its moves are closely watched -- and sometimes considered a market indicator.
For many months, Mr. Vinik has sung the praises of the cyclicals, which rise and fall with the economy. Caterpillar, for instance, the tractor and heavy-equipment maker, has been among the fund's top 10 holdings for more than six months.
Back in June, before Fidelity Investments muzzled its mutual fund managers, Mr. Vinik predicted in a speech in New York that the outlook for Caterpillar and similar stocks was particularly good because, he believed, the Federal Reserve would lower short-term interest rates "very soon and very rapidly over the next several months."
While his timing was a bit off, Mr. Vinik's thesis was essentially correct: Weakness in the domestic economy would lead the central bank to ease the access to cash. Last week, the Federal Reserve lowered two key short-term interest rates, the second round of rate cuts in less than two months.
Next week, Fidelity will disclose Magellan's asset allocation at the end of 1995, but some of the fund's recent moves can already be discerned from filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
In the last two months of 1995, Magellan greatly increased its holdings of several cyclical companies, including the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, inventor of the familiar pink insulation material used in home construction; A. Schulman Inc., a maker of plastic compounds sold to the auto, electronics and agricultural industries; the Sherwin-Williams Company, a paint manufacturer; and Shaw Industries, one of the country's largest carpet makers.
Also showing up on Mr. Vinik's "buy" list was Trinity Industries, a manufacturer of rail cars, metal containers, highway guardrails and other metal products.
In each case, Magellan sharply increased its holdings since the end of September, when the fund disclosed its full portfolio in its twice-a-year report to shareholders. While the holdings in each of the five companies represent a small portion of the total assets of the Magellan fund, they account for 5.8 percent to 7.8 percent of the individual companies' total shares.
To be sure, cyclicals do not account for nearly as large a portion of the fund as technology stocks did a year ago, nor have they drastically risen in the portfolio over the last year. Still, the buying provides a glimpse of what may be to come.
Mr. Vinik declined to be interviewed for this article, and Fidelity has gone out of its way in recent months to emphasize that its managers' comments reflect thinking only at the time they are made, and that their opinions are subject to rapid change.
But the most recent documented trading activities of Mr. Vinik suggest that he still believes much of what he said last June: "As bullish as I am on technology, right now I think the best opportunity in the U.S. stock market is in cyclicals." At the time, 44 percent of the Magellan fund's assets were in technology stocks, a weighting maintained for nearly five more months, while nearly a quarter of the fund's assets were in cyclical industries.
Other Wall Street experts continue to agree, albeit cautiously, with Mr. Vinik's comments. Byron R. Wien, portfolio strategist at Morgan Stanley, said last week he believes the underlying strength of the economy "is greater than most people think," and that bodes well for cyclical stocks.
"The common view is that the more the Fed cuts, the better the environment is for cyclical stocks," Mr. Wien said. "The more reasoned view is that the economy won't grow fast enough to allow those companies to have surprisingly favorable earnings.
"I own a lot of these stocks," he continued, "but you have to be very selective. They may not do as well as they usually do as a series of Fed easings takes place."
When presented with Mr. Vinik's apparent affinity for cyclical issues, Mr. Wien said his sentiment is similar, with a particular emphasis on paper and housing stocks. "I'm there, but I'm a little nervous about it," he conceded.
Mr. Vinik's latest cyclical bets have generally fared well, with four of the five stocks gaining ground from mid-December through the end of last week. Trinity Industries, for example, rose from about $30 a share six weeks ago to close at $35 last week; Sherwin-Williams closed at a new 52-week high of $42.50 on Friday, up from about $39 in mid-December.
Less profitable has been the Magellan fund's bet on Shaw, the carpet maker, whose stock price has declined in the last month as the company terminated a plan to acquire the Maxim Group, a rival floor-coverings company, and last week, Home Depot discontinued selling Shaw's products. Shaw said that it expects that action to have minimal impact on its sales, less than half of 1 percent of which went to Home Depot.
Caterpillar stock, which at the end of November was the fund's second-largest equity holding, has experienced big swings, trading above $75 in July and below $51 in October. Most recently, the shares traded at about $63, slightly above the average for the six months ended in September, during which the Magellan fund doubled its holdings of Caterpillar stock to more than 14 million shares.
Whether Mr. Vinik remains bullish on cyclical stocks will become more apparent in coming weeks. Just as closely as some on Wall Street are watching Mr. Vinik, the celebrated fund manager is likely to have his eyes glued on the next meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-making board, near the end of March.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Navigating 125th Street

BYLINE: By JANET ALLON 

 BODY:
DIAGONALLY opposite the burned-out shell of Freddy's clothing store, Barbara Askins, who heads the 125th Street Business Improvement District, is having a late lunch of okra and corn and oxtail stew and collard greens at Manna's Restaurant.
"Isn't it interesting that this is a Korean-owned deli with some black employees that serves soul food to a mixed but mostly black clientele?" Ms. Askins says as familiar faces drop by. Al Ward, the owner of the nearby Baskin-Robbins franchise, rails about non-black merchants on 125th Street who don't give anything back to the neighborhood. "That's what Minister Farrakhan means by 'bloodsuckers,' " he says. "People should be forced to give back." 
 When Ms. Askins, 44, hears that blacks are underrepresented on 125th -- and she hears it often -- she wants to make sure she has the straight story. She walks the street pointing out that in nearly every store there is at least one black employee. "A lot of people repeat these things," she says. "I think it's important to get the facts."
For instance, she says that although blacks own barely half the storefront businesses, more than half of the assessed property value in the BID is black-owned.
It is middle-of-the-road positions like these that have sometimes landed Ms. Askins in hot water in Harlem. She has been called a sellout and an outsider, although she has lived in Harlem for 10 years. A Louisiana native, she once planned a career in fashion, but wound up as a temporary worker for a consultant who explained public projects to the public. That job sparked her interest in economic development.
In 1989, the 125th Street Local Development Corporation hired Ms. Askins as its merchant liaison as the street was undergoing reconstruction. A year later, she started laying the groundwork for the BID, which began operations in October 1994.
Ms. Askins knew the merchants and what they wanted: to get vendors removed from the sidewalks. "There was congestion, unfair competition, disputes between vendors over space, parking problems, filth and noise," she said. "Merchants were getting summonsed for vendors' activities."
After an extensive search for an alternative site, the police swept the vendors away, leaving bitterness in their wake. But some have found success at a new market at 116th and Lenox Avenue. The Rev. Al Sharpton, who took up the vendors' cause, has measured words for Ms. Askins. "We have different visions," he said. "I respect that she has fought for businesses in Harlem, I just think that she should fight for street-level businesses as well."
Some of Ms. Askins's concerns are indistinguishable from those of the city's other BIDs. But Harlem's supercharged political atmosphere adds another dimension.
Walking along 125th, she talks to store owners about improving facades and signage. But the merchants talk about deeper problems: pervasive unemployment, cuts in welfare, shoppers who lack the economic confidence to buy, the lack of low-interest loans for minority-owned businesses.
What they need most, they say, are customers. The complain Harlem's status as a prime tourist attraction is bringing little economic benefit. "People need to come off of those tour buses and stop and shop," says Kevin McGill, who owns Men's Walker, a shoe store at Lenox Avenue. "Every damn half-hour they turn the corner."
More than the BID, the long-delayed $300 million empowerment zone, with its incentives for businesses, is intended to address the merchants' concerns. "The zone runs straight through 125th Street," says Ms. Askins. "We can't help but benefit."
She envisions 125th Street as a unique commercial strip with more opportunities for minorities, and with chain and anchor stores -- as well as small businesses -- to create and maintain foot traffic. And while she admits that chain stores drive up rents and perhaps diminish local flavor, she is convinced Harlem needs some to keep its considerable spending power at home.
Her critics fear the larger stores will destroy smaller merchants. Recently a group calling itself the Harlem Grassroots Coalition to Take Back the Hood marched on 125th Street protesting that chain stores squeeze out black-owned businesses.
The demonstration was an uncomfortable reminder of the Dec. 8 shootings and deadly fire at Freddy's, which overshadow any discussion of the retail mix along 125th Street. Ms. Askins knew there were tensions between the store owner, Fred A. Harari, and Sikhulu Shange, the owner of the Record Shack next door, whom Mr. Harari wanted to evict. She could watch the demonstrators and the police from her office. But she insists that it was a lease dispute, that "the BID does not get involved in lease disputes and that both parties said they were talking." She was out of town the day before the conflagration and returned to her office to see police officers running down the street.

HEADLINE: Terms of Engagement

BYLINE: By Strobe Talbott; Strobe Talbott is Deputy Secretary of State.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Over the past five years, the United States policy of steady engagement with Russia has paid benefits to the American people. With our help, the Russians have dismantled thousands of nuclear warheads and rocket launchers. Russian troops, having withdrawn from Germany and the Baltic states, are serving alongside their NATO counterparts in Bosnia. The United States is now the largest foreign investor in Russia, and bilateral trade has nearly tripled in the past three years.
When Secretary of State Warren Christopher meets with Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov in Helsinki this week, he will stress America's determination to preserve and, where possible, to deepen and broaden these accomplishments. He will also discuss some issues on which we have differences, such as Russia's intention to sell nuclear reactors to Iran. 
 The meeting will take place against the backdrop of troubling trends, as Russia's June presidential election approaches. Communists and ultra-nationalists, tapping into fear of the future and nostalgia for the past, are riding high in the polls and in the Parliament. Democrats and centrists are divided. An embattled President Boris Yeltsin, poised to announce his campaign for re-election, has dismissed a number of prominent reformers.
Even when the direction of Russian politics is uncertain, the fundamentals of American policy remain clear and consistent. One is that we support democracy. It is not our responsibility to choose Russia's leaders. It never was. The Russian people now have the power to do that themselves.
We believe that the enfranchisement of Russian citizens will, if sustained, be good for their country and for the world. The impressive voter turnout in December's parliamentary elections suggests that the Russian people are getting used to choosing their leaders. The Russian media, through their coverage of the devastating use of force in Chechnya, have demonstrated that they cherish their new independence.
Freedom of choice and speech will help move Russia toward the rule of law and the consolidation of a civil society. As President Clinton has repeatedly stressed, democracies are more likely to be reliable partners in trade and diplomacy, and more likely to pursue foreign and defense policies that are compatible with United States interests.
We will advance those interests in the short term as well as the long by giving priority to three objectives:
Nuclear security. We will press for implementation of arms control agreements that enhance international security and reduce levels of lethal weaponry left over from the superpower rivalry. Now that the Senate has ratified Start II, President Yeltsin, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin and Foreign Minister Primakov have vowed to intensify their effort for ratification by the Parliament. Meanwhile, we will look for new ways to control dangerous fissile material and enhance the safety of reactors at a summit meeting in Moscow in April.
An undivided Europe. Russia has yet to comply fully with the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty. We are working hard with Russia and the other treaty signatories to resolve this problem so that it no longer casts a cloud over a broad range of mutually reinforcing European security arrangements. They include an expanding NATO-Russia relationship as NATO takes in new members; an enhanced role for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, and increased practical cooperation between NATO and the former members of the Warsaw Pact, through the Partnership for Peace.
Peace and independence. Russia is stepping up its call for economic and political integration among the former Soviet republics. In Eurasia, as in other parts of the world, we oppose coercion and intimidation of neighboring states. We will endorse regional cooperation only so long as it is truly and totally voluntary and only if it opens doors to the outside world.
That sort of integration is our overarching aspiration for a democratic Russia and the other new independent states. It is in our interests -- and theirs -- that they join, as soon and as fully as possible, the growing community of market democracies. But the pace of their integration into the West will depend on the pace of their reforms and on their adherence to international norms.
These terms of engagement have undergirded Administration policy for the past three years. They have already furthered vital and enduring American interests. They will continue to serve the United States well in the suspenseful months -- and years -- ahead.

HEADLINE: Making Tax Cuts Work Is Harder Than It Sounds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In a generally laudatory essay on State Treasurer Brian Clymer ("A Whitman Cabinet Star Explains It All for You," On Politics, Jan. 21), Iver Peterson made an incredible assertion. He said the Treasurer is a star in the Governor's Cabinet because "he made her tax cuts work." 
 The phrase is curious. While it may be correct to say the Treasurer helped make the tax cut a reality, he certainly has not made the tax cut work the way the Governor originally promised.
When she unveiled her plan during her 1993 race for governor, Mrs. Whitman said the tax cuts would produce 450,000 new jobs and cure all of the economic problems that had riddled the state during the 1990-91 recession. She promised to offset the tax cuts with reductions in state spending while not driving up property tax rates.
This plan was doomed to failure for many reasons (including lack of internal logic: she preaches the inability of government to spur economic growth, but her whole platform is based on the claim that the government can create prosperity by adjusting tax rates). But as any newspaper reader can see, Mrs. Whitman gave the public false hope. The state's unemployment rate for December was a whopping 7.3 percent, the second highest in the country. All indicators point to a worsening jobless picture because of the layoffs announced by AT&T last month.
In fact, the state income tax, which is small compared to Federal, property and sales taxes, is a minor factor in investment decisions. The major effect of the income tax cut has been to put money in the pockets of the wealthy. Under Mrs. Whitman's plan, people making $300,000 or more receive 10 times the tax cut of an average New Jersey family earning $50,000. According to a Treasury Department analysis, New Jersey's richest taxpayers, the 6.7 percent who make $100,000 or more, will pocket more than 40 percent of the savings from the full 30 percent income tax cut.
At the same time, the Whitman administration has failed to trim the state budget to make up for the loss of revenue from her tax cuts. Instead, she and Mr. Clymer have raided $2.4 billion from a state employee pension plan, and reduced state aid to municipalities. Now they want to raid the state's disability fund. The results are not savings but shifting tax burdens, to local property owners and future taxpayers.
Treasurer Clymer may have made Mrs. Whitman's tax cuts work for her -- she is said to be on the short list of Republican vice-presidential nominees -- but he certainly hasn't made them do much for the rest of us.
 
BARBARA BUONO
Assemblywoman, 18th District
Metuchen

HEADLINE: Navy Facing Criticism In Toxic Dumping

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THE Navy may be using contaminated spoil to cap 1.2 million cubic yards of toxic-laden material that it dumped into Long Island Sound near Fishers Island, opponents of the project charge.
The dumping began in late 1994 and is to be completed early phis month. At issue is the material -- the spoils -- taken from dredging the heavily industrialized Thames River at New London to provide clearance for the Seawolf nuclear submarine at her home port. 
 The opponents, led by the Fishers Island Conservancy, said recent tests that they paid for had showed moderate levels of mercury, traces of dioxin and small amounts of other toxic substances in samples of the capping material used to cover the spoils.
They said the results should compel further tests by the Navy before the capping is allowed to continue.
"Any capping material that goes out there should be very clean," the president of the conservancy, John H. Thatcher Jr., said. "This should raise a red flag."
Mr Thatcher said if additional contamination was found officials should recap the dump site with material certified as clean.
The Navy official in charge of the project, Robert K. Ostermueller of the Navy Facilities Engineering Command in Lester, Pa., did not return three calls to his office.
But an assistant commissioner in the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, Arthur J. Rocque Jr., said the capping material was clean and met Federal and state standards for marine projects. Mr. Rocque said recapping would be unnecessary and potentially harmful to the home of the clean material.
Capping, the final step in the project, entails dumping clean dredged material from the Thames on top of the larger volume of contaminated material at the site. In theory, a three-meter-thick cap seals contaminants on the bottom of the Sound.
The one-mile-square site, in use since before World War II, is one and a half miles from Fishers Island, in an area where opponents said strong currents would spread contaminants, particularly if they are in the capping material.
In December the privately hired testers took seven samples from river-bottom areas to be used for capping while Navy observers videotaped from a patrol boat.
Test results showed traces of pesticides and heavy metals. Mercury, one of the most toxic heavy metals, was present in five samples in moderate levels, according to standards set by the New England River Basins Commission. The amounts ranged from 0.2 to 0.6 parts per million.
Mr. Rocque said the results were consistent with Navy findings. He said the moderate classification referred to ground disposal not to Federal standards for marine disposal. But Mr. Thatcher said the standards were the ones cited in the Navy environmental-impact statement for the dredging.
Although a portion of the disposal site is in New York waters, the Navy, the Army and Connecticut officials have said all dumping has occurred on the Connecticut side.
New York State challenged the project, saying New York permits might be needed because of the potential effects on the New York side. But the New York Attorney General's office dropped the legal action in Federal Court in Albany after Gov. George E. Pataki said in December that the dredging posed no damage.
The president of the 1,000-member Concerned Citizens of Montauc, Rav Freidel, attacked Mr. Pataki for "his support of the U.S. Navy's reckless poisoning of Long Island Sound." Mr. Freidel said in an interview that the project "was done in the name of national security."
"Give me a break," he said. "Where's the war? I'll tell you where. It's in Long Island Sound, and its the Government against our fish and our fishermen."
Mr. Rocque said Mr. Freidel's assertion that the project had been rushed to completion by dumping seven days a week 24 hours a day since October was "extremely economical with the truth."
"We are very careful about this stuff," he said. "We really are."
But Mr. Thatcher said conservancy members, including himself, ha' witnessed dumping during high winds and strong tides. "That has been going on from Day 1," he said.
The conservancy and other organizations like the Town of Southold, the Fishers Island Civic Association, the Long Island Sound Lobstermen's Association, the North Shore Baymen's Association and the Concerned Citizens of Montauk sued in Federal District Court in Uniondale in the fall to stop the dumping.
Those groups argued that dumping contaminated material in the Sound violated the Federal Ocean Dumping Act, which was amended to include the Sound. The Army, the Navy and the Environmental Protection Agency, the original defendants, argued that the dumping complied with all Federal laws. The Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, at its request, later joined the defendants.
After weeks of hearings Judge Thomas C. Platt ruled that the dumping could proceed. He said the opponents had failed to show that irreparable harm would follow the dumping. By the time of his ruling the work was nearly completed.
The opponents have subpoenaed a Navy report that catalogued contaminants near the Groton submarine base, a Federal Superfund site. Mr. Thatcher said the large report had information about highly toxic conditions in the Thames.
Mr. Rocque said he was familiar with the report. "Reports like that are used to inform us about what we should be looking for," he said. "But if you have a compound in the marine sediment that is chemically bonded to the sediment, the amount of the material is relatively irrelevant." He said many contaminants were bonded to sediments and remained so even when dredged up and dumped in the Sound.
Opponents have sharply different views. Mr. Thatcher said that the Navy made no tests for dioxin and that the cost of the samples, $2,000, limited the opponents to one test. But he said the tests showed that a number of the compounds were dioxin.
Dioxin is a highly toxic synthetic carcinogen that affects reproduction in fish, birds and mammals. "We found enough to show the Navy should have taken dioxin tests," Mr. Thatcher said.
He said the groups had spent nearly $100,000 for legal fees and expert testimony in the case in Uniondale.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS: Vox Populist;
Just Regular Ruling-Class Guys

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.H.

 BODY:
THE most striking thing about Steve Forbes's rapid rise from the protected bubble of his corporate jet, the Capitalist Tool, to the turbulence of life as the hot Republican Presidential commodity is what his opponents are not saying about him.
They attack his flat tax plan as wacky. They attack his barrage of television commercials as mean-spirited and misleading. They attack him for lacking government know-how. 
 But they are more reluctant to fault Mr. Forbes for what may seem his most glaring vulnerability as the first official tests draw near: that this member of one of the wealthiest families in America has bought his way to the top of the field while touting as a panacea for the middle class a plan that cuts taxes for the rich.
That is because Mr. Forbes, of all people, has managed to acquire a label prized by contemporary American politicians: he is a populist.
Populist? America's original populists, those sharped-tongued champions of struggling farmers and silver miners, were enemies of wealth and power. Their political party of the 1890's favored Government ownership of railroads and telegraph lines and promoted the graduated income tax. Their attacks on big business helped inspire the Progressive movement, which contributed so much to the very New Deal liberalism that Mr. Forbes and his Republican rivals want to bury.
They were the tribunes of class conflict, the polar opposite of today's conservatives. "You will see arrayed on one side the great magnates of the country, and Wall Street brokers, and plutocratic power," a Kansas populist named L. L. Polk said in 1890, "and on the other you will see the people."
Now come the self-described champions of a new populism whose enemies are not New York plutocrats but Washington bureaucrats. They are a surprising lot -- wealthy or Washington insiders or both. Malcolm Stevenson Forbes Jr. Ross Perot, one of the world's richest men. Patrick J. Buchanan, son of Washington and member of its media elite. Senator Bob Dole, the ultimate insider. Senator Phil Gramm, another Capitol powerhouse. Lamar Alexander, businessman and corporate lawyer. Morry Taylor, the tire and wheel magnate. (Not to mention Bill Clinton of Hope, Ark., Yale and Oxford.)
Rush Limbaugh, who turned himself into a millionaire by playing Mr. Populist to his listeners and viewers, recently warned them against taking potshots at Mr. Forbes. "We're taking the whole issue away from our side," Mr. Limbaugh said, "if we're going to criticize wealth."
There is nothing new about rich people in politics. George Washington was rich. But the most successful politicians among the fabulously wealthy -- Roosevelts and Rockefellers and Kennedys -- appealed to poor and working-class people by promoting government programs for the disadvantaged. Now candidates are promoting economic conservatism as the new definition of populism. The circle has been closed -- Mr. Forbes has defined himself by attacking the graduated income tax that the first populists championed.
"The Government has fallen into such a state of disrepute that politicians want to pick up on an anti-statist feeling in the country," said Prof. Jamin B. Raskin of the American University law school, an expert on money in politics. "So populism becomes a catch-all label for anyone who challenges the political system. Every politician tries to pick up the chord of populism but in that sense the word begins to lose meaning."
Rich-guy populism does seem to require certain ritual obeisances to the lives of ordinary folk. George Bush made a display of eating pork rinds. Mr. Forbes stood out last week when he showed up at a black-tie Congressional dinner in a business suit. Mr. Buchanan sheds his starched white shirt (he shed his Mercedes when he ran in 1992) for down-home garb as he rails against the Washington establishment, upon which he built a lucrative career. Mr. Alexander campaigns in a plaid work shirt.
 
'Richie Rich'
 Despite their own hefty bank accounts, Mr. Forbes's opponents cannot resist digs: Mr. Gramm mocks him as "Richie Rich," and Mr. Dole calls him "Malcolm." But they don't suggest any contradiction between his background or program and his profession of the populist faith. "If I were going to go back and choose parents again, I might choose rich parents," Mr. Gramm said.
Mr. Gramm, like all politicians, is well aware that while middle- and low-income voters may be economically insecure, they don't blame the rich for their predicament. Many agree with the supply-side advocates that loosening Government restrictions on business is just what the nation needs to climb out of economic malaise.
Polls last week showed that Mr. Forbes is neck-and-neck with Mr. Dole in New Hampshire, the first primary state, and is popular among middle-income and independent voters. In dozens of random interviews in New Hampshire and Iowa, most voters, including Democrats, said they liked Mr. Forbes's outsider message and his willingness to spend his own money, since it showed he could not be bought by special interests.
"I'm more impressed because he's trying to do it with his own money," said Bruce Bowman, 38, a small-businessman from Cedar Rapids, Iowa, after a Forbes speech.
Even anti-Forbes voters see nothing peculiar about the confluence of wealth and populism. Barbara Bingham, a 61-year-old homemaker from Nashua, N.H., who plans to vote for Mr. Dole, said of Mr. Forbes, "I dislike him intensely." But when asked if he was trying to buy the race, Mrs. Bingham replied: "That doesn't bother me. I think he's sincere in what he says about populist things even if he has not experienced them."
That kind of sentiment was central to the success of Mr. Perot, who put $62 million of his own money into an independent run for President in 1992. Others followed suit.
"Michael was definitely running as a populist," said Arianna Huffington, an outspoken conservative whose husband, Michael, spent $29 million and came close to winning a Senate seat from California in 1994. "He had tremendous support from blue-collar workers, from Reagan Democrats."
Mrs. Huffington argued that voters have been more critical of wealthy Republicans than of wealthy Democrats. "Republicans spending their own money becomes a bigger issue because Republicans are supposed to be for the rich and Democrats are supposed to care for the poor," she said. "It's part of a stereotype the G.O.P. needs to shake."
There are similiarities between the populists of today and their 19th century counterparts. Mr. Buchanan comes closest, complaining about large corporations and warning of too many immigrants. Mr. Forbes sometimes sounds like an original populist when he attacks the financial takeover of the political parties by monied interests.
Still, it is hard to picture the scion of the Forbes publishing empire repeating what William Jennings Bryan said in a speech in Chicago 100 years ago when his Democratic Party embraced populism: "If I had behind me the great trusts and combinations, I know that I would no sooner take my seat than they would demand that I use my power to rob the people in their behalf."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Latest History of the Gulf War

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

 BODY:
EVEN at its best, as the late Phil Graham of The Washington Post said, journalism is no more than a first rough draft of history. And sometimes, as in the case of the war in the Persian Gulf in 1991, the draft is very rough indeed. Not surprisingly, the war's fifth anniversary last month prompted a series of revisionist retrospectives.
To a degree unprecedented in recent American history, reporters were limited in what they were permitted to see in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. A good deal of what they did see never reached print or got onto the air, at least in the brief period when the world was paying close attention. Some of what they were told by United States officials was untrue, either because the officials did not know the truth or because they did not wish it to be known. Finally, more than in most earlier wars, many reporters lacked the knowledge of the region and of military affairs to evaluate what was going on.
 
Unraveling Accounts
 Happily, some people have kept tugging at the sleeve of this history, long after the last shots were fired, and a lot of the official version of events is beginning to unravel. As ever, heroes are seen to be human as well as superhuman; villains are seen to have had a method in their villainy. Causes are seen to be complex, and so are results; victories are less than complete. It is a valuable corrective, if it does not go too far, and it is a process as old as war itself. If it does go too far, the pendulum of correction eventually swings back. Grant and Patton, to cite just two examples, have both been up, down, back up and back down again in the years since their feats of derring-do, and the books are not closed on either of them. 
 This ongoing revisionism is the very nature of history, especially where war is concerned. The confusion of combat is axiomatic, as is the difficulty of grasping the operations of a battalion from the vantage point of a squad or the operations of a corps from the vantage point of a battalion. Only after the controversy of political decision-making has cooled can the participants' stories be gathered, compared and evaluated. Only when secrecy is no longer an imperative can sensitive documents be declassified. Only with the perspective of time can cause and consequence be clearly seen. Changing the lens can reveal new insights and relationships, as has been the case with historians who in recent years have focused more on the manners and mores of ordinary people and less on the high and mighty, or (more controversially) those who have applied Marxist economic theories.
But academic victimology and intellectual political correctness has given the phrase "historical revisionism" a slightly gamy smell of late. Rightly so. The process cannot work if the new conclusions precede the search for new evidence or the reexamination of the evidence already on the record. Anti-American or right-wing or feminist or racial biases are not adequate, by themselves, to challenge widely accepted ways of looking at things.
In the case of the gulf war, the revisionism began almost as soon as the last shots were fired. "The gate is closed," General Norman Schwarzkopf famously declared in Riyadh as the fighting was ending, but it wasn't. It was wide open at Basra, as the whole world could see within a week when two-thirds of Saddam Hussein's elite Revolutionary Guard escaped back into Iraq. It took a little longer to see, in the postwar words of Maj. Gen. Barry McCaffrey, the commander of the 24th Infantry Division, that the whole end-game was flawed. With hindsight, it was evident not only that the cease-fire came before the trap had been sprung but that the trap itself was badly designed -- that the Marines attacking directly toward Kuwait City went off too soon and too fast, reaching their objective so quickly that the Revolutionary Guard divisions never moved south to help in its defense and could not be cut off by the allies' left hook across the desert.
 
A List of Failures
 That was one of the major conclusions of "The Generals' War" (Little, Brown & Co., 1995), the first really thorough account of the politics, the diplomacy and the fighting, written by Michael R. Gordon of The New York Times and Bernard E. Trainor, a retired Marine lieutenant general who now teaches at Harvard. Based on exhaustive interviews, equally free of hagiography and cynicism, the book won quick acceptance, even among many of the generals. It also documented American diplomatic mishandling of Saddam before the war; the failures as well as the successes of the Patriot missile defense system; General Schwarzkopf's temper, and General Colin L. Powell's extreme reluctance, born out of the shattering experience of Vietnam, to commit American troops to battle.
Last month, television documentaries moved the process along. In an interview with David Frost on the BBC, George Bush disclosed that he had worried that Saddam would pull back across the border at the last moment, making offensive action impossible for the allies but tying them down indefinitely in defensive positions. The correspondent Bill Kurtis on A & E suggested that some British and American soldiers' exposure to toxins unknown -- lead in the smoke from burning oil wells, nerve-gas pills, insecticides, poison gases released by allied bombing raids? -- had produced genetic defects in their children.
A pair of two-hour "Frontline" programs on PBS offered testimony from important figures -- Brent Scowcroft, Generals Powell and Schwarzkopf, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Margaret Thatcher and the former Iraqi foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, among many others -- and challenged a lot of conventional wisdom. Civilian officials like Mr. Scowcroft and his deputy, Robert M. Gates, to say nothing of President Bush, had far more stomach for battle than the top generals, by "Frontline's" account and their own, and even some of the ground commanders, such as Lieut. Gen. Fred Franks of the VII Corps, were timid when battle came. The programs demonstrated how ragged the ending really was, with American mistakes at the Safwan talks inadvertently aiding Saddam in suppressing Shiites, whom the United States had urged to rebel, and in clinging to power. (Mr. Bush admitted as much in the Frost interview.) Mrs. Thatcher, who played an important role in stiffening President Bush's resolve, noted that she and Mr. Bush soon lost power, while Saddam "the aggressor" stayed in office. "I wonder who won," she said.
The answer to that, of course, is still hotly debated. The Iraqis were thrown out of Kuwait, a message of international resolve was delivered and Saddam's wings were clipped. But Shiites and Kurds in Iraq were massacred by Saddam's troops all the same, the regime in Baghdad is as repressive as ever and its nuclear- and chemical-warfare capacities were not destroyed as claimed. Like all wars, this one was full of ambiguity. Vietnam and its lessons remain contentious to this day. Whether the struggle in the gulf was worth the candle --- the loss of life, the billions of dollars spent --- is a question for decades, and for revisions of history, still to come.

HEADLINE: Backtalk;
Life at the Top: Jerry Bailey Reflects on Cigar

BYLINE: By JERRY BAILEY 

 BODY:
Cigar, who went 10 for 10 at the races last year to establish himself as the obvious horse of the year and the best horse of the decade, will begin his 1996 campaign next Saturday in the Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park in Florida. When he became a star last year, Cigar was already 5 years old. Now he's 6, and trying to do it again, with some expert guidance from his jockey, Jerry Bailey.
The 38-year-old Bailey is a star in his own right. He was inducted into the Racing Hall of Fame last year and also received the Eclipse Award as 1995's top jockey. He has been riding Thoroughbreds for two decades, long enough, as he makes clear in this article, to appreciate the once-in-a-lifetime experience that Cigar represents. 
 In recent months, many people have asked me what it's like to ride a horse like Cigar. I still have trouble responding, because the answer goes beyond stakes victories and purse earnings.
Frankly, I don't think I'll ever be around this situation again, because horses like this don't come around very often -- especially to the same jockey.
In fact, until Cigar, I never got too attached to horses because they come and go. I ride so many of them -- last year, I participated in 1,400 races -- that I simply don't have the time to develop any rapport.
I do remember riding Cigar for the first time in a grass race at Belmont Park in October 1994. He finished third, and didn't leave much of an impression.
After that, I watched him win a race on the dirt at Aqueduct, but I didn't ride him again until his next start: the N.Y.R.A. Mile in November 1994, his last race that year.
In that race, he won with complete authority and for the first time I had the feeling that he could be something special.
As it turned out, he was more than special. And in the course of his 10 straight victories in 1995, there were two incidents that really stamped him as a champion in my eyes.
The first came in the Oaklawn Handicap at Oaklawn Park on April 15, against the best group of handicap horses you could assemble at the time. As we were turning for home and approaching Silver Goblin, the rider on Silver Goblin, Dale Cordova, in an attempt to hit his own horse, struck Cigar right on the front of the face with his whip.
Most horses would have trouble dealing with that kind of a blow and would probably back out of the race at that point. The great ones turn it into something positive.
As for Cigar, he shook his head and pinned his ears, as if the whip had made him mad. He dug down, quickly opened up a couple of lengths on the field and won by two-and-a-half lengths.
The second incident took place in the Hollywood Gold Cup at Hollywood Park July 2.
As we were running around the first turn, tucked in behind five or six horses, a huge clod of dirt hit Cigar right in the middle of the head. He shook his head, grabbed the bridle in his teeth, nearly took the reins out of my hands and started running as hard as he could. I tried to hold him back and I was actually able to for about half a mile.
By then, the blood was gone from my fingertips, and my arms were exhausted. I had no choice but to let him run at that point, although I didn't think I would be able to hold the whip in my hand because my fingers were numb. The result? He won by two or three lengths.
Besides his mental toughness, Cigar is different from other horses because he is so efficient in his stride. His motion is so fluid, I don't ever feel him accelerating, except when he's leaving the starting gate.
And during the course of a race, he normally doesn't assert himself that hard at any one moment. It's a gradual flow. The only way you really know you're going fast is because you're whooshing by horses. With most good horses, you'll feel them go into another gear. And Cigar just doesn't do that.
With most horses, the pressure of running in all these top races would overtake them at some point, but with Cigar, I always knew in my heart last year that I could never get him into a situation, traffic-wise, that he wouldn't get me out of. That's how overwhelming he is.
In 1991, I won the Preakness and Belmont Stakes on a colt named Hansel. As good as he was, though, he hated to run inside horses so I was constantly trying to figure how to get him to the outside.
For a jockey, that's a nightmare, because any other smart jockey is going to pick up on that and try to trap you inside. Cigar does not have those idiosyncrasies: It is impossible for another jockey to find a chink in the armor. There is none.
Riding Cigar last year also gave me an appreciation for the average person who comes to the track and wants someone to root for. I noticed that when Cigar ran in the Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs in June.
I was on an all-sports radio station for a half an hour after the Massachusetts Handicap and again later in the year, and I can't tell you how many people called in who had gone out to the track that day to see Cigar run who don't normally go to the races. And that's what was really gratifying to me: that a horse like this can bring people out to racing. And believe me, racing needs it.
When Cigar came back to Belmont Park after that race, to his home base and mine, I really started to get to know him.
He had his routine: He'd go over to the track every morning and exercise -- whether it was a gallop or a work -- at around 7 A.M. and come back and get washed down. By a quarter to eight, he'd be taken out by Erma Scott, his hot walker, and be grazed in an enclosed area behind the barn of his trainer, Billy Mott, at Belmont.
I usually had some free time at that point in the morning -- there was track renovation from 8 to 8:30 and nothing much to do -- so I'd go and sit on the fence and watch Cigar graze and I kind of think he knew who I was. He'd come up, kind of sniff me and look at me and then go about his business.
In a sense, Cigar has more than one personality, depending on how close he is to a race. If it's within two or three days of a race, you don't want to get too close to him in front of the stall -- he might reach out and take a finger off. He's very aggressive and very focused. But in the weeks right after a race -- and he usually has a month between races -- he's a pretty docile horse. You can go up and pet him for two or three minutes and he'll be pretty submissive.
Actually, he's kind of a ham; he likes people looking at him and taking pictures of him. And he's the same way grazing.
I had never interacted with a horse the way I was interacting with Cigar. There were just too many horses and their careers were too fleeting. Just take the three other Breeders' Cup Classic winners I rode. I was on Black Tie Affair just one time and that was in the 1991 Classic right before he retired. As for Arcangues, the 1993 Classic winner from Europe, I merely saw him in the paddock, got on him, won -- and then he went overseas again. I'd ridden Concern, the 1994 winner, a couple of times, but he was an out-of-town horse, so I'd never really gotten to develop a rapport with him, either.
So my time with Cigar was a lot of fun for me. I was enjoying it. It wasn't like it was taking time out of my day; I really liked it.
When racing shifted to Saratoga, Cigar stayed behind at Belmont Park for a little rest, and I missed him. Then it got brutally hot down at Belmont Park for two or three weeks, so they brought him up to Saratoga, where it was a little cooler and I started going to see him again.
I had several people come up and stay with me during the Saratoga meet because I was being inducted into the Racing Hall of Fame and I'd say, "Want to come see Cigar? You've got to be real quiet and stay in the background, but come see him."
Billy Mott was very sporting about that, and so was Cigar.
As for this year, Billy has him prepared and where Allen Paulson, his owner, wants to run him, that's where he's going to go. So many people in the past have gotten a good horse and after one good year, he's off to stud for economic reasons. And that's not the case here.
As for me, I'm still driving the same car, living in the same places. The only thing I've done is put a little money in my 3-year-old son Justin's college fund.
If you ask Justin who his favorite horse is, he says, "Cigar." My wife, Suzee, has enjoyed the Cigar experience right along with me. She's probably the one who taught me the most about "appreciating the moment," and I'm grateful for that.
Two or three weeks after Cigar won the Breeders' Cup Classic, I went by Billy Mott's barn to see what was going on. And Billy said, "While you're here, I want you to do something for me."
Cigar was what they call walk-tacking, walking with a saddle on in the shed row as a way to let him cool down from training. And Billy said, "Get up on the horse."
And I got up one him, with no helmet on or anything, and I just walked around the barn on him for 30 minutes or so and I really enjoyed it. At first, when I got up on him -- because I think he knows the difference between a light rider like myself and a heavier exercise rider -- he thought he was going to go out and do something and he was kind of spunky. But after about 10 minutes, he settled down.
I was never one to just want to ride a horse. It was always the competition that got me going. But it was very enjoyable that morning walking around the shed row on Cigar, talking to him and reliving the memories.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jerry Baily on Cigar crossing the finish line of the Breeders' Cup Classic in October. To Bailey, the horse was No. 1 in many ways. (Agence France-Presse; Associated Press)

SECTION: Section 4; Page 12; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 610 words

HEADLINE: The Future of Taiwan

 BODY:
With the cold war over and the nations of East Asia booming, arguments over the status of Taiwan might seem the relics of another era. Sadly, they are not. A sudden surge of Chinese belligerence toward Taiwan has made the island one of the most volatile issues facing America and the world. Before the issue turns into a dangerous crisis, political leaders in Beijing, Washington and Taipei need to step back from confrontational policies and put Taiwan back into perspective.
For the better part of a year, China has been campaigning against attempts by Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, to win back some of the international recognition that Taiwan lost two decades ago when most of the world accepted Beijing's claim to be the legal Government of China. The mainland has conducted military maneuvers and missile tests off the island's coast to pressure Mr. Lee. 
 China should end this intimidation at once. Politicians in Taipei should stop indulging their voters and provoking the mainland with symbolic campaigns for international recognition and concentrate instead on building and protecting the freedoms and autonomy that Taiwan already enjoys.
Congressional Republicans, for their part, should refrain from inflammatory gestures like inviting Taiwanese leaders to Washington. Such official invitations call into question America's commitment to recognize only one China. The Clinton Administration must calmly, firmly and consistently remind Beijing that America's one China commitment is explicitly premised on the mainland's peaceful conduct toward Taiwan.
Taiwan is now neither an independent country nor a province governed by Beijing. After Chiang Kai-shek lost the Chinese civil war in 1949, he fled to Taiwan with his supporters and grandiosely proclaimed his administration the Government of all China. For cold war reasons, the United States went along with this fiction until 1979, when it shifted American recognition to the Communist regime in Beijing. That left Taiwan in diplomatic limbo, since Beijing insisted that any country recognizing the mainland regime break relations with Taiwan.
There increasingly is a case to be made for Taiwanese independence. Taiwan has not been ruled by China for most of the last century. It has a different political and economic system and its people enjoy a freedom and affluence many rightly fear could not survive under Communist rule.
But at least for now the costs of pressing for independence would exceed the potential gains. The most obvious cost is the very real risk of Chinese military attack. A showdown now over Taiwanese independence would also almost surely bring a rupture in relations between the United States and China. Given China's huge population, nuclear status and rapidly developing economy, such a crisis would have global implications.
Beijing, Taipei and Washington should lower the volume of the debate and avoid forcing issues that are best left alone for now. Beijing should stop flaunting its preparations for imminent military action. Taipei should stop pretending it can somehow redefine its international status without provoking a reaction from Beijing. The White House and Congressional leaders should agree to jointly counsel restraint on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Such a formula would allow Taiwan to hold on to and develop what it cares about most -- its freer, more prosperous way of life. It would allow Beijing to coexist with Taiwan without forfeiting its claims to eventual sovereignty. It would give American political leaders of both parties a chance to help preserve Taiwan's freedoms without wrecking relations with Beijing.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Word for Word/There You Go Again;
But Seriously, Folks, He Was Funnier Than Nixon

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV 

 BODY:
IT'S not every former President who has a chance to be a multimedia sensation, especially one who counted among his most humbling experiences a confrontation with a kindergarten computer class. "There they all sat in front of their computers," Ronald Reagan told a group of Republican women in 1984. "Finally, the one I was sitting beside said, 'Well, go ahead and push the button.' I was scared to death."
Democrats may be scared to death to push the button on a new CD-ROM, "President Ronald W. Reagan: Well, There You Go Again! The Humor That Shaped America, Volume One." The CD, compiled by N. R. Mitgang and Malcolm Kushner in conjunction with the Ronald Reagan Library, includes "every form of humor used by Ronald Reagan during his first Administration (covering over 500 different events as well as Ronald Reagan's philosophy and position on basic issues)." 
 The quips and anecdotes on the CD are delivered, as they originally were, with a studied cock of the head and a catch in the voice. Most of the material is offered in both text and audio forms, allowing this critical judgment: While Mr. Reagan's delivery improved the material, he benefited even more from that perquisite of the powerful -- a remarkably receptive audience. To mark his 85th birthday, on Tuesday, here is a sampling. ERIC ASIMOV
Mr. Reagan, the oldest President, had a zillion laugh lines about his age, but apparently only one joke:
To the Oklahoma State Legislature, March 16, 1982: "I appreciate having this opportunity to speak with you during the 75th year of your statehood. And it's not true that I was in the original land rush."
To the carpenters' union, Sept. 3, 1981: "This union has a proud history. Just 100 years ago, having only a few thousand members, you opened your first convention in Chicago. Now, it's not true that I attended that convention also."
State of the Union message, Jan. 26, 1982: "President Washington began this tradition in 1790 after reminding the nation that the destiny of self-government and the 'preservation of the sacred fire of liberty' is 'finally staked on the experiment entrusted to the hands of the American people.' For our friends in the press, who place a high premium on accuracy, let me say, I did not actually hear George Washington say that."
And then there was the letter-from-a-child gambit:
First speech after assassination attempt, April 28, 1981: "I have a letter with me. The letter came from Peter Sweeney. He's in the second grade in the Riverside School in Rockville Centre, and he said, 'I hope you get well quick or you might have to make a speech in your pajamas.' He added a postscript. 'P.S. If you have to make a speech in your pajamas, I warned you.' "
To the National Governors Association, Feb. 24, 1981: "One letter that really moved me was from an 11-year-old boy who wrote and said: 'When you get there, don't look to the past; look to the future. You won't have time to look to the past.' And he said, 'Make up your mind that when you leave there you will be older, and tired, and there will be a few more gray hairs in your wise old head.' And then he said, 'Just get to the office, go to work, and be happy that you're only President, you don't have to be God.' Out of the mouths of children. . . ."
For someone followed by a phalanx of Boswells, repetition is inevitable. Mr. Reagan used pre-emptive strikes:
To the Nevada Republican Party, Feb. 7, 1984: "Life not only begins at 40, but so does lumbago and the tendency to tell the same story over and over again. So, if you've heard it, just be polite and pretend you haven't."
At this point, some of the jokes have lost resonance:
At Point Mogu Naval Air Station, Feb. 19, 1981: "I know the ladies know about inflation. Once upon a time you used to put some money in your purse and go to the market and buy a bag full of groceries. Now you take a bag full of money, go to the market, and bring the groceries home in your purse."
And now, back to an inexhaustable topic:
To the White House News Photographers Association, May 16, 1984: "As you record history in the making, you, yourselves, are a part of historic tradition. Ever since Matthew Brady took his stirring pictures of Abe Lincoln and the Civil War, photographs have been imparting immediacy to American news. And it isn't true that I carried Brady's camera."
To the Ohio Association of Broadcasters, Oct. 24, 1984: "Coming in here, I couldn't help but reminisce and think about my first job at WOC, Davenport, Iowa. I'm not going to tell you how long ago that was. But it's not true that I was hired by Marconi."
While Mr. Reagan's one-liners leaned toward the cornball, some of his longer stories displayed surprising edge:
At a reception honoring National Review magazine, Feb. 21, 1983: "You know, a fellow comes in, stands in front of your desk, hands you a memorandum, and he stays and waits while you read it. And so you read:
'Action-oriented orchestration, innovation, inputs generated by escalation of meaningful, indigenous decision-making dialogue, focusing on multilinked problem complexes, can maximize the vital thrust toward nonalienated and viable urban infrastructure.'
I take a chance and say, 'Let's try busing.' And if he walks away, I know I guessed right."
To the Knights of Columbus, Aug. 3, 1982: "There was a fellow riding a bicycle one cold winter day -- motorcycle, I should say. The winds coming in through the buttons of his leather jacket were chilling him, and finally he stopped, turned the jacket around, put it on backwards, took it off again. Well, that solved the wind problem, but he hit a patch of ice; his arms were kind of restricted; he skidded into a tree. And when the police got there and elbowed their way through the crowd that had gathered and they said, 'What happened?' They said, 'We don't know. When we got there, he seemed to be all right. But by the time we had his head turned around straight, he was dead.' "
Not surprisingly, there are references to people and events no longer topical:
Speaking by telephone to the White House Correspondents Association, April 25, 1981: "I hope you don't mind, but David Stockman is making me call collect."
Presenting a check for the Westway project to Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York, Sept. 7, 1981: "Secretary of Interior Jim Watt would have been here, but he's working on a lease for strip mining of the Rose Garden."
Perhaps Mr. Reagan's greatest strength as a raconteur was his ability to return to earth fast:
On his return from a trip to Japan and South Korea, Nov. 14, 1983: "Coming home from Korea and Japan, all of us bring with us renewed energy and renewed commitment to our fundamental goals, building a new era of peace and prosperity -- just as soon as we readjust our clocks."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ronald Reagan in 1982; he was already joking about his age. (United Press International)

HEADLINE: U.S. WARNS CHINA OVER VIOLATIONS OF TRADE ACCORD

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER with STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Despite concerns about Washington's already tense relationship with Beijing, the Clinton Administration has warned China that it risks the imposition of stiff economic sanctions in the next few months because Beijing has ignored previous warnings and continues to violate a key trade agreement signed a year ago.
The warning, made after a series of White House meetings in recent days to reassess the Administration's China policy, comes despite considerable concern from some officials that prompting a confrontation over China's piracy of American software, music and videos could harm Washington's effort to defuse growing tensions between China and Taiwan. 
 Those officials also fear that the trade dispute could hamper American efforts to convince Beijing that it must end its crackdown on dissidents and stop the sale of missiles and other military hardware in South Asia and the Middle East.
But in the end, Mr. Clinton's economic and trade advisers, led by Mickey Kantor, the Trade Representative, convinced the White House that American credibility with China and other trading partners around the world would be jeopardized if Beijing is permitted to flagrantly ignore its agreement to close more than 30 compact-disk factories -- some apparently controlled by the Chinese military -- that are exporting millions of dollars worth of illegal copies of American products.
Mr. Kantor has warned China that the sanctions could be as large as 100 percent tariffs on more than a billion dollars in Chinese imports. But White House officials, still nervous about how hard to press Beijing, say they will not determine the exact nature of the sanctions, or their timing, until completing the negotiations that begin in the coming week.
Three months ago, Mr. Kantor issued a less specific, public threat of sanctions against China in hopes that Beijing would act against the factories making the pirated copies. Unsatisfied with the response, he went back to the Chinese on Wednesday to insist that time was running out.
Some aides to Mr. Clinton concede that election-year politics may color the decision over how hard a line to take. There is growing concern in the White House that Mr. Clinton's policy of "comprehensive engagement" with China -- and the decision two years ago to extend China's favorable trade benefits independently of its human rights record -- has shown virtually no results. That would provide Senator Bob Dole and other Republican Presidential aspirants with an opening to tar Mr. Clinton with the same charge that Mr. Clinton made about George Bush four years ago: that he is coddling the Chinese Communist leadership under pressure from American business interests.
The issue of China's piracy is particularly potent in California, the most critical state in the November election. Hollywood has lost millions of dollars because of the illegal replication of movies and music, and many of the plants that once churned out compact disks have converted to much more lucrative products -- illegal copies of computer software. Mr. Kantor, a longtime political operative in Southern California and Mr. Clinton's former campaign manager, is close to many of the executives in that industry.
On Wednesday, in a speech carefully reviewed by the National Security Council and National Economic Council, Mr. Kantor declared to the U.S.-China Business Council, a private group that represents American businesses in China, that the United States will "take decisive action if China does not meet its obligations." And he warned, "We will not wait forever."
In other forums, Mr. Kantor has said Washington would impose a larger sanction than the one it threatened a year ago but suspended when China agreed at the last moment to sign an accord promising a crackdown on the piracy of American products. The new sanctions are justified, he said, because China "is not only selling these goods in its own market, it is beginning to sell them around the world."
The same day that he gave the speech to the Business Council, Mr. Kantor delivered a similar warning to China's ambassador to the United States, Li Daoyu. And it is to be repeated in coming days, when one of Mr. Kantor's deputies begins the 17th round of talks with Chinese trade officials in Beijing over enforcement of the accord.
China's Deputy Foreign Minister, Li Zhaoxing, is due in Washington from Monday to Wednesday for an as-yet-unannounced visit in which he is expected to meet high-ranking American officials from the State Department and the White House.
Some Asia specialists in the State Department disagree with Mr. Kantor's aggressive strategy, as does the Deputy Treasury Secretary, Lawrence Summers, who at a recent White House meeting questioned whether it was worth jeopardizing America's huge interests in China "over the copyright on Mickey Mouse."
Several China experts have warned that in China's view the threat of sanctions is an attempt by the United States to "contain" what is fast becoming the world's second superpower.
But Mr. Kantor has argued the opposite: that China will only respect American toughness -- on Taiwan, human rights and other issues -- if Washington does not back down when it comes to enforcing previously negotiated agreements.
Senior officials say Mr. Kantor's strategy has been approved by Secretary of State Warren Christopher and by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. But at least one participant in the meetings recalled that "the issue has to be pursued with some balance," one reason that Mr. Kantor has not set a date by which China must destroy the factories or enter into licensing agreements to make their products legitimate.
"You hear the argument a lot that we should not be retaliating now," said Gregg Mastel, a China scholar at the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington trade and economics think tank. "But it is clear that the Chinese are testing our credibility on intellectual property. They don't want to crack down on this gravy train, but they will do it if they fear it threatens their lifeline: exports."
The piracy issue is expected to set the tone over the next few months for what American officials know will be a very difficult period for Chinese-American relations.
The annual State Department human-rights report will be released soon, having been delayed by the Government shutdown, and "we will tell it like it is about China," a senior American official said, while not expecting Beijing to like or react quietly to the report.
Moreover, China's threatening military exercises near Taiwan and explicit warnings to Taiwan ahead of the March 23 presidential elections there have left the United States in a delicate position. Traditionally, American forces have served to defuse potential conflicts in Asia.
The United States has warned Beijing "to cool it" around Taiwan, officials say, though they say there is no evidence of an imminent attack across the Taiwan Strait.
And American officials have done little to hide their anger at Taipei for its unrelenting efforts to seek a larger international status and role, pressing for "unofficial" visits and transit visas to the United States. The most recent downturn in American relations with Beijing came with the Administration's decision last year -- under Congressional pressure -- to allow Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, into the country for a reunion at Cornell University.
Also in March, the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva will decide whether to condemn China's crackdown on dissidents and other human rights abuses. The United States was hoping to avoid co-sponsoring a condemnatory resolution this year, but officials say there is now little alternative.
In May, Congress will have to review a Presidential decision to renew China's preferential trading status. "The concern is that unless we have the intellectual property issues resolved, Congress could refuse to go along," one of Mr. Clinton's top economic advisers said the other day.
Such threats -- that failure to comply with a trade accord could prompt a Congressional backlash -- have long been a staple of American trade-negotiating tactics with Japan.
But the mood in Congress is worsened by the growing evidence of human rights abuses and a soaring American trade deficit with China. While exports to China are booming, the overall deficit rose last year to about $37 billion, according to the Commerce Department. Mr. Kantor noted the other day that the deficit "is threatening to surpass our trade deficit with Japan."
Administration officials concede that their decision two years ago to "de-link" trade issues from other concerns, a step China insisted would create "a more constructive atmosphere," has largely failed. Instead, a senior American official said, "there has been no progress in human rights and even setbacks."
American officials also believe that their messages to Beijing are misunderstood as China's political leaders maneuver in preparation for the death of the country's supreme leader, Deng Xiaoping. The initial dispute over President Lee's visit to the United States was partly attributed to misunderstandings last spring during a meeting between Mr. Christopher and his Chinese counterpart. And there is a sense that Mr. Clinton's periodic meetings with Chinese leaders have been so stiff and formal that no real communication has taken place.
"Their view is that we're containing them and want to keep them weak," the official said, though he went on to say that while some Chinese leaders may believe that, others simply say it to put Washington on the defensive for tactical reasons.
The relationship is so odd, that "China is the only country in the world where we have an almost daily exchange of public views expressed through spokesmen," said the State Department's public voice, Nicholas Burns. "We'd like to get to the point where we're not debating transit visas in public."
But at times the American message has also been muddled by domestic politics. Given the demands of the American political debate in a Presidential election year, the supposed fire wall between economic issues and the political relationship will be hard to maintain.
For instance, the United States says it will accede to China's admission to the World Trade Organization as soon as Beijing agrees to meet the "commercial requirements" of the 120-nation treaty: lowering import barriers, loosening controls on foreign investment and trade, and abiding by international conventions, including those covering copyrights and patents.
But Chinese officials argue that the United States is blackballing Beijing to contain the expansion of China's economy, and thus limit its national strength. An argument that began over a trade accord has become an issue of national pride -- with billions of dollars riding on the outcome.
"There are a lot of mine fields out there," a senior Administration official said.
