HEADLINE: Fears That Loss of a Math Ph.D. Program Figures in a Bigger Equation

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The University of Rochester is scuttling its doctoral program in mathematics, a move that has surprised and angered scientists and educators nationwide, who worry it could signal erosion at America's research universities.
If Rochester could take such a step in tough financial times, they say, so could other leading universities. They are also concerned that it is a recipe for disaster at Rochester, a university respected for its strength in science and technology. 
 "This is not good for Rochester, for American science or for the country," said Arthur Jaffe, a mathematician at Harvard and president-elect of the American Mathematical Society, which condemned the decision last month.
Professors at other universities in the United States and abroad have urged Rochester to reconsider. Dr. Steven Weinberg, a Nobelist in physics, in one of the many letters sent to Rochester's president, Thomas H. Jackson, wrote: "It seems to me extremely unwise to eliminate your program in an area like mathematics, that stands at the intellectual center of a large part of modern science."
The physicist Herman Feshbach, a former president of the American Physical Society and a professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technolgy, put it bluntly: "In one fell swoop you have reduced the University of Rochester to a second-class status," he wrote.
Rochester defends its decision as necessary and sound in a time of budget constraints, pointing to operating deficits and a math department of only modest distinction. University officials say Rochester is only facing up to what other universities will also increasingly be called upon to deal with, as universities face financial pressures because of declining Federal aid, tuition revenues and state support.
"This is an issue almost every university is going to have to wake up to," Mr. Jackson said. "Most universities are going to have to pick and choose. I'm very confident that as hard as this decision was to make, it was the right one."
But even as he reaffirmed the decision, he offered the mathematics department an opportunity to test whether science, engineering and other quantitatively-oriented departments really cared about the program by asking the other departments how much they would be willing to pay out of their own pockets to save the graduate math program. But where the university saw such a poll as a concrete measure of the interest of other departments, the math department saw "the tragedy of the commons," the classic problem described by the ecologist Garrett Hardin, who said that the problem of the overgrazing of a common meadow cannot be solved by asking individuals to limit their cows from grazing voluntarily but must be addressed by a central policy reflecting the interest of all grazers together.
Now that the mathematics faculty members have rejected the idea of the poll, Mr. Jackson says it is up to them to make their case to the other departments.
"The math department needs to start opening the dialogue with other departments," he said yesterday. "They need to listen to them and try to persuade them. If they make headway, we will pay attention."
Mathematics is one of five graduate programs the university is phasing out; university administrators say they have not heard similar complaints over cuts in anthropology, comparative literature, linguistics and chemical engineering.
While the university will suspend its Ph.D. program, it plans to keep 10 of its 21 tenured faculty members and use adjunct professors for entry-level math courses. The cuts in tenured faculty are to be made through attrition.
"I don't disagree that mathematics is a core discipline," said Mr. Jackson. "But does that mean you have to run a Ph.D. program? To me, that linkage is much more tenuous than people in the mathematics community believe it to be."
The furor over the decision has struck a nerve, though, among many academicians worried about who will conduct and pay for research -- particularly theoretical research in subjects like mathematics -- if Federal money for research and higher education is cut. Universities like Rochester have been a large and important part of America's research base for half a century.
So far, Federal financing for scientific research, including mathematics, has held up: According to the National Science Foundation, federally financed expenditures for research in mathematical sciences at colleges and universities grew to $206 million in 1994, up slightly from $203 million the year before.
But many universities, including Rochester, have other financial problems. And there is a broad consensus that too many Ph.D.'s -- including too many mathematics doctorates -- are being produced nationally. When it comes to making cuts, however, there are differences over what should go.
"One can argue that there should be cuts," said M. Salah Baouendi, a mathematician at the University of California at San Diego who headed a committee of the American Mathematical Society that studied Rochester's cutback in math. "But one hopes these cuts would take place at the weaker programs, not the stronger ones, like Rochester."
Few are suggesting that Rochester will lose its standing as a research university. "There is not a standard-issue model of what you have to have to be a first-class research university," said Cornelius J. Pings, president of the Association of American Universities, a by-invitation coterie of 60 research universities, including Rochester.
Still, by cutting back mathematics, Rochester has touched an area long considered sacrosanct -- an integral part of many other disciplines, from engineering and the sciences to the social sciences.
"It is clearly a blow to the status of mathematicians and to their princely egos," said David Breneman, an economist who is dean of the Curry School of Education at the University of Virginia. "But they're not killing off a premiere, top-10 program, and there are probably more institutions that should do something like Rochester has done."
When Mr. Jackson began as president of Rochester in July 1994, the university, like many others, had been running operating deficits for many years. An expert in bankruptcy law who had been provost at the University of Virginia, Mr. Jackson had a broad mandate to position the institution for the long term.
In November, he proposed a broad plan to give the university a new focus on undergraduate education. The plan called for cuts of 20 percent or more in undergraduates and graduate students, and a 10 percent cut in faculty.
To determine which departments to cut, administrators weighed factors that included departments' stature, their finances, their teaching skills and their interrelationships within the university.
The university deemed the math department one of only "modest distinction" (it tied for 58th among 139 departments in the recent rankings by the National Research Council), called its undergraduate instruction "less than optimal" and said that its interaction with other departments at the university was minimal.
The mathematics department contests many of the university's judgments. Not only are its national ratings higher than those of some of the graduate programs being retained, it says, but its teaching ratings have been better than average in the school of science, and its faculty has done better than those of many other math departments at winning outside financing and has more interaction with other departments than the university has recognized.
Joseph Neisendorfer, chairman of the math department, calculates that the annual savings from closing his graduate program, which does not have heavy laboratory and equipment costs, will come to less than $1 million, considering that the average faculty salary in his department is less than $60,000 and that the total annual cost of stipends for graduate students is about $180,000.
Professors have yet to tell him of any plans to leave, he said. But he -- like the university -- anticipates that the best ones, with the most mobility, will.
"I do think you can get a good mathematics education at a small college without graduate programs," he said. "No one would deny that. But they are devaluing the mathematics department in the context of Rochester remaining a research university with other graduate programs. Any mathematician who comes here will be a second-class citizen. How are we supposed to recruit good people in those circumstances?"

HEADLINE: Mexican Drug Gang's Reign of Blood

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MATAMOROS, Mexico

 BODY:
The drug trafficking suspect Juan Garcia Abrego and his men became so brazen, and the citizenry so terrorized, during a decade of bloodshed in this border town that a gunman said to be working for him once shot a municipal policeman dead on a downtown street for giving the gunman a parking ticket and local newspapers largely ignored the crime.
When a young reporter, Oscar Trevino Jr., revisited the murder in a year-in-review piece months later, his publisher ordered the story killed. And when the article made its way into print anyway because of a newsroom mix-up, the publisher called Mr. Trevino to a restaurant to apologize to Mr. Garcia Abrego personally. 
 Mr. Garcia Abrego, who was arrested last month in Mexico and expelled to the United States, is to be arraigned on Tuesday in Houston on charges of cocaine trafficking and money laundering -- but not homicide.
Yet his United States indictment charges that he ordered "the murder of numerous individuals." And residents of his hometown, across the border from Brownsville, Tex., said he had ordered scores of killings. Many of their accusations have been corroborated by court testimony.
"The history of Matamoros during the reign of Juan Garcia Abrego was painted in blood and shame," said Jesus Cruz Medrano, an editor at the newspaper El Bravo. "For years, we have all lived in enormous fear."
Those whose murders Mr. Garcia Abrego is accused of ordering include disloyal subordinates, commercial adversaries, crusading journalists, hostile witnesses and romantic rivals. Many victims, like the two-month-old baby killed by mistake when the reputed trafficker's gunslingers sprayed a Matamoros home with automatic rifle fire in 1991, have been complete innocents.
Eduardo Valle, a senior Mexican Government investigator who pursued Mr. Garcia Abrego in 1993 and 1994, said the reputed trafficker was careful to isolate himself from killings. "He never gave instructions personally to his triggermen," Mr. Valle said.
Killers in many cases included Tamaulipas state and federal police officers, Mr. Valle said. The policemen were among hundreds of Government officials, including a deputy attorney general, to whom Mr. Garcia Abrego is said to have paid millions of dollars in monthly bribes.Mr. Valle and others contend that the reputed trafficker's ties to the Government of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari went even higher.
Whether such matters will be discussed during his trial is not clear. During Mr. Garcia Abrego's first interview with Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in Houston last month, he said he "would be glad to answer any and all questions" the agents asked him, the F.B.I. says. But his lawyer, Roberto Yzaguirre, said his client was not cooperating with prosecutors and would plead not guilty.
Asked about accusations that Mr. Garcia Abrego had ordered murders, Mr. Yzaguirre's assistant, Michael L. Sinder, said, "We don't intend to discuss Mr. Abrego's life with anybody."
Mr. Garcia Abrego's reputation for brutality first emerged in 1984, when he was a 39-year-old multimillionaire, the head of one of Mexico's rising drug gangs. During a battle for control of the Matamoros border with a rival trafficker, Casimiro Espinosa, one of Mr. Garcia Abrego's aides ambushed and badly wounded Mr. Espinosa.
At dawn the next day, May 17, 1984, gunmen in camouflage uniforms burst into the Raya Clinic, a private hospital where Mr. Espinosa was convalescing. During their 10-minute attack, they fired off 300 rounds, killing a guard, a husband and son who were visiting their ailing mother, a bedridden 35-year-old woman, and Mr. Espinosa's sister.
Mr. Espinosa survived the mayhem, but died of his original wounds days later.
Two years later, Ernesto Flores, 48, the editor of El Popular, then the largest-circulation daily in Matamoros, and a reporter, Norma Morena, were slain. Gangsters waiting at the newspaper entrance blasted the journalists' car with gunfire, then killed them with shots to the face.
One of Mr. Garcia Abrego's assistants, who took refuge in the United States later, said publicly that Mr. Garcia Abrego -- irritated by El Popular articles -- had ordered Mr. Flores's murder.
In 1991, a hired gunman named Armando Barrera took refuge in Brownsville and in a sworn deposition accused Mr. Garcia Abrego of ordering the murder of his brother and 35 other people. Most of the victims were shot to death, but some were tortured, burned alive or tied up and hurled into rivers, Mr. Barrera said.
Months after lodging his accusations, Mr. Barrera was gunned down in Brownsville.
Despite the seemingly endless bloodletting in Matamoros, there has been little protest about Mr. Garcia Abrego's presence. Hundreds of millions of dollars in drug proceeds have filtered back into the local economy, and people associated with him own banks, farm machinery and auto dealerships, clothing and shoe stores, real estate and construction companies, hotels, restaurants, seed companies, gas stations and farms, according to court testimony and interviews here.
In a city that was at once so bloodied and so compromised, community leaders -- politicians, lawyers, journalists -- have largely remained silent about the narcotics violence, said a Matamoros lawyer who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"What do you do in a city like this?" the lawyer said. "You keep quiet."
But Mr. Garcia Abrego's arrest has encouraged some new candor. On the day after his expulsion from Mexico, the headline in PM, the afternoon newspaper in Matamoros, read: "An End to 10 Years of Narco Terror!"

HEADLINE: Needs of Poor Veterans Draw New V.A. Focus

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: PERRY POINT, Md.

 BODY:
At a time when the Federal Government is squeezing many social programs, the veterans medical center here, on a serene 400-acre campus on Chesapeake Bay, has opened a cozy new refuge for people like Stanford Avant.
After his discharge from the Marine Corps, with which he had served in Vietnam, Mr. Avant spent 25 tortured years "drinking and drugging," as he puts it, on the streets of Wilmington, Del. Now he is 46, and he has been at Perry Point since a sanctuary for homeless veterans opened here in September. 
 He gets free health care, three meals a day and a room with a desk, a chair, a chest of drawers and, on the bed, a bright fluffy quilt. He also receives psychiatric and job-preparation counseling. "I'm feeling like I'm worth something," he said.
The Department of Veterans Affairs is best known for its network of hospitals, which continues to expand despite a decline in the population of veterans and despite health care trends that are forcing many other hospitals to close. But now the department's insulation from the fiscal and political pressures confronting the rest of the Government has helped give it an important new role as an agency that cares for the poor.
And a poor veteran often gets assistance that a welfare recipient accustomed to nothing more than cash or food stamps might find lavish.
"If you're a vet," said Martha Burt, director of social service research at the Urban Institute, a Washington-based research organization, "you have a resource that a lot of other people don't have."
With the plunge in the number of war-maimed veterans treated at the agency's 173 hospitals, the V.A. has been turning more of its attention to veterans who are among the nation's drug-addicted or indigent, mentally ill or physically disabled. To qualify, most need only have put in some time in the service, in combat or not, in wartime or peacetime.
"If you serve 180 days on active duty," said one Republican Congressional aide who specializes in veterans issues, "and if for whatever reason you do not succeed in life, you get this complete safety net."
As a result, a department that is the nation's largest employer of doctors and nurses has also become the largest employer of social workers, with 4,241 on the payroll last year.
The cost of programs for homeless veterans, though still a minuscule part of all Veterans Affairs spending, has more than doubled in three years, to $75 million from $32 million, and much of that is used to support 94 centers like the one here. Such programs are often the sole source of help to a part of the population -- single men -- for whom access to other kinds of government aid is the most restricted because they generally do not have dependent children.
As for total spending, while many Federal agencies face cuts under White House and Congressional proposals alike for the still-unsettled 1996 budget, Veterans Affairs, supported as strongly as ever by a politically potent phalanx of veterans organizations, appears assured at least a small increase from the $37.7 billion of the last fiscal year. President Clinton has proposed adding $1.7 billion, and he has vetoed legislation that would have added $200 million.
Given Washington's tight-budget environment, Veterans Affairs Secretary Jesse Brown, a Vietnam veteran whose right arm was disabled in combat, has had to contend with a new skepticism from Congressional Republicans and the White House Office of Management and Budget toward a V.A. spending request that once would have gone unchallenged. "Everybody beat up on me," Mr. Brown said.
But in thwarting big budget cuts, he said, he has been supported by Mr. Clinton, whom many veterans berate for having avoided the Vietnam-era draft and who is sensitive to their political power.
Mr. Brown notes that the agency is required by mandate to provide free health care to only some 10 million veterans, about 40 percent of the nation's total of 26 million.
Fewer than half of the men and women it must serve are those, rich or poor, who are at least 50 percent disabled by "service-connected" conditions: illnesses and injuries that occurred during active duty or that, years after discharge, can be traced to active duty. The others whom the V.A. must serve are loosely defined as poor, those whose annual incomes are less than $20,469, which is close to the average earnings of an American worker.
Many members of both groups are covered by private health insurance or Medicare, however, and so those who actually enter a Veterans Affairs center for free care are often very poor. Twenty-seven percent of all new V.A. hospital patients are homeless, Mr. Brown says, and so the agency is becoming more attentive to their needs as a whole.
In addition to free medical care, many veterans receive monthly benefit checks. An indigent veteran who has a disability wholly unrelated to his years in the service can collect $650 a month. To qualify, he must have served at least 90 days (including at least one day during wartime, though not necessarily in a combat zone) and be unemployable because of the disability. Last year, that program supported 432,000 veterans.
Benefits for veterans with service-connected disabilities are more generous -- up to $1,800 a month -- and wartime service is not required. Under that program last year, 2.2 million veterans received checks that averaged $400 a month.
Perry Point specializes in psychiatric care but has added care for homeless veterans in "domiciliaries," a uniquely V.A. institution that once provided just meals and shelter for indigent veterans but has now expanded to treat various conditions that they bring in from the street.
The room, board and counseling in domiciliaries accommodate just 6,000 a year of the 250,000 former servicemen who the agency estimates are homeless. But through hospitals and clinics, alcohol and drug treatment centers, job training and rehabilitation, subsidized care for the house-bound and outreach offices in cities, Veterans Affairs reaches hundreds of thousands of other poor veterans.
Phyllis Osbun, acting chief of the domiciliary care program here, opened Perry Point's first domiciliary for the homeless in September and will add another this year, so that in all she will be able to serve 50 clients. To be admitted, a veteran may have an income of no more than $1,100 a month.
The common denominators among Ms. Osbun's clients are alcoholism, drug addiction and the mental disorders that can arise from either.
Reginald Marks spent his time as a marine in Japan and at Camp Lejeune, N.C., mostly as a clerk who was trusted with supervision of supply cages containing weapons and ammunition. After his discharge, he says, he took to drinking and drugs. Then, about three years ago, a girlfriend accused him of assaulting her. "I was drunk," Mr. Marks said. "I really don't know if I hit her."
He was convicted and spent two years in jail. Upon his release, he said, a V.A. counselor asked him whether he wanted to continue his life sober. "I said yes," the 39-year-old Mr. Marks recalled, "and they sent me over to the dom." After four months here, he said, "this is the first time in 20 years I've been sober for this long."
In defending against budget cuts those programs that help veterans like Mr. Marks, Secretary Brown, former president of the Disabled American Veterans, makes a distinction between veterans and everyone else the Government helps: veterans earned their care, he says, by volunteering, or being forced through the draft, to risk their lives in defense of the nation.
"When I think of veterans," Mr. Brown said, "I think of missing legs, missing arms. There's a moral obligation that the nation has to those who served it and served it well."
That obligation, he said, applies equally to peacetime veterans. "I have no problem providing that person with full medical care," he said, "because that woman or man was there for the nation if need be."
Veterans' advocates say the V.A. fills holes that have been torn in the safety net of nonveterans programs. In addition to helping ill, disabled and poor men, it is an important source of aid to drug abusers and alcoholics -- all people whom other Federal programs either reject or have made targets of spending reductions.
"We are the only ones out there that can actually respond to people like that," Mr. Brown said. "Society should say, 'Thank God for the V.A.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Department of Veterans Affairs says 27 percent of all new V.A. hospital patients are homeless. So the department is devoting new attention to their broadest needs, partly by creating "domiciliaries" and expanding other programs at existing medical centers like this one in Perry Point, Md. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: With First Voting Near, Republicans Ask Who Can Win

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 3

 BODY:
In the final weekend of campaigning before the first actual votes are cast, candidates for President stormed around New Hampshire, Iowa and Louisiana today, each jousting for advantage in an atmosphere that is looking increasing volatile.
What was most notable about the dialogue on the campaign trail today, as in recent weeks, was that it had not evolved into a debate over the budget machinations on Capitol Hill or over one defining issue like the economy, as was the case here four years ago. 
 Instead, there seems to be no overwhelming issue other than the candidates' squabbling over whether a flat tax is good for America and what form it should take and over who has the best chance of beating President Clinton in November.
The first test is at the Louisiana caucuses on Tuesday. But that will be a showdown between Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and the conservative commentator Patrick J. Buchanan because most of the other candidates chose not to compete. They did not want to offend Iowa and New Hampshire voters who were threatened by another state's horning in on their tradition of holding the first contests.
After a year of sitting atop a commanding lead in the polls, Senator Bob Dole is struggling to keep his front-runner position in the first two important battlegrounds, Iowa and New Hampshire, as his rivals are fighting for the chance to take him on. Several have cast themselves as Washington outsiders and sought to outflank each other on the right.
Kicking off a three-day tour of Iowa, which holds caucuses on Feb. 12, Mr. Dole acted very much like the front-runner. "We are the front-runner," Mr. Dole told about 200 supporters gathered at the Holiday Inn in Dubuque this morning. "We know we're going to take a lot of heat. A lot of people are spending a lot of money. But we've got a message to tell the people in Iowa, and we're going to stick with that message."
Mr. Dole pointedly avoided mentioning the names of any of his opponents, particularly Steve Forbes, the publisher who has threatened to topple his lead in the polls in recent days. The majority leader left it to the other candidates today to keep up their attacks on Mr. Forbes, though later on at an event in Indianola his aides passed out news releases criticizing Mr. Forbes.
After a rather lackluster run-up to the primary season, in which the most excitement seemed to be over whether Colin L. Powell would run, the candidates were beginning to display signs of the excitement of a campaign in full force.
"We've had the warm-up now for some time," Mr. Dole said, "and we're ready to go."
While Mr. Dole had Iowa virtually all to himself today, the most frenetic stumping was here in New Hampshire, where voters in the nation's first primary, on Feb. 20, were courted not only by a handful of Republicans but also by the President.
Mr. Clinton, who has the luxury of being unopposed in the primaries, maintained such a posture of Presidential reserve that it was hardly possible to tell that he was a candidate. In appearances at a police substation and parish hall in Manchester and in a roundtable discussion on small business at a hydraulics company in Merrimack, he assured his listeners that the question was no longer whether big government was acceptable but how to make a small government work more sensitively and efficiently.
The President did engage in some real campaigning. He started his day at the Chez Vachon diner on this city's west side, which he visited twice in the 1992 campaign. He had a vegetarian omelet with no cheese but indulged in pan-fried potatoes.
"Here's where it all started," Mr. Clinton said as he walked around the restaurant. "It's wonderful. It's good to be back."
But campaigning just a few miles away, in hamlets and towns that were newly covered by an overnight snowfall, the Republican contenders eagerly engaged in bald political jockeying. They were spurred to press hard by recent polls that show Mr. Dole may not have an easy stroll to the nomination.
A daily tracking poll of 485 people released today by the American Research Group here in Manchester showed that as of Friday among likely primary voters, Mr. Dole had 23 percent. But it also showed that Mr. Forbes's momentum may be slowing. He has hovered in today's poll and earlier ones around 18 percent, while Mr. Buchanan was creeping up and is now also at 18 percent. The margin of sampling error is plus or minus five percentage points.
Speaking to an audience that packed the Town Hall in Nashua, N.H., Mr. Gramm hammered away at Mr. Forbes, whom he wants to knock out of the way before he can take on Mr. Dole, by portraying him as a liberal.
"Bill Clinton on many issues would run to the right of Steve Forbes," Mr. Gramm asserted. "Bill Clinton is the only liberal in this campaign. Let's keep it that way."
Nearby, a the Hesser College gymnasium in Manchester, Mr. Forbes ignored Mr. Gramm and others as he set his sights on the leading contender, Mr. Dole. He called on Mr. Dole to drop a television commercial that asserted that Mr. Forbes's flat tax proposal would raise taxes in New Hampshire.
"All of my advertisements have been issue oriented," said Mr. Forbes. But the targets of many of his commercials have accused Mr. Forbes of distorting their positions.
While most of the campaigning was in New Hampshire, Mr. Buchanan stumped through Louisiana today in a final push before the caucuses on Tuesday. He said that the competition was turning in his favor with the endorsement on Friday of Gov. Mike Foster, who chided Mr. Gramm for accepting donations from the gambling industry.
Like Senator Gramm, Mr. Buchanan also portrayed Mr. Forbes as a liberal. "I think the Dole campaign continues to implode," Mr. Buchanan said in an interview from a car phone on his way to the Sylvester Crawfish Processors in Whiteville, La. "At some point the voters are going to catch up that behind all the videotape of Steve Forbes's ads is a social liberal."
Unlike four years ago, when New Hampshire was in a slump and the economy was the prevailing issue, the candidates this year have been searching for issues that would hit home with the voters. Even before 1992, there seemed to be more dominant issues, like the cold war or inflation.
"The primary is very volatile right now and I would say every Presidential primary is volatile at this point," said Robert Craig, a political science professor at the University of New Hampshire. "But with this one there are no clear anchors of issues. There are no clear points of view for voters."
Morry Taylor, the Michigan businessman, also campaigned in New Hampshire today, and Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana was due here on Sunday. Former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee took a break and was home in Nashville today.
One voter, Henry Bertel, 54, a pipefitter from Somersworth, said the campaign was reaching an intense stage but less from actual campaign than from the saturation of television commercials.
"It's pretty intense right now," he said. "And it's because of that fellow Forbes and what he's done on television."

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Governor a Tough Rival for Senator Kerry

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
While it swept across most other parts of the country, the Republican revolution of 1994 spared Massachusetts. Not a single incumbent Democrat in Congress lost, leaving unchanged the state's reputation as one of the most left-leaning in the nation.
But this year, Republicans in Massachusetts are crowing. They not only see a chance to pick up a seat or two in the House delegation, where the Democrats outnumber them 8 to 2, but in Gov. William F. Weld, they also see a challenger to Senator John Kerry who might be popular and personable enough with his hybrid form of Republicanism to win a Senate seat for his party. The last time a state Republican did that was in 1972, when Edward W. Brooke was re-elected to a second Senate term. 
 At the same time, by leaving the Statehouse so soon after his re-election in 1994, Mr. Weld has catapulted the race into national prominence as a contest between two popular officeholders with opposing views on most issues, some that even set them apart in their own parties.
Mr. Kerry's supporters, many of them impressed with Mr. Weld's success in reducing the size of the state government and cutting taxes 11 times in five years, say that Mr. Kerry, who is seeking a third term and is one of the remaining moderate Democrats in the Senate, has never faced such a tough election. Calling Governor Weld "the strongest Republican in Massachusetts," Representative Martin T. Meehan, a Democrat from Lowell, conceded, "He's a threat, no question about that."
As Republican Presidential candidates like Bob Dole, Phil Gramm and Patrick J. Buchanan try to outflank one another on the right, Mr. Weld represents a more iconoclastic mix -- fiscal conservatism, social libertarianism and a strongly held view that "government ought to do less with less," as the Governor said today in an interview in his office.
That combination has played well around the state, supporting a notion that Massachusetts, which Bill Clinton won in 1992 with 48 percent of the vote, might not be so liberal as its national image suggests.
While registered Democrats outnumber Republicans about 3 to 1, Mr. Weld has been elected twice with support from moderates of both parties. He won in 1994 with 71 percent of the vote, while Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the standard bearer of liberalism, won a sixth term by his lowest margin ever, with 58 percent of the vote to 41 percent for his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney.
"Bill Weld is consciously trying to carve out a spot on the ideological spectrum," said David Osborne, a co-author of the book "Reinventing Government" (Addison-Wesley, 1992), "that is different from where gravity is in the national party. He is probably where Republicans need to go to be the dominant party in the future."
After winning the governorship by three percentage points over his Democratic opponent, John R. Silber, in 1990, Mr. Weld immediately set his views of minimalist government in motion. He balanced the budget in his first year in office, cut taxes seven times, reduced the growth rate of Medicaid from 20 percent to less than 3 percent and eliminated 8,000 state jobs. After his re-election in 1994, Mr. Weld passed the most stringent welfare legislation in the nation, cut taxes four more times and proposed further reductions in the size of state government.
Like many Republicans, he supports the death penalty, term limits and $245 billion in tax cuts that Republicans say will balance the Federal budget, all of which Senator Kerry opposes. But the Governor steps away from other party-line positions by supporting President Clinton's national service program and his 1994 crime bill. He also supports gay rights, abortion rights, environmental protection, student loans, grants for university research and development, and tax credits for low-income wage earners.
Mr. Weld has also tried to distance himself from his recent characterization of Speaker Newt Gingrich as "my ideological soul mate" by saying, "That was probably too strong an imprint for this state."
Many Massachusetts voters have suggested that Mr. Weld has grown bored with being Governor. But he assures them that is not the case at all.
"I've got this place running pretty well," he said. "I'm amazed that in Washington they have not been able to do what we are doing here. I am surprised to the extent Washington lets partisanship get in the way of results. I think I can make a difference there, a big difference."
Mr. Kerry argues that Mr. Weld's policies have failed to address the economic insecurities facing average citizens.
Mr. Kerry's solutions to those problems, a mix of public-private collaboration in which government would play a leading role in education and job-training programs, make him also appear to be something less than a cookie-cutter member of his party. While he shares concerns with other Democrats over tax breaks and subsidies for businesses, a policy that opponents call corporate welfare, he supports programs that he says will promote economic growth, like reduced capital gains taxes, and has questioned some aspects of affirmative action.
"This is the fight, one of the most important in a long time," the Senator said the other day over a bowl of clam chowder, echoing themes that Mr. Clinton raised in his State of the Union Message last week. "Not only do we have a fiscal deficit in this country, but also a cultural and spiritual deficit. These also need to be addressed, and I don't accept the view that government has no role."
Mr. Kerry cited the Works Progress Administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy's support for strengthening the economy through tax cuts and incentives as examples of government at his best. "I'm in favor of a smaller Federal Government," he said, "one that's less bureaucratic but also one that provides greater empowerment of communities."
Both candidates were born into wealthy families within 19 months of each other -- Mr. Kerry is 52, Mr. Weld 50 -- and they share similar pedigrees. Mr. Kerry is a lawyer from Yale, Mr. Weld a lawyer from Harvard. Both served as prosecutors before running for office. And both lost before they won.
By the late 1960's, however, they were headed down different political paths. Mr. Kerry served in the Navy in Vietnam and became a decorated hero, but when he returned he organized Vietnam veterans in 1971 to protest against the war. A bad back kept Mr. Weld out of the war.
Watching veterans struggle in their return to civilian life helped convince Mr. Kerry that government should play a leading role helping less fortunate people become productive citizens. Mr. Weld, meanwhile, became fascinated with the works of Friedrich A. von Hayek, an economist who warns against the increasing power of government.
With the campaign just beginning, each has already found the other an easy target. Mr. Weld said he planned to "hang the nanny state around my opponent's neck," a reference to the Democrats' softer line on welfare and Mr. Kerry's willingness to maintain a larger government than Mr. Weld.
Mr. Kerry said he would attack Mr. Weld as an aloof administrator whose policies abandoned people who most needed help to adjust to economic change. The Senator said he would question Mr. Weld's consistency on some issues, like his support for immigrants rights and his early endorsement of Gov. Pete Wilson of California, whose brief Presidential campaign highlighted anti-immigrant positions.
But the larger question is whether a popular Republican Governor can convince a largely Democratic electorate that his unusual mix of politics would better serve the country when Republicans and Democrats in Washington can agree on little more than the weather.
That is just the point that might scare away the Democrats Mr. Weld needs to win.
"To most people he's, hands down, superior to John Kerry," said Mr. Osborne, the author. "But my gut says he can't win. People in Massachusetts don't want to send another vote to Washington for Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich."

He says government must address the economic insecurities of workers. (Evan Richman for The New York Times); Gov. William F. Weld, just a year after re-election, hopes to become the first Republican elected to the Senate from Massachusetts since 1972. Mr. Weld's policies mix fiscal conservatism with social libertarianism. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Where Big Snowfalls Are No Reason to Moan

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo., Feb. 2

 BODY:
Against the brilliant white landscape of a 10,450-foot summit here, a snow blower worked doggedly today, clearing a path to allow an aerial ski tram to pass without dragging through snow drifts.
"There was not enough room for the chairlifts to run," Scott Caplan, 21, of Philadelphia, said of the record snowfall that blanketed Jackson Hole this week. "Until now, I had never skied in powder up to my waist." 
 From the Tetons to the southern Rockies, ski boots are squeaking in freshly packed powder as skiers line up to take advantage of January snowfalls that were double and sometimes triple monthly averages.
For an industry haunted by stagnating ticket sales and by the aging knees of baby boomers, the January blizzards give the sport, in the par lance of mogul-jumping snow boarders, "free air."
The Rockies, the nation's dominant ski region, sold 50 percent more ski-lift tickets last year than either of its closest rivals, the Northeast or the Pacific West.
"If it snows, they will come," said Kelly Ladyga, spokeswoman for Colorado Ski Country U.S.A., a resort group for the state that attracts the biggest number of skiers. "We are like snow farmers. And without the snow, the skiers stay away."
Last winter, skier days across the nation were down by 3.6 percent from the previous season. With spotty snowfalls giving this season a bumpy start, Colorado's skiing days were down by 2 percent last November and December.
But today, much of the Rocky Mountains, from Wyoming to Utah to Colorado, looks as if it had been hit by a pastry chef who was overgenerous with icing. Fresh snow hangs from eaves, sometimes joining drifts on the ground in unbroken snowy arcs.
At Jackson's airport, where jets touch down daily with Eastern skiers, piles of snow bulldozed from the tarmac rise as high as the one-story terminal. In Breckenridge, Steamboat Springs and other Colorado ski towns, shoppers thread their paths through shoulder-high mazes created by unrelenting snowfalls.
In Frisco, another Colorado ski town, traffic accidents have doubled, crews have trucked 8,500 tons of snow from the business district, and workers have dug holes in snow mounds to uncover fire hydrants and stop signs.
"February and March are typically our big snow months," said Tim Mack, director of public works for this alpine town 75 miles west of Denver. "So now we are wondering where we will put all of this snow when we get more in the next couple of months."
With Colorado's high country disappearing under eight and a half feet of snow in January, 15 of the state's 23 ski resorts recorded record January snowfalls.
The champion was Steamboat Springs, which recorded slightly over 18 feet, nearly triple the normal January snowfall. Steamboat's January snowfall is the largest recorded for any month in Colorado in this century.
In a publicity coup for a publicity hungry industry, the Steamboat Ski and Resort Corporation happened to be the host of a six-day convention of television weather reporters in late January.
Mike Lane, the resort's spokesman, said: "With 20 weathermen from around the country, and 105 live shots from the area, once the snow dumped on us, people were seeing it in their hometowns all over the country. And then the calls started coming in."
Here in the Tetons, Seth Konheim, a 33-year-old New Jerseyite, disembarked from Jackson's ski tram this morning for his first run. Joining three friends from New York, he said, "We've been tracking the weather from New York for several days now."
Around the Rockies, resort operators report that bookings are heavy for the Presidents' Weekend this month, the industry's February high point.
After 8 feet of snow fell in 10 days on Crested Butte, resort operators sealed a deal with American Airlines to provide daily jet service for six weeks from Dallas to Gunnison, the nearest airport to the southern Colorado ski area.
For Vail, the nation's largest ski area, 14 feet of new snow in January was a blessing. With snow falling 26 days in January, Vail received almost triple is normal snow quota.
Here at Jackson Hole, the 10-foot snowpack has stunned skiers, amateur and professional, young and old.
"It's been awesome," Joni Madere, a 25-year-old Jackson waitress, said today as she clutched her snowboard, waiting for the aerial tram.
Pepi Steigler, an Austrian Olympic gold medalist who started the ski school here 30 years ago, preferred to call conditions "superb."
"The quality is unbelievably good," said Mr. Steigler, a veteran whose creased face spoke of a life on the slopes. "We haven't seen this kind of snow in over a decade. We used to have it in the '60's and '70's."
At the base of Jackson's tram, in an office adjacent to spinning flywheels, these words were confirmed by statistics kept by Larry Livingood, an avalanche hazard forecaster for the resort. Last Sunday, Mr. Livingood's sensors measured 24 inches that had fallen in 24 hours.
"In 30 years, that's the most snowfall we have ever seen," he said, running a finger down snow statistics recorded since the resort opened here in 1966. The ski area's total January snowfall of 140 inches was the highest January accumulation since 1970.
In the Rockies, this symphony in white also brought a few discordant notes.
In Idaho, Sandra Day O'Connor, the 65-year-old Supreme Court Justice and skiing enthusiast, broke her right shoulder on Tuesday while testing Sun Valley's new powder. She was reported to be recuperating well.
In Colorado, five small mountain passes were still blocked by snow avalanches.
On Friday, a ski patrol, concerned about skiers' safety, set off an avalanche that ended up burying three cars, two snowplows and a shuttle bus at the Loveland ski area. The site of the avalanche, which swept away 100-year-old trees on a quarter-mile path, might become a new ski run.
In Wyoming, road crews were only able to open today a mountain highway pass that had been blocked between here and Idaho since Sunday. With the road closed, many service workers who live in Idaho were unable to commute to work this week in this affluent community.
North of here, heavy snow forced officials to close Yellowstone National Park for two days. In recent years, snowmobile tours of the park have become a major contributor to Jackson's winter economy.
"The only way I can get out is by snowshoeing for two miles," said one of several snowbound residents here, Jean Weiss, managing editor of Jackson Hole magazine.
With frigid weather and a massive snowfall pushing pockets of the Rockies back in time, it seems fitting that Sunday will see the re-inauguration of an old pastime here.
With shouts of "yee" and "haw," parka-clad mushers from around Arctic North America are to drive their husky teams down Jackson's snow-covered streets for the first International Rocky Mountain Stage Stop Sled Dog Race.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With record January snowfalls blanketing the Tetons and Rockies, skiers are enjoying powder conditions like some of them had never seen. Aaron Brown, 32, of Glen, Ridge, N.J., on a slope this week at Teton Village, Wyo. Snowfalls were double and sometimes triple monthly averages. (Jim Evans for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A DIRECTORY OF WORLD CRUISES;
Busy Seas, Exotic Ports

BYLINE: By VERNON KIDD; VERNON KIDD writes about ship travel and music festivals for the Travel section.

 BODY:
IN a wait-and-see economic climate, at least nine major new ships will be sailing this year, some of them having entered service in December, and others are planned for introduction as far ahead as 1999.
Two new ships, which together added space for 3,700 passengers at the end of 1995, are the Sun Princess, at 77,000 tons Princess Cruises' largest ship, which entered service in Fort Lauderdale, and the Century, Celebrity Cruises' first 70,000-ton ship, which made an elegant entry into New York after a storm-tossed Atlantic crossing. At the end of a week of festivities, she headed for the warm waters of the Caribbean. 
 Noteworthy among other new ships is the Destiny of Carnival Cruise Lines, the first cruise ship in the 100,000-ton category with a capacity of 2,600 passengers. More than half her staterooms will be suites with sitting rooms and balconies, and she will have a nine-deck-high atrium, a three-deck-high auditorium for Broadway-style shows and a three-deck-high slide to one of the pools. Before the Destiny arrives in November, Carnival will launch the 2,040-passenger, 70,367-ton Inspiration next month, and Costa Cruises will introduce the 1,950-passenger, 75,000-ton Costa Victoria in July.
Among others are the 1,750-passenger, 72,000-ton Galaxy of Celebrity Cruises due in December, the 1,266-passenger, 55,000-ton Veendam of Holland America Line, scheduled to enter service in May, and the 1,804-passenger, 69,000-ton Splendour of the Seas and the 1,950-passenger, 74,000-ton Grandeur of the Seas, both of Royal Caribbean Cruises. The Splendour of the Seas is expected next month, and the Grandeur of the Seas is scheduled to arrive in December.
On a smaller scale, Victoria Cruises is introducing its 154-passenger Victoria III this month for service on the Yangtze River, and Swan Hellenic will put its new 300-passenger Minerva, originally announced as the Okean, into service in the Mediterranean in April.
The Mediterranean is continuing to see an increase in ships sailing there on a year-round basis, and both Dubrovnik and Beirut have returned as ports of call. Interest in other offbeat ports like Tartus in Syria and Sousse and Tunis in Tunisia is also growing, and the Trimiti Islands off the Adriatic coast of Italy remain an alternative to ports in the politically tenuous eastern Adriatic. East African ports like Mombasa in Kenya and Dar es Salaam in Tanzania and the islands of Madagascar and the Seychelles are growing in popularity in the Indian Ocean, as is Zanzibar, where investors are seeking to turn the island into a free port that might someday rival Hong Kong.
A new port, Calica, in Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, close to Tulum and Coba, will be visited by Norwegian Cruise Line later this year, and Holland America Line is planning to call there when the port is completed in 1997.
This directory covers sailings from March 1 to Oct. 31. Dates, ports of call and fares are subject to change. Unless otherwise noted, fres are for one person in double occupancy, excluding port taxes. More information is available from travel agents or the cruise lines. Addresses and telephone numbers appear on page 36.

 Princess Cruises

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 2; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1665 words

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Stanley Braginsky;
Why Olympus Decided to Keep American Headquarters on L.I.

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
WHEN Stanley Braginsky became president of Olympus America Inc. in Melville on Oct. 1, 1994, he became the first American to hold that post in the 26 years that the company has been a subsidiary of the Olympus Optical Company of Japan.
Mr. Braginsky, 58, joined the company in 1970. A graduate of Queens College, he first worked at the American Optical Company in Buffalo. 
 He and his wife, Sharon, have three children and live in Dix Hills.
Q. Why were you, an American, selected to head a Japanese-owned company?
A. I think the trend in Japan toward globalization has moved not only from a concept, but in many cases to a reality. The concept of globalization, at least in the Japanese context, is to localize and use as many local people to respond to local markets. And Olympus, being one of the more aggressive and the more optimistic companies, has chosen to go with an American.
Q. Like JVC?
A. So has Sony and some of the larger auto companies. But Sony did it much earlier than the other Japanese companies. It was much more progressive than the others, which did it within the last five years.
Q. Is there a difference in styles?
A. Yes. The concepts of how to do business and the decision making is quite different. Once a decision is made, the flexibility of accommodation is different. I think business generally transcends most cultural issues. Whether you are in business in Japan or the United States or Europe, everybody basically has the same ideas and aims. Customer satisfaction -- the customer is No. 1 -- doesn't vary very much. If you have that as your goal, the way you do business is basically the same. It's a matter of decision making and the inflexibility of the decision making that is different.
Q. Is decision making more of a cooperative venture here?
A. You try to get more of a consensus instead of being autocratic. At times it can be autocratic. But I think consensus is the more ideal procedure in getting things done.
Q. Is that in Melville?
A. No, I think it's general. I try to adopt what I think works in this cultural and social setting from what I've seen in Japan. In many cases it adapts well. In some it doesn't.
Q. What is an example?
A. When you have a staff meeting the style I've been using is that the staff can influence and is informed that it should influence decisions. They don't come from the top down, unless I finally lose my patience. Then you have to take the leadership that is necessary.
Q. Do you come in with a suggestion and ask whether they agree or just lay out the problem to be solved by everyone together?
A. Both ways. It depends on the type of problem. If it's a divisional problem, I ask them to please solve it and come back. If it's a corporate problem, I give them some ideas of how I would like it solved and then have their response. Not that there's a buy-in, but that there's an understanding of what the problem is and how we would like it solved. The style I think is one that fits the two cultures we have to work with, one in Japan and the other in the United States.
Q. Would you recommend it to American companies?
A. It depends on the company. I think it works in many cases. But again, you can't ever fail in leadership, whether you're depending upon a Japanese-based consensus business decision-making process or American autocracy. In all cases leadership management must be basically the same all over the world. The leader has to be perceived as the leader, and he must have a goal, and it has to be made very clear.
Q. So that the people buy into it more?
A. I don't like the word buy-in. Buy-in means you have more or less shifted responsibility. I believe in more of a consensus, where you have made your arguments, and it's more like a court of judgment. Everyone has heard the two sides, and the decision is made, each having an opportunity to sway the opinion. But it isn't a buy-in. Once the decision is made there is no buy-in. You must perform.
Q. What work goes on in the headquarters?
A. This is strictly a business office. We have a manufacturing facility in Albuquerque and a major repair facility in San Jose, Calif.
Q. This was a company that was established in 1968 and had offices in Lake Success and Woodbury.
A. That's correct and that's why we came together here. Consumer products was in Woodbury, and our scientific products were in Lake Success. We wanted to put the two organizations together, get management combined and get the synergies that you get when you can centralize.
Q. When did you start looking for a new building?
A.Over five years ago. We were turned down in Huntington by people who felt we may not be the neighbor they wanted.
Q. Why didn't you leave Long Island?
A. That was considered, seriously considered. But when you consider that a business runs on its people and we have 550 people and many, many of them are very competent, I didn't want to lose them. There would have been a total disruption.
Q. With the Melville site Olympus stayed in Huntington.
A. I live in Huntington Town. The Town of Huntington was in all cases very helpful. It was correct in responding to the concerns that the homeowners had. I don't think it is necessarily a good idea for industry to push its way into areas local residents feel is inappropriate. I have no problem with that. It was just very frustrating that it took so long. It started in 1992 and went through 1993, quite an extended period.
Q. Did the case go to court?
A. The community threatened to go to court. The problem, we felt, when you are dealing with the state against the community is that the courts would stretch this out to some indeterminate date, and our leases were being extended. We had to move. We considered moving off Long Island. The pressures of finding a facility were tremendous, and our expenses and rent all had increased.
Q. Where did you look?
A. We started looking in New Jersey and we were also considering going down to Maryland. We had an office in Columbia, Md.
Q. Had you looked at your present site before?
A. We had looked at this site -- which we moved into about five months ago -- in 1992 and we rejected it. It was a Grumman building, and we felt it was not the structure we wanted. Internally it was not appropriate for our business. But when Mutual of New York picked up the building it was gutted, and the only thing that was left were the girders, the windows and the floors.
Q. How big is the building?
A. Approximately 270,000 square feet.
Q. How many Of the 550 employees are from Long Island?
A. About 500 of them.
Q. Had you spoken to them about relocating?
A. No, we looked at it from a corporate need, and there were so many people that we would have needed that it would have been impossible.
Q. What did the people in Japan say or was it basically up to you?
A. It was up to us. But it's always best to have a consensus. They are very happy, although they think it's a little big. When you compare it to the expensive real estate in Japan, this would be a luxurious site in Japan. It's comparable if not better than the state site.
Q. How do you respond to people who say it is not economical to do business on Long Island because the cost of living, wages, taxes and utility rates are too high?
A. I think some of what you say is correct. Transportation is poor. There is still regional segmentation for schools. Taxes are too high. Our utility rates are too high, and there are too many police departments. What you have here is a redundancy that increases the tax base, and taxes on Long Island are just too high. But the productivity and the people are really what keep companies here. You have Computer Associates and Symbol Technology and other hi-tech companies on Long Island.
I wish the state would support the university at Stony Brook a little more, to give us a "world-class" university on Long Island. We draw and depend upon educated people here, and our university system is under a great deal of pressure. Generally we have a very good labor supply, and that is key to any company.
Q. Where do you hire from?
A. We try to use local people. We are an international company. We sell all over the United States, and our business really is not on Long Island. We also draw people from such places as California and Virginia.
Q. What are the plans?
A. We'll be expanding our product line. We'll be going into digital imaging and communications. But we will also support our four core businesses, our medical health-care group, endoscopes and microscopes, chemistry analyzers, and consumer products such as cameras and tape recorders.
Q. Do you plan to increase business in Latin America?
A.Right now we are in the $50 million range, and I'm planning in the next five years to see a 300 or 400 percent increase.
Q. Where are your products made?
A. Currently, I would say, 95 percent of our equipment is made in Japan. That will shift. Japan is a very expensive provider of equipment. It's of the highest quality, and at times pricing is not as competitive as it used to be. So we'll be looking at broadening our line with competitive products made in the United States, as well as Europe.
Q. Would you hire other companies?
A. That's correct.
Q. What proportion of the products will be made in Japan in the next 10 years?
A. Seventy-five percent or less. That's a major shift, but that helps the company stabilize and be less influenced by the fluctuation of currencies.
Q. As a board member of the Long Island Association, what would you like to see it concentrate on?
A. We would like to see it take the lead in fostering technology and technology companies on Long Island. There are very particular problems that these companies have such as manpower and government regulations. Sometimes there are government regulations that are eliminated that do not support American technology.

HEADLINE: A Church Asunder Awaits the Pope in Salvador

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR

 BODY:
Gunned down by a right-wing death squad in 1980 as he was celebrating Mass, Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero has been revered ever since as "the saint, prophet and martyr of Latin America" by the progressive wing of the Roman Catholic Church here and throughout the region.
But when the Vatican needed to name a new Archbishop of San Salvador last spring, Pope John Paul II chose to ignore that legacy. Instead of turning to a close associate of Archbishop Romero, as the clergy here had requested and the Pope had done on an earlier occasion, the Pontiff selected Bishop Fernando Saenz Lacalle. Bishop Saenz is a Spanish-born prelate who is a former Vatican liaison with the Salvadoran Armed Forces and a clerical member of Opus Dei, a conservative lay organization dedicated to promoting traditional Catholic doctrine. 
In a country still reeling from the dozen years of civil war in which Archbishop Romero and 75,000 other people were killed, most of them by the Salvadoran Army, Rome's decision came as a shock. And the impact of the move has reverberated far beyond this small Central American country named for the Savior, which John Paul II will visit as part of a trip beginning Monday that will also take him to Guatemala, Nicaragua and Venezuela.
Perhaps more than any other recent development, the elevation of Bishop Saenz signals that the theology of liberation, the doctrine that has largely defined the character of the Roman Catholic Church in Latin America for more than a quarter of a century, has been forced into retreat. Wherever the Pope sets foot on his trip, he is likely to find a church divided along ideological lines and struggling to adapt to a new theological climate.
Across Latin America, dozens of activist bishops are being replaced by clerics who "toe the line very carefully on issues of doctrine, who you might say are yes-men" doing Rome's bidding, said the Rev. Joseph E. Mulligan, an American Jesuit who lives in Nicaragua and has written extensively on the church in Central America.
As a result, he added, the church is experiencing "a pulling back from the strong commitment to social justice and liberation that we saw in the 70's and 80's."
 
Mix of Catholic Dogma And Marxist Economics
The theology of liberation dates to the Second Vatican Council, which from 1962 through 1965 instituted reforms intended to make the Roman Catholic Church more dynamic in its service to "the people of God." As it has evolved over the years, liberation theology has blended Catholic teachings with Marxist economic analysis to provide the theoretical basis for what is called "a preferential option for the poor."
In practical terms, that has led to the creation of "ecclesiastical base communities" in which lay people and clergy analyze religious and political texts and seek to bring about social change. But adherents have clashed with governments throughout Latin America, and some members of base communities have, to the alarm of the Vatican and the local church hierarchy, joined left-wing guerrilla groups.
On his first visit to Central America, in March 1983, the Pope warned the supporters of liberation theology that they were going too far. In Managua, he publicly chastised the Rev. Ernesto Cardenal, a prominent liberation theology advocate who has since been suspended from the priesthood. The Pope was later jeered by leftist supporters of the Sandinista National Liberation Front, then in power in Nicaragua.
As a Pole who had long lived under Communism and worked to insure its fall, John Paul II was naturally suspicious of any school of theology that smacked of Marxism. But in the early years of his papacy, he also gave the Latin American church some leeway and showed himself willing to appoint bishops sympathetic to liberation theology, like Archbishop Romero's immediate successor, Arturo Rivera y Damas.
But over the last decade, the ranks of the liberal theologians have been thinned, at least at the more visible levels of the church hierarchy.
Some, like Jean-Bertrand Aristide in Haiti or the Rev. Fernando Cardenal in Nicaragua, a brother of the priest publicly criticized by the Pope, have been forced to leave the priesthood or resign from their orders.
Others, like six Jesuits who were taken from their residence here and executed by Salvadoran Army troops in 1989, have come to be regarded by many as martyrs.
The attrition has been stepped up by a process of favoring conservative bishops over those who identify with the theology of liberation.
"The fact is that the appointees are distant from social concerns and the Vatican is undergoing an ecclesiastical involution," said the Rev. Jon Sobrino, a Jesuit theologian who teaches at the University of Central America in San Salvador and is the author of books like "Jesus Christ, Liberator."
 
Purging 'Red' Clerics; Redefining 'the Poor'
Typical of the new generation is the 49-year-old Bishop of Esteli, Nicaragua, Abelardo Mata Guevara. In a recent interview with a Nicaraguan church publication, he spoke of "imposing order" after arriving in his diocese in 1988 and purging it of what he called "red clergy."
"Certain priests pushed the idea of a people's church, and thought the bridge for this people's church was in place in Esteli," he said. "They took Esteli as a laboratory for their pastoral experiments, which were nothing more than putting in practice the directives of the Sandinista Front."
A similar process has occurred in Brazil, Mexico, Chile and Colombia. As a result, the Latin American Episcopal Conference, the association of bishops that had twice endorsed the precepts of liberation theology at regional conferences, took a much less sympathetic stance when it last met, in the Dominican Republic in 1992.
With conservatives in control of more and more dioceses, the adherents of liberation theology have found it harder to operate. Bishops are reluctant to back them when disputes arise with civil authorities, there is less money available to support the programs they favor, and "radical" priests sometimes find themselves transferred from parishes where they have put down roots.
In an interview at his office here, Bishop Saenz said he had maintained "a close and sincere friendship" with Archbishop Romero. But he made no effort to mute his disagreement on doctrinal issues with followers of liberation theology who claim Archbishop Romero as their inspiration.
The theology of liberation is in reality based on "a Marxist rereading of the Gospel, with a tendency toward violence," said Bishop Saenz, who at the time of his appointment was an auxiliary to the Bishop of Santa Ana, El Salvador's second-largest city.
"Properly understood, the most orthodox and sound Catholic theology is the true theology of liberation," the new Archbishop said. "Jesus died for our sins, and if we free ourselves from sin, all injustices will disappear."
Furthermore, the "preferential option for the poor" endorsed at Vatican II has been subject to "a series of deviations," Bishop Saenz argued. It should not "transform the church into a church based on classes" nor "limit itself to an economic concept of the poor," but rather should seek to minister to all of those suffering from spiritual poverty, regardless of their social strata.
 
Rebuilding a Church: With Stones or Charity?
But the new Archbishop's critics here say he has gone too far in the other direction, cozying up to the Government, the upper class and the military. That marks a sharp break with the approach taken not only by Archbishop Romero, but also by his successor, Archbishop Arturo Rivera y Damas, and by Bishop Gregorio Rosa Chavez, who had been favored to succeed Archbishop Rivera y Damas, but was passed over.
"Under the three previous archbishops, we saw a separation of church and state," said the Rev. Miguel Ventura, a practitioner of liberation theology who spent much of El Salvador's civil war ministering to left-wing rebels. "Now we are surprised to see the hierarchy seek an alignment of the two."
To many in the church's "popular wing" here, the clearest symbol of that new relationship is Bishop Saenz's decision to resume construction of a Cathedral on a main downtown square here. Archbishop Romero is buried inside, but the structure had been left unfinished since his tenure because, as he once put it, "it is time to build the Church instead of building churches."
But Bishop Saenz has accepted more than $1 million for reconstruction from the Government, big businesses and wealthy families. That deeply offends many in the clergy, who say they can never forget that President Armando Calderon Sol is a member of the political party whose founder ordered the assassination of Archbishop Romero.
"This turnabout is scandalous, given the tradition of this Church," said one priest who considers himself a disciple of Archbishop Romero and spoke on condition that neither he nor his order be identified. "It is abhorrent and it is aberrant."
 
Pope Opts for TV Mass Over a Visit to a Grave
It is hardly surprising that the itinerary of the Pope's nine-hour visit here has also become the object of an intense struggle.
Advocates of liberation theology, as well as many other priests and lay people, want John Paul II to visit the grave of the six slain Jesuits, but Bishop Saenz said "technical reasons" make such a stop impossible.
Instead, the Pope is scheduled to pay a call on Mr. Calderon Sol and to celebrate a televised open-air Mass that is expected to draw one million people or more. "They are mounting a spectacle, as if it were the Rolling Stones or Michael Jackson who were coming," one priest complained.
No matter what the outcome of the papal visit, the advocates of liberation theology say they intend to continue their efforts here, working at the level of individual parishes and base communities. As they see it, the current situation of official hostility is just one more test of their faith.
"The true Church of God is going to have to bear this cross," Father Ventura said. "Christ too felt all of the temporal powers against him, but still managed to strengthen himself. So must we."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS

 BODY:

UNSHACKLING
Oh, Brave New World . . .
Call it the ultimate test of the benefits of competition. Congress finally sorted out its disagreements and passed a bill intended to promote a free-for-all among cable television and broadcasting companies, local and long-distance phone companies and who knows what from the realm of cyberspace. Each of them will be able to offer services now provided by the others. The bill's enthusiasts (only 16 members of the House and 5 senators voted against the bill) and the companies themselves say Americans will have more choices, and companies will compete through lower rates and better service. "We have broken up two of the biggest government monopolies left: local telephone service and cable TV," crowed Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia, who managed the bill through the House. Consumers Union, however, predicted that cable television rates would rise, and others worried about what impact the concentration of power in the broadcasting business would have on local ownership and program content.
 
DIGITAL COMMERCE
In the Name of Security
The fierce rivals Visa International and Mastercard made a rare agreement, and brought along to the peace table two battling software companies, Microsoft and the upstart Netscape. The glue that binds them all is a new technology called Secure Electronic Transactions, which, it is hoped, will mend holes in the pipeline of secure data transmission. The goal is to allow customers to transmit scrambled credit-card numbers to businesses in a way that shuts out snoopers.
 
M&A
A Week's Maneuvering
Baxter International offered $3.8 billion to W. R. Grace for its National Medical unit, which dominates the kidney dialysis market; Mattel abandoned its $5.2 billion bid for Hasbro after Hasbro refused to bargain, citing antitrust concerns, and I.B.M. agreed to pay $743 million for Tivoli Systems of Austin, Tex., a maker of software designed to keep client-server networks healthy.
 
THE ECONOMY
Once More, a Rate Cut
For the second time in six weeks, the Federal Reserve moved to stimulate the economy by nudging down interest rates. The decision to cut by a quarter point the Federal funds rate, to 5.25 percent, and the discount rate, to 5 percent, is likely to ripple through the economy, nudging down the rates charged for corporate borrowing, home mortgages, auto loans and more. And the data showing that economic growth is slowing continue to pile up: the Commerce Department reported that consumer prices rose just 2.5 percent in 1995, the lowest rate in nearly a decade, while the Labor Department reported that nonfarm payroll jobs fell by 201,000 and the unemployment rate rose to 5.8 percent. It all provided fuel for those who criticized the Fed's decision to raise interest rates seven times in 1994-95. Did stomping inflation, they ask, kick the economy in the ribs?
 
INQUIRIES
Study of Milken Intensifies
Taking its investigation of Michael R. Milken, the former junk-bond king, to a new level, the Securities and Exchange Commission assumed subpoena powers, which enable it to compel people to be interviewed and to produce documents. The agency is trying to determine if Mr. Milken, who pleaded guilty in 1990 to securities-law violations, breached an April 1990 order by advising Ted Turner, Rupert Murdoch, Ronald O. Perelman and MCI Communications on recent deals. A lawyer for Mr. Milken described the S.E.C. action as a routine step toward completing its investigation.
 
MUSIC
Standing at the Altar
How important are awards to the performers who generate very substantial revenues for the recording industry? Last week at the American Music Awards, which were created by Dick Clark 25 years ago and poll "a representative sample of record buyers" to pick the winners, Garth Brooks declined the top award of performer of the year. "I can't agree with this," he told the audience, then walked offstage, leaving behind the award.
 
THE NEWS BUSINESS
Is Four a Crowd?
Rupert Murdoch joined the bettors who think either that CNN is vulnerable or the audience can be greatly expanded. Mr. Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation and Fox Inc., announced plans for a 24-hour cable news service and hired Roger Ailes to run it. NBC and ABC previously announced plans for all-news services. Some people speculated that Mr. Murdoch was positioning himself for a long-term attempt to provide news on demand, an audience now being tested by the on-line services.
 
THE NEWS BUSINESS

Rupert Murdoch joined the bettors who think either that CNN is vulnerable or the audience can be greatly expanded. Mr. Murdoch, right, chairman of the News corporation and Fox Inc., announced plans for a 24-hour cable news service and hired Roger Ailes to run it. NBC and ABC previously announced plans for all-news services. Some people speculated that Mr. Murdoch was positioning himself for a long-term attempt to provide news on demand, an audience now being tested by the on-line services.
 
RETAILING
Another Chain Goes Under
Two years after it filed for bankruptcy protection, Merry-Go-Round Enterprises decided to liquidate. All its 536 stores will be shut. The company's management said it would no longer persuade vendors to keep up shipments and financial houses to provide more money to stay afloat. Another apparel chain, Today's Man, filed for bankruptcy protection.
 
NO-SHOWS
Hold That Table!
American Express has been experimenting with a service that imposes a fee on people who make a restaurant reservation and fail to show up. A handful of restaurants are testing the program, imposing a fee of $10 to $25 for each unused reservation, and they say it has sharply reduced no-shows.
 
HEALTH CARE
Cost Rise Again
The cost of employee health are climbed in 1995 and is continuing to rise this year, two surveys of businesses found after a dip in 1994. The increase reflects the higher cost of traditional insurance, the increased demand for new and expensive tests and the number of older and retired employees. The cost of care provided by managed-care networks fell for the first time.
 
PERSONAL COMPUTERS
An Antidote to Clutter
Compaq Computer retained first place among marketers of personal computers, and also rolled out a truly unusual option for PC's: a keyboard with a built-in scanner. The device, which takes up far less desk space than a typical scanner, is included with the Presario model 7232 ($2,199 without monitor) and is a $349 option on 10 other Compaq models. Based on scanner technology licensed from Visioneer, the keyboard will be sold for use with other companies' computers later this year.
 
TRAVEL
Afloat on the Road
The repressive military Government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, which took control in 1988, has not deterred Venice Simplon-Orient-Express Ltd., best known for its luxury train travel, to initiate a new luxury service. The 120-berth cruise ship Road to Mandalay sits in the Irrawaddy River at Pagan, from which it carries passengers to Mandalay and back. (Photo: Business Wire)
