HEADLINE: Coming to a Theater Near You: the Latest Format War

BYLINE: By LAURIE FLYNN 

 BODY:
For movie theater owners, the digital revolution is proving anything but peaceful.
Digital sound systems are bringing resonance and clarity of the quality of compact disks to movies, making it possible to hear the quiet desperation in Oliver Stone's "Nixon" and the gritty mayhem of Martin Scorsese's "Casino." One in five American cinemas is now equipped to play digital soundtracks, and new theaters are being outfitted weekly. 
 The trouble for theater owners is that competing audio formats means that the digital equipment used for a film that drops audiences in the middle of an antiwar demonstration is not the same hardware used to imbue a soundtrack with the chaos of 1970's Las Vegas life.
Three companies -- the Sony Corporation, Dolby Laboratories Inc. and an upstart called Digital Theater Systems Inc. -- are battling to become the preeminent digital standard for movie soundtracks.
And with one system for a single screen costing as much as $11,000, "the competition is very strenuous," said James Fiedler, the president of Sony Dynamic Digital Sound of Culver City, Calif.
Digital Theater, or D.T.S., has its system in the most theaters, but no guarantee that its lead is more than temporary. So some exhibitors are gambling on one technology to eventually triumph over the others.
"Ultimately, one of the formats will win and the other equipment we have bought will be for naught," said Howard Lichtman, an executive vice president of Cineplex-Odeon Theaters, the Toronto company that operates one of North America's largest theater chains. "It's very difficult when you know some of your money will go out the window."
A few ambitious exhibitors, not wanting to risk an inability to screen the next box-office hit in its full aural glory, have armed themselves for all possibilities by cramming projection booths with the three competing types of digital sound systems.
"Theater owners that play movies from all the major studios have to buy equipment from all of us," said Bill Neighbors, vice president and general manager of D.T.S.
Four years ago, "Batman Returns" introduced moviegoers to digital theater audio with a Dolby Digital soundtrack. Since then, theater owners have not been the only ones grappling with the problem.
Film makers must also choose which format to use, in hopes of assuring that their films can play in the greatest number of digitally equipped movie houses. And to insure that the films can be played in the far larger number of movie houses that still use conventional sound systems -- converted screens remain just a fraction of the 25,000 theaters in the United States alone -- all movies must also include an analog track.
With digital audio, a sound is translated into computer code for precise recording and playback. The less precise analog audio technology uses an optical pattern along the edge of the film, in which flashes of light corresponding to actual sound waves are played back by the theater's speaker system.
Since the first "talkie" -- Al Jolson in "The Jazz Singer" in 1927 -- movie sound has generally lagged well behind improvements in color and special effects. But with advances in digital sound, moviegoers can now hear the trampling of rhinoceroses in "Jumanji" and the whistling of the wind in "Pocohantas" with all the clarity and crispness that the films' sound engineers intended.
The development represents a leap in sound quality similar to that delivered to home stereo systems when the CD replaced magnetic tapes and vinyl LP's. Dolby, which introduced stereo sound to theaters 20 years ago, had the advantage of being first with a digital system. But the company soon found that even this edge, and its brand recognition, did not assure market dominance.
In 1993, D.T.S., a company based in Westlake Village, Calif., with financial backing from the film director Steven Spielberg and the MCA/Universal studios, introduced a competing format with the release of Mr. Spielberg's "Jurassic Park."
Many other film makers apparently agreed with Mr. Spielberg's assessment that D.T.S. delivered audio superior to Dolby's. Today, D.T.S. has triple the presence in North America, with 3,305 screens to Dolby's 1,004 -- though Dolby has a greater hold on the international market, with 2,295 screens to D.T.S.'s 1,895.
But D.T.S. is hardly secure. In June 1994, Sony, the parent of Columbia Pictures and Tristar, introduced Sony Dynamic Digital Sound, or S.D.D.S. Despite its late entry into field, Sony's system has managed to gain considerable momentum, with the system installed at 1,502 screens in North America in just 18 months.
Exhibitors and at least some studios hope that one format prevails soon. With a system for a single screen costing from $5,900 to $11,000, buying more than one format for each screen can cost a theater multiplex tens of thousands of extra dollars. For studios, the cost of making a film playable in more than one digital format is smaller, though not insignificant, involving more mixing time and licensing fees.
"This whole industry is still searching for what's going to be 'it,' " said Alan Stokes, vice president of marketing for Metropolitan Theaters, a chain of 130 theaters in Southern California. "The problem is when certain film companies have allegiances to certain sound formats, and you want to be able to play the big films while at the same time keeping an eye on the economics."
Many films today are still produce with just an analog soundtrack, but the trend among many film makers is to introduce pictures in more than one format, sometimes in all three, despite the higher costs.
"Waiting to Exhale," for example, was produced in all three formats to give the movie the largest possible base of potential theaters. "Grumpier Old Men," was released only in Dolby and the Sony system.
In 1995, 67 movies were released in D.T.S. format, 76 in the Sony format and 122 in Dolby Digital. That includes films released in more than one format.
Not everyone cares which format wins in the end. Bruce Marko, a spokesman for MGM/UA, whose releases with digital soundtracks last year included "Get Shorty" and "Leaving Las Vegas," contends that any difference in quality among the formats is imperceptible to the typical moviegoer. A year and a half ago, MGM/UA struck a deal with D.T.S. to release all its films only in that format, but Mr. Marko said that the studio would re-evaluate the market when the contract expires.
"Some people feel one sounds better than another, but I disagree; they all give an enhanced experience," he said. "The technical differences between them are much less than the acoustical differences from theater to theater. The average audience would never be able to tell."

HEADLINE: Media Business Now a Job Fair For Executives Once Removed

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER with GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
For someone who was just thrown out of work, Frank J. Biondi Jr. certainly acts like a busy man. On Thursday, two weeks after he was ousted as the president and chief executive of Viacom Inc., Mr. Biondi raced from one meeting to another before heading to a going-away party at La Grenouille, the venerable midtown restaurant, where his former colleagues toasted him over a lavish dinner of ravioli with lobster and rack of lamb.
"The only difference between this and working," he said in an interview at his temporary offices, "is that people used to come and see me. Now, I go to see them." 
 Mr. Biondi is the newest member of an elite but growing fraternity: top media executives who have been dismissed by their companies and have not yet landed another corporate perch. In the last six months, Viacom, Time Warner, Sony and MCA have all forced out top executives. Time Warner has dismissed the chairmen of two of its five divisions within the last year.
Executives and headhunters said that Mr. Biondi and his unemployed colleagues are the visible products of a wave of anxiety that is sweeping media companies, as consolidation creates a handful of giants and technological change forces relentless questioning of corporate strategy.
The intense coverage of the industry in the news media has added to the instability by turning even divisional executives into celebrities. Like the managers of professional sports teams, media executives now play out their problems under a spotlight, making simple disputes potentially explosive.
"This industry is more volatile and fast paced than most," said Gerard R. Roche, the chairman of Heidrick & Struggles, an executive recruiting firm. "That breeds restlessness on the part of boards and C.E.O.'s."
With Mr. Biondi and others looking for work, the media industry these days has taken on the characteristics of an elaborate job fair. Among the dismissed are Michael J. Fuchs, the former chairman of Home Box Office; Michael P. Schulhof, the former president of the Sony Corporation of America; Al Teller, the former chairman of MCA Music, and Richard E. Snyder, the former chairman of Simon & Schuster, Viacom's publishing unit.
Executives familiar with MCA said Mr. Biondi had lunch in Los Angeles last week with Edgar Bronfman Jr., the new owner of MCA, to explore Mr. Biondi's interest in becoming chief executive of that company. Mr. Fuchs was rumored to be a candidate for the top job at CBS, recently taken over by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, while Mr. Teller's name came up in industry speculation about a senior job at Sony Music Entertainment.
None of these rumors has proved true yet -- which may indicate that it is easier to get fired than hired in today's media industry. Indeed, Mr. Biondi, Mr. Fuchs and Mr. Teller were all producing solid results at their respective companies before they were forced out.
In dismissing Mr. Biondi, Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom, said he believed the company needed to move more aggressively into overseas markets. Although Viacom has already become an $11 billion behemoth through its acquisitions of Paramount Communications and Blockbuster Entertainment, executives close to Mr. Redstone said that he was concerned that he was falling behind another billionaire, Rupert Murdoch, in the race for dominance of the global media marketplace.
Few industry executives hold Mr. Biondi responsible for Viacom's supposed sluggishness. Indeed, several headhunters said that Mr. Biondi's skills as a professional manager would make him more attractive to prospective employers than some of his out-of-work colleagues.
"Frank is the hottest of these guys," said Bill Simon, the managing director of the worldwide entertainment and media division at Korn Ferry in Los Angeles. "He lets the managers run their own businesses. He is also able to deal with the talent side."
The trouble is, as the executives have received more publicity, the line between managers and talent has blurred. People close to Viacom said that relations between Mr. Biondi and Mr. Redstone chilled noticeably after The New Yorker magazine published a lengthy profile of Mr. Biondi in 1994. Mr. Redstone complained to several people that Mr. Biondi had received too much credit for various Viacom deals, including its acquisition of Blockbuster and its sale of cable systems to Tele-Communications Inc.
"The publicity that anyone else got was of no concern to me," Mr. Redstone said yesterday. Then he added: "The fact is, the actual deals were made by me."
Robert J. Morgado, the former chairman of Time Warner's music division, who was ousted last May in a highly publicized power struggle with other music executives, said, "Making decisions in the vortex of such attention sometimes drives people to act perversely."
Mr. Morgado said that as the companies have grown, more of them were falling under the control of a single powerful leader, determined to operate the company like a proprietor. Mr. Redstone often refers to Mr. Murdoch, the News Corporation chairman and the prototypical proprietor, as his model of a chief executive.
Some executives are victims of the proprietor's desire for change. Mr. Teller lost his job at MCA shortly after the Seagram Company, which is controlled by Mr. Bronfman's family, took it over.
Even when they are not the biggest shareholders, some bosses are behaving more like owners. This is partly because the boards of media companies have become more pliable, said several industry experts.
At Time Warner, Mr. Fuchs was dismissed by the chairman, Gerald M. Levin, in a revamping that came on the heels of Time Warner's agreement to acquire the Turner Broadcasting System. In 19 years at HBO, Mr. Fuchs had turned the premium cable channel into a profitable global company. But executives familiar with Time Warner said that Mr. Fuchs opposed the Turner deal. That set him on a collision course with Mr. Levin, who later reorganized Time Warner so that Mr. Fuchs no longer had a place in it.
If Mr. Fuchs and his colleagues tire of searching for their next jobs, they can look to Mr. Morgado for an example of how one can seize the opportunity to chart an entirely new course.
After he was dismissed by Mr. Levin, Mr. Morgado took the estimated $60 million he received in severance from Time Warner and used it to finance a new charitable foundation and a media investment firm.
"What Jerry did was give me my next life, three years early," Mr. Morgado said with a smile, "and he underwrote the transition."

HEADLINE: The Wealthy Town That Has Fostered Forbes
<HEADLINE>Where Less Government Is the Rule

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

DATELINE: BEDMINSTER, N.J.

 BODY:
When Steve Forbes, on the Presidential campaign trail, talks about shrinking the government, his neighbors know where he's coming from: a private and pristine pocket of the country where government still knows its place.
Government's place here is a modest one. There is no municipal garbage collection; it is all done privately. As for water and sewer service, many families have their own wells and septic tanks. The fire and emergency squads are volunteer. When the town needed a library, it turned not to government but to citizens with dynastic names like Forbes and Merck. 
 Even the Department of Public Works is deferential. It posts the schedule for the Essex Fox Hounds on its bulletin board -- so road crews can stay out of the hunt's way and not frighten the horses.
In this election year, Bedminster is Forbes country. But it is not, perhaps, the most typical of American towns. It has produced more than its share of secretaries of the treasury. And it is not unheard of for girls headed to boarding school to take their horses with them.
Horse farms make up most of Bedminster's 27 square miles. Families have lived here for generations, attending the same colleges, going into the same businesses, occasionally marrying into one another.
Bedminster and four neighboring Somerset County towns are known collectively as "the Somerset Hills," and the roster of residents reads like the Social Register cross-indexed to a textbook of American economic history.
There is Mr. Forbes's family, of publishing fame; various heirs to the Mellon banking and Mars candy fortunes; John Z. DeLorean, the former auto maker, and descendants of founders of pharmaceutical-industry giants like Johnson & Johnson and Merck.
There's Jane Engelhard, the widow of Charles Engelhard, the platinum king. Jacqueline Onassis had a farm in the area. There's Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, former Gov. Thomas Kean and King Hassan II of Morocco.
Nicholas F. Brady, Treasury Secretary under President George Bush, lived here until recently. So did C. Douglas Dillon, another former Treasury Secretary and former chairman of the Wall Street investment firm of Dillon, Read & Company.
About an hour from New York City, most of Bedminster is still rural, and people work to keep it that way. About 80 percent of the township is zoned for private lots of 10 acres. The town spent a decade in court trying to defend its zoning against the charge that it discriminated against lower-income people. A developer argued, successfully, that New Jersey law required the township to change its zoning to allow construction of at least some "affordable" housing.
What has resulted is a kind of town within a town -- The Hills, 3,300 condominium units scrambling up the side of Schley Mountain, relatively packed at the rate of 10 units an acre into a corner of Bedminster. A town house begins in the $160,000 range; three- to five-bedroom homes are in the $400,000 range. Among them, 620 are earmarked for low- and moderate-income people.
Along with the development has come a shopping center, a fancy supermarket, a bookstore that sells "The Somerset Hills Landed Gentry Map." At night, the glow of hundreds of ersatz antique street lamps can be seen for miles around.
The development more than doubled Bedminster's population, to 7,800. So the police force has doubled, and the township has had to build a new school and make baseball fields out of open land.
Yet much remains the same. Seventeen miles of township roads are deliberately kept unpaved, dirt or gravel. The residents of Bedminster, and their horses, prefer it that way.
On most Saturdays, Sundays and holidays between Labor Day and Easter, the Tewksbury Foot Bassetts -- "foot," in this case, because the followers are not on horseback -- still roam the countryside pursuing the descendants of hares brought from Europe 100 years ago.
"It's amazing how little Bedminster Township has changed," said John Schley, whose family has been there as long as the hare. "When I drive through, it still appears to be the place I knew in the mid-1940's."
The campaign trail runs smack through the center of Bedminster. Store windows display "Forbes for President" signs. Bumper stickers and buttons abound. Locals lick envelopes at campaign headquarters in the middle of town.
Many people here say without hesitation that they support Mr. Forbes. Many know him, or his family, and like what they know. But many also say they like his ideas, that his brand of Republican thinking is their own.
Many say they are excited by the notion of a flat tax, though some are skeptical that it could be as simple as Mr. Forbes says it is. But even they seemed to be extending to Mr. Forbes the benefit of the doubt.
"Certainly, the old tax system is appalling," said Alice W. Lorillard, 76, who lives on an 80-acre farm and rides twice a week. "I think the capital gains taxes are too high and the inheritance taxes are absolutely ludicrous."
Others said they would welcome a businessman as President. They said they doubted that voters cared that Mr. Forbes has money. Many said they were not at all concerned that Mr. Forbes has never held elective office.
"Steve Forbes's views reflect, to a great degree, the views of people in our area," said Dean D. Porter, a corporate lawyer and father of five. "These are people who don't look to the government for help."
Many of their families first came to the area in the late 19th century, when wealthy Wall Street types started buying up small farms in the Somerset Hills and piecing together vast weekend and summer estates.
For 60 years, the area remained an almost private domain. But in the 1960's, two interstate highways came through -- I-78 running east-west, I-287 running north-south, intersecting in Bedminster.
Then AT&T, outgrowing its offices in lower Manhattan, moved into the area. It opened its headquarters in Basking Ridge in 1975, a division in Bedminster in 1977 and another office in neighboring Bridgewater in 1985.
Other companies followed, bringing thousands of employees with them. As land values rose, it became increasingly expensive to hold on to large tracts. Families began selling off pieces and were not always able to control how the land was used.
Kenneth B. Schley Jr. sold land on Schley Mountain to a group that he says intended to build a private recreation center. But the group couldn't find backing and the land tumbled into other developers' hands.
"I had no intention of selling it to the people who bought it," said Mr. Schley, now 78, who watched his grandfather's land become the development known as The Hills. "I feel terribly. But I don't feel it was my responsibility."
Fourteen years after the first house went up in The Hills, construction continues. For the last several years, the job of managing the development has fallen to a man from a family that has lived in the area for four generations.
Sitting in his office on the second-floor of the mall, Thomas H. Dillon pointed out that he had not been involved at the beginning. But he said he had long believed that growth in the area was inevitable.
"A lot of people think The Hills are a strain on local services and an intrusion into a way of life," Mr. Dillon, who is 43, said. "There were people that said, 'How can you do this in the area you're from?' "
Bedminster has never been a place that lavished money on public services. In a county with one of the highest average per capita incomes in the country, the township has prided itself on keeping taxes low.
In addition to the absence of municipal garbage collection and the like, the library is shared with neighboring Far Hills. The township has also signed several dozen agreements to share the cost of other services with its neighbors. For example, a half-dozen communities share a single public health department, a service required by the state.
And when George Mantz retired from the township's Department of Public Works on Dec. 31, there were six department employees -- just as there had been when he first went to work there 33 years before.
"I call it minimalization of services," said Joseph H. Metelski, a former Bedminster mayor. Mr. Metelski said it took him four years in the 1970's to persuade the township to convert his private street into a public road.
So it has not been easy for Bedminster to accommodate The Hills -- even though the development itself maintains nearly all of its streets and arranges privately for sewage treatment.
In fact, the question of whether to convert some township land into athletic fields proved so controversial last year that it became a campaign issue and helped cause an upheaval on the Township Committee.
"Local politics in Bedminster is a very closely followed event," said Mr. Dillon, who, like most people in the township, votes Republican.
Oddly enough, both sides of Bedminster seem to support Mr. Forbes.
Elizabeth Merck, who has a horse farm and spent 15 years on the Township Committee, said: "It would be a real treat to have someone who is not just a politician. And I say that having been 'just a politician' myself."
David Weiss, who is 22 and lives with his family in The Hills development, said he admired Mr. Forbes for using his fortune to get his views across to the public in defiance of what Mr. Weiss described as a closed political system.
One township resident, however, had little good to say about Mr. Forbes. G. Daniel Walker, president of the Somerset Airport, said he resented that Mr. Forbes, among others, had opposed his plans to improve his airport.
Mr. Forbes owns land adjoining the airport, a so-called private public-use airport started by Mr. Walker's father, George, 50 years ago. Mr. Forbes also lives near the airport, across Burnt Mills Road.
Though many people in town say they believe Mr. Walker's intention has been to expand the airport's operations, he says he only wants to improve it. He says the opposition has cost him thousands of dollars for permits and legal fees.
"He doesn't have ideas that I think are workable," Mr. Walker said of Mr. Forbes. "Like the flat tax. I don't think it's ever going to go through. It's a bag of wind."
But last week, Mr. Walker appeared to be in the minority in Bedminster.
Joseph B. Wiley Jr., a joint master of the Tewksbury Foot Bassetts and a retired engineer, recalled a recent conversation with an acquaintance who learned that Mr. Wiley was from Mr. Forbes's home town.
"He said, 'What makes him think anyone's going to vote for him for President?' " Mr. Wiley recalled. "I said, 'Last time I was in the post office, everyone was in favor.' "

HEADLINE: Essay;
Beware Smilo-Communism

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
"Look at those businessmen dancing around that Communist," said an unemployed Russian at the World Economic Forum held at this ski resort every year. "Don't they realize he will doom their investments?"
Center of the executive fandango is the global man of the hour, Gennadi Zyuganov, who led the Communist Party to its victory in the parliamentary elections, and who now leads in the race for president of Russia scheduled for June. 
 A recent poll shows Zyuganov (accent on the "gan") ahead with 14 percent, trailed by the democrat Yavlinsky at 11, the fascist Zhirinovsky at 7, the military Lebed at 6 and incumbent Yeltsin at 5, with half the population too chilled to choose.
The balding, 51-year-old former mathematician and philosopher -- solid in private but stolid in public -- is here on a heavy-handed charm offensive, eager to show the West it has nothing to fear from resurgent Communism and thereby persuade Russians that his election would not dry up foreign investment. I caught him early Sunday morning just before he set out to work over George Soros.
If Communists take over, what becomes of newly freed markets in Russia? "We want a mixed economy, a stable balance of public, private and collective ownership. Privatization in the U.S. took a hundred years [sic] and ours took place in two years, which is barbarian. But what happened, happened -- if we turned back suddenly, all Russia would be in flames. If an enterprise is productive, and if collective rights are preserved, let it flourish."
That sounds like sweet reason, but when pressed Zyuganov made plain that the clock would be turned back: "The state should control basic industries, energy, railroads, defense production, education, medical care."
What about the robust free press, which says anything it likes while Yeltsin does anything he likes? That draws a chuckle from today's Communist boss: "We will insure the right of all legally recognized organizations to have access to the media. The previous muzzle on the media by the Communist Party of the Soviet Union was fruitless."
Thus, government would order the media to print or broadcast officially "recognized" views. Would he purge and punish current and past leadership, as those around Yeltsin and other opponents fear?
"No. A purge is a dead-end street, a nightmare," he said reassuringly. "We will evaluate people by results, not by ideological beliefs."
The word is that Zyuganov is the nice-guy Menshevik, who would be pushed aside by the hard-line Bolsheviks soon after the Communists gained power. Not so, he smiled: "Communists agree that our candidate should present a program aimed at the whole population, not just at Communist followers: good jobs, respect to the elderly, education and medical care, personal and state security. A president must be leader of the whole nation."
Soothing answers are the name of his game. Even when talking at home about "integrating" the freed former Soviet republics, reconquest dear to nationalist hearts, he inserts the word "voluntary" for foreign consumption. Does he really expect Ukraine to "voluntarily" rejoin Russia? "We have no claims on the political sovereignty of Ukraine. Life itself will define the face of the new unity.
"This is not about conquering the world. Communism, in my interpretation, means collegiality, sustainable development, spiritual values, major investment in the human being."
His message: Relax. The only anger he showed was about the gathering of a million signatures from at least 15 regions to qualify for the coming election. Communists, with legions of loyal pensioners, are set to do that; to a lesser extent, so are democrats. Zhirinovsky will have to pay collectors, his money suspected as coming from Yeltsin, who wants to face him rather than Zyuganov in the runoff. But Yeltsin has his own cost-free signature-gathering technique: no pay to government workers until they sign.
"This is rampant, outrageous illegality," Zyuganov flashed. "The Duma has sent this to the prosecutors."
He then reached for the hot button of American hard-liners: "Nixon was able to conduct relations irrespective of ideological differences. I like that kind of conservative."
Smooth pitch from a well-briefed politician. No sale.

HEADLINE: In America;
Sliding Pay Scale

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The buying power of the Federal minimum wage will soon reach its lowest level since 1955, when the minimum wage was 75 cents an hour.
Minimum-wage workers currently make $4.25 an hour, which is $170 for a 40-hour week. That enables them to live like peons. There are free marketeers who say they shouldn't even be guaranteed that much. The House majority leader, Dick Armey, a robust fellow who hasn't missed a meal in a long time, would like to get rid of the minimum wage altogether. With that trap door yanked open, he would offer tax benefits to those who fell through. 
 It has been a year since President Clinton proposed a modest 90-cent-an-hour increase in the minimum wage. The increase would come in two increments -- 45 cents immediately and another 45 cents a year later. It is not exactly a radical proposal and it has overwhelming public support. But it has gone nowhere. The Dick Armeys of the world have said "nyet."
Over lunch a few days ago, Labor Secretary Robert Reich cited the importance of even a modest wage increase to the families of low-wage workers. If President Clinton's proposal had been approved last summer, the $525 in additional wages could have provided food for three months, or 10 months worth of electric bills, or new clothing for several children.
Nearly 60 percent of the workers who would benefit from a minimum-wage increase are women. Nearly two-thirds are adults struggling to support families, as opposed to the stereotype of a teen-ager flipping hamburgers after school for movie money and other non-essentials.
Most minimum-wage workers lead very difficult lives. They skip meals. They defer medical care. They dream about vacations they can never afford to take.
"It is fundamentally immoral to expect people to work full time for $8,600 a year," said Secretary Reich.
An "additional level of absurdity" is reached, he said, by those who want to move large numbers of people off welfare but do not want to do anything about the sinking value of the minimum wage.
It has been nearly seven years since the minimum wage was increased. When that proposal was being debated, Bob Dole criticized those who were clamoring for a cut in the capital-gains tax while opposing the minimum-wage legislation. Said Mr. Dole, "I never thought the Republican Party should stand for squeezing every last nickel from the minimum wage."
Congress went on to vote overwhelmingly in favor of an increase of 90 cents, to $4.25 an hour. But much of that increase has already been eroded by inflation.
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities has prepared a chart that traces the value of the minimum wage, in 1995 dollars, since 1955. The 75-cent-an-hour minimum in 1955 was worth $3.92 in 1995 dollars. In 1956 the minimum was raised to $1 an hour, bringing its value to $5.14. In 1968 the $1.60 minimum wage was worth $6.45.
By 1983 the minimum was up to $3.35, but its value in '95 dollars had slipped to $5.11 and was heading steadily lower. By 1989, still at $3.35, it was worth just $4.11. Unless Congress steps in, the value of the minimum wage in 1995 dollars will soon slip below $4 an hour.
There are two basic arguments against raising the minimum wage. The first is ideological. The most fervent worshipers of the free market believe government should not interfere at all in the affairs of business. If that idea were pushed to its extreme, there would be no minimum wage, no workplace safety or environmental protection regulations, no prohibitions against child labor.
The other argument is practical. Opponents of an increase in the minimum wage say it would cost jobs, thus hurting the very people who are supposed to be helped. Secretary Reich counters that argument with a series of studies that have shown no such impact. Modest minimum-wage increases do not cost jobs.
On Saturday President Clinton repeated his call for an increase, a minor wage adjustment that would keep the purchasing power of hard-working men and women from sliding to a 40-year low.

HEADLINE: Forbes Gains a Local Endorsement

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: SOMERVILLE, N.J., Feb. 4

 BODY:
If not for a few campaign banners and a box of blue "Forbes for President" buttons, it would have been hard to tell whether it was a campaign rally or halftime at a high school basketball game.
But there were elements of both today when Steve Forbes returned to his home county to receive the endorsement of local Republicans. Between 200 and 300 people, many casually dressed families with small children, crowded into the Somerset County Administration Building to see Mr. Forbes's first political rally in New Jersey. 
 Although the Forbes family has been well known here for years, Mr. Forbes's surge in the polls has brought him increased notice.
"I like his tax proposal," said Art Tropiano, 80, who owns a jewelry store. "He's a young guy, 48 years old. The big issue about Dole is his age. The thing is that the President can't do that much in one term, so he has got to be young enough to serve two."
The crowd cheered and flapped blue cardboard "Forbes for President" banners when the candidate entered. Meg Florio, 7, daughter of the county Republican chairman, presented Forbes with a small Somerset County commemorative pin in the shape of a balloon. "I promised to be here today so when the reporters ask you what I was like when I was a wee bit smaller, you will say nice things," Mr. Forbes told the crowd.
The crowd responded to Mr. Forbes's call for lower taxes and less government, applauding his repeated criticism of "our friends from Washington."
Mr. Forbes's insistence that economic issues should be the heart of this year's campaign drew the most support.
Tom Kotarsky, a draftsman who was laid off after 27 years with the Unisys Corporation, agreed.
"I hear President Clinton saying there are eight million new jobs, but I don't see the jobs they are talking about," said Mr. Kotarsky, who described himself as a lifelong Republican rather than a Forbes supporter. "What we need is for industry to put people to work. Let's see the statistics on how they will do that."

HEADLINE: Forbes's Positions Found in Early Writings

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Contrary to the impression left by his speeches and his television ads, Steve Forbes's flat-tax plan is not the only mantra that throws this Republican Presidential candidate into overdrive. Advocating Congressional term limits gets his adrenaline flowing, too.
"Term limits would break the grip of lawyers," he says. "People from different walks of life who don't wish to spend all their professional lives in politics could still serve effectively." 
 This particular version of his term-limits rationale is not Forbes Nouveau. It is, rather, vintage Forbes -- straight from the Nov. 9, 1992, Fact and Comment section of the business magazine that bears his family name and where, as editor-in-chief, he has opined for years.
When he gives a stump speech these days, Mr. Forbes flags his support for term limits. In fact, many issues he now mentions, as part of a deliberate strategy to show off a broader political portfolio, are riffs on his positions in the pages of Forbes. In effect, Fact and Comment is a de facto briefing book on what and how the magazine mogul thinks today.
While his candidacy until now has been largely defined by his laser-like emphasis on his 17 percent flat-tax plan, Mr. Forbes in recent days has been reminding voters that he has positions on a wide range of issues and causes. "We have a whole program, a number of ideas," he said in a recent campaign stop in Iowa, inviting questioners to ask him about something other than the flat tax.
The compendium of views Mr. Forbes is now reciting on the stump, like those he has been rehearsing in the magazine, reflect a variety of influences. On economics, he is bullish on supply-side theory and committed to reviving Ronald Reagan's upbeat, low-tax approach. So he is not only telling voters that he now wants to abolish the current graduated income tax system in favor of a single flat tax, but he also campaigns on issues like tying the value of the dollar to the price of gold, and eliminating the capital gains and inheritance taxes.
Mr. Forbes says he is interested in balancing the budget but thinks there is an overemphasis on bringing down the deficit. Instead, he promotes lowering taxes as a way to spur growth in the economy.
On social issues, Mr. Forbes's positions often parallel the so-called compassionate conservatism of Empower America, a Washington-based idea factory. The group serves as a base for Jack Kemp, the former Housing Secretary and an advocate of supply-side economics, who is committed to helping the inner-city poor, and for William Bennett, the Education Secretary in the Bush Administration, who now writes on family values and culture.
As a result, Mr. Forbes supports providing vouchers to parents, so they can send their children to the public or private secondary school of their choice. He also favors greater involvement by religious and nonprofit organizations rather than having the Government run programs for the poor.
But he does toe a tough line on crime, arguing, for example, that first-time violent offenders should serve their entire sentence, instead of being eligible for parole.
Mr. Forbes's foreign policy positions reflect an excitement about the power of high technology, an opposition to isolationism and a commitment to promoting freer political and economic institutions in other nations. In recent campaign appearances, he has warned against the nation turning inward as it did in the 1930's, and has strongly advocated a continuing American commitment to the defense of western Europe and democracy in the Far East and Asia.
On the campaign trail in Iowa last week, Mr. Forbes said: "It's still a dangerous world even though the cold war is over. We must stay involved. We have been a stabilizing influence."
Many of Mr. Forbes's ideas and arguments on the stump these days got their first airing in his columns. For example, he first took issue with what he described as the isolationist politics of Patrick J. Buchanan, one of his current rivals, in a column that appeared in March 1992.
On the stump, there usually is not a lot of ideological daylight between Mr. Forbes, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas and their rivals. Like so many others, Mr. Forbes wants to reduce the size of the Federal Government, end race-based quotas, create "taking" legislation to compensate those whose property values drop because of environmental and other regulations, use vouchers to give parents a chance to send a child to a private school, set term limits, cap welfare benefits while making work a requirement.
Mr. Forbes is never strident about hot-button issues. He wants abortion "to vanish in America" but says that will be an incremental process. He has found some of his party's rhetoric about immigration divisive.
Michael Novak, Mr. Forbes's friend and a theologian at the American Enterprise Institute, says he believes the candidate's philosophy reflects the distant influence of the Scottish Enlightenment, an eclectic, 18th century intellectual movement that emphasized a kind of civic humanism. Among other things, the movement, whose adherents included Adam Smith, sought to preserve individual liberty in the face of the state, including limiting the state's authority to tax.
"Steve doesn't talk about this," Mr. Novak said. But factoring in the influence of the Scots' old-fashioned form of liberalism and freedom from government, helps illuminate how Mr. Forbes thinks, Mr. Novak believes. Both served on the Board for International Broadcasting, which oversees Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty.
"The economic system that allows individuals to make decisions that bring out the best in them" is always what his friend is drawn to, Mr. Novak said.
Mr. Forbes's economic and political thinking has also been strongly influenced by Friedrich von Hayek, the economist and author of "The Road to Serfdom," the 1944 work that helped sharpen conservative thinking about limiting the role of government in peoples' lives.
But Paul R. Krugman, a Stanford University economics professor and author of "Peddling Prosperity: Economic Sense and Nonsense in an Age of Diminished Expectations," takes a far dimmer view of Mr. Forbes's economic theology.
"The point is, he's a crank," said Mr. Krugman, who says that Mr. Forbes is weak on basic economics, and is, in essence, recycling shopworn 1980's supply-side views. "So this is once again crank economics posing as economic expertise," said Mr. Krugman, who said that Mr. Forbes's ability to talk "like a nerd" tends to create the impression that he knows what he is talking about.
William Kristol, a conservative theorist, who is editor and publisher of The Weekly Standard, said in an interview that Mr. Forbes's candidacy "is Kemp plus Perot and that proves to be a potent combination." He gives Mr. Forbes credit for blending the sentiments that fueled Perot to 19 percent of the 1992 vote with the impulses that helped Republicans take control of Congress in 1994.
In an editorial in the weekly's new edition, Mr. Kristol and John Podhoretz, the deputy editor, bemoan the decision by Mr. Bennett, Mr. Kemp and others to sit out 1996. While the editorial has great respect for Mr. Forbes and his ability to exploit the field's weakness, it concludes that voters will not gamble by sending someone without a record of public service to the White House.
Mr. Forbes, he said, "is an intellectual in politics. The irony is it is the left that has featured intellectuals in politics." The downside of intellectuals as candidates, he said, is that they often lack practical experience and do not have a good feel for the lives of ordinary Americans.

HEADLINE: Soothing Tone by Russian Communist at Business Forum

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Plutocrats of the world, you have nothing more to lose in Russia if a Communist is elected President than you do already under the unpredictable incumbent, Boris N. Yeltsin.
That was the message the Russian Communist Party leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, brought to business and political leaders from around the globe in this Alpine ski resort over the weekend. 
 Mr. Zyuganov's promises to safeguard private property and to continue a market economy in Russia if he is elected in June were vague, and he refused to say today whether he supported ratification of the Start II strategic arms limitation treaty with the United States.
Privatized companies, he said, could stay in private hands "if they work well and are being run properly."
"What we are going to do is create a climate of confidence," he promised, and since public opinion polls in Russia show he would get 14 percent of the vote, compared with 5 percent for Mr. Yeltsin, business leaders listened.
But some of them, at the annual privately sponsored World Economic Forum here, appeared to feel that Russia was on a slippery economic slope no matter who wins the election.
"Russia has a poor reputation," said Percy Barnevik, president and chief executive of ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., a Swedish-Swiss company that has invested $500 million there.
Grigory A. Yavlinsky, expected to be one of the leading anti-Communist candidates and also leading Mr. Yeltsin with 11 percent in the polls, was here fencing with Mr. Zyuganov. Their debates made clear that both men share the view that Mr. Yeltsin and his Government have bungled Russia's transition to a market economy and have strengthened the forces of nationalist reaction.
"In our country, it's the mafia and corrupt bureaucrats who have power," said Mr. Zyuganov, referring to the organized crime that has become endemic in Russia.
"We believe in a regulated market where every type of ownership -- state, collective, partial, private -- is allowed to have its place in the sun," he said.
Mr. Yavlinsky, who has been a leading proponent of economic change in Russia, said the Government had botched it by letting inflation run wild and then reining it in by simply not paying workers, coal miners and retirees for months at a time.
The Russian Minister of Economics, Yevgeny G. Yasin, was here reassuring potential investors that Mr. Yeltsin's recent replacement of important economic officials did not mean he was giving up on the market economy.
Mr. Yasin also pointed out that inflation had been reduced from 320 percent to 60 or 65 percent annually and was still going down.
That, Mr. Yavlinsky noted, was like saying the operation had been a success when the patient had died.
Mr. Yeltsin was not here to defend himself, but a battery of Government officials came for what has become an annual Russian invasion of Davos in answer to invitations from the conference organizers to meet with movers and shakers of the business world in informal surroundings.
Mr. Yasin had estimated the need for foreign direct investment in Russia at $12 billion to $15 billion for the next 20 years, 10 times more per year than foreign companies risked there last year.
Mr. Zyuganov interjected, "No serious investor is going to invest in a country like ours if you think that every three or four years the rules are going to change."
Mr. Yavlinsky dismissed Mr. Zyuganov as a mere figurehead controlled by a party yearning to bring back the old Soviet days of iron-fisted rule.
His audiences appreciated Mr. Zyuganov's wit but went away with little concrete indication of what policies he would pursue if he were President. In legislative elections in December, the Communists fell short of a majority but won the largest bloc of seats in the lower house of Parliament.
Some foreign investors have begun complaining that neither Mr. Yeltsin nor the staunchly independent Mayor of Moscow, Yuri M. Luzhkov, have made good on promises to treat foreign investors well.
"In the last 12 months, there is an atmosphere of real unfriendliness in Moscow," said Beat Curti, representing Sadco, a company that operates 16 Western food stories and 7 restaurants in the Russian capital.
"Tax inspectors from the city come and spend months in our offices looking over our books and then they come back and say, 'We forgot to tell you -- the liquor tax since January is double what you've been paying,' " Mr. Curti explained. He told Mr. Luzhkov, "We are considering withdrawing."
The Mayor promised to look into the matter, but Sadco's complaints are far from unique, other experts say.
With all the chaos, Mr. Zyuganov's Communists are being taken seriously. "There are many ways in which our party is different from the Communist Party of the Soviet Union," he told the business leaders. "That was not a party as such, but a power structure that ran the whole country. We recognize political pluralism, and we no longer put all our ships on atheism and all the other isms we used to subscribe to."
But Mr. Zyuganov said the possibility of NATO expansion cast a shadow of doubt over Russian ratification of the Start II treaty.
Mr. Yeltsin, under pressure from the powerful far-right nationalist bloc led by Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, also opposes NATO expansion, and sent Deputy Minister of Defense Andrei Kokoshin to Munich, Germany, this weekend to tell a European security conference there that pressing ahead with it could backfire and turn Russia against the West.
Mr. Yavlinsky, asked about his attitude toward NATO expansion, replied: "Russia has no right to teach other countries what to do and what blocs they want to be in. Russia has enough problems inside."

HEADLINE: Charities Aiding Poor Fear Loss of Government Subsidies

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
While critics of Government spending on social services have been asking the nation's charities to take responsibility for the poor, sick and elderly who would be hurt by budget cutbacks, many of the cuts would force those groups to turn away people they now help.
Many large religious and other social service organizations get more than half of their budgets from Federal, state and local government support, as much as 40 percent from Washington alone. Dozens of executives of these organizations, who run everything from soup kitchens to hospitals, said in interviews that moves to cut spending in Washington and state capitals, including Albany, would endanger their programs. 
 From what is known of the latest Congressional and White House proposals for balancing the Federal budget in seven years, charity groups would lose $140 billion to $150 billion in revenues now earmarked for health, education, welfare, community development and overseas relief, according to a study by Lester M. Salamon, director of the Institute for Policy Studies at Johns Hopkins University and Alan J. Abramson of the Aspen Institute, a think tank.
The Federal ax has not fallen on most programs yet, with President Clinton and the Republicans in Congress still wrangling over a balanced-budget plan. And the full effects of many of the spending limits on the table would be put off until the end of the seven-year period, which could allow time for Washington to change its mind and for social service providers to seek other sources of money.
But the scope of the reductions being considered is immense. In New York City, they threaten to curtail programs ranging from the daily brown bag lunches for 80 homeless people at the Episcopal Church of Christ and St. Stephen's in Manhattan to the home-health-care programs for the elderly operated by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. Nationally, they would drain billions from Medicaid and Medicare programs that keep hundreds of religious-affiliated and other nonprofit hospitals and nursing homes afloat.
Many critics of social programs say that private groups can pick up the slack. Speaker Newt Gingrich, for example, has said private orphanages could do a better job for troubled poor children than Federally financed welfare programs. And a Republican Presidential candidate, Steve Forbes, has called current programs a "monstrous system" that should be dismantled, making it "possible for private charity to become more involved."
For the most part, the mainstream religious charities, groups that provided much of the private charity in the United States, say that they have no contingency plans for maintaining their safety nets for the poor if the Government pulls back. The charities say private donations cover only a fraction of their costs and are growing slowly at a time of widespread economic uncertainty.
"Even before the welfare and other cuts go through, we are having a hard time," said Lisa Carr, a government affairs expert with Catholic Charities USA in Alexandria, Va. "More people are coming into our agencies for a meal," she said. "Some agencies have to triage."
The growth of government support for services provided by religious institutions has partly been deliberate and partly coincidental.
For certain kinds of aid -- for the homeless, mentally ill, immigrants and battered women, for example -- the Government turned to religious and other private nonprofit agencies on the theory that the services "could actually be better, more efficient and responsive, less tangled in red tape," said Martha R. Burt, a social services expert at the Urban Institute, a Washington-based research center.
But now, the rising tide of antigovernment sentiment is washing over these mainstream religious charities, whose liberal social agendas are under attack and whose political allies are in retreat. "They are being punished, in part, because of their ties to the Democratic Party," said Theda Skocpol, a professor of government and sociology at Harvard University.
By contrast, a number of conservative churches, including the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and many evangelical denominations, have shunned government aid, preferring to avert constitutional restrictions on the spiritual content of their social work. These churches often dispense a religious message along with food and shelter for the homeless or drug and alcohol counseling, said Paul Nelson, president of the Evangelical Council for Financial Accountability. The council, which includes 815 churches and television ministries, like Pat Robertson's Christian Broadcasting Network, raised $4.4 billion in public appeals last year.
In large measure, the growing reliance by church groups on government money simply reflects the runaway growth of spending on health care, a sector in which Jewish and Christian charities long have played a big role.
Nonprofit hospitals typically depend on government for 48 percent of their revenue from patient care, according to the American Hospital Association. Nonprofit hospitals and nursing homes were projected to get more than $130 billion in Government money last year, largely through Medicaid and Medicare, up from $60 billion in the late 1970's.
So the blow would be sharp if those programs were curtailed. On the seven-year road to a balanced budget, the nation's Catholic hospitals alone say they would lose $17 billion in reduced Medicare and Medicaid reimbursements.
The proposed Federal and state cutbacks would take an enormous bite from the budgets of big New York hospitals, for example: $2.5 billion over the seven years from seven Jewish-affiliated hospitals, $1 billion from the 15 Catholic hospitals and 9 nursing homes in the New York Archdiocese, and $200 million from the 4 hospitals and 3 nursing homes of the Brooklyn and Queens diocese.
For social services -- like soup kitchens, foster children's care, temporary shelters for the homeless, refugee resettlement, and training programs for unemployed youths -- the nation's charities will spend about $87 billion in 1996, almost half of it from Federal money, according to the Independent Sector, a nonprofit research group. And Congress is calling for 20 to 30 percent reductions in many of these programs.
Based on projections by Mr. Salamon and Mr. Abramson, Catholic charities across the country would receive about $200 million less from Washington, measured in 1994 dollars, for social service programs when the full effects of budget balancing would be felt in 2002, compared with what they would get under current law. Lutheran Social Services would be set back at least $200 million in 2002, and the Salvation Army would get about $50 million less in Federal money.
The religious-based charities insist that their services to the poor and elderly cannot help but be crippled amid a Government retreat. "We need partnerships between the Government and labor and business and the nonprofit and charitable organizations, so that our society as a whole embraces a sense of compassion and shares responsibility," said Major Paul Bollwahn, a national spokesman for the Salvation Army.
Mr. Abramson and Mr. Salamon estimate that to make up for lost Federal money, private giving would have to increase 50 percent by the year 2002.
"The Pollyanna-ish notion that churches will make up the difference is not serious," said Megan McLaughlin, executive director of the New York Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. "All the foundation grants across the nation could not fill the gap created in one of our big programs in the city."
The Federal cutbacks would be compounded in New York -- which, like other big cities, has a dense web of religious-based social service groups -- by reductions planned or already implemented by state and local governments.
In the budget he announced last December, Gov. George E. Pataki called for 26 percent cuts in welfare payments and other benefit reductions that the social-service agencies fear will increase the demands on their already overtaxed food and housing assistance programs. Mr. Pataki said on Tuesday that his overall budget plans could be devastated if Washington does not give the states the flexibility they anticipate in welfare and Medicaid spending.
In New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has already cut many contracts with child welfare agencies in the current fiscal year -- reductions that have translated directly into job losses and diluted services. For example, 20 jobs were cut and the remaining caseworkers' loads increased in the Bedford-Stuyvesant programs operated by Miracle Makers Family and Children's Services, an offshoot of the Free Will Church of God and Christ.
In New York, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies said that Federal, state and local spending cuts being considered would take $14 million from its child welfare services this year, along with $12.5 million from nursing homes, $6 million from home care for the elderly, and $5 million from mental health centers, said Stephen D. Solender, executive vice president.
Most other states already are strapped for cash, as well -- and are passing the squeeze on to the nonprofit agencies.
For example, the Lutherans, who operate one-third of the nation's nonprofit nursing homes, are losing an average of $15 a day on every Michigan nursing home occupant on Medicaid, said Kay Bengston, a spokeswoman in Washington for the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.

HEADLINE: Chinese Tiptoe Into Internet, Wary of Watchdogs

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Inside a gray six-story office building, a dozen young men gathered around a conference room table on Saturday evening to discuss the Internet. Only one was over 30, and all looked like computer nerds, the kind of people who prefer to spend a Saturday night talking about their favorite software, rather than venturing into one of the lively cafes on the street below.
Yet with the Chinese authorities tightening control over information networks, even something as innocuous as an Internet club is now suspect. So the participants met with an air of secrecy, engaged in a lengthy debate over lukewarm cups of tea on how to avoid Government interference, and wondered about the true identity of five latecomers who sat to one side of the room and said little. 
 "The Internet is still very sensitive in China," said a 24-year-old computer technician, who like the other participants asked not to be identified. "We're not trying to do anything illegal, but if the Government finds out about us, we're finished."
The Internet is just starting to grow in China, and the authorities are trying to keep it firmly within their grasp. Today, China issued a new set of rules to regulate Internet use, the latest in a recent series of moves to assert control over the flow of information here.
Rather than try to choke off Internet access, as some of the young men gathered around the table had feared, the regulations instead appear to be steering the flow of electronic information through officially controlled ports so that it can be better monitored.
The new regulations require that any network offering Internet service be subject to close supervision by the Ministry of Post and Telecommunications or one of three other designated Government agencies, the New China News Agency announced.
The new regulations are intended to insure "healthier development of the exchange of international computer information," the news agency said. But the rules were clearly also concerned with information the Government deems threatening.
"Neither organizations nor individuals are allowed to engage in activities at the expense of state security and secrets," the agency said. "They are also forbidden to produce, retrieve, duplicate or spread information that may hinder public order."
The transmission of pornographic or obscene material was also expressly banned.
The rules come at a time when Internet users in China have gained easy access to a wide range of politically sensitive material posted by dissident groups based outside of China.
Reports that were accessible within China via the Internet today were offered by Human Rights in China, a New York-based group; the Center for Modern China, run by the dissident writer Liu Binyan and based in Princeton, N.J., and China Spring, another New York-based dissident group.
China's security apparatus is widely believed to monitor an enormous volume of telephone and fax connections, and it is expected to do the same with Internet messages. It is an open question whether the authorities will try to block access to information they do not like, and whether they would succeed if they tried.
Access to the Internet, however, is still a privilege for relatively few in a country where few homes have a private telephone let alone a computer. Most who have access to a computer do so through their workplace.
About 4,000 people have registered for Internet accounts with the Ministry of Post and Telecommunications in Beijing and Shanghai since it began offering China's main commercial Internet service in mid-1995.
Zhang Shiyong, a computer science professor at Fudan University in Shanghai who directs the university's Internet operations and advises Shanghai's Post and Telecommunications on computer networks, estimates that fewer than 30,000 Internet users in China have an e-mail address, mostly university professors and students, and scientific researchers.
Others familiar with the Internet assert that 50,000 to 100,000 in China may be using it, many of them university students with irregular access because of limited computer time, and others who privately pay a registered user to share an e-mail address.
A main impediment to Internet growth is the high cost. While university professors and students get e-mail free, Shanghai's Post and Telecommunications office charges $75 a month for 40 hours of use, a sizable fee in a city where a typical office worker makes $250 a month.
For all the free speech potential that the Internet portends, Robin Munro, Hong Kong director of Human Rights Watch/Asia, said few if any dissidents within China had access to it, because of limited access to computers. He suggested that, with official monitoring, the Internet would not be an ideal route for transmitting politically sensitive information anyway.
Most professors who use the Internet focus on research, Professor Zhang said, while most graduate students he knows use it to get information on how to study overseas.
"We're not happy about that, of course, but we don't stop it," he said. "We want to encourage them to use the Internet as much as possible."
Proponents of the Internet hope that Chinese users will eventually send 70 percent of their electronic transmissions to other domestic users, Professor Zhang added. He estimates that only about 10 percent are domestic now, with an overwhelming majority of e-mail directed overseas.
Today's regulations were not the only recent effort to control information services in China. Last month, the Government announced that foreign news organizations selling economic information would now be supervised by the New China News Agency, which will have the final say over who can have access to the service and how much they pay.
President Jiang Zemin, in one of several efforts to assert wider political authority, recently called on the nation's news media to "pay special attention to politics." In less formal wording: obey orders.
In early January, the Ministry of Post and Telecommunications suspended all new subscriptions to the Internet indefinitely. The official reason was that this was necessary while the network's technical capacity was expanded, but officials of the Shanghai Post and Telecommunications said that authorities in Beijing suspended the system's growth while they formulated the new regulations.
Now that the regulations are out, new subscriptions will presumably resume soon.
As concerned as they are about the Internet's ability to spread undesirable information efficiently, China's leaders also recognize its benefits.
Shanghai's municipal government recently announced plans to link its tax offices and social security services via a local Internet connection, as well as to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in telecommunications infrastructure.
"Over the past few years, with the growth of a market economy and progress in spreading information, computer information networks have been playing an active role in accelerating China's economic, scientific, technological and educational development," the New China News Agency reported in January.
At the gathering on Saturday evening, nearly all of the participants voiced optimism that the expansion of Internet China would help businesses, in particular, because of the way it would expand their access to information.
All, that is, but the four conservatively dressed men and one woman who came late and sat in a clump to one side. None offered a name card when all others attending passed out their own, and none signed the e-mail address list.
They watched, they listened, they said little. One took notes. And everyone else was reminded that, Internet or not, best watch what one says.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Washington Confronts China

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Washington has chosen the issue on which it will at last acknowledge and confront Chinese Communist action detrimental to the United States.
There was a considerable list to choose from. China threatens daily missile attacks against Taiwan. Beijing sells missiles to Iran and other Mideast dictatorships. At home it increases arrests and jail sentences for dissidents. It allows Internet use to only a relative handful, and from now on only through government-controlled ports. 
 Each act involves the U.S. An attack on Taiwan would force U.S. involvement. Sales of missiles endanger Mideast peace and defy U.S. policy against proliferation of high-tech weapons.
Increasing repression and closing access to international information is a slap at the U.S. Washington had assured the world of the opposite -- that freedoms would increase in China after the 1994 Clinton Administration decision not to use economic pressure to ease oppression.
Well, enough is enough. Washington now says it will show its staunch determination to resist Chinese provocation -- about compact disks. If China does not stop counterfeiting these disks, the Administration will increase tariffs on Chinese goods by as much as $1 billion.
Any commercial piracy costs manufacturers and artists money and should be opposed. But to appreciate the CD episode fully it helps to have a taste for bitter comedy.
1. The Communists will not keep any new promise better than they keep existing ones -- or others, like ending slave-labor exports to the U.S.
2. If they do camouflage piracy better, they will demand concessions -- like even tighter zipping of the U.S. mouth on human rights.
3. The U.S. announcement accentuates the moral disaster of Clintonian policy on China. CD's yes, people no. Mr. Clinton broke his promise to use tariff pressure to persuade Beijing to treat its Chinese and Tibetan political victims less viciously -- maybe a mite less torture. Beijing answers by increasing, not decreasing, political oppression. He acts surprised.
Democrats and Republican politicians talk about the danger of cynicism. But they expect Americans not to see the cynicism of putting CD's above the blood of dissidents in China's gulags.
Worse, they may be right. I do not hear American university students or professors mobilizing against Chinese Communist cruelties, or consumers organizing a boycott like the one that helped kill South African apartheid.
If war comes to Taiwan, it will not be because Beijing believes its lie that Taiwan is preparing to declare its deserved independence. It will be because 100 miles off China's shore, Chinese people have created a society that is both prosperous and democratic. That so terrifies the perpetually insecure Politburo that it risks war -- not only against Taiwanese independence of government but Taiwanese independence of mind.
Beijing uses missile threats to intimidate Taiwanese into voting for a party that is running on a pro-China platform and against independent-minded opponents.
The Taiwan Relations Act, passed by Congress in 1979, says that U.S. recognition of Communist China rests on the expectation that Taiwan's future will be determined by peaceful means.
The law states that any effort to determine Taiwan's future by other than peaceful means -- which includes threats of daily missile attacks -- are of grave concern to the U.S. and should be "promptly" reported by the President to Congress.
The President has not done that, promptly or at all. Nor has Congress demanded it, despite some members' attempts. Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Dole, the agenda-setters, become accomplices in the President's decision to ignore U.S. law.
Restraint is needed, we are told by U.S. officials and some journalists -- we do not want a war over Taiwan, do we? Of course not. That is what facing the possibility is all about.
As long as Congress and President ignore their legal obligation to deal with China's threat to Taiwan, decide what steps to take and let China know, Beijing will believe it can attack Taiwan or keep terrorizing it, with no risk.
That is not restraint of confrontation that could lead to war. It is the blundering encouragement of both. How terribly many times must we learn?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
