HEADLINE: Space Probe Is Set to Visit Eros, An Earth-Grazing Asteroid

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
SPEEDING through the wastelands of space is a riot of rubble left over from the creation of the solar system, including lumps of rock up to hundreds of miles wide that orbit the Sun, mainly in a belt between Mars and Jupiter. These bodies, known as asteroids, are studied for clues to how the solar system formed more than four billion years ago.
Recently they have also been recognized as doomsday rocks that can stray away from their usual paths to mutilate planets, as suggested by craters on the Moon, Mars and Earth, and perhaps by the demise of dinosaurs and many other creatures 65 million years ago. Today some asteroids pass quite close by Earth and others cross its path. In the future, they might pose a threat to terrestrial life by smashing into the planet and kicking up enough dust to temporarily blot out the Sun and alter the climate, though scientists know of no killer rocks headed in this direction. 
 Later this month, an assault on the riddles of the asteroids is scheduled to begin as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration launches the world's first spacecraft meant to orbit one of these rocky interlopers. A three-year, 1.3-billion mile journey through space is to culminate with nearly a year of asteroid study. The car-size probe carries seven instruments and is to orbit within 20 or so miles of the rocky surface, and perhaps much closer during the mission's final days.
The target is an asteroid named Eros after the Greek god of love. Twice the size of Manhattan, the elongated rock passes relatively close to Earth on its chaotic sweep through the solar system and in the future may start crossing the planet's path, raising the possibility of a collision. Eros is representative of the dominant class of asteroids that roam near Earth, so its investigation is expected to answer a swarm of questions about the nature and hazards of asteroids as well as the origins and composition of the solar system.
"We've flown past asteroids but it was like taking snapshots of the Grand Canyon out the window of a car," Dr. Richard P. Binzel, a planetary scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said in an interview. "Now we're going to stop and look and study one in detail. I think the mission will challenge our understanding of small bodies and force us to relearn fundamental things once we're confronted with the detailed data."
In an important milestone for space science, given the shrinking Federal purse, the mission is the first of a new class of low-budget explorations that are seen as the wave of the future. The current Galileo mission to Jupiter, launched six years ago, cost $1.6 billion. But the bill for the asteroid rendezvous is less than $170 million, including its launching by a Delta rocket -- a pittance by traditional standards.
"This is a revolution," Dr. Wesley T. Huntress Jr., NASA's associate administrator for space science, said in an interview. "It's a whole new way of doing business."
So great is the change that the builder and operator of the spacecraft is not NASA. Instead, in a bid for thrift, the work was done by the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory in Laurel, Md., marking the first time an outside organization has run one of the agency's deep-space explorations.
"We took a planetary mission and did it better, faster and cheaper," said Dr. Stamatios M. Krimigis, head of the space department at the Applied Physics Laboratory, adding that the probe's design and building took a little more than two years, an unusually speedy pace.
Spacecraft have occasionally drawn close to some of the leftovers of creation, but none have orbited them for close scrutiny. A decade ago, an international fleet of probes flew past Halley's Comet, one within about 300 miles of the icy body. And the Galileo probe on its way to Jupiter photographed two asteroids a thousand or so miles distant, 12-mile-long Gaspra in 1991, and 34-mile-long Ida in 1993, the latter body turning out to have a small satellite, which was given the name Dactyl.
Eros was first seen by telescopes in Germany and France in 1898 and soon afterward was recognized as the first asteroid that could speed close to Earth. Today, after decades of surveillance with Earth-based telescopes and radars, the rocky body is thought to be about 25 miles long. And it is the second largest of the hundreds of known asteroids that approach Earth, many of whose orbits cross the planet's path.
The composition of Eros is an enigma that mirrors the general confusion about the nature and origin of the asteroids.
Many of the rocky bodies are apparently made of crude material that is thought to be the same primitive stuff that occasionally falls to Earth in the form of the stony meteorites known as chondrites, which contain lots of primitive silicate rock, as is found widely on Earth. Others were apparently once heated and transformed early in the solar system's history, separating into rock and metals, not unlike iron-rich meteorites that sometimes fall to Earth.
The former type of asteroid suggests primordial matter that never jelled into a planet. The latter implies debris from small planets or planetoids that formed and became geologically active, perhaps with volcanoes and hot cores, before they broke up in catastrophic collisions.
Eros is a kind of asteroid, known as an S type, meaning silicate bearing, that dominates the population of the inner asteroid belt. Yet scientists cannot agree on whether all S-type asteroids are made of primitive or melted material.
"Three decades of increasingly detailed telescope observation have not resolved the dilemma," Dr. Robert Farquhar and Dr. Joseph Veverka, project team members, recently wrote in The Planetary Report, a publication of the Pasadena-based Planetary Society.
The plan for an orbital mission to Eros has been aggressively promoted by Daniel S. Goldin, NASA's Administrator for nearly four years and a champion of doing things smaller, cheaper, better, faster, as he puts it. The flight is the inaugural mission of the Discovery Program, a NASA initiative for small planetary missions with a maximum three-year development time and a maximum cost of $150 million.
The Eros probe is known officially as NEAR, for Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous. It is scheduled to lift off on Feb. 16 from Cape Canaveral, Fla. The Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., is to navigate the craft on its journey of more than a billion miles through space, as the laboratory has done for all of NASA's deep-space missions.
The voyage to Eros is complex because the asteroid orbits the Sun at an angle 10.8 degrees off that of the disklike plane that the planets whirl through, loping down many millions of miles below that horizontal layer in its rush through the solar system. The probe, to achieve the rendezvous, must match this unconventional orbit.
After its launching, the spacecraft is to swing out far past the orbit of Mars, passing by the large asteroid Mathilde on this leg of the journey and possibly photographing it, and then come barreling back toward Earth for a close flyby in January 1998. At this point flight controllers will use the planet's gravity to increase the probe's speed and change its orbital plane to match that of the prime target.
Final maneuvers are to begin in January 1999. As the spacecraft approaches Eros, it will begin firing a large rocket engine to slow itself and match the asteroid's speed, making its first close encounter in February 1999 at a distance of about 300 miles.
If no dangerous satellites are discovered that would hamper a closer approach, the probe will slowly be maneuvered toward the asteroid until in March 1999 it reaches its optimal orbit for scientific study of 20 to 30 miles high. The detailed observations are to last until the end of the millennium.
The main scientific aims of the mission are to measure the asteroid's size, shape, volume, mass, gravity field, spin state, surface composition, geology, morphology, texture, mass distribution and magnetic field. To do so, the probe carries a camera, a gamma-ray spectrometer, a near-infrared spectrograph, a magnetometer and a laser range finder, among other instruments.
Scientists believe that clues to the nature of the early solar system are preserved on small bodies like asteroids. In contrast, the cosmic records of large, planetary bodies have been altered or destroyed over the ages by the traumas of planetary evolution. In particular, near-Earth asteroids are thought to hold clues to the nature of the building blocks of the inner planets, including Earth.
In addition to raw scientific insights, the mission to Eros is seen as possibly yielding findings that may help humankind wrestle with the possibility of killer rocks descending on the planet from space. First, a better understanding of asteroids would aid predictions of how the rocky bodies would interact with the atmosphere and Earth upon fiery impact. Second, it would aid in developing possible safeguards.
"The more knowledgeable one is about these objects," said Dr. Clark R. Chapman, a senior scientist at the Planetary Science Institute, based in Tucson, and a member of the mission team, "the more we can figure what we'd have to do to move them or otherwise get out of harm's way."
In recent years, scientists have speculated about using bombs or rocket engines to nudge threatening asteroids out of Earth's path or to destroy them.
Scientists are closely watching the Eros mission not only for its insights but as a critical test of the space agency's new small-is-beautiful philosophy, which is sometimes viewed skeptically by a generation of experts that relied on large budgets to push the glory days of planetary exploration to the dim edges of the solar system and beyond.
"These things are being touted as a whole new way of producing science cheaply," said Dr. Joseph A. Burns, an astronomer at Cornell University who is a past chairman of the Committee on Planetary and Lunar Exploration at the National Academy of Sciences, a private group that advises the Government. "But it's not clear that the science return per dollar is going to be there. It's an experiment."
But the chief scientist of the rendezvous mission, Dr. Andrew F. Cheng, an astrophysicist at Johns Hopkins University, said no corners had been cut to develop the spacecraft, which relies on many more miniaturized components and innovative materials than did past probes.
"It's a full-science mission in the grand old tradition," Dr. Cheng said. "But it doesn't bust the budget."

The NEAR craft is the first of a series of no-frills spaceships, designed for simplicity, reliability and economy.

HEADLINE: Helium Won't Fill Future Demands, Physicists Warn

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
IN the century since it was discovered as a trace ingredient of the uranium mineral clevite, helium, the second lightest of all elements, has become indispensable to science and technology. Scientists believe it could play a vital role in helping the world through future energy shortages.
But as Congress and the White House move to end Government participation in helium conservation, the American Physical Society, a professional society of physicists, warns that the most economically exploited source of this nonrenewable substance will be depleted in 21 years unless steps are taken to halt a growing helium hemorrhage. 
 The society calculates that although American producers recover about 3.3 billion cubic feet of helium from natural gas each year, another 3.2 billion cubic feet are thrown away because gas companies lack financial incentives to separate, refine and store it. The Federal Government operates a combined stockpile and buffer stock, into which commercial producers deposit helium when demand is low, for later withdrawal if necessary. Critics contend that Government involvement is unnecessary and interferes with the market's ability to match supply with demand.
A world shortage of helium a generation from now could obstruct the development of superconducting power lines, motors, generators, electricity storage systems, magnetically levitated trains and many applications not yet even imagined, the American Physical Society says. Helium is not only irreplaceable; it can also do things that no other substance can even approximate.
Helium is commercially recovered from certain natural gas reservoirs, mainly in the United States. Because it is a noninflammable gas with nearly as much lifting power as inflammable hydrogen, it was prized by airship builders and users following World War I, a conflict in which hydrogen-filled Zeppelin bombers had proved to be deathtraps. After the war, the United States banned the export of helium to deprive potential enemies of fire-resistant airships, and later created a strategic helium stockpile, a reserve that now contains 32 billion cubic feet.
But dirigible airships are no longer regarded as strategically important weapons and, in any case, many lawmakers opposes the continued maintenance of any Federal stockpiles. One of the present targets of Congress is the national helium stockpile, as well as Federal participation in the extraction of the gas.
In December, the American Physical Society deplored the projected liquidation of Government helium reserves and reported that 3.2 billion cubic feet of helium are being dumped into the atmosphere each year and are forever lost. Unless the Government creates economic incentives to private industry for extracting and storing the otherwise wasted helium, one of the world's most valuable resources will be squandered at incalculable cost to future generations, the group said.
"The present world growth rate in demand for helium is about 10 percent per year," the society's report said. "A simple calculation shows that if that rate were to continue, and if helium production could keep up with the demand, United States helium-rich reserves would be exhausted in only 21 years."
The United States has large reserves of helium mixed with natural methane in the gas fields of Texas, Wyoming and a few other states. America is virtually the world's only source of natural gas containing 0.3 percent or more of helium. In Russia and Poland, two of the other main sources of helium, natural gas generally contains 0.1 percent or less of helium, and such a lean mixture is much more expensive to separate, said Dr. Robert L. Park of the University of Maryland, spokesman for the physicists' society.
Helium is separated from the natural gas with which it is mixed either by adsorbing the natural gas in charcoal or other materials, or by compressing and cooling the methane and other gases until all but the helium are liquefied. Helium, which remains a gas unless it is chilled to minus 452 degrees Fahrenheit, is then pumped off.
The main obstacle to extracting and storing helium, experts agree, is the mismatch in market demands for natural fuel gas and helium. When demand for natural gas is heavy, as is normally the case in winter, large amounts of helium are withdrawn from gas wells along with the natural gas, but if there is little commercial demand for helium at that point, there is no economic incentive to extract and save it, said Dr. Park. Gas companies then generally avoid the expense of separating the helium, which consequently remains mixed with the natural gas and is lost when the gas is burned.
Congress has decreed the demise of the Bureau of Mines, and has ordered the shutdown of the bureau's helium separation plant near Amarillo, Tex., which produces about 10 percent of the nation's helium. (The rest is produced by commercial gas companies: Praxair Inc. of Danbury, Conn.; the BOC Group, a British company with American headquarters in Murray Hill, N.J.; Air Products and Chemicals Inc. of Allentown, Pa., and the Exxon Corporation are among the main producers.) In his State of the Union address last year, President Clinton also proposed closing down the Government's helium reserve program, including the closing of the Cliffside Dome storage well -- a depleted natural gas cavern near Amarillo -- which contains the national helium stockpile.
The Cliffside Dome, which is about one-third full, is connected by pipelines to other helium-rich gas fields, and when supplies of the extracted gas exceed demand, Cliffside serves as an overrun storage site, from which helium can be later drawn.
Even defenders of the maintenance of a helium stockpile acknowledge that the Bureau of Mines's Exell helium refining plant near the Cliffside Dome is outdated, inefficient and expensive, and they say it holds an unfair financial advantage over private competitors. All Government agencies that buy helium must by law purchase it from the Bureau of Mines, which sells the gas at $55 per thousand cubic feet, nearly 10 percent more than the price offered by commercial suppliers.
The bureau's helium operation, moreover, is heavily in debt. But the debt of $1.4 billion is misleading, said Dr. Philip C. Tully, a helium expert at the Bureau of Mines.
"Most of that money consists of interest we supposedly owe the Treasury Department for the $252 million they advanced to us to create the strategic helium reserve," Dr. Tully said in an interview. "It's just one Government agency in debt to another Government agency -- a paper debt -- and Congress could wipe it out with the stroke of a pen, at no cost to taxpayers."
But neither the Bureau of Mines nor helium conservation has many friends in Congress.
A key sponsor of legislation to end all Federal helium programs is Representative Christopher Cox, a California Republican, who believes the fears expressed by the American Physical Society are groundless.
"No matter who gains title to the helium in the Federal stockpile, the helium will still exist," Mr. Cox said in an interview. "It won't be wasted. The only real risk is that the Government might sell it off quickly to get cash to reduce the deficit. That's misleading accounting practice. But we are contemplating a gradual transfer of ownership, taking half a lifetime."
Market demand will determine how much helium commercial producers extract from the natural gas they sell, and as supplies of helium decrease, Mr. Cox believes, higher prices will create incentives to extract more helium. "The gas companies are already extracting 90 percent of the helium produced in this country, and they will certainly continue," Mr. Cox said.
Dr. Park says the American Physical Society takes no position as to whether helium conservation should be the responsibility of Government or of private companies. "Our grandchildren aren't going to give a damn who saves the world's richest supply of helium, as long as someone does it, and does it before supplies run out," he said. "Surely, our politicians should be able to devise some incentive system to encourage private industry to save the helium. Congress has created lots of incentives for other purposes."
But Mr. Cox rejects this approach, saying that "Government tinkering with future price structures would be very dangerous."
Helium was first discovered in the sun, not on earth. In 1868 while observing a solar eclipse, a French astronomer, Pierre Janssen, detected lines in the sun's light spectrum that did not match those of any known element. The presumed new element was dubbed helium after the Greek word for sun: helios. In 1885, helium was discovered to exist on earth as well. Helium is now known to be the second most abundant element in the universe, after hydrogen. But when it escapes from underground caverns where it has collected over the eons chiefly as a decay product of radioactive minerals, it mixes with air, rises into the atmosphere and is lost.
Although American airships and balloons -- both the full-size versions and small weather balloons -- are still inflated with helium, that use of the gas accounts for only about 10 percent of its consumption. (The toy balloons popular at parties and political rallies consume such trivial amounts of helium that conservation advocates say they represent no significant drain.) Major American uses of helium are for purging and pressurizing the fuel tanks of NASA and Defense Department spacecraft, for high-temperature welding and in cryogenic applications like the magnetic resonance imaging machines used by hospitals.
About one-third of America's annual helium production is exported to foreign users, and foreign demand is increasing steadily.
Helium has special importance to scientists because its physical properties are unique among all the other 100-odd elements. It is the only element that remains liquid at even a tiny fraction of a degree above absolute zero, which is equivalent to minus 459.67 Fahrenheit. Liquid helium cannot freeze solid, no matter how close to the absolute zero it is chilled.
Because it remains liquid at ultralow temperatures, liquid helium is vital as a medium for chilling mercury, arsenic, niobium and other elements to temperatures at which they lose all resistance to electricity, becoming superconductors.
Although various compounds based on copper oxide become superconductors at much higher temperatures, warmer than that of liquid nitrogen (minus 320.4 degrees Fahrenheit), these compounds are difficult to incorporate into useful implements, and so far, their use has been limited.
Among the major users of liquid helium for chilling superconductors are the huge accelerator laboratories studying nature's fundamental particles. The Fermilab Tevatron accelerator at Batavia, Ill., is a four-mile ring of superconducting magnets, all of them continuously cooled by liquid helium. Fermilab operates the world's largest liquid-helium refrigeration plant, but it will soon take second place to a project under construction near Geneva.
On a smaller scale, astronomers are heavily dependent on liquid helium for cooling infrared and microwave sensors in their telescopes. Such sensors must be chilled to eliminate the heat "noise" that otherwise masks the faint heat signals from distant celestial objects.
"Sooner or later we're going to have to start husbanding our helium," Dr. Park said. "If we do it now, we can save the helium-rich supply before it goes up the chimney. If we wait, we'll still need helium, but it will be vastly more expensive to separate from helium-poor gas supplies. Have we the right to mortgage our future?"

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against the Mark On Doubts of Further Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar weakened yesterday as expectations faded that Germany would soon push interest rates lower.
Germany yesterday reported a stronger-than-expected industrial output figure, showing a slightly stronger economy. In addition, Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the Bundesbank, the German central bank, reiterated remarks that the German economy was likely to improve this year. 
 The news dampened expectations that Germany would lower key interest rates, which typically hurt the mark's value.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar was trading at 1.4665 German marks, compared with 1.4823 on Friday. It finished at 105.10 Japanese yen, compared with 106.55 the previous session. The British pound rose to $1.5401 from $1.5235.
The dollar, drawing support from recent interest rate cuts in Germany, has been rising since late last year against the mark and yen.
But given that the dollar still has not recovered fully from post-World War II lows hit last spring, "the dollar's long-term trend is still down," said Dan Ascani, editor and publisher of Global Market Strategist, an advisory firm in Gainesville, Ga.
The dollar fell against the yen yesterday as an opportunity evaporated to borrow at low Japanese rates and buy United States Treasury bonds at higher yields. The dollar's recent strength made the tactic too risky, analysts said.
Traders had been borrowing yen at half of 1 percent and 1 percent, the prevailing Japanese interest rates, then converting the yen into dollars and buying American bonds for a higher return. That worked when the dollar was worth 100 yen to 101 yen.
But now, said John Ryding, senior economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, with the dollar hitting 107 yen last week, that equation was no longer worth the risk.
With the dollar down to 105 yen, that wipes out about 2 percent of the return.
So yesterday, some traders were "just cashing in some chips" and taking profits, Mr. Ascani of Global Market Strategist said.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, were: 1.1960 Swiss francs, down from 1.2139; 5.0370 French francs, down from 5.0915, and 1,569 Italian lire, down from 1,574.

HEADLINE: The Arts Are Again Invited to the Budget Dance

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
The arts may be an economic engine driving New York City, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has often said, but once again City Hall is threatening to cut back the fuel supply.
This time, in the face of an estimated $2.75 billion city budget gap over the next year and a half, the Mayor has proposed a reduction of nearly 17 percent from last year in the amount spent to maintain New York's major cultural institutions and to subsidize hundreds of local arts groups. The preliminary budget announced by the Mayor last week sought about $65 million for the major groups and $7 million for the smaller ones for those purposes in the fiscal year 1997, which begins July 1, compared with $84 million in the current budget. Other cultural appropriations bring the total to $98.1 million. 
 People in the arts say they know that when budget cuts are reaching the Police Department, the pain has to be spread around. "There's no question this is a bad year and the Mayor has to confront some hard questions," said Janet Schneider, executive director of the Cultural Institutions Group, which represents 32 museums and other organizations on city-owned land. But she said, "We stand to supply revenue to the city."
Thus the news that they were expected to take a harder-than-average hit alarmed them, coming as it did from a Mayor who has so frequently spoken out for the arts. ("Culture is to New York what steel was to Pittsburgh 30 years ago," he declared last April as he sliced the birthday cake at the 125th-anniversary celebration of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.) Many officials of cultural organizations appealed for help to Schuyler G. Chapin, Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, and to the City Council, which in the past six years has added about $45 million to the allocations proposed by the Mayor.
"We're tired of moaning and groaning," said Rochelle Slovin, director of the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens. "We've got to go forward and do our political best."
The truth is, moaning and groaning and doing one's political best is the way the budget game is played. Those with long memories know that the Mayor's preliminary budget is the first step in a ritual involving trial balloons, hand-wringing, staring matches and more often than not, compromises that ease the pain.
If past years are a guide, a good part of the money is likely to be restored by the time the budget works its way to final approval by the City Council, usually in June. "The Mayor looks to slash and the City Council looks to restore," said a former city official well acquainted with the process. "Right now they're all shooting across the bow, and nobody has the faintest idea what's happening."
Mr. Giuliani's preliminary budget, the rough outline of what the Mayor intends to present as his executive budget in April, calls for a 10 percent cut in spending for utilities and personnel for the Cultural Institutions Group, which includes many of the more prominent organizations, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Carnegie Hall and the New York and Bronx zoos. It proposed cutting 42 percent from program grants to more than 400 arts groups large and small, including the Alvin Ailey Dance Company and the New York Philharmonic, the Bronx Arts Ensemble, the Thalia Spanish Theater in Queens and the Billie Holiday Theater in Brooklyn.
Because the Cultural Institution Group receives the bulk of the money, its 10 percent cut would equal about $7.2 million while the 42 percent cut for the arts groups would mean a loss of about $5 million of their current $12 million.
But at this stage of the budget process last year things looked worse than that, with program grants to be cut 80 percent. In the end the program groups received nearly as much money as they had the year before, and the major institutions lost only 5 percent.
Last year, $10 million (half of it from the state) of the city's cultural budget was distributed as matching funds, available only to recipients that privately raised $1 for each $1 of government money. This fiscal year, the city has allocated $4.5 million (with no state component) at a rate of $1 for each $1.50 raised on the outside. The program is renewed in the Mayor's preliminary budget for the coming year.
Over the last few days, representatives of arts groups have said they are looking to Mr. Chapin, the Cultural Affairs Commissioner, as their champion, although it may be putting him in a delicate position with the Mayor, who has not encouraged outspokenness by his commissioners. "If he tries to kick him in the butt or do an end run, he's out of a job," Harvey Lichtenstein, president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, said of Mr. Chapin.
Mr. Chapin, a former manager of the Metropolitan Opera and former dean of Columbia University's School of the Arts, does not deny some awkwardness. "The Mayor is facing a huge budget deficit and everyone is going to have to take his knocks," he said. But he added that "this is the first go," and "the budget business is never over until the final budget is put together."
Mr. Chapin also did not deny that he has had differences with John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, who oversees the Cultural Affairs Department. Even before the Giuliani administration took office in 1994, Mr. Dyson drew fire for suggesting that city money should be funneled to the large museums and performing arts companies that draw tourists and that subsidies to the smaller community based groups could be withdrawn.
"John and I have different interpretations of the purpose of cultural affairs," Mr. Chapin said. Such differences have led some arts representatives to conclude that Mr. Chapin's influence at City Hall is negligible. When representatives of the Cultural Institutions Group wanted to voice their concerns to the administration last year, they essentially bypassed Mr. Chapin and set up a meeting directly with the Mayor and Mr. Dyson. In what a participant described as an awkward gathering, Mr. Chapin essentially audited the session.
Calls to Mr. Dyson and a deputy mayoral press secretary, Deirdra L. Picou, were not returned.
While waiting for the Mayor to present a firm budget proposal in April, many people at arts organizations are taking a temperate view. Some express confidence that the Mayor expects the City Council to increase allocations in categories including the cultural affairs budget, and that the expectation of such increases is even part of the Mayor's calculations.
"The proposed cuts are not enough money to solve the budget problem and would have an extraordinarily bad impact on the arts communities and the economy as a whole," said Norma P. Munn, chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, representing more than 200 smaller arts groups.
Still, this year could be different. The budget gap may be even worse than it already seems. Already the Mayor is talking about a new round of proposed cuts. The budget director could look at the Cultural Institutions Group and ask why the city is cutting the school budget while paying millions of dollars in electrical bills and maintenance services for large museums with multimillion dollar endowments. The legal answer is that it has to, up to a point: the city has a contractual relationship with museums and other cultural institutions on city land.
In any event, some arts representatives warn against demonizing an administration that has long been solicitous. "The Mayor and Deputy Mayor thoroughly understand what culture means to New York," said Ms. Slovin of the Museum of the Moving Image. "It may well be that the Mayor wants to see if we're out there." she said. "Well, we are awake."

HEADLINE: Job Trainees Support Whitman on Welfare

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: PENNSAUKEN, N.J., Jan. 31

 BODY:
Kathy Scott is a single mother of three who has been getting by on public assistance for more than a decade. Under Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal to overhaul New Jersey's welfare system, Ms. Scott risks losing the only source of income she has known since the bridal shop where she worked shut down.
Yet Ms. Scott, 35, and several other aid recipients interviewed at a job training center here say they think Mrs. Whitman has the right idea. 
 "I think five years is enough to get your act together," Ms. Scott said. "I don't think I would have been on it as long as I was. It makes you dependent on a system that is not really working for you."
A five-year limit on benefits was just one of several proposals to revamp welfare that Mrs. Whitman presented to the Legislature, a package intended to enourage more welfare recipients to get jobs. Her first step to build support was to tour three job training sites, where she heard encouragement from beneficiaries, including Ms. Scott.
Of course, Ms. Scott has concerns. She lives in Camden, where the unemployment rate is 16 percent. More than two-thirds of the city's 87,400 residents depend on welfare as their main source of income.
She has heard that the state's economy is worsening and that Governor Whitman plans to eliminate 1,200 state jobs.
But Ms. Scott said she was hopeful that she would find a job, since she has completed eight months of training in medical billing at Future Works, a new program near her home that offers courses based on the local job market's needs. Ms. Scott has been making cold calls to prospective employers for a month and has some promising leads. "It can get a little discouraging," she said. "But I know I'm going to make it."
Mrs. Whitman proposed shifting the emphasis from education and job training that would permanently raise recipients' income levels to moving people quickly into entry-level jobs. Benefits would be limited to five years. Welfare recipients would be required to cooperate with efforts to collect child support. And teen-age mothers must finish their education and live with an adult to qualify for welfare payments.
In exchange for what Mrs. Whitman calls "personal responsibility," she promises incentives that will persuade beneficiaries to take the lower-paying jobs, including allowing them to keep 50 percent of their income while maintaining benefits, up to $850 a month.
She also said that she would double the state's investment to provide a "support system" to keep recipients employed by expanding child care, offering transportation and continuing a program that extends Medicaid for two years after a welfare recipient moves off the rolls.
"The change on emphasis is work," Mrs. Whitman said after touring Future Works. "You have to start somewhere. We want to move people off welfare."
But Mrs. Whitman, whose proposal must be approved by the Legislature and Federal Government, has not persuaded many advocates for welfare beneficiaries that minimum-wage jobs are the answer. "You need education," said Felicia Sallie, a case manager at the Anna M. Sample Family Shelter in Camden. "You need the skills to get the kinds of jobs that will allow you to support yourself. No one can live on $5.05 an hour."
Mrs. Whitman defended her plan, saying that previous state programs to wean beneficiaries off welfare "have failed." She also noted that a new Federal flexibility had presented more opportunity to the states.
"We need to keep trying," Mrs. Whitman said. "There is a revolution going on in Washington. I went to my Commissioner of Human Services and said, 'Design me the ideal welfare program if we had block grants."
There are now 35 states with Federal waivers for 50 demonstration programs around the country. Of them, 17 states have imposed some kind of limit on benefits. In Connecticut, Gov. John G. Rowland began imposing a 21-month limit last year. Fourteen states now require welfare recipients to cooperate in identifying parents who neglect to pay child support. Twenty states have parental responsibility programs, from requiring teen-age mothers to stay in school or risk losing benefits to demanding that parents make sure their children attend school.
The New Jersey Commissioner of Human Services, William Waldman, said that he had taken some ideas from other states and dismissed others. Unlike New York State, New Jersey is not seeking to reduce benefits for single men after 60 days. "Sometimes the people on general assistance may be family connected," Mr. Waldman said. "They may be fathers. You can't just ignore them."
The Whitman administration's goal is for 15 percent of recipients to move off the welfare rolls within five years. But Mrs. Whitman also said that she had not included any more money to pay for these expanded support programs in her new proposed $16 billion budget. She said the money for these programs would come from savings elsewhere in the state's $1 billion welfare system. She cited, as an example, consolidating welfare offices and slashing administrative costs. Counties now administer benefits that average $424 a month to 117,000 families; municipalities distribute benefits that average $140 a month to 35,021 single adults and childless couples. The administration estimates the state could save $25 million by shutting municipal welfare offices and turning that responsibility over to the counties.
Exactly what these changes mean for a training program like Future Works and its 118 participants is unclear. The year-old program has helped 41 of 44 people who completed training find jobs, with an average hourly wage of $8.05, but no one can say how many of those will return to welfare. It cost about $7,000 to train each person.
Unlike many training programs, Future Works designs its courses based on the needs of local businesses. So, when a local hospital recently laid off 31 billing clerks, the program dropped medical billing and offered medical office administration and customer service training.
Maryann Amore, vice president of the Work Group, the nonprofit organization that runs Future Works, said the group's $1.7 million budget was recently cut by $330,000. While she said Mrs. Whitman spoke favorably about the program, Ms. Amore said she worried about the state's commitment to offer the level of training that welfare recipients need to get that first job. "It is a concern because people need so many skills," she said. "If there were entry-level jobs for everyone, this would be less of a problem."
Elena Roman, 21, was sitting across the room from Ms. Scott, using the yellow pages to call businesses for a job as a receptionist. She had just completed an office automation and administration training course and her instructors said she was one of their best students. Ms. Roman has been receiving public assistance since giving birth three years ago. She said that she was able to participate in the program because of state-financed day care for her son. "He is learning there and this has been good for me," Ms. Roman said. "I have upgraded my skills. I believe there is going to be a job for me."
She worries, however, that a minimum-wage position, even with some benefits continuing, would not allow her to provide for her son. "I want to be able to afford to pay my bills, so I don't have to fall back into the system."
Of the more than 50,000 new jobs created in New Jersey last year, only 2,000 were in Camden County. This year, the Whitman administration is projecting that 10,000 fewer jobs will be created statewide.
Several women at Future Works who were interviewed after the Governor left said they agreed with limiting benefits, as long as decent-paying jobs -- and training to qualify for them -- were available.
"I am going to make it," Ms. Scott said. "I have fears and sorrows for those people who don't have the chance or who won't take advantage of the opportunities for training or for getting a job."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Refunding Dominates Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were mixed yesterday as the market is facing the task of absorbing a huge supply of new debt securities this week.
With market participants wondering if investor demand will be weak at this week's quarterly sales by the Treasury, primary dealers -- securities firms required to bid at all Government sales -- were setting up and busy discounting prices as they often do to raise yields and try to insure that the securities will be attractive to investors. 
 The yield spread between the 2-year note and 30-year bond widened in a sign that investors are betting that the Federal Reserve will continue to lower short-term interest rates. Two weeks ago, the spread was 102 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point; at the close of the New York session yesterday, it was 122 basis points.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 3/32 , to 10925/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.15 percent, from 6.16 percent on Friday. Traders said the long bond was bolstered by tumbling energy prices and a retreat in gold prices.
With a mountain of new supply coming to market, investors will likely wait out the dealers to buy at the lowest prices. The Treasury plans to sell a record $44.5 billion of notes and bonds in addition to yesterday's regular weekly auction of bills and a sale of cash-management bills on Thursday. Three-year notes will be auctioned today, and 10-year notes will be sold tomorrow.
Rates at yesterday's weekly bill auction fell to their lowest levels in about a year and a half, after last week's interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve.
The average rate for a three-month bills was 4.88 percent, down from 5.01 percent last week and the lowest since 4.79 percent on Sept. 26, 1994, while the average for a six-month issue was 4.79 percent, down from 4.90 percent last week and the lowest since 4.75 percent on Aug. 1, 1994.
In when-issued trading ahead of the Government's quarterly sales, the 3-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.06 percent, up 3 basis points since last week, while the 10-year issue was priced to yield 5.68 percent, up 11 basis points. The yield on the 30-year bond has gained 12 basis points, to 6.09 percent.
There were no big economic reports yesterday, and the only report scheduled today is the Johnson Redbook Service report on retail and chain store sales.
Yesterday's decline in gold prices and in the Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities -- whose recent gains have raised inflation alarms -- did nothing to shake the market's uneasiness.
According to some economists, the movement in the price of gold has not always been a good indicator. "But since financial markets often fluctuate in response to changing perceptions instead of fiscal rigor," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors, "the market may continue to exhibit overt signs of skittishness if the upward movement in the price of gold persists." Wayne Schmidt, a fixed-income portfolio manager with Mimlic Asset Management in St. Paul, said the market's biggest concern was supply. "There's not much in the way of economic numbers this week," he explained, "so everyone is zeroing in on supply. Right now, it seems as if it's just a waiting game, with the fear of getting supply placed into the hands of investors the greatest concern."
Dealers do not relish holding large inventories on their shelves, exposing them to losses if rates should surge higher.
In the corporate debt market, the Philip Morris Companies yesterday sold $400 million of 10-year notes due on Feb. 6, 2006, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The noncallable issue is rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Given a 6.375 percent coupon, the notes were priced at 99.925 to yield 6.385 percent, or about 70 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
The low spread, market analysts said, confirmed that investors found the issue attractive.

HEADLINE: The Doctor's World;
New AIDS Therapies Arise, But Who Can Afford the Bill?

BYLINE: By By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Shortly after AIDS was first recognized in 1981, activists demanded: give us new therapies. Now the latest worry of activists and many others concerned about the costs of health care is: who can afford them?
A five-day meeting on H.I.V. and related viruses here last week made it clear that the treatment of AIDS is entering a new phase, much more complex, perhaps more effective and certainly more costly. 
 The latest development is a class of drugs known as protease inhibitors. Short-term studies show the combination of these new drugs with standard older ones is the most potent therapy against H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. As Dr. David Cooper, a leading AIDS researcher from Sydney, Australia, put it, the new phase involves "the ascendancy of combination therapy" and "the demise" of single-drug therapy for H.I.V.
But the combination anti-H.I.V. therapy costs $12,000 to $18,000 a year. The many other medications that patients with advanced AIDS may need for related conditions could raise the bill to $70,000.
Many doctors expect heavy promotional pressure to treat more H.I.V. patients earlier in the course of the infection than is now the case. Since several hundred thousand Americans are infected, though many do not know it, the increased costs could be substantial.
Private health insurance plans will cover the drug costs for some AIDS patients. Medicaid covers the drugs for many others, although the number of individual drugs covered each month may be restricted. For others, the drug costs may be covered by the drug assistance program under the Ryan White act, the Federal program for treatment of AIDS patients. And many others may have to pay out of pocket if they can.
None of the new treatments are a cure for AIDS, although some of the initial results seem to show striking benefits. One study reported last week found that the combination of an experimental protease inhibitor and two older drugs, AZT and 3TC, suppressed the amount of H.I.V. in the body to levels that cannot be detected by the latest laboratory techniques. The effect is more powerful than many would have dreamed possible when the studies began only a few months ago.
The AIDS virus still remains in the body, but the hope is that if H.I.V. does not become resistant to the drugs and they can be given safely for many years, AIDS can be treated successfully as a chronic disease.
Increased cost is only one of the challenges that new treatments and new hope pose for researchers, doctors and patients. But there are others as well -- the ever present difficulty of squandering the effectiveness of new treatments by using them in a way that fosters resistant strains of the AIDS virus, and a related need to conduct controlled studies to know which combinations of drugs work best.
How much costs will increase is not clear. The Food and Drug Administration has so far approved only one protease inhibitor, Roche's saquinavir, for marketing. It costs about $7,000 a year. Merck and Abbott have asked the drug agency for permission to market their experimental protease inhibitors, indinavir and ritonavir, which they promoted heavily at the meeting. But they declined to say how much the drugs would cost. And the agency will have much more information to evaluate than was presented here before approving either drug.
As two of the meeting's main scientific organizers, Dr. Robert T. Schooley of the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center in Denver, and Dr. Douglas D. Richman of the University of California at San Diego, both cautioned at a news conference, "The devil is in the details."
Nonetheless, costs will undoubtedly rise, and budgets may not. Dr. Harold W. Jaffe, an official of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who also treats AIDS patients at Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta, said, "just in the last few months in our clinic at Grady, we have gone from one to two drugs as the standard initial treatment" and may go to three. "But we have a fixed pharmacy budget, so what are we going to not supply in order to accommodate these new drugs?" he asked.
Other important studies show that a new test that measures the amount of H.I.V. in the body can provide a more accurate way to predict the course of H.I.V. infection. Researchers suggested that the test would allow them to establish categories of progression of H.I.V. infection, as is done with some cancers, in hope of making drug therapy more effective.
But that important development has raised further concern about the costs of the new AIDS care. The Food and Drug Administration has not approved the test for marketing, although it is used extensively in research. The test is expected to cost about $200, would need to be repeated about four times a year and, if approved, would be added to many others that are now used.
"Because of the patient advocacy for AIDS, there will be a lot of pressure to make the standard of care a very expensive one," Dr. Jaffe said in an interview. "It won't just be individuals asking questions. It will be organized community groups pushing for this higher standard."
After the meeting, the AIDS Action Council in Washington, the AIDS Healthcare Foundation in Los Angeles, and a group of 20 leading non-government AIDS researchers and clinicians warned that the costs of the new therapies might make them unaffordable for the vast majority of Americans infected with H.I.V.
Dr. Charles Farthing of the AIDS Healthcare Foundation said that while the range of treatments had expanded and the number of people needing treatment had grown, budget constraints had forced state and Federal programs to cut back on the number of drugs for which they would pay.
These advocates urged drug companies to lower the costs of protease inhibitors and private insurers to cover the new drugs and the monitoring tests that are required. And they called on the Federal Government to increase financing for the new drugs through the Ryan White act.
If the source of payment for the new drugs is not clear, the goals of their use are, to "lower the virus load as much as possible to undetectable levels as long as possible," said Dr. Emilio Emini, who helped develop Merck's indinavir. But that means determining which combinations are the safest, most effective and most economical -- something that is not known. And that raises the challenge of designing and conducting experimental studies, something that has been difficult in the past.
Early on in AIDS treatment, scientists pinned their hopes on single drug therapy. But AZT, the first licensed anti-H.I.V. drug, had an extremely limited ability to reduce the amount of virus in the body, and resistance quickly became a factor.
In infections like tuberculosis and some cancers, combinations of drugs overcame resistance and achieved cures. So AIDS researchers began looking to combinations of anti-H.I.V. drugs. The combinations now used against H.I.V. are numerous. There were at least seven in a study of ritonavir in which patients continued to take whatever licensed drugs they were taking. But that study was not designed to determine which combination was most effective.
Dr. Cooper, the Australian expert, said that "unless doctors cooperate, there is a serious danger that our patients will receive anecdotal combinations," meaning that doctors will rely on accounts of treatment of individuals or small groups rather than data from large clinical trials. In other words, doctors must be willing to refer patients to such trials and patients must be willing to enter them. Without such cooperation, Dr. Cooper said, "the renewed optimism in therapy shown in recent months will turn sour, as it has done in previous years."
Future studies need to address many thorny questions about when to start combination treatment. Should it be as soon as infection is detected? Are there groups of H.I.V.-infected people who would benefit from aggressive therapy and other groups who would benefit from watchful waiting? What should be done for those who have been taking one anti-H.I.V. drug for a long time and seem to be doing well? And will patients respond to a second protease inhibitor if they develop resistance to the first?
Answers to those questions can come only from well-designed trials, which the National Institutes of Health intend to help develop, Dr. William Paul, who heads the Federal office of AIDS research, said in an interview.
But AIDS activists have vigorously opposed such studies in the past because a controlled study inevitably includes a group that receives a new, supposedly powerful treatment, and, for comparison, a group that does not receive the new treatment. Thus, some patients may lose out in the short run. But without such studies, researchers argue, knowledge that is necessary for the long run is never gained. The benefits of valuable drugs, like those used to treat tuberculosis, have been lost through misuse, and many AIDS experts are determined not to add protease inhibitors to the list.
One priceless piece of information that careful studies would yield is exactly how much of each drug should be used in a combination. A danger in not gaining such information is that if protease inhibitors are given in amounts that are too small, they can lead to the emergence of resistant H.I.V. strains. Dr. Richman of San Diego, a virologist, said such strains might already exist. Scientists have learned that H.I.V. strains resistant to AZT and some protease inhibitors existed before the drugs were ever given to AIDS patients.
Thus, drug treatment can lead to the emergence of resistant strains.
To prevent the emergence of resistance in long-term drug therapy it is necessary to completely suppress the virus's ability to replicate, since continuous replication is what allows a viral strain to produce enough mutations so that some will be resistant and help it survive, experts say.
As such difficulties in developing treatments make clear, the best way to treat AIDS has always been to prevent it. In this area there are also reasons for cautious hope.
Dr. Susan A. Fiscus and her team from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Duke University in Durham found that use of AZT among pregnant women and their infants significantly reduced the incidence of H.I.V. infection in those babies in North Carolina.
Two years ago, a study showed that AZT given to pregnant women and their newborns prevented AIDS in a significant number of the infants. But in part because it often takes a long time for doctors to put many new findings into practice, many questioned whether the benefits achieved in the study would apply to everyday medical practice.
Dr. Fiscus's team found that the proportion of H.I.V.-exposed children in North Carolina who were identified and tested increased to 90 percent in the last quarter of 1994 from 60 percent in 1993. The infection rate among babies born to infected mothers fell to 8.5 percent in 1994 from 21 percent in 1993. Babies born to mothers who took the drug had an infection rate of 5.7 percent, as against 18.9 percent in untreated babies.
Similar findings were seen among pregnant women in a federally financed study in several cities.
Another recent report in The Lancet of a randomized trial in six communities in rural areas of Tanzania showed that treatment of sexually transmitted diseases like syphilis and gonorrhea reduced the incidence of H.I.V. infection by about 40 percent. The study showed convincingly for the first time that the concept of controlling sexually transmitted diseases to control H.I.V. worked in the general population.
Ideally, the most effective anti-H.I.V. drugs would safely keep the virus in check for a lifetime and prevent development of infections that occur as complications of AIDS. It is these complications, which occur as a result of weakened immune systems, that usually debilitate and kill AIDS patients. The savings from the therapies and care needed to deal with these opportunistic infections would probably be greater than the high costs of the ideal drugs.
Although protease inhibitors can significantly raise blood levels of critical immune cells, like CD-4 and CD-8 cells, there was little talk of them as the ideal anti-H.I.V. drugs. Much discussion was about using the latest findings as a spur to develop additional drugs. And no one knew how the total bill would be paid.

HEADLINE: New York's Thin, Angry Blue Line

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

 BODY:
Since he began campaigning for the job he now holds, Rudolph W. Giuliani has modeled himself as a Mayor every police officer could be proud of. He made crime and "quality of life" central themes of the campaign and now considers among his greatest accomplishments a stunning drop in murders, car thefts and other offenses.
But these days, many police officers see the Mayor in a different light. Officer Luis Rivera, 37, of the Bronx, for instance, is angry that Mr. Giuliani is opposing legislation that would raise officers' salaries."Giuliani pays his managers raises to keep the best, but that doesn't hold for us," he said. "The honeymoon is over." 
 Another Bronx officer, Steve Mattioli, 32, also said he felt underappreciated. "I feel good work is not rewarded as it should be," he said, "unless it serves a political role or serves as good public relations."
And Lieut. Lawrence Hotaling, commander of the detective squad in Flatbush, Brooklyn, grumbled that recent cuts in overtime had hamstrung investigations. "If I disclosed which cases have been impacted I'd be back in uniform in no time," he said. "Sometimes I feel like I don't have enough fingers, and the dike is about to fall in."
While the Mayor's popularity among the city's police and their unions -- a solid base of support during his 1993 campaign -- appears to be falling fast, some police officials worry that the disaffection in the ranks has created significant morale problems that could affect officers' performance.
In interviews with more than 30 officers throughout New York City, every one criticized Mr. Giuliani, and many complained that Commissioner William J. Bratton was too concerned with attracting publicity.
While many expressed pride in their new dark blue uniforms and the innovative tactics Mr. Bratton is using to fight crime, the vast majority had complaints about pay. Many criticized the department's efforts to cut overtime, a move that amounts to an average annual loss of $2,500 for an officer with a base yearly salary of a little more than $30,000. Others complained about Mr. Giuliani's budget proposal to cut 1,500 of the force's 38,000 officers.
But officers reserved their most severe criticism for the opposition of Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Bratton to a state arbitration bill that many officers say would help narrow the broad gap between what they are paid and what officers make in the suburbs. A 10-year veteran of the city force makes about $43,600 a year, according to union figures; in Suffolk and Nassau counties, the same officer would make about $59,500.
The arbitration bill would shift jurisdiction over contract disputes involving police officers from the city's Office of Collective Bargaining to the State Public Employees Relations Board, which the police union believes would be more generous. Mr. Giuliani opposes the bill, known by the acronym Perb, which he says would cost the city more than $200 million a year.
"I thought everything was going fine until the Mayor came out against the Perb," said Officer Robert Crespi, who works in Harlem. "If they want us to act like professionals, they should pay us like professionals."
To be sure, none of the officers interviewed suggested that they wanted to return to the days of David N. Dinkins, who as Mayor won the enmity of many officers for his support of an all-civilian board to review complaints against officers and an independent panel to investigate charges of police corruption.
Moreover, many of those interviewed said they liked their jobs better today than before Mayor Giuliani took office, in large part because they believed their new anti-crime tactics were producing historic results.
But they still said that the Mayor and Commissioner had let them down.
Mr. Bratton said that labor complaints had become so powerful a distraction for his officers that when he visited two officers with bullet wounds in the hospital last week "they brought up the subject of Perb and pay."
"Money is definitely on their minds," Mr. Bratton said. "Their average salary is $30,000 to $31,000 a year. You can't live in the city on that. The Mayor is in a tough spot. The money is not there."
For his part, Mr. Giuliani said he could support police raises "in the same way that other unions have been given raises -- in exchange for productivity gains."
"I believe the police officer on the beat does not understand that the P.B.A. has been unwilling to negotiate raises in exchange for productivity gains," he said, "and that I cannot allow a union to wreak this kind of havoc on the city."
Several precinct union delegates and middle-level police managers, who spoke on the condition that their names not be used, warned that deteriorating morale could easily prompt a series of work actions similar to the 10-day slowdown in parking and traffic ticketing in December that cost the city several million dollars.
Even worse, they said, the grumbling is dampening enthusiasm within the ranks about a new anti-drug effort Mr. Bratton is planning.
Morale problems, Lieutenant Hotaling said, "definitely have an impact on crime fighting."
The work slowdown in December was a response to Mr. Giuliani's successful effort to convince Gov. George E. Pataki to veto a similar arbitration bill last year. The new measure is now on the Governor's desk, and the Mayor has warned that if it is signed he may be forced to cut thousands more officers. That has prompted leaders of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to threaten to withhold support for the Mayor's re-election bid.
"He's not in our good graces now," said Louis Matarazzo, the P.B.A. president. "We're not endorsing anyone now."
Clearly, the union has helped stir up the emotions of many officers. Union delegates have pasted newspaper articles on the walls of nearly every precinct about how the Mayor and Police Commissioner have opposed the arbitration bill.
But Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, said he was concerned that the bad feelings ran far deeper than union-inspired badmouthing of management. "Officers would be less than human to think they did not deserve a substantial raise after accomplishing the great fall in crime over the last two years," he said. "That could translate into a morale problem."
As remarkable as the unanimity of opinion among the 30 officers interviewed was the sharpness of their language about their superiors -- an act almost akin to insubordination when spoken with the knowledge that their names would be published.
"We're supposed to be the backbone of this city, and they're paying us like we do nothing," said Officer Frank Frontera, 32, a member of a robbery squad in the 70th Precinct in Brooklyn.
"We're getting compared to people who clean bedpans," he added, noting that police salaries -- particularly the $350 rookies take home each week, after taxes -- have fallen behind inflation over the last decade.
Speaking of Commissioner Bratton, Officer Jim Bennett, a 30-year-old veteran of the 48th Precinct in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, said: "The guy is not getting on the cover of Time magazine for nothing. They want us to do the job so they can wave the flag."
Resentment toward the Mayor is palpable even in squads known for their diligence, like the community policing unit of the 84th Precinct, whose undercover burglary and anti-prostitution tactics have won widespread praise in Brooklyn Heights and helped improve the image of downtown Brooklyn.
Officer Leslie Richardson, 37, whose undercover poses as a jewelry thief have stung numerous Brooklyn fences and won her a Detective's Achievement Award last week, is a rising star in the department. But she expressed extreme disappointment in the city's leaders, even if she would not criticize the Mayor and Police Commissioner by name.
"If it were the politicians' own relatives on this job and they went through all the dangerous situations we do," she said, "don't you think we'd get a raise? We matter to them only if they can say rape went down 100 percent this week and it makes them look good."
But not all the concerns involved salaries. Officer Joseph Spicciatie, 35, who works undercover posing as a male prostitute in downtown Brooklyn, said he worried that cost cutting was also hurting crime fighting.
"They are so worried about the overtime," he grumbled. "If you have a current investigation, they make you stop and pick it up the next day. In the meantime, the person you're after may have left town. Or the apartment you want to search -- they'll have the time to clean it out."
Officer Frank Delaney, 38, is a hero among many merchants on Fulton Street after his mapping of a burglary pattern led to the arrest of two Fort Greene men who had committed 80 recent commercial burglaries. But he said he felt underappreciated by his superiors.
Divorced and paying child support, he said: "I can't live like this. I have to figure out what bills to pay this month and which to wait to pay next month. I risk my life day in and day out, and I have the same bills as anybody else, but I'm not paid like a policeman or fireman working in the other suburban counties."

HEADLINE: G.M., Sharing Some Profit, Lifts Dividend

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Deciding to share more of its record profits with shareholders, directors of the General Motors Corporation today raised the quarterly dividend on the company's common stock by a third to 40 cents.
Wall Street analysts had been expecting a dividend increase and said that the company could afford the additional $300 million annual outlay. 
 "It wasn't a big surprise, but it was a positive indicator that G.M.'s board would like to return some of the success of G.M.'s turnaround to the shareholder." said Kenneth A. Blaschke, an auto analyst at Dean Witter.
The dividend announcement came after the closing bell on the New York Stock Exchange, where G.M. shares closed at $52.875 a share, up 87.5 cents.
John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said that the increased dividend "can be sustained over the long term thanks to the fundamental profitability improvements we've been able to achieve as well as the continued strengthening of our balance sheet and ongoing improvement in our cash position."
General Motors announced last Tuesday that it earned profits of $6.88 billion in 1995, including a fourth-quarter profit of $1.87 billion, both records for the company. But the company is also facing high costs as it introduces several new midsize sedans over the next year and a half.
The Ford Motor Company has found over the last six months that these costs, running into the hundreds of billions of dollars, can severely erode profitability.
G.M.'s cash reserves are large, but not remarkably so for a company with $168.83 billion in revenue last year that competes in an industry known for huge swings as the economy rises and falls. General Motors, the world's biggest auto maker, had $10.9 billion in cash and marketable securities on hand at the end of last year. The reserves are up from $8.8 billion at the end of last September and little changed from the end of 1994, when they were $11 billion.
The dividend increase by G.M. is likely to raise the pressure on Ford to raise its quarterly dividend, which is 35 cents a share. Although Ford sold 23 percent fewer vehicles last year, it held $12.4 billion in cash at the end of last year. Indeed, Mr. Blaschke said he expected Ford to raise its dividend later this year.
Officials at Ford have defended the size of its hoard as necessary protection for a recession, although they predict that the economy will continue to grow this year.
General Motors raised its quarterly dividend to the current level of 30 cents from 20 cents last spring.
The General Motors board also raised the quarterly dividend for the company's class E common stock, which is linked to the earnings of EDS, a General Motors subsidiary that provides computer processing and advice to governments and companies. The dividend rose to 15 cents a share from 13 cents.
The board also raised the dividend on class H common stock to 24 cents a share from 23 cents. The class H stock is linked to G.M.'s Hughes Electronics subsidiary.
All of the new dividends are payable on March 9 to shareholders of record on Feb. 15.
The company also said it was calling its series C preferred stock in a move related to G.M.'s plans to spin off its EDS subsidiary. The terms encourage series C owners to convert their shares to G.M.'s class E common stock, Mr. Blaschke said. G.M. said it would pay $52.42 a share for the series C stock. But each share is also convertible into 1.4078 shares of G.M.'s class E stock, and based on today's closing price, each would be worth $78.84. Investors have until Feb. 22 to choose, after which G.M. will automatically redeem the shares.

HEADLINE: Assembly Democrats Press for Records on Pataki's Inaugural Funding

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Setting the stage for a confrontation with the Pataki administration, Assembly Democrats threatened today to subpoena records from two former officers of the private corporation that raised at least hundreds of thousands of dollars for the Governor's lavish three-day inauguration last year.
Charging that the administration had repeatedly rebuffed their efforts to obtain the corporation's records, the Democrats also announced today that they planned to hold public hearings next month at which they would try to compel many of the Republican Governor's closest aides to testify about fund raising for the inaugural. 
 "Maybe they can't give us documents, but when called to testify, they could give us their view on how this corporation operated," said Assemblyman Paul Tokasz, a Buffalo Democrat and chairman of the Elections Committee, one of three Assembly committees investigating the inauguration.
The private corporation, called Inaugural '95, was formed just after Mr. Pataki's election in 1994 to raise money for his inauguration so that no taxpayer dollars would have to be spent. At the time, Zenia Mucha, the Governor's director of communications, said the corporation would abide by state campaign contribution limits and disclose the names of all donors.
But the corporation did neither, allowing many companies to give more than is allowed under state campaign laws and then, in November, announcing that it would not release a list of contributors or any accounting of its activities.
Last month, the three Assembly committees sent letters to over a dozen Pataki advisers and Republican officials requesting records relating to Inaugural '95.
Mr. Pataki's aides contend that the corporation, which was dissolved in November, raised about $600,000. But the Democrats, based on their conversations with some contributors, say the total was closer to $1.4 million.
In almost every case, the Pataki advisers -- including three state commissioners as well as the Governor's director of communications, counsel and chief of staff -- either said that they had none of the records or failed to answer at all.
In response, the Democrats today sent a second round of letters to Lawrence Kalkstein, the inaugural corporation's lawyer, and Charles J. Palombini, the corporation's former chief officer.
"It is imperative that you immediately comply with our requests," the Democrats' letter said. "Your failure to do so will render the issuance of a subpoena necessary."
Democratic officials said they would give the two men a week to comply before issuing the subpoenas.
In an interview today, Mr. Kalkstein declined to say whether he would fight a subpoena in court. But he said the Democrats had no right to the documents they were demanding. "I told them they are not entitled to anything," he said. "We didn't do charitable work or any work that would require public disclosure. There is no reason for the government to interfere with the operation of a private client."
But Democrats contend that the corporation served a fundamentally political purpose and should abide by state campaign finance laws.
Ms. Mucha called the Democrats' demand "beyond sad." Ms. Mucha herself has been asked for records and said that she had none.
"Both the Board of Elections and the Attorney General have said these committees have fully complied with the law, have paid their taxes," Ms. Mucha said. "It's time to move on."
Calls to Mr. Palombini's office were not returned.
In late December, Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco, a Republican, said he believed that the inauguration corporation and a second corporation, Transition '95, set up to help finance the Governor's transition to the office, had not violated any laws.
However, State Sen. Richard A. Dollinger, a Rochester Democrat who had requested Mr. Vacco's inquiry, criticized Mr. Vacco's findings as partisan and called on him to appoint an independent investigator. Mr. Vacco refused.
Ms. Mucha said in November that the names of contributors had been kept secret not just from the public but also from Mr. Pataki and his advisers so that they would not feel pressured to do favors for donors.
But Democrats charged that Mr. Pataki's aides were actually worried that disclosing donors' names would lead to embarrassing revelations about inaugural contributors receiving favorable treatment from the administration.
The Democrats also expressed doubts that Mr. Pataki's advisers had as little knowledge of Inaugural '95 as they have claimed, noting several links between the corporation and the administration.
Mr. Palombini is one of Mr. Pataki's chief campaign fund-raisers. Mr. Kalkstein is a partner in the Peekskill law firm that the Governor's chief counsel, Michael C. Finnegan, once belonged to. Robert Boyle, the corporation's original chief officer, was appointed by Mr. Pataki to be chairman of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. And state Commissioner of Economic Development, Charles A. Gargano, was chairman of the committee that arranged many inaugural events.
Mr. Gargano was also Mr. Pataki's chief fund-raiser in the 1994 campaign. Mr. Gargano said today that some of his fund-raising knowledge might have "rolled over" into his work for the inauguration. But he said he was not an officer of Inaugural '95 and had none of its records.
