HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Looking for Mr. Outside

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: LE MARS, Iowa, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The tensions within the Republican Party that hindered its efforts to advance a legislative agenda on Capitol Hill last year are showing up in the struggle for the party's Presidential nomination this year. They provide one key to understanding the surge of Steve Forbes in Iowa and New Hampshire, the two often pivotal states that vote later this month.
All the Republican hopefuls describe themselves as conservatives, but these days that description conceals more than it reveals. Of course, they share some views -- notably the conviction that the bureaucracy in Washington is evil. In the post-cold-war world, the bureaucracy has replaced Communism as the enemy that pulls the party together. 
 But they differ sharply on such questions as a balanced-budget amendment, term limits, abortion, homosexuality and tax policy, and it is Mr. Forbes, in terms of issues as well as background, who stands apart from the crowd.
Mr. Forbes and Patrick J. Buchanan, the commentator, go much further than their rivals in picturing government itself as the principal problem. In his stump speeches, Mr. Forbes ridicules not only bureaucrats but lawyers, politicians, lobbyists and journalists. He said this morning in Sioux City that "the whole culture of Washington" works overtime to throw "obstacles, road blocks and barriers" in the path of "the desires, ambitions and dreams of the American people."
Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee, sees Washington as a villain, but he thinks the answer is to transfer its responsibilities back to state governments, which he considers more efficient. Bob Dole and Richard G. Lugar, one a legislative craftsman, the other a policy wonk, are career insiders, and Phil Gramm, once an academic economist, has long since earned his inside-the-Beltway credentials.
So it is Mr. Forbes and Mr. Buchanan, neither of whom has ever held elective office, who can most credibly appeal to the broad group of Americans who think the answer to the country's ills is someone who comes to Presidential politics unsullied by the calculations and the compromises of a political career.
Many of them supported Ross Perot four years ago and voted for doctors and businessmen making their electoral debuts in the Congressional elections two years ago.
Emboldened by that constituency, many of the freshman House members have taken an extreme antigovernment posture, opposing all compromise. That brought them into conflict first with Mr. Dole and his Senate colleagues and eventually with Speaker Newt Gingrich and other senior Republicans in the House as well.
The old notion that expertise is as important for a President as it is for a surgeon or or a physicist is rejected by many voters. Disgusted with career politicians, Bill Thorpe, an 84-year-old retired architect, said he had come to hear Mr. Forbes "because he hasn't held any office, because he doesn't know his way around and he doesn't know the ropes."
Years in the trenches used to be the only apprenticeship for would-be Presidents. But television has made Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Forbes well enough known to run for President without first serving in lesser office -- years as a talk-show host and panelist for Mr. Buchanan, saturation television commercials for Mr. Forbes. Mr. Buchanan is the glowering outsider of this campaign, Mr. Forbes the smiling outsider, which may be why Mr. Forbes's approval ratings are higher.
Attitudes toward term limits, one of the reforms most popular with the new Republican majority of November 1994, offer a clue here. Mr. Alexander favors a part-time Congress; he wants to move the action to the state legislatures. Mr. Dole and Mr. Gramm favor term limits, but not retroactive ones. In other words, they would exempt themselves and their colleagues in Congress. Mr. Lugar opposes term limits outright; Mr. Forbes and Mr. Buchanan are unqualified supporters.
Mr. Forbes is an odd man out when it comes to economics, too.
Like Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, Mr. Forbes is a devotee of supply-side doctrines; they share an adviser in Jude Wanniski, an economic theoretician and unapologetic fan of Reaganomics. Alone among the major Republican candidates, Mr. Forbes opposes a balanced-budget amendment, arguing that the deficit can best be eliminated through economic growth spurred by lower taxes. Hence his flat-tax proposal, which has formed the centerpiece of his campaign.
Mr. Buchanan parts from his brethren in bitterly attacking the North American Free Trade Agreement, which they back. He and Mr. Gramm have flat-tax proposals of their own, but they are less flat than Mr. Forbes's. Only Mr. Forbes the nonpolitician has a tax so flat as to countenance the serious political heresy of ending the deductions for home mortgages and charitable contributions.
And then there is social policy, notably the abortion issue.
Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Gramm have dwelt at length on their fierce opposition to abortion, and Senator Bob Dole staged a special event in Dubuque Saturday, appearing with Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, an antiabortion crusader, to re-emphasize his antiabortion bona fides. Suspect in some conservatives' eyes because he has refused to sign a pledge to support the party's platform plank, he said he would reverse on his first day in office executive orders issued by President Clinton that are "forcing abortion even further into American life."
Mr. Forbes has sought to straddle the abortion issue. He said last September on the NBC program "Meet the Press" that he wanted "to help create an environment where abortion will wither away." To that end, he has opposed mandatory government funding for abortions and opposed abortion late in pregnancies or for sex selection. Unless underlying social attitudes change, he has been saying during his bus tour of Iowa, making abortion illegal would be no more effective than Prohibition.
Despite Mr. Forbes's best efforts to placate them, the national antiabortion organizations remain unimpressed. Colleen Parro, director of the Republican National Coalition for Life, said over the weekend that the millionaire publisher's position was "based on some nebulous reversal of the moral climate in America, which hasn't happened and isn't going to happen anytime soon."
And abortion-rights campaigners count him as one of them -- or almost so. After Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania dropped out of the Presidential race last November, Ann Stone of Republicans for Choice commented, "Our best person left is Steve Forbes, who's against any regulation in the first trimester."
Mr. Forbes's positions on homosexuality would also seem unacceptable to the Christian right. Asked last month by Armed Forces Journal what he thought of President Clinton's policy on gays in the military, he replied, "On the subject of 'Don't Ask/Don't Tell,' I say: Don't change." Asked last week in central Iowa whether he approved of same-sex marriages, he said he did not, but he added "If you want to live together, fine. If you want to have a life together, fine. But compassion is not approval."
Alone among the major Republican candidates, he has argued that the nation needs more immigrants, not fewer.
"Bill Clinton on many issues would run to the right of Steve Forbes," Mr. Gramm said in New Hampshire on Saturday, but his attempts to paint Mr. Forbes as an apostate, a Rockefeller Republican, appear to have had little impact.
Many potential voters and caucus-goers, including some prominent Christian conservatives, are in a highly pragmatic mood this year, more concerned about beating President Clinton in November than about the candidates' positions.
A measure of the pragmatism that has seized many Republicans here is the presence of Ione Dilley and Marlene Elwell in the Dole camp. Christian activists, both were instrumental in the successful effort several years ago to defeat the Equal Right Amendment in the state, and neither is a natural, died-in-the-wool Dole backer. But as Ms. Elwell said, "Our target is to beat Bill Clinton." Some leading evangelical conservatives were even willing to consider backing Gen. Colin L. Powell, a supporter of abortion rights, had he decided to run.
The rise of the religious right in Iowa has weakened, but not eliminated, moderate Republicans. Eager to strike back, they see an opening with the evangelicals split three or four ways. A number of women who came to hear Mr. Forbes in recent days said they were interested because he was the only candidate not beholden to the antiabortion forces.
In the end, though, it is Mr. Forbes's status as a political newcomer and his advocacy of a flat tax, driven home by $4 million in TV advertising, that has excited Iowans. Many of them know and care to know little else about him.

HEADLINE: 26 Members of Chinese-American Groups in Atlanta Indicted

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Federal law-enforcement officials today charged leaders of several Chinese-American fraternal organizations here with money laundering and drug trafficking, suggesting that these organizations, or "tongs," have been used as fronts for organized crime not only in New York and California but also in the South.
The officials said a primary purpose of the three-year sting operation that led to the indictments was to root out criminal activity before it became entrenched in the tongs. 
 "We don't want it to become what the La Cosa Nostra became in this country," said David W. Johnson Jr., the special agent in charge of the Atlanta office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. "We want to stop it now."
Tongs have been fixtures in the Chinatowns of New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles for much of this century. Organized like traditional secret societies in China, they serve as business and neighborhood associations that provide members with credit unions, social outlets, job referrals and other legitimate services.
But some tongs have also long been known as cover organizations for wide-ranging criminal activities, including gambling, smuggling, drug distribution, prostitution and murder.
The Asian population in the greater Atlanta region more than quadrupled between 1980 and 1990, to 51,820 from 12,529, according to the Census Bureau. Attracted by the warm climate and booming economy, Asians have moved here in large numbers from overseas and from other American cities. As the population has grown, so has membership in the tongs, some of which are chapters of groups based in New York, say leaders of Chinese business and community groups here.
"People go there to socialize," said Godwin Ku, the editor of Chinese Community News, an Atlanta newspaper with 5,000 subscribers in seven Southern states. "Every year they have a Chinese New Year's banquet. I think in New York these tongs are involved with crime maybe. But in Atlanta I don't think so."
Federal authorities emphasized at a news conference today that they did not regard the tongs themselves as criminal organizations. "We are not indicting the tongs as an organization," Mr. Johnson said. "However, some of these are criminal-influenced tongs."
But most of the 26 people whose indictments were announced today were leaders or members of the Hip Sing Tong, the Hung Mung Association, the San Gian Tong and the Fujien Fellowship Association of Southeast America, said Kent B. Alexander, the United States Attorney for the Northern District of Georgia.
Although the investigation was based in Atlanta, some of those arrested lived in New York; Birmingham, Ala,; Boston; Denver; Ellicott City, Md.; Portland, Ore.; San Francisco; Washington and Wheaton, Md.
One of those arrested on Sunday night was Sui Long Ying, the president of the San Gian Association, whose headquarters are at 25 Division Street in New York's Chinatown. Mr. Ying was charged in both New York and Atlanta with operating an illegal casino in the association's building, and with money laundering.
Federal officials said the drug laundering charges stem from a lengthy undercover operation in which tong members agreed to "wash" more than $500,000 in cash that they were told came from Colombian cocaine trafficking. Drug traffickers typically must invest their profits in businesses, either real or fictitious, to circumvent Federal requirements that banks report deposits of more than $10,000.
Undercover agents, working under the guise of a dummy corporation in Atlanta named Jasmine Inc., invested the purported drug cash in illegal casinos and other gambling operations run by the tong members, Mr. Alexander said. He described how they later received checks and money orders from the defendants for the principal, interest and dividends on their loans.
"Once we advised that we had money available we literally had people knocking at our door seeking to get money from illegal drug trafficking to put into their gambling businesses," said James Deichert, an assistant United States Attorney in charge of the Organized Crime Strike Force here.

HEADLINE: U.N., Facing Bankruptcy, Plans to Cut Payroll by 10%

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb 5

 BODY:
The top financial official of the United Nations said today that the organization is sliding toward bankruptcy and will have to cut about 10 percent of its permanent staff of more than 10,000 people at its headquarters in New York City and in seven foreign cities during the next two years.
The official, Joseph E. Connor, Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, told a General Assembly working group dealing with the financial crisis that by the end of this year the organization is expected to be about $420 million in debt for regular budget expenses alone, not counting peacekeeping operations. 
 The personnel cuts, forced on the United Nations by a combination of reduced budgets and the failure of member nations to pay dues on time, would, for the first time, begin to shrink an organization that has been widely criticized for its bloated bureaucracy and the sinecures provided for underemployed political appointees from around the world.
Even before the cuts begin, the organization's harshest critics were saying they were not enough.
The United Nations secretariat, which includes the organization's permanent bureaucracy but not its independent agencies like Unicef or Unesco, employs 10,150 people, about half of them in New York. Worldwide, 53,589 people work for the United Nations and its related agencies.
More jobs outside the secretariat may be affected if voluntary contributions to agencies continue to be cut by the United States or other governments. Also, thousands of people from professional experts to secretarial support staff who are on fixed-term contracts may not have them renewed. Hiring already has been largely frozen and buyouts are being offered to senior officials.
The failure of the United States to pay its regularly assessed bills has been a major factor in pushing the United Nations into crisis, Mr. Connor said today. He called the American shortfall, now at about $1.5 billion, "very severe."
"The payment situation of one member state is of overwhelming significance," Mr. Connor, an American who was chief executive officer of the Price Waterhouse accounting firm, said today. He added that other nations were also in arrears and that "the total level of unpaid assessments has increased to unprecedented levels."
The total in annual assessments owed to the United Nations by members rose to $2.3 billion by the end of 1995, a jump of $500 million over the previous year. New assessments were levied at the beginning of this year, and American officials were not able to predict when and if these would be paid, Mr. Connor said.
In an interview after his report to the General Assembly working group, Mr. Connor said that how and where personnel cuts are made will be left to individual department heads. Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali is expected to say more on this subject when he speaks to the same working group on Tuesday or Wednesday.
An advisory panel had earlier suggested that at least 600 secretarial and other support staff should be cut this year, 480 of them in layoffs and the rest through attrition and retirement. The panel also recommended a reduction in 550 professional level jobs, a cut of nearly 14 percent.
A cut in staff may still not be enough to close the budget gap, diplomats say. Last fall, the secretariat asked the General Assembly to approve an operating budget of $2.8 billion for this year and next. The Assembly instead voted a budget of $2.6 billion and then asked the organization to find another $104 million in additional cuts and report back to member states by the end of March.
Last week, Mr. Connor said that the "tough" budget would lead to zero growth in expenditures by the end of 1997, a first for the United Nations.
In making further reductions, the United States is asking the United Nations to look into areas like publications and public information. In an electronic age, diplomats say, there may be too much paper and too many people doing work that could be done by computers. Americans have also suggested turning over some services like translations to private companies.
Looking for longer-term solutions, the European Union and Japan are proposing new methods of assessment that would better reflect changed economic patterns and reduce somewhat the dependency of the United Nations on the United States. Washington is assessed a quarter of the regular United Nations budget and 31 percent of the costs of its peacekeeping operations, a figure Congress unilaterally reduced to 25 percent last year.
The Clinton Administration has welcomed the staff cutbacks as reforms that can be held up to skeptical members of the hostile, Republican-led Congress when the Administration asks for the money to pay its United Nations arrears.
But among many Republicans, where there are occasional calls to withdraw from the United Nations entirely, staff cuts or other money-saving measures may not be enough.
Today Marc Thiessen, spokesman for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said that a 10 percent staff cut was "a very, very small start." He said that the committee, chaired by Senator Jesse Helms, had demanded a 50 percent cut in the State Department, and would expect at least that large a cut in the United Nations.
The relationship between Congress and the United Nations -- with the Clinton Administration in the middle -- has recently been further complicated by the introduction of bills two weeks ago that would cut off all money to the organization if it tries to find alternate, independent sources of income.
The bills, among whose sponsors is Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate majority leader and a leading contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, were written after some Republicans heard reports that Secretary General Boutros-Ghali discussed in Britain in January the possibility of levying international taxes to avoid depending on national contributions. Mr. Dole characterized the Secretary General's comments as an example of the United Nations "out-of-control pursuit of power."
Transcripts showed that Mr. Boutros-Ghali, speaking at Oxford University and to the BBC, was referring to suggestions that have been made over several years to impose small levies on international currency transactions or arms sales.
In the interview, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said that only member nations had the power to change the way the United Nations is financed. "We are still an instrument in the hands of the member states," he said.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CAUCUSES;
Ever So Quietly, G.O.P. Is Beginning to Choose

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MANDEVILLE, La., Feb. 5

 BODY:
The fact that the first voting of the 1996 Presidential campaign takes place in Louisiana on Tuesday is as much a secret here as the ingredients of Chef Paul Prudhomme's signature debris sauce that graces his beef filet.
In random interviews today with dozens of residents in this Republican enclave on the north shore of Lake Pontchartrain, about 30 miles from New Orleans, almost no one had heard of the caucuses where voters will choose 21 delegates to the Republican National Convention, more even than in the first primary in New Hampshire. 
 The state's resurgent Republican Party had moved up the date to give Louisiana -- and the South -- more relevance in national politics. But there is little sign of activity: There are few television commercials, even fewer bumper stickers. In this morning's Times-Picayune of New Orleans, the state's dominant newspaper, there was not one word about the caucuses.
"I had no idea there was going to be an election," said Jan Land, 40, who was shopping at a strip mall here. "I've heard not a word. Not anything. You'd think I'd know: I'm a librarian."
Despite the lack of attention, and the fact that only a tiny fraction of registered Republicans are expected to participate, the voting here will be a closely watched showdown between two conservatives, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Patrick J. Buchanan.
"The process is not as important as the result," said Rhett Davis, a consultant to the state Republican Party. "Somebody's going to win and somebody's going to lose -- and the winner will establish momentum going into Iowa and New Hampshire." Louisiana will hold a more traditional primary in March in which eight additional delegates will be selected.
Mr. Gramm and Mr. Buchanan are vying to emerge as the favorite of the most highly charged conservatives who will endure unusually cold weather to make it to 42 caucus sites. Both contenders are looking for a lift before the more crucial competition among all nine candidates in the Iowa caucuses on Feb. 12.
The leading candidates in Iowa and New Hampshire, Senator Bob Dole and Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate, had chosen to boycott the caucuses here to avoid angering voters in those states who wanted to preserve their tradition of holding the first contests. Another candidate who is popular with conservatives, Alan Keyes, is also competing here, though he only qualified to contend for delegates at a limited number of caucus sites.
For months Mr. Gramm, who hails from a neighboring state, was seen as the favorite after assembling the most sophisticated organization here. "I've never seen anyone come in and organize the way he has" Mr. Davis said. "He came in nearly a year ahead of time."
Rather than dampen expectations, Mr. Gramm tells all who will listen that he will triumph on Tuesday. "The people in Iowa are going to look at the Louisiana caucuses as a sort of semifinal to decide who is the real conservative candidate," the Texan said at a campaign stop today in Muscatine, Iowa. "If we win convincingly in Louisiana, that process is going to turn into an avalanche."
But in recent days, Mr. Buchanan has become such a presence that local Republicans joke that he has bought a house in Baton Rouge and a summer home in New Orleans.
"It's the best decision of the campaign to come down here and have a one-on-one battle," Mr. Buchanan said tonight at a crawfish farm in Vinton, a small town on the border with Beaumont, Tex. "Gramm's behaving very overconfidently."
Mr. Buchanan's one coup here came on Friday, when he won the support of Gov. Mike Foster. The Governor's decision may have been influenced by the fact that Mr. Buchanan had hired Mr. Foster's top campaign aides for his campaign. Mr. Buchanan was also the only Presidential candidate to endorse Mr. Foster in the Republican primary last year.
While Mr. Buchanan has been campaigning here for days, Mr. Gramm is confident enough -- or is so concerned about placing well in Iowa -- that he has remained in Iowa and will not return to Louisiana until late on Tuesday for an afternoon of campaigning before voters attend the caucuses in the evening.
Religious conservatives are expected to be particularly active in the caucuses, which have become a testing ground more of social issues than economic ones. While Mr. Gramm has campaigned in most parts of Louisiana, a longtime Democratic bastion, Mr. Buchanan has concentrated on the west side of the Mississippi, particularly in the Catholic regions of southwest Louisiana, where his outspoken opposition to abortion might be especially well received. He has also emphasized his protectionist trade views.
Emile Peppi Bruneau, the Speaker pro tem of the State House of Representatives who backs Mr. Gramm, said that Mr. Buchanan's small core of supporters are enthusiastic but that the Senator has wider appeal. "The fewer people who vote, the better it is for Buchanan," he said.
What was most notable in the random interviews in Mandeville was that among those who said they planned to participate, virtually every person identified Mr. Forbes as his or her favorite candidate -- even though he is not even taking part.
Even the Republicans who know about the caucuses are not entirely impressed. Saying he had only a sketchy notion they were coming up, Wayne Cox, 43, a management consultant here said: "Isn't it something with Louisiana trying to be first? It sounds pretty ludicrous to me."

HEADLINE: NYC;
Firebombing: Putting Blame On Prozac

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
A 90's version of the Twinkie defense holds center stage in the plain, wood-paneled chamber that is Part 72 of State Supreme Court in Manhattan. That is where Edward J. Leary has been on trial for the last week, charged with attempted murder in two subway firebombings that burned and scarred 50 people in December 1994.
The Twinkie defense, you'll recall, was used in behalf of Dan White, a San Francisco Supervisor who killed Mayor George Moscone and a fellow Supervisor, Harvey Milk, in 1979. Psychiatrists for the defense argued that Mr. White's huge intake of sugar-laden junk food, like Hostess Twinkies, heightened his emotional distress to a point where he came unglued. To a degree, their testimony worked. The Supervisor was found guilty of voluntary manslaughter instead of first-degree murder. 
 Midway through this decade when olestra is in, sugar is most definitely out. In Part 72, the modern equivalent is Prozac.
Basically, the defense argument goes like this:
Mr. Leary, a gaunt, pasty-faced man of 50, fell into depression after losing his job as a computer analyst and went to a psychologist who prescribed Prozac together with other drugs. It was a reckless combination, the lawyers say, because it produced a volatile psychotropic cocktail that drove their client mad.
They do not contest that Mr. Leary caused the underground fires on Dec. 15 and Dec. 21, 1994. But they are telling the jurors to forget prosecution claims of a plot to extort money from the Transit Authority. Mr. Leary, they say, had no intention of harming anyone.
THAT includes the more severe incident of Dec. 21, when he boarded a downtown No. 4 train with a volatile cocktail of his own: two jars of gasoline, matches, flashbulbs and a kitchen timer. As it turned out, the device blew up in his face, burning him and dozens of others and turning a routine ride into a purgatory.
This is the latest of many prominent cases in which the defense has held that the accused was either not himself or had motives other than those alleged by prosecutors. To cite but two, Yigal Amir now says in Tel Aviv that he was not trying to murder Yitzhak Rabin last November but sought instead "merely" to paralyze the Israeli Prime Minister by firing three bullets into his back. And closer to home, Colin Ferguson's lawyers tried, though unsuccessfully, to create an argument of "black rage" for why Mr. Ferguson went on a shooting spree that killed six people on the Long Island Rail Road.
Now there's the Prozac defense.
For the most part, this sort of drug defense has not worked in New York, but it is too early to tell this time. While the strategy is at the heart of the case, psychiatric and pharmacological testimony lies ahead. Thus far, the jury has focused on the two subway incidents themselves, especially the one on Dec. 21 and Mr. Leary's flight that day through a tunnel between Manhattan and Brooklyn. They have heard from police officers, from paramedics and, most of all, from victims themselves, some of whose faces remain horrendously seared from the terror.
ONE of them, Winfield Edey, limped into the courtroom yesterday to recall for the jurors the burst of fire on that No. 4 train, followed by "the most horrible screams you can think of."
Mr. Edey, born in Barbados 61 years ago and living in Far Rockaway, was turned into a human torch, although he testified that in the confusion of the moment he was not even aware for a while that he was on fire. He suffered burns over 67 percent of his body, from head to toe. His face is now a chiaroscuro of browns and whites. His hands, splotched and blistered, may require surgery. He cannot straighten one, and the knuckles of the other do not bend. His feet, he said, were "burned to the bone."
"I don't know what I'm going to do," said Mr. Edey, who has not been able to work since that day. Unemployed truck drivers with hands and feet that do not function right are not in great demand.
"This was one of the most difficult days for me, having to see face to face the man who did this to me," he said after leaving the courtroom. But he bears Mr. Leary no malice, he added, an attitude that brought a frustrated sigh from his wife, Vadna. No, her husband retorted, "There's no point carrying around all that hate."
But that does not mean he accepts the Prozac defense. "If he doesn't come up with a defense like that, what other defense would make any sense at all?" Mr. Edey said as he hobbled out of the courthouse at 100 Centre Street. "When the chips are down, that's the one you use and hope you get away with it."
The only question now is whether the jury agrees.

HEADLINE: Clinton Meets Deadline With an Outline of 1997 Budget

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
With the Federal budget for the current year still far from settled, President Clinton today proposed a $1.64 trillion spending plan for 1997, sketching how he would balance the budget in seven years with a small tax cut. But the Republican-controlled Congress has already dismissed the plan as inadequate.
In contrast with the usual multivolume document of 2,000 pages, the budget that the President released today is a scant 20-page outline. It includes virtually no new proposals, instead repeating the last offer Mr. Clinton made to the Republicans when balanced-budget talks collapsed last month. 
 The White House issued the document today simply to comply with the legal deadline for proposing a budget and to keep pressure on the Republicans to resume negotiations over a broad plan to end the deficit and resolve current spending disputes. It promised to provide by March 18 the usual detailed proposal for the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1.
"I am very hopeful we can achieve a balanced budget this year," Mr. Clinton said at the White House today, meeting with the governors attending the winter meeting of the National Governors' Association. "I hope we can set aside partisanship and divisions, as you often do in the N.G.A., and provide a balanced budget plan to the American people in the near future."
Mr. Clinton would increase spending about 4 percent from the projected $1.58 trillion in the current fiscal year. Although the budget year is already four months old, many agencies are still operating on a stopgap spending measure that expires next month because Congress and the White House have failed to agree on regular appropriations, and Mr. Clinton did not spell out agency-by-agency plans in his proposal today.
The Republicans, who broke off negotiations last month, have said they will not resume talks until Mr. Clinton produces a more serious proposal, with greater specifics. They argued that his plan failed to force needed cuts in the rise of spending for rapidly growing benefit programs like Medicare and did not provide for adequate tax cuts.
The document released today had so little bearing on the state of the debate that Republican officials, whose fax machines would normally be busily spitting out reactions, barely bothered.
Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, issued a statement calling the proposal "warmed-over status quo." The House Republican leadership branded it "the deja vu budget."
For their part, Democrats have been divided over the President's approach, with liberals in Congress fearing that Mr. Clinton is too ready to compromise, while some moderates have complained that he is still skirting the tough choices.
"What is driving the White House is re-election," former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts said at a news conference of the Concord Coalition Citizens' Council, a bipartisan group he helped found to advocate fiscal discipline. Mr. Tsongas, who was Mr. Clinton's bitter rival in the 1992 Democratic primaries, said the President's plan failed to control spending for entitlement programs like welfare and Medicare and offered tax cuts in the early years while putting off most spending cuts until later years.
"It front-loads the joy and back-loads the pain," Mr. Tsongas said.
Mr. Clinton's document remains a starting point.
"This is not a budget that was ever meant to have a life of its own," said Stan Collender, a budget expert at the Price Waterhouse accounting firm in Washington. "I don't think anyone in the Administration is pretending otherwise. They probably would have been justified in taking more time, but rather than leave themselves open to rhetorical charges that they were late with the budget, they did this."
Under new economic assumptions released today, the White House projected that the gross domestic product would grow 5.1 percent this year and for the next six years, before taking inflation into account. That would compare with an estimated growth of 4.2 percent last year, without adjusting for inflation.
Joseph Stiglitz, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said the Administration believed that the current softness in the economy was the result of temporary factors like the recent Government shutdowns and winter storms and was not a sign of recession.
"We believe we will continue to see noninflationary growth with low unemployment," he said at a White House briefing. "The outlook for the economy is good."

LENGTH: 1199 words

HEADLINE: GOVERNORS GROUP FINDS AGREEMENT ON MEDICAID PLAN

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Leaders of the nation's governors said tonight that they had agreed on a bipartisan proposal on Medicaid, one of the major stumbling blocks in the budget impasse between President Clinton and Republicans in Congress.
The governors, at a conference of the National Governors' Association, said they had also made progress toward a compromise on welfare, another major issue in the budget debate. 
 By themselves, the governors cannot alter Medicaid or welfare policy now set by the Federal Government. But both the White House and Republican leaders in Congress have been looking to them for suggestions about how to overcome the current impasse.
Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican who is chairman of the association, said he hoped the agreement on Medicaid would be "the catalyst to break the deadlock and get everything else moving."
Under the bipartisan Medicaid proposal offered by the governors, each state would receive a lump sum of Federal money, known as a block grant, to finance health care for the poor. But the proposal would guarantee a package of medical benefits, to be defined in Federal law, to millions of poor people. The proposal thus strikes a compromise between the desire of many Democrats to keep Medicaid as an entitlement and Republican demands for block grants.
Governor Bob Miller of Nevada, a Democrat who is vice chairman of the association, said the negotiators "agreed not to use words that were politically divisive like entitlement and block grant."
Earlier today, the governors met with President Clinton, who said that he and Congress were close to an agreement on "sweeping welfare reform that is very consistent with what the governors have advocated for years."
Many Republicans in Congress have said they will give serious consideration to any proposal approved by their party's governors. President Clinton said in 1992 that he wanted to "end welfare as we know it," but he vetoed a Republican welfare bill last month on the ground that it was too harsh.
The Medicaid compromise, endorsed unanimously by a group of 26 governors this afternoon, will be put to a formal vote at a meeting of all governors on Tuesday, just before President Clinton speaks to the organization. Mr. Thompson predicted that it would be approved by the three-fourths majority needed for such action.
Medicaid finances health care for 37 million poor people, including many children and many residents of nursing homes. Governors have a huge interest in Medicaid because it is financed jointly by the Federal Government and the states, its cost has quadrupled in the last decade and it now accounts for about 20 percent of all state spending. If Republicans succeed in turning much of the authority for Medicaid over to the states, governors will have a larger role in running the program and deciding how to allocate money.
Governor Miller said the Medicaid compromise would give states "a lot of flexibility" to shape their own health programs for the poor. But he said it would also guarantee coverage for certain groups of people, with an assurance that states would get more Federal money if the number of needy people increased because of economic downturns or migration from other states.
Governors outlined their Medicaid proposal to Mr. Clinton at a meeting in the White House this morning. Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, a Democrat, said, "The President looks with favor upon the concepts we laid out, but he needs to see the detail." Mr. Miller said, "The President's reaction seemed to be very positive."
Republican leaders in the House have not seen the details of the proposal. But in the past, they have worked closely with Republican governors and indicated that they would probably support any reconfiguration of Medicaid recommended by those governors.
The Medicaid compromise was negotiated in the last two months by three Republican governors -- Mr. Thompson, John Engler of Michigan and Michael O. Leavitt of Utah -- and by three Democrats -- Mr. Miller, Mr. Romer and Lawton Chiles of Florida.
Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a Republican, said: "There is an agreement in principle on Medicaid. If we can get it through Congress and the White House, it will have a very positive impact for New York."
In an interview, Mr. Pataki said, "A bipartisan consensus among the governors will go a long way to ending the Federal impasse."
But Medicaid is a notoriously complex program, and it may take weeks of work for Congress to translate the governors' conceptual agreement into legislative language. The legislation must then be evaluated by the Congressional Budget Office, which will assess its cost.
In his 1997 budget, issued today, President Clinton proposed savings of $59 billion in Medicaid in the next seven years. A proposal offered by Republican governors last week would have saved $85 billion. The bipartisan governors' proposal will presumably generate savings somewhere between those alternatives.
A detailed summary of the bipartisan proposal, circulated among governors tonight, says that Medicaid recipients would be assured of coverage for hospital services, doctors' services, nursing home care, family planning services and supplies, laboratory services and X-rays. But, it says, states would have "complete flexibility in defining the amount, duration and scope of services."
The summary of the bipartisan governors' proposal says it has these provisions:
*States would have to provide Medicaid for pregnant women with family incomes up to 33 percent above the official poverty level; for children under 6 in families with incomes up to 33 percent above the poverty line, and for children 6 to 12 in families below the poverty level ($11,821 for a family of three in 1994).
*States would have to provide Medicaid for disabled people. States could define disability, but their definitions would be subject to approval by the Federal Secretary of Health and Human Services.
*Welfare recipients would generally be entitled to Medicaid, as they are under current law.
*People improperly denied Medicaid could appeal to a state agency and could then file suit in state court, with a right of appeal to state courts and then ultimately to the United States Supreme Court.
*States would have "complete authority" to set Medicaid payment rates for health plans, doctors and hospitals, "without interference from the Federal Government or threat of legal action" by health care providers. States would no longer need Federal permission to require Medicaid recipients to enroll in health maintenance organizations, and they would no longer be subject to lawsuits by health care providers demanding higher reimbursement.
*Federal grants to the states for Medicaid would be adjusted for the rising cost of health care and expected changes in the number of poor people. The Federal Government would provide extra money for states with unexpected population growth.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, a Republican, predicted that the governors' agreement "will break the logjam" on Capitol Hill, and she declared that "the needy population is not going to be ignored" by state officials.

A1); President Clinton greeting the nation's governors yesterday in the East Room of the White House after meeting with them during a conference of the National Governors' Association, where a bipartisan accord was reached on Medicaid. At left was Gov. Mike Lowry, Democrat of Washington. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: Ford to Offer Cheaper Cars As Sales Sag

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it would begin selling a lower-cost version of its redesigned Taurus sedan as it reported that its sales of cars and light trucks dropped in January, pushing the pace of total industry sales into negative territory, compared with levels a year ago.
The cheaper Taurus -- which will be $605, or some 3 percent, less than the starting point for a Taurus now -- will be a new car called the Taurus G. It represents the latest retreat by Ford from its strategy of building ever-fancier cars and trucks and charging premium prices for them. Last month, as Taurus sales got off to a disappointing start for the year, Ford announced a $600 rebate through April 2. 
 Ford has poured billions of dollars into developing sophisticated engines, transmissions and suspensions that are costly to manufacture, only to find that it is introducing them when consumers are especially price sensitive.
With sales of Taurus and its sibling, the Mercury Sable, down last month, Ford said that its total sales of cars and light trucks fell 3.4 percent in January from a year earlier. That follows a report on Friday by the Toyota Motor Corporation that its January sales plummeted 17.3 percent from a year earlier. Toyota attributed the decline to a decision to offer fewer discounts this year.
But total-vehicle sales do seem to be holding up at the Chrysler Corporation and, to a lesser extent, the General Motors Corporation. Indeed, G.M. provided another sign of its continuing recovery today as its board voted to increase the quarterly dividend on common stock to 40 cents a share from 30 cents, effective Feb. 15. [Page D9.]
For the entire industry, the negative reports from Ford and Toyota mean that the overall sales rate fell 1.6 percent in January from a year earlier. Percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate because showrooms were open one more day last month than in January 1995.
The latest data were a contrast to January reports from a dozen other auto makers last Thursday that showed a slight sales gain from a year earlier. Those reports had prompted Wall Street analysts to declare that sales seemed to be relatively resilient despite signs of weakness in the economy.
At Ford, the new Taurus G is scheduled for introduction on April 3, the day after the rebates are set to expire, and will have a base price of $18,545, including destination charges. That compares with $19,150 for the cheapest version of the Taurus GL, the best-selling car in the United States. Ford will also offer a less expensive version of the Mercury Sable, which is quite similar to the Taurus.
Even in the G version, the Taurus will remain more expensive than a Chevrolet Lumina sedan, but less expensive than the Toyota Camry or the Honda Accord. G.M. officials quickly pointed out today that the Lumina price starts at $16,895, which is $1,650 less than the Taurus G. The Lumina is "priced correctly for the marketplace," said William J. O'Neill Jr., a Chevrolet spokesman.
Many car shoppers have said that the new, bubble-shaped Taurus, which went on sale in September, feels smaller inside than its predecessor although Ford engineers insist that the vehicle has slightly more room.
Ford officials have scrambled in the last two months to come up with the Taurus G, which will be available only in white, red, gray, silver and green for the exterior, while all of the interiors will be gray, the most popular color. The mirrors and side moldings will be black only, instead of matching the paint color as they do in other Taurus models.
Some popular options will not be offered on the Taurus G, as a way to limit the number of buyers who choose the less expensive vehicle. Standard equipment will include an AM-FM stereo radio, air-conditioning, dual air bags and a 3.0 liter V-6 engine with automatic transmission.
Robert Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing and sales, predicted that the G version will account for only 5 to 10 percent of all Taurus cars sold. He said that the company had not overpriced the original vehicle but that public reaction had produced considerable concern among Ford dealers.
"We're responding to a lot of coverage in the press and elsewhere about where the Taurus is positioned," he said in an interview today. Ford's overall pricing strategy remains in place, he said, adding that the decision to offer the Taurus G and the decision last month to offer discounts on half of Ford's product line represented isolated responses to market needs.
The daily rate of Taurus sales fell by 3.5 percent in January from the previous year, still a better showing than that of many other Ford models. But Christopher W. Cedergren, a consultant at AutoPacific Group, in Santa Ana, Calif., said the Taurus sales were unimpressive in light of the incentives being offered.
"Given the $600 rebate, they probably should have done more," he said.
Mr. Rewey said that small-car sales were the weakest last month, while the F-150 pickup truck, the Ford Explorer sport-utility vehicle and the Ford Contour sedan all sold well, as did the large Ford, Lincoln and Mercury cars.
Ford dealers today played down the importance of the weak sales. January sales were "maybe a little softer than we normally have," said Larry V. Sexton, a dealer in St. Roberts, Mo. "It's not like the bottom fell out."

HEADLINE: Beijing's Public Relations Gambit Won't Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"China, Vying With Taiwan, Explores Public Relations" (front page, Feb. 2) states that Taiwan's Government, which has lobbied Capitol Hill for decades, "is paying $4.5 million over three years to the Washington lobbying firm of Cassidy & Associates." Cassidy & Associates is employed not by Taiwan's Government but by the Taipei-based Taiwan Research Institute. 
 A private, nonprofit study group, the Taiwan Research Institute is headed by Liu Tai-ying, an economist and former classmate of Taiwan's president who also happens to be the chairman of the business management committee of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang.
The three-year contract with Cassidy & Associates, which was signed in 1994 to advance American "appreciation of Taiwan's history, culture and democratic development," is but one example of how vast sums are spent to have Taiwan's voice heard.
 
BRADFORD TREBACH
Bronx, Feb. 2, 1996
The writer is a lawyer specializing in international affairs.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Stock-Trading Seat Is More And A Gold-Trading Seat Less These Days

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
STANDING on the New York Stock Exchange floor costs more than ever before. But trading gold costs a lot less than it used to.
The Big Board reported yesterday that a seat sold for $1.25 million, up an amazing $200,000 from the most recent sale, recorded on Dec. 4, 1995, and $100,000 over the old record high, of $1.15 million, which was set on Sept. 21, 1987, less than a month before prices crashed. 
 The word "seat" is something of a misnomer; traders do a lot more running around and yelling than they do sitting, and in fact many of the 1,366 members lack a place to sit.
The price of a Big Board seat is up from a post-crash low, reached Nov. 27, 1990, of $250,000. The prices reflect the money that people think can be made trading stocks on the exchange, which in turn depends on an appraisal of the popularity of investing in stocks and on the New York Stock Exchange's competitive position with other stock markets.
Currently, both look good. Big Board volume is up sharply over the last couple of years, and the public interest in equity investing, both directly and through mutual funds, is also high. Those factors are related to share prices, but not completely, and as a result seat prices can be far more volatile than stock prices. The Dow Jones industrial average is more than three times as high as its post-crash low; the trading value of a Big Board seat has quintupled.
By contrast, investing in precious metals seems much less attractive, either to individual investors or to professionals. In 1984, a seat on the Commodity Exchange of New York -- the pre-eminent market for futures on precious metals -- sold for $200,000. Yesterday, such a seat (now on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange) traded for $115,000.
That price is down from a 1995 high of $149,000, indicating that despite the fact that gold prices have come alive in recent weeks, with gold leaping more than $20 an ounce, there is still no confidence that trading will rise enough to help profits of the brokers who execute public orders.
At other commodity exchanges, the picture is not quite as glum, in large part because many exchanges trade financial futures, which have done well. But the Chicago Board of Trade reports its last sale of a seat was for $625,000 last week, a price that is 12 percent below the peak of $710,000, reached just over a year ago. And at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the last sale was for $585,000, down 37 percent from a peak of $925,000, set in August 1994.
The interest right now, among those who want to trade and among those who want to collect commissions by executing those trades, is clearly in stocks. The number of seats on the Big Board has been fixed at the same 1,366 since 1953, and seats do not trade that often. Last year, total volume came to 11 seats. But it is unusual for prices to move by huge amounts, particularly in the absence of such major events as crashes or new laws that seem to radically change the outlook for stock trading.
Even in the heated market of 1987, when the stock market seemed headed for the moon, until it crashed, the largest single increase from one trade to the next was $150,000, another record that was broken yesterday.
Still, the ascent of seat prices over time is not quite as rapid as in 1987. When the 1987 peak was set, the price was up 132 percent over the last 12 months, with a seat having sold for $480,000 on Sept. 22, 1986.
A year ago, the most recent sale had been at $750,000. The increase since then is 67 percent, a lot more than share prices have risen but perhaps an indication that the seat market is not quite as overheated as it was in 1987.
Seat prices can come down quickly. On Oct. 15, 1987, the Thursday before Black Monday, a seat traded at $1,025,000. On Oct. 26, less than two weeks later, a seat sold for $625,000, a drop of 39 percent. And the price was destined to go lower until it bottomed amid widespread pessimism during the 1990 recession.
And now, everything looks lovely to those who want to trade on the Big Board.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 8, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart with the Market Place column in Business Day on Tuesday, about the rising price of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, mislabeled the years shown. The prices shown were end-of-the-month figures from January 1980 through Monday.

HEADLINE: On Eve of Talks, Iraq Is Hopeful U.N. Will Let Oil Exports Resume

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Feb. 5

 BODY:
As Iraq and the United Nations prepare for talks that could allow the Baghdad Government to resume exports of oil, optimism has surged in the Iraqi capital, where the dinar is now seven times stronger against the dollar than it was at the start of the year.
But for the American military planners and others responsible for maintaining a cordon around Iraq, the prospect that Iraqi oil could begin flowing again through the Persian Gulf is seen as a new challenge. 
 With talks to begin in New York on Tuesday, it is not clear that the two sides can reach agreement on the United Nations plan, which would allow Iraq to sell $2 billion worth of oil over six months, but only under conditions that Baghdad has previously rejected.
Yet Iraq has already announced that its oil terminals at the head of the gulf are ready to receive tankers. And commanders of the American-led flotilla offshore have had to begin planning for a possible easing of the United Nations sanctions -- a step that the official Iraqi press has heralded as "the beginning of the end for the embargo" that was imposed five-and-a-half years ago.
The Security Council imposed the sanctions after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990 and has stipulated that they will not be lifted until Iraq accounts for all its weapons of mass destruction and the United Nations can certify that they have been destroyed.
In recent weeks, the main preoccupation of the American vessels has been efforts by small dhows to smuggle out prized Iraqi dates. If Iraq is allowed to turn on its oil spigots, even under strict limits, enforcing the sanctions will become far more complicated.
In an unusual step, Vice Adm. Scott Redd, commander of the United States Fifth Fleet, briefed United Nations officials last week about the American-led operation in the gulf, which since 1990 has intercepted some 22,000 vessels in its mission to halt seaborne trade to and from Iraq.
Under Security Council Resolution 986, which would allow Iraq to sell a limited quantity of oil and use the proceeds to buy food and other goods for its civilian population, exports must be carried out under United Nations supervision.
But the form the supervision will take has not been worked out. While the resolution says Iraq is obliged to export the "larger share" through a pipeline to Turkey, Baghdad has expressed reluctance in part because the route passes through Kurdish-controlled areas of northern Iraq.
Iraq is demanding that it send much of the flow through the gulf from its ports at Mina al Bakr and Khor al Amaya. Oil traders and diplomats say that arrangement would be more difficult to monitor.
"I certainly wouldn't say that it's going to be easy," an American official in the gulf said of the Navy's likely involvement in policing oil exports.
Iraq, which has not been permitted to sell oil abroad except for limited sales to neighboring Jordan, is plainly eager to regain its place as one of the world's leading oil merchants. With a new confidence that has fueled the spectacular rise in its currency, Baghdad seems to think that it might at last be back on that track.
Diplomats and journalists in Baghdad have reported that the increased strength of the dinar means that essential items like sugar, rice, eggs and flour now cost at least 75 percent less than they did three weeks ago.
They have also reported a buying spree by residents suddenly able to afford dollar-denominated luxury goods, along with a rush to exchange hoarded American dollars at favorable rates. The dinar, valued at 3,000 to the dollar at the New Year, is now trading at 450 to the dollar.
On Sunday, after President Saddam Hussein met with his economic advisers, the Government issued astatement saying, "We expect positive results from the dialogue with the United Nations."
For nearly a year, Iraq has rejected the plan, and diplomats and officials at the United Nations remain skeptical that it is ready to accept their terms. Even in sending its negotiator, Abdulamir al-Anbari, for the talks in New York with Tono Eitel of Germany, who heads the United Nations sanctions committee, Baghdad has refused to refer to Resolution 986 by name.
Baghdad regards as one of the most nettlesome provisions the United Nations' insistence that some oil revenue be used to distribute food to rebel Kurds in the north and to Shiite dissidents in south. In a statement today, the Arab League made clear that it shared that concern "about the sovereignty, safety and sanctity of Iraq's soil."
The organization urged the United Nations and Iraq "to reach a compromise" that would allow the limited oil sales to begin. That sentiment has found support well beyond the Middle East among Western governments troubled by the toll the sanctions have exacted on the Iraqi population, one-fifth of whom may now be malnourished, according to a recent United Nations report.
But American officials led by Madeleine K. Albright, the chief delegate to the United Nations, have said there will be no negotiations about the resolution itself. 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 9, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about negotiations to let Iraq resume limited oil sales misstated the year of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. It was 1990, not 1989.
The article also misidentified the chief United Nations negotiator in the talks with the Iraqis. He is Under Secretary General Hans Corell; Tono Eitel is head of the Security Council sanctions committee.

HEADLINE: We Can't Afford Voodoo 2

BYLINE: By Herbert Stein; Herbert Stein, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, was chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers under Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The experienced Republican Presidential candidates are amazed at the surge of Steve Forbes. They shouldn't be. They prepared the way for Steve Forbes. Indeed, they made him inevitable. 
 At least since the time of Andrew Mellon, the idea that taxes are evil has been forefront in the Republican creed. Ronald Reagan refined the creed: Taxes are not only evil; they are also unnecessary. In the post-World War II era, the party's platform has had two main planks -- anti-Communism and anti-taxes. With the collapse of the Soviet Union, the platform is down to one plank.
Of course, responsible Republican officials could not live by their own ideology. Once in Washington, they had to recognize that taxation is a legitimate and necessary function of government. So, President Dwight Eisenhower found himself repeatedly resisting calls for tax reduction. In 1969 President Richard Nixon resisted a drive for a big tax cut led by Senator Albert Gore Sr., a Democrat and father of the current Vice President.
President George "Read My Lips" Bush agreed to a tax increase in 1990. Bob Dole, as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, took the lead in raising taxes in 1982. And every other veteran Republican Senator has agreed to a tax increase or resisted a cut.
This is now a problem for Republican candidates who have held office. They want to show their adherence to the Republican anti-tax creed. But their own records, and their appreciation of the realities of the budget, keep them for doing so unreservedly. So the way is clear for a candidate uncontaminated by prior contact with the Federal budget, who can sing that old sweet song, "Let Me Cut Your Taxes, I Just Love Your Vote." That gives us Steve Forbes and the flat tax.
Of course, the term "flat tax" is a diversion. What it means is "low tax." No one is trudging through New Hampshire trying to sell a 25 percent flat tax. It has to be a 17 percent flat tax or some other impossibly low number because the flat tax is terribly unflat in its impact on different people, depending on whether they have home mortgages or employer-provided health benefits, and so forth
To be attractive, the flat tax has to be low enough so that even those most disadvantaged by it get something. Such a low rate would lose a lot of revenue, but that doesn't bother Mr. Forbes, because he hasn't yet encountered the Federal budget. That is presumably what he means when he boasts of not being a Washington insider.
 Thus cutting taxes serves all purposes in the Forbes campaign. You want 4 percent economic growth? Cut taxes! You want 4 1/2 percent interest rates? Cut taxes!
You want foreign policy? Cutting taxes will make America such a model society that the Serbs, Croats and Bosnians will stop shooting one another and emulate us. You want anti-crime policy? Cut taxes on legal income and you will eliminate the incentive to engage in illegal activity. You want fewer single mothers? Eliminate the tax code's marriage penalty.
The "insider" candidates find it hard to deal with this. They can't say that the Forbes tax rate is much too low. There is no such thing in the Republican campaign lexicon -- or in the Democratic one either -- as a tax rate that is too low.
The political mythology that cutting taxes is the sure road to electoral success is an indication of how few politicians know history. After the Republican 80th Congress cut taxes in 1948, Harry Truman won an election that he wasn't supposed to win. After the Republican 83rd Congress cut taxes in 1954, Democrats took control of the House for 40 years.
Yes, there was one politically successful tax cutter: Ronald Reagan. Mr. Forbes's friends like to compare him to Mr. Reagan. But there are critical differences. For one thing, Mr. Reagan had spontaneous charm. Also, Mr. Reagan had two big issues on which to base his 1980 campaign -- Communism and inflation -- and he later deal with both successfully. And he even went on to raise taxes by his second year in office.
The country faces an entirely different fiscal situation today than in 1980. Then the Federal debt was 26.8 percent of the gross domestic product, only slightly above its postwar low. The ratio today is more than 50 percent, and without a radical change it will likely exceed 100 percent in the next generation. We could afford Ronald Reagan once. We cannot afford him again.
Meanwhile, I'm cool. As far as I can figure it out, the Forbes flat tax would save me a lot money.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Celebrating Four Who Shaped American Tastes in Food

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
A SERIES of celebrations honoring individuals and establishments that have shaped the way Americans cook and eat is taking place this month in New York.
Tonight, a 12-course salute will be given at An American Place for Fannie Merritt Farmer, whose "Original Boston Cooking School Cookbook" was first published 100 years ago. The dinner, a daunting example of eating at the turn of this century, will be based on a typical "full course dinner" of those days. An abbreviated version, a mere six courses, will be available to the public tomorrow and Friday evenings. 
 On Feb. 23, a seven-course bicentennial dinner will be held at the James Beard Foundation based on recipes from "American Cookery," published in Hartford in 1796 by Amelia Simmons, said to be the first cookbook written and published by an American. And several Amelia Simmons dishes will be served at the restaurant Home through the end of the month.
Last Monday, a 10-course fish dinner was given to mark the 10th anniversary of both the Beard Foundation and Le Bernardin, the restaurant transplanted to New York from Paris by Gilbert Le Coze and his sister, Maguy. The complete dinner, which alternated dishes by Mr. Le Coze with more recent creations by Eric Ripert, the executive chef, can be ordered at Le Bernardin throughout the month.
These influential experts represented vastly different points on the evolving time line of American cuisine. But Amelia Simmons, Fannie Farmer, James Beard and Gilbert Le Coze all shared a passionate advocacy of the ingredients produced in the United States, insisting on only the freshest and best.
Mr. Le Coze died in 1994, but his approach to cooking fish continues to have a profound influence on American chefs. Though a native of France, he made a point of serving fish like halibut, pompano, black bass, monkfish and grouper from American waters, not the imported Dover sole his peers in top-flight restaurants tended to prefer. He went to the fish market at 2 A.M. himself, bought only what was sublimely fresh and prepared it with great delicacy, slightly undercooking it to create a silky richness.
"It's like a school, like painting," Mr. Ripert said. Because Mr. Le Coze never wrote a cookbook, his impact was far greater in restaurants than in homes.
Mr. Beard not only counseled chefs but was also an invaluable guide for cooks at home. And now the foundation that bears his name, through its dinners and awards, is helping today's professionals and keeping his legacy alive. In 1972, when Mr. Beard wrote "American Cookery," he understood that the cuisine of this country depended on "the products of the soil and native traditions," and also on "the gradual integration of many ethnic forms."
Miss Farmer's target was the housewife, not the chef. She is remembered, for better or worse, as the person responsible for introducing standardized measuring cups and spoons to American kitchens.
Nonetheless, there is more to Fannie Farmer than the soulless home economist with a scientific approach to cooking.
"I have trouble believing she was devoid of passion," said Japser White, the Boston-based chef, who owns eight editions of Fannie Farmer cookbooks and was instrumental in organizing tonight's din'er at An American Place. "She placed real focus on seasonality and taste." For the centennial, a new facsimile edition of the cookbook that was a bible for generations of Americans, and that was revised over time, has been published by Hugh Lauter Levin Associates.
She certainly insisted on fresh, local ingredients. "Summer vegetables should be cooked as soon after gathering as possible," she wrote. Unfortunately, she was largely ignored when she suggepted cooking lamb chops rare.
As for Miss Farmer's precursor, Amelia Simmons, it is possible to go back another 100 years and still find advice that resonates.
She recommended sending roast lamb to the table with "a nice salad, green beans, fresh peas or a cauliflower or asparagus." She wrote about blackfish, a type of fish caught in the Atlantic Ocean off New York and New England, which is becoming popular again.
She also had the luxury of seven kinds of fresh peas and five of cabbage, more than are in American markets today. She was notable, too, as the first to publish recipes for some thoroughly American specialties like cole slaw, pumpkin pie and soft gingerbread, and to include recipes like Johnnycakes thap call for corn meal or "Indian meal," as it was known.
Barbara Shinn, the co-owner of Home restaurant in Greenwich Village, said Miss Simmons validated native American ingredients for her contemporaries. David Page, Ms. Shinn's partner and the chef, is interpreting Miss Simmons's recipes for dishes like shad roe, potted duck, stuffed veal leg and Indian pudding in their restaurant and at the James Beard Foundation.
Tonight's Fannie Farmer dinner will closely follow her recipes, Mr. White said, including oysters on the half-shell with Boston brown bread, oxtail consomme, puff-pastry turnovers filled with veal and cepes, halibut "sandwiches" with a stuffing of minced halibut, roast venison loin, a "cutlet" of lobster and chanterelles, a vegetable course, quail with salad, ginger sherbet, passion fruit and pineapple jelly, chocolate charlotte, cheese and nuts.
"The menu was designed to show the depth of what Fannie Farmer offered," Mr. White said. For Larry Forgione, the chef at An American Place, the best part of getting the dinner ready has been discovering how up-to-date many of Miss Farmer's recipes were. The lobster cutlet, for example, is not unlike a dish that David Burke concocted for Park Avenue Cafe.
At Monday's dinner at Le Bernardin, the mood was congratulatory and festive. But the focus was on the food, beginning with Mr. Le Coze's now-famous slivers of raw black bass with basil and coriander leaves.
This dish was followed by slices of rare tuna crusted with pepper, oysters anointed with truffled cream, poached lobster in a spicy bouillon, buttery baked sea urchins and Mr. Ripert's sublime sea scallops and foie gras wrapped in cabbage. Then came another Le Coze specialty, which was probably the star of the show, halibut simply poached and bathed in a warm, herb-flecked vinaigrette. Crispy red snapper with cepes in a rich port sauce followed. Like the main courses, the desserts, a plate of caramel variations and a delicate chocolate napoleon, were served in modest portions.
The 86 guests cleaned their plates. It was a deliciously defining moment for the restaurant that changed the American attitude toward fish.
 
Where to Eat a History of Dinner
At Le Bernardin, 155 West 51st Street, the 10-course anniversary dinner is a menu option through the month of February for $100, not including wine.
Reservations: (212) 489-1515.
A six-course version of the Fannie Farmer dinner can be ordered tomorrow and Friday at An American Place, the restaurant at 2 Park Avenue (at 32d Street), for $65, without wine, $85 with wine by the glass. The prices include a copy of the book.
Reservations: (212) 684-2122.
Three dishes based on recipes from Amelia Simmons will be served all this month at Home restaurant, 20 Cornelia Street (near Bleecker Street).
Reservations: (212) 243-9579.
On Feb. 23, the dinner based on the Simmons book will be served at the James Beard Foundation, 167 West 12th Street. The price will be $45 for members, $65 for nonmembers.
Reservations: (212) 675-4984.

HEADLINE: Borden Putnam, 73, Commissioner of Commerce

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Borden R. Putnam, New Jersey's first Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development and a pivotal figure in the state's economic growth during the 1980's, died on Monday at his home in Franklin Lakes, N.J. He was 73.
The cause of death was complications of Parkinson's disease and recent surgery, according to his son, Borden Putnam 3d of Half Moon Bay, Calif. 
 From 1982 to 1990, in the administration of Gov. Thomas H. Kean, Mr. Putnam played a major role in shifting New Jersey's economic base from manufacturing to services and high technology.
"He presided over the largest growth in the state's history -- three quarters of a million jobs from the time I was sworn in as Governor till the time I left," said Mr. Kean, who is now the president of Drew University in Madison, N.J. "A lot of the corporations who came told me afterward that the kinds of efforts Borden Putnam made were directly responsible for their decision to locate in New Jersey. In other words, there are a number of people who have jobs today in New Jersey who really owe their thanks to Borden Putnam."
Guiding initiatives sponsored by his department, Mr. Putnam was instrumental in forming the New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology. He served as chairman of the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, the Corporation for Business Assistance, the Urban Enterprise Zone Authority, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey Development Advisory Committee and the Governor's Advisory Council on Minority Business Development.
In an interview in 1989, a year before his retirement, Mr. Putnam said he was hard pressed to enumerate the principal accomplishments of his office, but he pointed to three: "The development of our urban centers, our tourism commercials and our efforts in promoting international trade."
He said: "I start with our urban centers, because it is here that we have developed financial programs to help minorities find jobs and enjoy the benefits that go with employment. Remember, it's financial programs that move the world."
He added that the "New Jersey and You, Perfect Together" travel and tourism campaign had brought business into the state. "Although the ads are aimed at promoting tourism, they are seen by business people looking for a place to locate a plant or an office who start to think New Jersey might be a good place to make a capital investment," Mr. Putnam said.
With regard to international trade, he pointed out that New Jersey was 10th in the nation in gross dollars earned in international trade and seventh in the foreign investment it was attracting. He noted that the state had opened an office in Tokyo and was considering opening others. New Jersey now has offices in London and Israel.
Mr. Putnam came to state administration from two of New Jersey's major industries, chemicals and pharmaceuticals. A chemical engineer by education, he worked for the American Cyanamid Company of Wayne, N.J., for 35 years and was a senior vice president and member of the board when he retired in 1982 to join the Kean administration.
Mr. Putnam began his career with Cyanamid in 1947 as a chemical engineer, and served in various managerial posts with Cyanamid until 1965, when he was appointed assistant general manager of its Lederle Laboratories Division. He became general manager in 1968 and a vice president in 1971.
After his retirement from state administration, Mr. Putnam served on the boards of Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J., Montclair State College, the Silicon Technology Corporation of Oakland, N.J., and the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark.
Mr. Putnam, who was born in Washington, grew up in the Jackson Heights section of Queens and graduated in 1943 from Princeton, where he received a bachelor of science degree and a master's degree in chemical engineering.
During World War II, he was a Navy lieutenant (junior grade) in the Pacific.
Mr. Putnam's wife of 43 years, the former Jean Mason Woodside, died on Jan. 23. Besides his son, Mr. Putnam is survived by two daughters, Ashley Putnam of Piedmont, Calif., and Andrea Orchard of Middletown, N.J.; a sister, Mary Follette of Metuchen, N.J., his stepmother, Frances Wisenant Putnam of Plymouth, N.H., and seven grandchildren.
