HEADLINE: Eating Well;
A New Goal Beyond Organic: 'Clean Food'

BYLINE: By Marian Burros 

 BODY:
A GROWING number of Americans are taking their health and well-being into their own hands, in part because they have lost faith in the institutions that are supposed to improve their lives.
Upper-middle-class and middle-class baby boomers who are facing their mortality, along with younger people who have grown up with a concern for the environment, are turning to food, dietary supplements and alternative medical treatments to enhance the quality and length of their lives. One of the most obvious manifestations of the movement is what Gerald Celente has christ'ned the "clean-food diet." 
 In the winter issue of The Trends Journal, Mr. Celente, the director of the Trends Research Institute in Rhinebeck, N.Y., describes the clean-food diet as something beyond organic -- "a new standard for health and reliability." The keys are "foods free of artificial preservatives, coloring, irradiation, synthetic pesticides, fungicides, ripening agents, fumigants, drug residues and growth hormones" and those that are "processed, packaged, transported and stored to retain maximum nutritional value."
Other trend watchers agree. Peter Stisser, a vice president of Roper Starch Worldwide, a marketing research company in Manhattan, says that one of the growing fears that may be driving the clean-food movement is biotechnology. "There is a backlash against technology, against bioengineering, a fear that technology will worsen people's lives," he said.
Although there is evidence that many people still view food as an indulgence, there is also ample data to support the contention that the clean-food movement is growing:
* Sales of organic produce nearly doubled in five years, from $3.9 billion in 1989 to $7.6 billion in 1994.
* Sales of bottled water have nearly tripled since 1984, from 933 million gallons that year to a preliminary figure of 2.87 billion last year.
* Sales of milk from organically fed cows are rising. For example, Horizon Organic Dairy, based in Boulder, Colo., opened in 1992, selling milk from about 300 such cows. Today, the company sells milk from 10,000 cows, and its sales reached $7 million last year, compared with $1 million in 1993.
* In 1991, there were 195 health-food supermarkets across the country, defined as containing more than 5,000 square feet; by the end of 1994, there were 650. Five years ago, there was not a single health-food supermarket in the Washington, D.C., area; today there are nine.
* Last year, a third of Americans made use of alternative medical treatments, spending $14 billion of their own money to do so.
* Sales of dietary supplements in grocery stores, drug stores and mass marketers like Wal-Mart rose 11 percent in each of the last two years.
Clean food is also becoming the new standard for quality. Although there is no nationwide definition for organic, the term generally refers to vegetables, grains and fruit that are free of chemical pesticides, herbicides, fungicides and fertilizers and to meat and products from animals that are raised without hormones or antibiotics.
Organic, once symbolized by a shriveled-up piece of fruit in a funky health-food store where customers bagged their own groceries, now stands for the highest-quality, freshest and best-tasting food. But clean food goes beyond organic, to include food and drink that is as pure as possible: water without harmful bacteria, chickens that are raised without antibiotics and that range freely on the farm, and fruits and vegetables not only grown without insecticides and pesticides but also picked and eaten at the peak of freshness and flavor when the nutrients are at their best.
Linda Walrafen, 57, of Washington, prefers the new health-food supermarkets like Fresh Fields to conventional supermarkets. "It's the quality I'm looking for," she said. "I like nice things, and it makes my cooking taste better."
For Clark Wolf, a food consultant in Manhattan, clean food means quality, in part because those who sell clean food have become more sophisticated marketers.
"Five years ago, health food came to the Fancy Food Show looking like hospital supplies and cleaning fluid and failed miserably," Mr. Wolf said. "Now, it has come back packaged as specialty food. It is pure and delicious food, not health food."
Distrust in the Government's ability to keep the food supply safe, the water pure and the air clean is growing. Despite Congressional efforts to weaken environmental laws, Mr. Celente said, "there's no mandate to reduce environmental regulations." Polls consistently show that most Americans support environmental laws. In a nationwide telephone poll of 1,000 adults conducted by the Wirthlin Group last summer, 72 percent of the respondents said the environment should be protected regardless of cost.
Increasingly, people are assuming more responsibility for protecting themselves from hazards. "The 80's were about control; the 90's are about self-reliance," said Mr. Stisser, the Roper research executive. "There is a growing number of people who see food not just as an indulgence, but as a way to protect against the future."
Today, perhaps 3 percent of the population is engaged in this effort, Mr. Celente said. In the next 20 years, he predicts, the figure will be about 30 percent.
Clean food is what some of the leading chefs across the country -- like Alice Waters at Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., and David Bouley of Bouley in Manhattan -- have been talking about for years, though that is not what they called it.
"Part of it has to do with health," said Ms. Waters, the first American chef to stress the importance of locally grown, organic food for its taste and its environmental soundness. "It's also a connection with the kind of food that is alive, fresh, seasonal and a connection with the people who are growing it. A deep and lasting sensual connection is made, and once you eat food like that, you can't turn back. Just the growth of farmers' markets is an indication of what is happening. There must be 50 or 60 in the Bay area."
This search for quality and health is generally a function of affluence. There are enough middle-class people, as well upper-middle-class people, to sustain and broaden it, says John Naisbitt, the author of "Megatrends 2000" (William Morrow & Company, 1990) and "Megatrends Asia," published last month by Simon & Schuster. A similar phenomenon, he said, is occurring in Asia.
Even though organic food costs less than it did a few years ago, it is still sometimes more expensive than conventional food. More people will buy organic food, Mr. Stisser said, when it is price-competitive. An increasing number of people are already willing to pay the difference.
Lynn Perlik, 40, a massage-therapy student from suburban Maryland who was recently shopping at the Fresh Fields in Washington, said she supported organically grown food because it was better for the environment. But she added: "I wish it could be within everyone's reach. The prices are kind of high and limit how much I can buy."
Jane Wiznia, 37, a clinical social worker who lives in Bedford, N.Y., said she was willing to pay a premium for more healthful, safer food. "More and more research points to the fact that nutrition and the environment play a role in disease and health," she added. She and her husband, Andrew, a pediatric immunologist, have a 14-month-old daughter and are "concerned about the environment and what we are going to leave for our kids," she said, adding: "I don't want irradiated strawberries, bioengineered food, milk with bovine growth hormones. Thank God I have the option."
Ms. Wiznia is among the 3 percent of the population that does 90 percent of its shopping in health-food stores, said Chris Hitt, the president of the natural-food supermarket chain Bread and Circus, a subsidiary of Whole Foods Market Inc. Another 10 percent buys a quarter to half of its food in these stores.
Whole Foods Market, based in Austin, Tex., is the largest health-food supermarket chain in the country, with 44 stores. "Our niche is growing 10 percent a year," Mr. Hitt said.
Six weeks ago, Lifethyme, a natural-foods supermarket, opened in Greenwich Village, at 408-410 Sixth Avenue, near Eighth Street, in a seemingly unlikely spot -- near Balducci's and Jefferson Market, two of Manhattan's best markets. But Paul Kralyevich, the owner of the new store, says business is better than expected.
"Balducci's does Italian very well," he said. "We do natural and organic very well. The products we sell they don't. People are scared of what's in their food, especially if they have kids." The store also sells household products that are supposed to be better for the environment, like recycled paper towels.
Natural-food supermarkets have been a long time in coming to New York because of high rents here. But smaller stores are opening. Fresh Fields, which has two stores nearby in New Jersey and one in Greenwich, Conn., is looking for locations in Manhattan, as is Bread and Circus.
Traditional supermarkets have heard the message. Karen Brown, the senior vice president of communications for the Food Marketing Institute in Washington, says the landscape is very different today than it was just a few years ago. 'Before, traditional supermarkets didn't feel they had to stock organic foods or make them visible, but new competition has shown it's needed," she said.
Barry Sher, the vice president of public affairs at Giant Food, a 165-store supermarket chain in the Baltimore-Washington area, said the chain tried organics six years ago but "they flopped miserably, in part because the price differential was so great." Today, the increasing affordability of organic food, and the concern for health, have had a big effect on what the company sells. A hundred Giant Food stores carry a line of organically prepared foods, and 12 of them also carry organic produce. "People write to us all the time saying they want healthier food and pesticide-free food," Mr. Sher said.
Mr. Celente said the people who are driving the clean-food movement would "perceive a genuine interconnectivity between land, water, air and life" in the next century. And, he added, they will "conclude they are not simply on the earth, but of the earth" -- a coming of age for the 1960's hippies.
Not everyone is joining in.
Other trends also point to more people who see food only as an indulgence. Steakhouses, with 24-ounce porterhouses, are also on the rise.

HEADLINE: THE NEEDEST CASES;
Donors Taking Up Government's Slack

BYLINE: By SARAH JAY 

 BODY:
Some people have had to reduce their annual gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund this year, but others have gone in the opposite direction, intent on being more generous as the government becomes less so.
Berenice K. Cohen of Mount Vernon, N.Y., wrote, "As our Mayor and Governor try to cut all programs for the needy, I, as a middle-class benefactor of their programs, feel it is necessary to double our usual contribution to the fund this year as a way of compensating for the unfair budgets proposed for next year." 
 Mrs. Cohen, a retired New York City social studies teacher, gave $400 this year, money she earned by selling some of the pottery she makes. Along with her husband, Robert, who taught shop in New York City schools, Mrs. Cohen has been a regular contributor for several years.
"We feel fairly lucky and financially comfortable," she said in a telephone interview. "We have decent pension arrangements. The younger generation hasn't been as lucky."
Mrs. Cohen, who volunteers to help the homeless, said she is troubled greatly by the way the poor seem to be targeted by the politicians and by the way the middle class has been affected by the sluggish economy.
"So many of them are hurting," she said.
For the same reason, Helene Schoenfeld of Manhattan doubled her donation to $50 this year, as did Elizabeth Tom, also of Manhattan.
"I see a lot of poverty and people in need around me," Ms. Tom wrote in a note accompanying her $100 gift. "I feel there is a great need to help those who are down on their luck and lack the resources to help themselves," she said.
Since 1912, The Neediest Cases Fund has not only provided the poor with the basics, like food, clothing and medicine, but has also assisted middle-class families who may need one-time help with a utility check. The annual campaign to raise money for the fund ends on Feb. 29. Since The Times pays administrative costs, all donations go directly to the seven charities supported by the fund.
Some people, like Nancy P. Nemlich of White Plains, will snatch at any excuse to double their donations. "I am increasing my contribution this year from $50 to $60," she wrote, "and adding another $40, which represents a check from my cleaners for a ruined garment."
Others need no excuse at all.
"Every year I like to try and 'beat' what I gave the previous year," wrote Jody Saunders of Valley Cottage, N.Y. "For 1995, I'm fortunate to be able to do so, and am privileged to help my neighbors in the best city in the world, N.Y.C.!"

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Shows Banks Are Tightening Up on Loans

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Big banks are making it tougher for businesses and consumers to get loans, the Federal Reserve said today, at least partly because they fear a weakening economy will make it less likely that they will be repaid.
The Fed's survey of 59 American banks and 23 branches of foreign-owned banks suggested that lenders were less willing and borrowers less eager for loans than was the case late last year. 
 It fit with other signs of slowing in national economic activity as 1995 closed that has made consumers less willing to spend and more concerned about job security.
The bleaker outlook may be giving bankers the jitters about the creditworthiness of their customers.
"The survey results are consistent with a slight firming of credit standards over the past three months," said the periodic report from senior lending officers. The last report was issued on Nov. 21.
Bankers said lending standards for commercial and industrial companies of all sizes had been made more strict in the last three months, as have standards for real estate loans.
"This is the first survey to report a net tightening of standards on business loans in the past three years," the bankers said.
Though there was no reported change in standards for making home mortgage loans, about one-third of the bankers said there has been a slowdown recently in the growth of real estate loans on banks' books.
That was because bankers were packaging more loans into marketable securities as more people switched to fixed-rate mortgages and there were fewer new loans in many regions where the housing market was weakening.
Demand for loans was mixed.
The survey found little change from November in the numbers of large and midsized companies seeking to borrow, but small-business loan demand was up.
"Demand for consumer installment loans weakened, however," the bankers said in the survey. About one-quarter of banks raised their standards to qualify for new credit card accounts or to get a loan to buy a new car.
Banks attributed the tightening to "increased delinquency rates, increased household debt burdens, an increased willingness of households to declare bankruptcy and a less favorable economic outlook," the survey said.
The survey of senior lending officers was closely watched during the 1990-91 recession and in the period just after it ended because of concern that lack of credit was hampering the ability of business to borrow and expand.
In the latest survey, the bankers noted that notwithstanding an overall firming of standards for business loans, at least some lenders were making it easier for corporations to qualify.
But they added, "The shares that reported having eased terms were the smallest in several years."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Is Lower Again on Signs High Price Is Curbing Demand

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Gold prices fell yesterday for a second consecutive session on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange on signs that six-year-high prices had begun to curb demand from retail buyers and jewelers.
"With gold inching toward $420 an ounce, we see people hesitating," said Murray Kirsch, a vice president of Ross Refiner Inc. in New York, which sells gold to jewelers and other retailers. "Consumers are comfortable with gold in the $390-to-$410-an-ounce range." 
 On other commodity markets, crude oil and wheat prices rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities gained 0.77 point, to 246.61.
Gold for April delivery fell $1.30, to $414.60 an ounce in New York. Gold prices reached $420.20 an ounce on Friday, their highest since August 1990. Other precious metals also fell. The March silver contract fell 3.8 cents, to $5.777 an ounce, while April platinum dropped $2, to $431 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Traders expect demand for gold in Asia to slip even faster than demand in the United States. It was the surging demand for gold from India, China and Taiwan that drove gold consumption to a record 3,550 metric tons in 1995, outstripping supply by almost 700 tons.
"The Asian economies react much more quickly to price changes in gold," said Jim Steel, analyst at Refco Inc. in New York. "You can see the ups and downs clearly on a month-to-month basis."
Crude oil prices rose as Iraq and the United Nations began talks on a plan to allow Iraq to sell as much as $2 billion of oil every six months to pay for food and medicine.
Crude oil for March delivery rose 15 cents, to $17.69 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
An Iraqi negotiator said he expected a first round of talks to last up to 10 days, to be followed by another round of meetings.
Most traders said they expected prices to hover between $17 and $18 a barrel while the talks went on.
"The Iraq thing is hanging over us now," said Ed Kevelson, a broker at Paribas Futures Inc. in New York. "The market might sit a bit and wait for some news."
Wheat prices jumped after reports that too little rain and severe cold left the winter wheat crop in poor condition.

HEADLINE: Weekly Earnings Off Slightly in December

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Average weekly earnings of United States workers, after adjusting for inflation and seasonal factors, fell two-tenths of 1 percent in December after declining a revised seven-tenths of a percent in November, the Labor Department said today.
The department previously reported that real average weekly earnings fell four-tenths of 1 percent in November. 
 The December figures stem from a drop of three-tenths of 1 percent in average weekly hours, an increase of three-tenths of a percent in average hourly earnings and an identical increase in the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers.
Real average weekly earnings in December were four-tenths of 1 percent above their level of December 1994, the department said. In constant 1982 dollars, weekly earnings for nonsupervisory private workers outside the farm sector averaged a seasonally adjusted $255.49 in December, compared with $256.01 in November and $256.94 in December 1994.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Rise As Auction Is Success

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday as the Government's quarterly refunding began with a successful auction of Treasury notes.
The 30-year bond rose 13/32, to a price of 110 6/32 to yield 6.12 percent, down from 6.15 percent on Monday. 
 The Government sold $18.5 billion in three-year notes with an average yield of 5.043 percent, but analysts said yesterday's auction was the easy part of the refunding. The remaining $26 billion of securities is expected to be harder to sell, with $14 billion of 10-year notes scheduled today and $12 billion of 30-year bonds set for Thursday.
"The remaining two are usually harder auctions to complete successfully," said Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc. "But we still won't know if this refunding is successful; that will depend on whether the price of these securities at settlement on Feb. 15 will be at or above the average price at auction."
Mr. Guild said investors were worried about the heavy supply. There is a chance, he said, that the yield on today's 10-year note could be below the 25-year low of 5.69 reached in November 1993, and the 30-year bond below the more-than-20-year low of 6.33 percent in August 1993.
"The economic fundamentals, low inflation and the slowdown in economic growth are positives," Mr. Guild said, "while the big negative remains the impasse between Congress and the President on budget and debt ceiling. I personally do not believe the market will do well until the issues are resolved, which may not be until after the election. As a result short rates likely will decline more than long rates."
Traders said investors bid strongly for the three-year notes because they believed that the Federal Reserve would continue to lower interest rates to help the economy. The average yield on the three-year notes was down from 5.549 percent in November and the lowest since 4.83 percent on Feb. 8, 1994.
In when-issued trading, the 10-year notes in today's auction were being offered at a price to yield 5.65 percent, and Thursday's 30-year bond, 6.06 percent.
Last week the Fed lowered short-term rates for the third time in eight months, cutting the Federal funds rate a quarter-point, to 5.25 percent.
David Ader, managing analyst with Technical Data in Boston, termed yesterday an uneventful day, with buying interest at the note auction seen coming from central banks and retail investors. "Although today's auction went off without a hitch, the 10- and 30-year auctions will not be as easy," he said.
"The market is currently trading in the middle of a range," Mr. Ader added, "and players don't know if they want to buy or sell. I expect, though, that the market is setting itself up for a buy."
The economic reports issued yesterday were the Mitsubishi Bank/ Schroder Wertheim report on retail sales, which showed salesdown three-tenths of a percent for the week ended Saturday, and the Johnson Redbook report, which put retail sales for the first week in February up seven-tenths of a percent.
Elsewhere in the fixed-income market, Argentina plans to sell $1 billion in five-year bonds within the next several weeks, said an official at Merrill Lynch & Company, which will co-manage the sale with CS First Boston.
Argentina had planned to sell $750 million worth of bonds in January, with those bonds expected to be priced to yield about 425 basis points more than comparable United States Treasury securities. According to traders, Argentine bonds have rallied in recent months as investors bet that the country would emerge from a recession in 1996 and more money would flow into emerging markets.
Bloomberg Business News said the Argentine 8 3/8 percent global bond due in 2003 was trading around 89 1/2, up from 72 on Nov. 15, dropping the yield to 10.35 percent, 485 basis points more than comparable United States Treasury securities.
Slim pickings in higher corporate-grade issues brought investors out for yesterday's junk-bond sale by the El Paso Electric Company, which is emerging from bankruptcy.
Underwriters led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette priced six maturities running from 3 to 15 years, with the longest maturity priced to yield 8.9 percent.

HEADLINE: Priorities at the Port Authority

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has declared war against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for shortchanging New York City and favoring the interests of New Jersey. The Port Authority is a great regional resource, but unfortunately many of the Mayor's complaints make sense.
Mr. Giuliani's list of examples of the Authority's alleged favoritism to New Jersey is impressively long. Newark International Airport, for example, has a nifty new arrivals building while Kennedy Airport is still saddled with old, depressing and inadequate facilities that make visitors from abroad feel they are arriving steerage class. 
 Thanks to Port Authority subsidies, mass-transit systems that serve New Jersey commuters, from the PATH service to the Port Authority Bus Terminal, cost less than similar services in the rest of the region. In the same vein, the George Washington Bridge toll is $4 for a two-way ride, compared with $6 for the Triborough Bridge on the other side of Manhattan. Mr. Giuliani complains bitterly about shrinking payments from the city's airport leases, which dropped from $84 million to $3 million over a four-year period.
Mr. Giuliani contends that the Authority has cheated New York City out of $400 million in revenue from leases on the city's airports. He complains about "Hollywood accounting" and the fact that the Authority does not give the city a share of the $3-per-passenger facilities tax. The city is suing to get the money back. The issue will ultimately be decided in the courts or by arbitration.
Whatever favoritism may exist, the Port Authority is run by a board of directors equally divided between New York and New Jersey appointees. If the agency has been shortchanging New York City, it has been with both Governors' support. But New York has wasted its influence on trivial or short-sighted purposes. Gov. Mario Cuomo plundered Port Authority resources to balance his last budget, by getting the Authority to "buy" a parking lot at Aqueduct racetrack from the state. Gov. George Pataki insisted on appointing the executive director, and then used that power to make a weak but politically well-connected choice -- George Marlin, a favorite with the New York Conservative Party.
Right now, the Mayor should be pressing the Authority to complete Kennedy Airport's far-from-finished renovations. J.F.K. desperately needs a better international arrivals building, better transportation between terminals and a long-term solution to the problem of getting passengers to the airport. The Port Authority says it is moving on these projects. But it might be moving faster if it were not spending a disproportionate amount of its resources on the $186-million-a-year PATH subsidy.
The PATH train between Manhattan and New Jersey is a critical prop to the regional economy, like the subways and commuter railroads. But there is no reason the Port Authority should use its money to keep New Jersey commuter costs lower than those for city residents or workers from Long Island or Westchester County. If the Port Authority wants to demonstrate its evenhandedness, it can start by raising PATH fares from $1 to $1.50.
Mr. Giuliani can badger the Port Authority further by lobbying for expansion of the bridge capacity between Staten Island and New Jersey, and for serious thinking about rail freight delivery from the airports. He might even remind the Authority that it was formed in the 1920's to build a rail freight tunnel under the Hudson, a job not yet done.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Plan to Put Washington In Maryland

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Frustrated by the District of Columbia's fiscal crisis and the city's lack of representation in Congress, a new citizens group has begun a campaign to give most of Washington back to Maryland.
Under a plan that preserves the Capitol, the Mall and the White House as a Federal enclave, Maryland would get back the 70 square miles it donated for a national capital in 1791. Virginia had provided an additional 40 square miles but reclaimed the land in 1846. 
 "We're not saying it's the only solution," said Lawrence Mirel, a lawyer who was elected last month as president of the Committee for the Capital, a 30-member group promoting retrocession. "But any plan devised for the District must be economically viable and provide full and equal democratic rights. Ours is the only alternative that does."
For now, the idea has no known support beyond a suggestion by Speaker Newt Gingrich last year that District residents be allowed to vote in Maryland, a generous offer given the likelihood that Washington's population of 554,000 would give Maryland one more representative in the House, probably a Democrat. In Washington, the ratio of registered Democrats to Republicans is more than 10 to 1.
"I can't remember even a ripple of interest any time the idea has been raised," said John Allem, a spokesman for Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.
Dianna Rosborough, a spokeswoman for Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland, said Mr. Glendening would not consider retrocession until "a serious discussion of the issues" made clear what it would mean for the state.
District residents who once pined for statehood, now virtually a lost cause with a Republican-controlled Congress, view retrocession as "ultimate defeatism," as Mark Plotkin, a local political commentator and statehood supporter put it. "Sure, these are rough times," Mr. Plotkin said, "but this is a throw-in-the-towel group."
Still, something has to change, Mr. Mirel insisted, pointing to a local economic tailspin that has led to a decline in services, a shrinking tax base, a steady exodus of middle-class residents to the suburbs, hundreds of millions of dollars in overspending by the city government and, finally, a financial control board, which Congress created last year to restore order.
Progress has been slow. With Congress unwilling to increase the annual Federal payment the District receives in lieu of taxes, Mr. Barry and the control board remain uneasy partners in efforts to cut spending and the size of government. And while they now haggle over $150 million in spending cuts for the 1996 fiscal year, which began last October, streets in full view of the White House remain covered with snow more than three days after the last storm.
In recent years, a variety of solutions have been proposed to lift Washington out of its economic doldrums, but none has generated much support. They have included granting statehood, which Congress opposes; returning the city government to Congressional control, which local elected leaders oppose, and taxing commuters, which members of the Maryland and Virginia Congressional delegations say they will not allow.
But Mr. Mirel said none of those initiatives would solve the city's two most pressing needs -- lifting the local economy and giving local residents voting representation in Congress. Currently, the District has one nonvoting member of the House.
Mr. Mirel said that for Maryland, the economic benefits of retrocession would be enormous, raising the state's population to 5.5 million, or to 15th place from 19th, according to 1992 Census data, and creating a strong Baltimore-Washington market that could compete more effectively with Pennsylvania for new businesses.
The political advantage for District residents would be full representation in Congress, where Maryland has eight representatives.
Mr. Mirel, a 35-year resident of the city, acknowledged that gathering support for retrocession will be difficult. But he predicted that within a year or so, more people will view it as the logical way to proceed.
"Eleanor Holmes Norton told me I'm dreaming," Mr. Mirel said of the District's delegate in Congress. "And none of the elected leaders in Maryland have endorsed or embraced the idea. But fairly soon, I think, people will begin to realize this is it. This is the only answer."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Tagliabue Summons No Support for Antitrust Exemption

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Twice, Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, has testified before a United States Senate committee to the need for legal protection to keep teams from hopscotching the country. Twice, he got a favorable reception.
But yesterday, in testimony before the House Judiciary Committee, Tagliabue met resistance to his pleading that only an exemption from Federal antitrust laws would provide the league the power to block franchise movement. 
 The hearings were originally called in the aftermath of the Browns' planned move from Cleveland to Baltimore. But since then, the Houston Oilers said they would move to Nashville, and last week, the Seattle Seahawks said they want to start football life anew in Southern California.
With legislation providing an antitrust exemption, Tagliabue believes the N.F.L.'s house would be back in order and owners would not be preparing to vote on the Browns' move Friday.
"I am not certain that legislation is necessary or justified in this case," said Rep. Henry Hyde, Republican of Illinois and chairman of the committee. "What is the compelling public interest here?"
Said Rep. George Gekas, Republican of Pennsylvania, who objects to Government interference, "I come to this hearing with a closed mind."
Even Rep. Martin Hoke, an Ohio Republican who is sponsoring pro-exemption legislation that would let sports leagues enforce their franchise relocation bylaws, parried with the commissioner, saying at one point that Tagliabue had "colossal power" but was unsatisfied without "omnipotence."
Hoke said that the exemption is not enough. "It is not that leagues can't restrict team movement -- it is that they refuse to -- and they refuse to because it is clearly against the owners' economic self-interest to do so," he said.
He accused the league of accruing economic power that has been used in the franchise relocation crisis "as a bludgeon to beat even more money and greater benefits from cities, taxpayers and fans."
Tagliabue said the league stands to suffer great financial loss without Congressional protection and has "become powerless because of exposure to treble damage litigation," that is, the tripling of financial damages in the event of a verdict against the N.F.L. Tagliabue added that an exemption "would allow a sports league to exercise its reasonable business judgment."
Arguing for the exemption was Gary Locke, the King County (Wash.) Executive, who said, "If we let this team leave Seattle with 10 years left on a valid lease, what is to stop any other owner from betraying any other community?"
In an emotional moment, John (Big Dawg) Thompson, a Browns fan clad in a brown team jersey, orange shoes, white pants with a brown and orange stripe and a "dawg collar," choked up as he described his devotion.
"I'm just one fan," he said. "There are hundreds of thousands of N.F.L. fans across the country that have the same investments that I do and also the same feelings."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Asian Markets Start the Year With a Bang

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Asia's stock markets, those darlings of 1993 and the dogs of 1994 and 1995, have come roaring back to life.
Since Jan. 1, stock markets in Southeast Asia are up, up, up. Hong Kong -- which is considered a level above an emerging stock market -- rose 13.7 percent in January. Among the emerging markets, Indonesia climbed 13.1 percent and Thailand 11.6 percent. 
 Is it just the new year's money from fund managers in the United States and Europe, betting that their rallies at home won't last? Or is it something more fundamental? Probably a bit of both.
The immediate cause, fund managers and analysts say, is an influx of cash from overseas. Portfolio-wielding investors sated with their gluttonous gains in the United States over the last year started looking outside the United States and trained their sights intensely on market laggards, namely ones in Southeast Asia.
Although no one tracks international cash flows accurately, some telltale signs point to the proclivities of calendar-conscious fund managers.
"It happened on Dec. 31, and was concentrated on big, liquid, blue-chip stocks," said Richard A. Schmidt, a director at Jardine Fleming Investment Management in Hong Kong. "But is it all U.S.? Maybe not. Is some from Japan? Probably. Is it locals getting in on it? It's that, too. It's a little bit of everything."
The money, sloshing in, tagged almost every Asian market with increased liquidity and daily trading volume. In Hong Kong, for example, daily turnover on that maturing market leaped in January to $794 million worth of stock, up from the 1995's daily trading average of $432 million.
"Prices were not cheap, not expensive," said Elizabeth Tran, chief investment director of IDS Fund Management in Hong Kong. "But the 'little tigers' are supposed to be outperforming everywhere else. And even Hong Kong, the region's best performer last year, didn't do as well as Wall Street."
In Hong Kong, where the Hang Seng index is heavily weighted by property companies, the stock market is extra-sensitive to interest rate changes and their long-term effects on mortgage rates. Recent indications that American interest rates will continue to fall are being interpreted as a thumbs-up.
"When the property companies do well, that knocks right on to the banks," said Roland Bruce, associate director of research at Standard Chartered Securities in Hong Kong. "More managers are starting to reallocate their funds."
The positive effects of lower interest rates, Mr. Schmidt said, will not be limited to Hong Kong, and may actually offer a more fundamental reason for the surge in Southeast Asian stock markets.
Countries throughout Asia are affected by interest rates in the United states, especially in places where the local currencies follow, in varying degrees of closeness, the value of the dollar.
"And guess what? There is, almost in exact order, a correlation between the top-performing markets and how closely their currency is pegged to the dollar," Mr. Schmidt said.
The stock market in Hong Kong, where the currency rises and falls with the dollar, has performed best this year. Indonesia, next closest in dollar linkage, is a close second, followed by the Philippines, Thailand and Singapore.
Even China, where the stock markets open to foreign investors remain tiny, has bounced up this year. Shanghai's B market index jumped 7.9 percent in January.
And at the low end of the scale, Mr. Schmidt pointed out, the progression is the same: the worst-performing market in Asia, the Bombay Stock Exchange, is the least affected by the dollar. It is down down 5 percent as of Monday. Taiwan's stock market is also down nearly 10 percent, and South Korea's market is flat. All of these calculations are in dollar terms.
Politics played heavily in each of those three markets -- Taiwan's stock market took a dive after reports that China had drawn up fresh plans for a possible invasion -- but the trend that Mr. Schmidt noticed held up.
For a dose of pessimism, Ms. Tran suggested a look at economic fundamentals in the region.
Growth rates in Southeast Asia, which have been high, may be hard to sustain. And inflation may be equally difficult to keep under control because world food prices are rising and, in developing countries, account for a large portion of an overall price index.
And anyway, Ms. Tran added, it may soon be time for the money that has sloshed to Asia to slosh in another direction.
"The consensus expectation, worldwide, is extremely optimistic," Ms. Tran said. "That is always troubling."

HEADLINE: Pretoria to Lose U.S. Aid

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The United States will start phasing out aid to South Africa beginning in fiscal year 1997, J. Brian Atwood, Administrator for the United States Agency for International Development, said today. He said that aid cuts were inevitable once a three-year, $600-million-program expires after fiscal year 1996.
Any additional aid will continue to focus on easing the transition from white minority rule to a multiracial South Africa, Mr. Atwood said. 
 South Africa has the world's largest gold reserves, controls the global diamond market and has the most advanced industrial, transport, and communications sectors on the continent. Yet an estimated 40 percent of the work force is unemployed.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Revolt of the Wannabes

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
As a barometer of global affairs, the annual Davos World Economic Forum is as good an indicator as you can find. The meeting brings together top industrialists and political figures from every corner of the world. Each year, one or two individuals stand out as trend-setters. One year it was Nelson Mandela, then Shimon Peres and Yasir Arafat, then Russian reformers. And that is why this year's Davos Forum was so interesting. Because this year the star -- the man everyone wanted to interview -- was a Communist: Gennadi Zyuganov, head of Russia's resurgent Communist Party.
Think about that. The Davos Forum is the ultimate capitalist convention. It is an annual celebration of globalization -- that loose combination of free-trade agreements, the Internet and the integration of financial markets that is erasing borders and uniting the world into a single, lucrative, but brutally competitive, marketplace. And who is the star but this dinosaur from the Jurassic period of the cold war. How come? 
 It is because the business and political leaders here seem to intuitively understand that Mr. Zyuganov is the cutting edge of a new global trend -- the backlash against global integration and free trade arrangements, which have created many winners but also many losers. The losers are now asserting themselves, whether it is labor unions in France, Pat Buchanan supporters in America or pensioners in Russia.
The Economics Minister of a leading developing country confided to me that his Government was desperate to become part of this new global marketplace. He and his colleagues at the top understand that in order to survive economically and attract foreign investment they have to open up their markets and upgrade their telecommunications, airports and commercial laws. But, he added, "Half the time I am dealing with bureaucrats who don't understand this new game, and half the time I am dealing with workers who are not prepared to compete. We will join in, but it is going to be very painful for some of our people. The cost will be a lot more social unrest and fanaticism. We all have our Zyuganovs."
Another sign of the times was the fact that the day the Davos conference opened, The Herald Tribune ran an essay by Klaus Schwab and Claude Smadja, respectively the founder and managing director of the Davos Forum. It was entitled: "Start Taking the Backlash Against Globalization Seriously." Messrs. Schwab and Smadja are two of the most renowned advocates of global trade and integration. Their essay is the equivalent of the presidents of Ford, G.M. and Chrysler writing an article in the 1960's entitled: "Start Taking Ralph Nader Seriously."
Messrs. Schwab and Smadja wrote that: "Economic globalization has entered a critical phase. A mounting backlash against its effects, especially in the industrial democracies, is threatening a very disruptive impact on economic activity and social stability in many countries. The mood in these democracies is one of helplessness and anxiety, which helps explain the rise of a new brand of populist politicians. This can easily turn into revolt."
It is now clear, they added, that global integration and free trade are not necessarily win-win propositions. Technological advances and productivity increases at corporations don't automatically translate into more jobs at higher wages. Unless countries can help their people adjust to this new world, globalization is going to become synonymous with "a brakeless train wreaking havoc."
When I asked him what prompted him to write the essay, Mr. Schwab said: "In the 19th century people thought the machine was going to destroy their life as they knew it, and today many people think that globalization is going to destroy their life as they know it. We have gotten accustomed to the idea that globalization will inevitably succeed. But I am not so sure anymore. Those of us who believe in globalization need to be more pro-active."
He's right. And the successful governments will be those able to design the right formula of worker training programs, tax policies that create jobs and preserve resources, population controls and sustainable social safety nets to deal with globalization. The good news is that many world leaders are beginning to understand this challenge. The bad news is that no one has found the formula yet.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Technology Stocks Lift The Market

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
A recovery in technology stocks accelerated yesterday, lifting the market broadly higher.
Confident that technology companies will buck a sluggish economy, investors drove up shares of I.B.M., Intel and Micron Technology. 
 "There's a lot of hope out there that their profit growth is still strong," said Steven Zenker, money manager at McCabe Capital Managers in King of Prussia, Pa.
The Dow Jones industrial average surged 52.02 points, to a record 5,459.61. It was the ninth record so far this year for the Dow, which has risen 5.2 percent in the last two weeks. The Dow gain was led by I.B.M., which touched a 52-week high of 115 1/8 before retreating.
Technology also drove the Nasdaq composite index, which is rich with technology issues. The index gained 5.74 points, to 1,089.08. Since hitting a low of 988.57 for the year on Jan. 15, the Nasaq has risen 10 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 4.90 points, to a record 646.33.
The records came even as one prominent market strategist advised investors to cut their stock holdings. Charles Clough of Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest securities firm, recommended that clients lower the amount of American stocks in their model portfolio to 45 percent from 50 percent. He warned that the economy "is nearing recession conditions."
I.B.M. closed up 2 1/2, to 114 3/4, bringing its gain for the year to 26 percent. I.B.M. contributed more than 7 points to the Dow's gain. Intel led the Nasdaq advance, rising 1, to 59 1/2.
Among other makers of computer chips, Micron Technology jumped 4 1/4, to 41 7/8. CS First Boston raised its opinion on Micron to "buy" from "hold."
Smith Barney raised its opinion on Texas Instruments, which makes both chips and computers, to "buy" from "neutral." The stock rose 1 1/2, to 54 5/8.
Inso surged 2, to 47, a day after reporting fourth-quarter profit of 34 cents a share, surpassing analysts' estimates by 10 cents. The software company's stock has risen 14 percent in the last two days.
Broderbund Software tumbled 7 1/8, to 46, after the company, which makes entertainment and educational software, said it expected earnings for its second quarter ended Feb. 29 to fall below analysts' estimate of 58 cents.
Airline stocks soared and helped push the Dow Jones transportation average up 36.59 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1991.75. In the last few days, USAir Group; UAL, the parent of United Airlines, and Delta Air Lines increased fares for the second time in two weeks.
Delta shares jumped 1 3/4, to 71 7/8; UAL climbed 1 1/2, to 163 1/4; AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose 2 7/8, to 81, and USAir advanced 1/2, to 15 3/4.
Bank shares were among the best performers, as falling bond yields and the prospect of still-lower interest rates improved the outlook for earnings. When borrowing costs fall for banks, they are able to keep more of the money they take in on personal loans, credit cards and mortgages.
Chase Manhattan climbed 1 1/8, to 68 5/8; Nationsbank jumped 3/8, to 69 1/2, and Banc One rose 7/8, to 37 7/8.
Hershey Foods led the advance in food issues after the company announced that it would buy back as much as $200 million of its common stock in three years. Hershey rose 2 3/8, to 73 5/8; Sara Lee gained 1 1/2, to 34 1/2, and H. J. Heinz climbed 1 3/8, to 35.
American International Group added 3 1/2, to 99 3/8, after Dow Corning said it had reached a tentative settlement with the insurer over reimbursement for claims stemming from silicone breast implant lawsuits.
Knight-Ridder gained 2 3/4, to 68 3/8, after Investor's Business Daily reported that the company's financial unit could be bought by the Thomson Corporation.

HEADLINE: Haitian Taking Office, With Daunting Job Ahead

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The task facing Rene Preval beginning Wednesday is one no Haitian envies. As the successor to President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, he inherits what one diplomat here calls "the hardest job in the Americas": trying to lead a country that historically has been the poorest and most blatantly misruled in the hemisphere.
As if that were not enough, Mr. Preval will be governing in the shadow -- and many believe under the thumb -- of the charismatic, popular and dominant Mr. Aristide. Indeed, there is widespread suspicion that the new President is merely keeping the office warm until Mr. Aristide can return in five years. 
 Add to that Mr. Preval's need to maintain good relations with the United States, which in the past has viewed him as something of a dangerous radical, and with the United Nations-sponsored military force that has been here since September 1994.
He also takes on vital unfinished business, including economic reforms that even Mr. Aristide, with his great popularity and moral authority, was unwilling to carry out.
All of this will temper the joy of the transition, the first peaceful hand-over from one democratically elected President to another since Haiti's independence in 1804.
"The situation is difficult," Mr. Preval, a slight, bearded and reserved figure, conceded in an interview here this week, his first since winning 88 percent of the vote in an election in December that saw more than two-thirds of the electorate stay home. "My mission is to bring everyone together and create confidence so a social partnership can emerge."
Mr. Preval, 53, is to be sworn in Wednesday amid signs the United States and other countries that have supported the restoration of democratic rule here are scaling back their commitment to Haiti. As a result, Mr. Preval, who served as Mr. Aristide's Prime Minister in 1991 but has never before held elective office, will be forced to rely on his own wits and resources to an extent his better-known predecessor has not, even as he struggles to establish an identity independent of Mr. Aristide.
In the interview, the President-elect said that his two top priorities would be protecting the people from political violence and rebuilding the economy. He said he recognized he must make a quick start on both fronts to win popular support.
Unwilling to risk his popular standing by demanding popular sacrifice, Mr. Aristide made little effort to set a direction in either area since Prime Minister Smarck Michel resigned four months ago, and popular nervousness over the shape of the post-Aristide era has been growing.
Mr. Preval said recent outbreaks of violence, including lynchings in the slums of the capital, indicate that the country's new police force still needs help from the United Nations to do its job. He said he welcomed an extension of the United Nations presence here, scheduled to expire at the end of the month, through the summer, but hesitated to ask for a longer commitment.
"Let's go with six months, and afterward we will evaluate the situation," said Mr. Preval, who spoke mostly in French, with an occasional foray into English. "After all, the United Nations also has financial problems."
The Clinton Administration, which sent more than 20,000 soldiers to Haiti in September 1994 to restore Mr. Aristide to power, has decided not to continue as part of that smaller United Nations force. Instead, all American troops are scheduled to be withdrawn by spring, to be replaced largely by Canadians.
Even many of his countrymen have regarded Mr. Preval as a shadowy and secretive figure whose beliefs and policies have largely been unknown. He has worked closely with Mr. Aristide for more than a decade, but until now has always preferred to remain out of the limelight.
Unlike the humbly born Mr. Aristide, who in the past has described their relationship as "so close, people say we are twins," Mr. Preval comes from an urban, middle-class background. His father was a government minister in the 1950's, but the family was forced into exile in 1963 during the dictatorship of Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier and Mr. Preval later studied at a university in Belgium.
As an exile, Mr. Preval also lived for about five years in New York City in the 1970's. "I was working in a French-language book store, in Queens first and then in Manhattan," he recalled. He returned to Haiti in the early 1980's and opened a bakery.
During his brief tenure as Prime Minister, he and Mr. Aristide planned a dramatic social transformation based on redistributing Haiti's scant wealth from the privileged mulatto elite to the impoverished majority. The alarmed rich encouraged the military to overthrow Mr. Aristide, and Mr. Preval accompanied the President to exile in the United States.
He was Mr. Aristide's closest confidant in Washington and after the President was restored to power became the director of his patronage operation, rewarding supporters with development projects and jobs.
Lacking any independent constituency, Mr. Preval has derived all his power from Mr. Aristide. In office, it is generally believed that he will still depend on Mr. Aristide to prod the party faithful and rally the public behind whatever initiatives he undertakes.
Mr. Aristide, who under the Constitution may not succeed himself, has not discouraged speculation that he intends to return to office after Mr. Preval's term expires.
In the past, Mr. Preval has had a somewhat edgy relationship with American officials. But he said he was not offended by the American decision to pull out and does not regard it as a lack of confidence in him, arguing that the make-up of the United Nations force is less important than its resolve.
"I understand that they have some difficulties and that because of those difficulties they will not be able to participate," he said of the Clinton Administration. "But the essential thing is a force with good equipment and training to help our police do this job."
An equally pressing piece of unfinished business is the privatization of state enterprises, which Mr. Aristide proved unwilling to carry out and which led to the disintegration of his first Cabinet. As a result, foreign aid to Haiti has slowed to a trickle and the Government now appears likely to run out of money by the spring if progress cannot be made.
Mr. Preval has had a reputation as a man of the left, deeply suspicious of private enterprise and foreign investment. But in the interview he said he intended to "modernize the state" in order to satisfy international lending agencies, a process he said included "not spending money on public enterprises that lose money" and "making sure the private sector participates in the management" of such companies.
"How do you define man of the left?" he responded when asked about his image as an economic nationalist. "Is it that we have nationalized the resources of the country? I ask them to see the relationship we have with the International Monetary Fund and World Bank during the next six months."
By training, Mr. Preval is an agronomist, and he indicated that he would promote land reform to improve prospects for the 70 percent of the Haitian population that still lives in the countryside.

HEADLINE: No Salvation From the Governors

 BODY:
The nation's governors voted unanimously at their conference yesterday for reforms of welfare and Medicaid that are harsher toward the poor in key respects than anything Congress has passed or that the Republicans privately negotiated with President Clinton in their ill-fated budget talks. This unfortunate outcome is the price for achieving the governors' primary goal of protecting state treasuries. What they did not achieve is a proposal that would guarantee essential security for the impoverished. A civilized, wealthy society should do no less.
On Medicaid, the governors said their plan would split the difference between turning the health insurance program over to the states to run, as the G.O.P. wants, and preserving the existing entitlement that poor families have to medical coverage. But the entitlement has shriveled. The governors' plan would guarantee undefined medical benefits to a diminished group of recipients. 
Under current law, families receiving Federal welfare assistance automatically qualify for Medicaid. But under the governors' plan, states would not have to cover adults or children over age 12, no matter how poor. Worse, the loosely worded requirement would allow states to skimp on hospital and other benefits, making an entitlement of questionable value even for those eligible.
The governors propose giving themselves plenty of room to reduce state Medicaid funds. Gov. George Pataki of New York, for example, would "win" the right to reduce state contributions by 20 percent without sacrificing any Federal money. Nationwide, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities estimates that states could cut their own spending on Medicaid by about $200 billion over seven years under the plan. The governors did improve the Congressional plan in one respect by agreeing to spend more Federal money in states whose Medicaid rolls rise. But whether the formula would truly protect states from soaring Medicaid enrollments is unclear.
The governors' welfare proposal rips away the Federal guarantee of additional money for states experiencing rising welfare rolls, as the President unwisely invited the Republicans to do. It puts a five-year cap on benefits even for adults who can find no job. The proposal would also allow states to make huge cuts -- up to 30 percent -- in the money they spend on welfare. The Federal Government would have little ability to force states to treat their poor residents fairly.
Nor would the plan provide enough money for states to maintain cash and other assistance while also putting recipients to work. The governors would make unacceptable cuts in food stamps and, borrowing the worst planks from the Congressional plan, would allow states to opt out of the Federal food stamp program and cut off childless adults after four months who cannot find work. If that happens, Americans -- who might, under the plan, be losing cash assistance and medical insurance -- would no longer be guaranteed a minimal, federally defined food benefit.
Many Americans held out hope that the bipartisan National Governors' Association would succeed in welfare and Medicaid reforms where Congress and the President miserably failed. But the governors proved parochial. They made sure that Federal law would let them do pretty much as they please when taking care of the poor. That might be a terrific solution for those who believe that states, left alone, would have the will and ability to act generously. But several governors, including Mr. Pataki, are already planning to slice welfare benefits. Over the past two decades, many states have allowed benefits to wither under the force of inflation.
It is not that state legislatures or governors are mean-spirited. States are simply the wrong place to set benefit levels for the poor. They are under tremendous pressure to balance budgets and cannot do so if they take care of the poor in ways that attract more poor families and repel taxpaying families and corporations. The governors say it is unfair to think they would shortchange the poor. The plan they passed overwhelmingly says the opposite.

HEADLINE: Moderating Path, Rowland Aims At Healing of Connecticut Cities

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Riding the Republican wave to scrap the Great Society programs of the 60's, Gov. John G. Rowland last year won bipartisan approval to remove families from welfare after 21 months -- the nation's strictest time limit -- and to cut their checks 7 percent.
Now, with the next session of the Legislature opening on Wednesday, Mr. Rowland has rejected additional cuts in welfare for families and embraced an issue rarely associated with the Republican Party: revitalizing the state's ailing cities. 
 Mr. Rowland's new focus has caught both Republicans and Democrats here off guard, but as Democrats nationally are trying to cast Republicans as too extreme, it is one in a series of moves that Republicans nationwide have taken to soften their conservative images.
To be sure, Mr. Rowland's budget proposal is expected to include cuts in social service programs and other state operations. Yet in touting his concern for cities and vowing to protect programs for the elderly and for children, he has joined a number of Republican governors who have steered a more moderate path, as the conservative agenda in Washington has met with growing opposition.
Last month, Gov. John Engler of Michigan, known for his deep cuts in welfare, has proposed higher spending on child care services and transportation for welfare recipients. Gov. Pete Wilson of California focused his State of the State address last month on teen-age pregnancy, not mentioning the affirmative action and illegal immigration issues that have divided his state. And in New Jersey, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has rejected cuts in welfare benefits, instead emphasizing programs that encourage welfare recipients to take jobs.
"They're not going soft and mushy, but they're trying to cast their policies in such a way that they will be broadly popular, not just popular among the most conservative of their constituents," said Mark Rom, a political science professor at Georgetown University. "That's much different from the Republicans in Congress who are much more hard-edged conservatives."
Many Democrats view Mr. Rowland's urban agenda, focusing on economic development, as a political strategy to broaden his base in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans by a ratio of roughly 3 to 2, and they caution that it may provide cover for further cuts in state government.
Mr. Rowland dismisses such critiques and says he has steered a steady course. He complained that he was wrongly cast as a conservative, and claimed the mantle of a moderate, citing his support for state financing for the arts and culture, among other programs.
"In the Northeast," Mr. Rowland said, "the interesting thing is if you took, for example, Weld, Rowland and Whitman, and throw in Pataki" -- a reference to the Republican Governors William F. Weld of Massachusetts, Mrs. Whitman of New Jersey and George E. Pataki of New York -- "I suspect Pataki would be the most conservative of the four of us."
"Weld might even be tougher than we are on some of the fiscal issues," Mr. Rowland said. "He's really hard-nosed. I would say Christie and I are really close."
Over the last few months, Mr. Rowland surprised Republican state senators by rejecting their plan to cut welfare benefits for families even further. He rescinded cuts in rental subsidies to the elderly and promised not to touch a program that helps them buy prescriptions. He also unveiled legislation to strengthen the Department of Children and Families, which oversees 30,000 children, and promised to hire more employees there. In an interview, he also talked about improving drug prevention and treatment programs.
Mr. Rowland said he never intended his budget cuts to affect the elderly, though last February he proposed phasing out the rental assistance program that serves the elderly and the poor. His welfare program is intended to help people break a cycle of dependency and find work, he said, and the deeper cuts sought by Republican senators were not needed in a program that he described as the "most aggressive in the nation."
Mr. Rowland also said his action on behalf of children transcended any political label, with the state aggressively intervening in a way that officials of all parties once shied away from.
And Mr. Rowland, who comes from the blue-collar city of Waterbury, sees his urban agenda as a continuation of his effort to correct problems caused by the Great Society programs of the 1960's.
"My urban agenda is to tear down the mess that we've made in our cities," he said in a interview on Sunday on a Sharon radio station. "The Federal solution has been let's go to Waterbury, New Haven, Hartford, Bridgeport and we'll build a massive warehouse called public housing, put all the poor people there. The developers get rich, the people in those houses become drug dependent, welfare dependent.
"All the social service problems exist in one community, and unfortunately, we drive out everyone else."
Now what needs to be done, he said, is "to tear down the buildings, to tear away the infrastructure that has maintained welfare dependency," create more opportunities for home ownership and use public-private partnerships to pursue economic development.
The plan to help the cities is, to some extent, a logical follow-up to last year's changes in the state welfare law. If Mr. Rowland's plan is to succeed, he must find work for roughly 50,000 welfare recipients. To do that, jobs must be created in the cities where most of them live.
At the heart of the plan are "neighborhood revitalization zones," a Democratic initiative passed last session, that would waive environmental and zoning regulations to give cities more flexibility to redevelop blighted areas.
But Mr. Rowland may take this idea a step further. In an interview, he said he was interested in creating tax-free zones in certain cities to attract businesses there, an idea that Governor Engler championed in Michigan.
Mr. Rowland's urban proposals are likely to complement the urban agenda that the Speaker of the State House of Representatives, Thomas D. Ritter, a Democrat, released last week, and some Democrats see political motives for the Governor's stand.
"His focus on cities, while it may not turn out to be more than talk, is a way of saying we're not what they're about in Washington," Kevin B. Sullivan, the Democratic minority leader in the State Senate, said. "How far it goes, in terms of actually making a difference, remains to be seen. If nothing else, it shows that the Governor is a gifted politician."
Betty Gallo, a lobbyist in Hartford for welfare advocacy groups, said: "I think what we've seen nationwide is a realization by leaders that the American public thinks they've gone too far, that the cuts have been dangerous, particularly to older people and children. That is what Governor Rowland is responding to."
She warned against seeing the move as evidence of a "kinder and gentler John Rowland," and with the state facing a deficit in next year's budget, Mr. Rowland will present more cuts on Wednesday, including substantial reductions in General Assistance, a welfare program for single adults.
In his own party, Mr. Rowland's urban agenda has the support of legislative leaders but runs the risk of alienating suburban residents who have traditionally been the heart of the state's Republican Party.
"It doesn't turn me on," said Representative Raymond V. Collins, a Republican of West Haven. "There are those of us here who say the suburbs have been hosed for years by Democrats, and now its our turn."
In turn, Mayor John DeStefano of New Haven questioned whether it could have any impact if state spending, which he said was weighted to the suburbs, was not adjusted.
And Mr. DeStefano, a Democrat, said he was surprised by the Governor's sudden focus on the issue. "He didn't talk a lot about it in his campaign, though it's less important to me how he got here than where he'll go," he said.
Still, Mr. Rowland's supporters say that his concern with cities is long held, dating from his first election to the State House of Representatives in 1980, and that he is charting a new course for his party. He recently appointed a state party chairman, State Representative Chris DePino, a New Haven Republican known for breaking with the party line, to add more of an urban slant.
In an interview, Mr. Rowland insisted that helping the cities did not mean taking from the suburbs. The residents of the cities do not want handouts and are sympathetic to the conservative messages that he has made the centerpiece of his administration, he said.
"I won Bridgeport in 1990," he said, referring to his previous, unsuccessful run for office, "and I came within about 900 votes of winning it this time. I didn't win Glastonbury, I didn't win Simsbury," two well-to do suburbs that Mr. Rowland described as havens for "limousine liberals."
"My point is that people don't understand the cities," he continued. "The cities are much more conservative than you think they are. These people want the death penalty. They want welfare reform."
Mr. Rowland said that he had always planned to pursue an urban agenda, but that it did not make sense to do it his first year.
"I had to look at what were the immediate problems, where was the sense of urgency," Mr. Rowland said, "and that answer was the biennial budget, welfare reform, which is the backdrop of urban redevelopment, improving the business climate and certainly the crime issues. You can't help the cities until you've addressed those other problems."

HEADLINE: Apple Computer Talks With Sun

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Despite widespread public speculation that Apple Computer Inc. had broken off merger talks with Sun Microsystems Inc. last week, executives from the two companies met secretly at a Palo Alto, Calif., law firm over the weekend, people familiar with the discussions said today.
It could not be determined whether the meetings indicated that the companies were considering a merger, or other types of strategic alliances. 
 Apple and Sun have been reported to be discussing a merger, and Apple's board has considered several offers from Sun, people familiar with the negotiations said. Last week, however, Apple's board decided to accept the resignation of Michael Spindler, its chief executive, and replace him with Gilbert F. Amelio as chairman and chief executive.
Many industry analysts have said that the move indicated that Apple was going to try to solve its financial crisis independently. However, some people familiar with Apple's financial situation have suggested that it may be more severe than is publicly known.
