HEADLINE: A BILLION AT RISK: A special report.;
Public Money Foots the Bills For 'Privatized' Foreign Aid

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Business does it better. That is the rallying cry on Capitol Hill and in statehouses across the country, where legislators are turning over to private companies traditional government functions ranging from running jails to exploring outer space.
But an experiment in "privatizing" foreign aid has shown that the private sector does not offer a guaranteed cure for problems that critics say have plagued traditional foreign assistance programs: mismanagement, ineffectiveness, political infighting and conflicts of interest. 
 All these have cropped up at the Czech and Slovak American Enterprise Fund, part of a program that now involves more than $1 billion of taxpayers' money and some of Wall Street's biggest names. Similar funds have suffered from some of the same -- though less severe -- problems.
Congress started the enterprise funds in 1989 to foster capitalism in Poland and Hungary, and the program soon spread to other formerly Communist countries. The funds were to invest in Eastern European companies, much as Wall Street's venture-capital funds finance start-up or struggling businesses. There was one big difference: taxpayers, not investors, put up the money.
And it is the taxpayers who face the losses in the Czech and Slovak fund. Government documents obtained by The New York Times under the Freedom of Information Act and from both critics and supporters of the program -- as well as interviews with United States officials, former fund employees and American executives familiar with the program -- draw a picture of failure at the fund:
*Bad investments appear to have eaten up a third to two-thirds of its$26 million investment portfolio.
*The costs of running the fund are surging, to $3 million last year.
*The fund has made few loans to small businesses.
*It has not developed and trained local people.
*It has had little, if any, effect on government policies in either the Czech Republic or Slovakia.
The fund "is failing to achieve either commercial success or developmental impact," according to an independent evaluation done last year by Development Alternatives Inc. of Bethesda, Md., for the United States Agency for International Development, which provides the money for the program. "The investments are suffering major losses, and are generally marginal both in market and in development terms," the evaluation said.
Furthermore, the fund's longtime chairman was ousted from its board in November after a Federal investigation involving procurement problems and accusations of conflicts of interest. The United States Attorney's office in Washington says it is considering whether to bring charges in the matter, at the heart of which is the former chairman's personal relationship with his assistant and payments for computer work that the fund made to a third person who is part of their household.
Also, a key member of the fund's volunteer board, who pushed to remove the chairman and improve the fund's performance, was himself forced out in December by directors loyal to the old chairman -- and a second board member quit in protest. The Clinton Administration is expected to decide in the next few weeks if the fund can be salvaged or should be closed.
The Czech and Slovak fund's experience, critics say, shows that trying to meld business practices and government policies can lead to the worst of both worlds: a program that is vulnerable to political meddling, but lacks the accountability that businesses have to their investors as well as the rules and regulations that government uses to keep its employees in line and programs on track.
The problems at the fund have emerged at a time when the program as a whole is growing rapidly in size and importance, even as traditional foreign assistance falls victim to tight Federal budgets and doubts about its effectiveness. And the program is expanding to some countries that have almost no experience with capitalism.
Today there are 10 funds with total capital of $1.3 billion that can invest in more than a dozen countries, including Albania, Belarus, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Romania, Russia, Ukraine and Uzbekistan. And more are probably on the way: Croatia and Macedonia are lobbying for funds of their own, for example.
Doing business in these countries is clearly difficult, which obviously accounts for some of the funds' troubles. And venture-capital investing always involves a lot of risk.
To be sure, many of the funds are too new to have track records, and at least one, in Poland, is widely regarded as a big success.
But some people who have investigated the funds say that problems stem from the very nature of the program. "I think you can say there is potential for abuse," said Robert R. Chapman, an assistant United States attorney in Washington.
Because the funds would be venturing into terra incognita, the so-called SEED Act of 1989 (SEED stands for Support for Eastern European Democracy) did not specify any targets for them to meet. Instead, it set two broad mandates: to help develop the private sector and to promote policies and practices necessary for capitalism. What would happen if the funds lost all their money -- or even made a profit -- was left unclear.
To insure that they have enough flexibility to do their work, the funds are subject to little control from Washington. Instead, each is run by an unpaid board originally picked by the President. The boards vote to approve new members suggested by the White House, and can vote out current members, making the boards almost completely autonomous.
The boards have included some of the best-known names on Wall Street and in Washington: E. Gerald Corrigan, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York; W. Michael Blumenthal, former Secretary of the Treasury; John C. Whitehead, former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company; John Train, the investment adviser and author, and John P. Birkelund, chairman of Dillon, Read & Company.
But as the number of funds has grown, finding and keeping strong directors has become more difficult. "There are not enough good people," said one longtime Congressional aide who insisted on anonymity.
At the Czech and Slovak fund, two of the most experienced directors -- David O. Maxwell, former president of the mortgage giant known as Fannie Mae, and former Representative Charles A. Vanik, an Ohio Democrat -- resigned in 1994 and 1995, respectively, and were replaced with friends of the chairman.
 
Central Figure
A Banker but Not A Venture Expert
From the fund's inception in 1991, that chairman was John R. Petty, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in the Nixon Administration who retired in 1988 as chairman of the Marine Midland Bank of New York.
Mr. Petty is not a venture capitalist, however, and that may partly account for some of the problems with the fund's investments.
One measure of those problems is the amount of money the fund shows as reserves, basically the amount it expects to lose on its investments. In the year ended September 1995, those reserves more than doubled, to $9.6 million from $4.3 million. The 1995 figure represents 37 percent of its investments.
The two board members who recently left, Joseph S. Fichera and Robert M. Rubin, suggest the level of reserves should be much higher; one investment professional familiar with the portfolio has suggested 65 percent. While the other funds also have reserves, they are far lower; the Polish fund's expected losses amount to about 8 percent, but that is almost matched by projected gains.
Among the troubled investments of the Czech and Slovak fund are bakeries that went broke, a joint venture with an American company that was supposed to produce fertilizer and cattle feed, and companies that make everything from charcoal briquettes to motorcycles.
"It was the blind leading the blind," said Harvey M. Schuster, an American who runs the Corus Funds, a mutual fund company in Prague. "The Czechs didn't know how to manage and the Americans didn't know how to invest."
Mr. Petty was interviewed in November and again last week. In a brief telephone interview Thursday from Hawaii, where he was vacationing, Mr. Petty said that the main issue was risk and that the fund's original board "did not believe Congress created the fund to do transactions that would compete with private funds." He canceled a longer interview scheduled for Friday and could not be reached for further comment but later provided extensive written material.
 
Managing Risk
Hands-On Way To Run a Fund
In the past, Mr. Petty has said that the fund's problems date from its early days, when he said it was under pressure from the State Department and the Agency for International Development to make investments more quickly than he would have liked, according to several people with whom he discussed the matter. Executives of other funds have made similar complaints.
While the fund's investments have performed poorly, the Czech economy has been booming and its entrepreneurs thriving. Indeed, international aid organizations are so confident that the Czech Republic will prosper without further help that they are pulling out of the country.
Not surprisingly, the State Department has suggested that the fund wind down its Czech operations and focus on Slovakia, where the economy is faring poorly.
Despite difficult circumstances, most of the fund's problems "are related to management," according to a report by the Institute for East West Studies, a New York research center that is generally a big fan of the fund program.
At the successful Polish fund, the board sees its job as "finding the right people to run it and supporting them," said the chairman, Mr. Birkelund. "If I tried to run it myself, that would be impossible."
But Mr. Petty, who is 65, took a different approach. Unlike other fund chairmen, he did not have a substantial job in the private sector. Instead, he had his own office at fund headquarters, in Washington, and was involved in daily operations. At times he also served as chief executive, again in an unpaid capacity. Even after he stepped down as chairman last August, he remained a director and chief executive.
In a memo he wrote last October to the new chairman, Lawrence McQuade, Mr. Petty said that in the beginning he served as a hands-on executive to get the fund up and running quickly, as the State Department had requested. He intervened later when various people did not work out, according to the memo. The fund has gone through several chief executives in its brief history and is now searching for a new one.
But former employees, including Stephen L. Wald, who served as the fund president in Prague in 1992, and Karel Kosman, former head of the Prague office, complained that Mr. Petty's involvement amounted to interference. Mr. Petty says he was simply trying to enforce accountability. Both men resigned under pressure from Mr. Petty within a year.
 
Questions Arise
Mixing Business And the Personal
Mr. Petty probably could have continued as chairman and chief executive except for two developments. One was the arrival on the board of two Wall Street executives unconnected to him: Mr. Fichera, a former investment banker at Bear, Stearns who is now a fellow at the Woodrow Wilson School of International Studies at Princeton, and Mr. Rubin, executive vice president of the AIG Trading Group, which trades commodities and currencies.
The other development was complaints made in December 1994 by some fund employees in Prague that led to an investigation by the inspector general of the Agency for International Development.
According to a report of the investigation obtained through the Freedom of Information Act, in 1991 Mr. Petty put his longtime assistant on the fund's payroll, and soon got her a raise of more than 50 percent, to $85,000. They became romantically involved and in October 1992 he moved in with her but did not formally inform the board of this until last March.
The assistant, Alexandra Ossipoff, resigned last July after admitting that in 1991 she had fabricated documents in an effort to get the fund and its sister Hungarian American Enterprise Fund, with which it shared an office, to pay $1,500 for computer consulting work, according to the inspector general's report. The work was done by another member of her household in McLean, Va., named Judy Shaw.
Mr. Petty, the report said, ordered the chief financial officer of the two funds to pay the $1,500 in a memo that included the fabricated documents, which were supposed to make it look as if the funds had obtained competitive bids on the computer work. The inspector general's report says that Mr. Petty approved other bills and signed checks to the consultant even after they were living in the same house.
Over all, Ms. Shaw received about $100,000 from the two funds while living with Ms. Ossipoff, according to several people familiar with the transactions. In an interview earlier this week, Ms. Shaw said that while she could not confirm the exact figure, $100,000 was "in the ball park"; she said that it included not just several years' worth of consulting services, but also hardware she purchased for the funds.
Describing herself as an expert in Eastern European telephone systems and noting that the Czech and Slovak fund's staff "felt free to call me 24 hours a day," Ms. Shaw said "they certainly got their money's worth." She also said that no one raised concerns about the fact that she shared a house with Ms. Ossipoff or complained to her about the computer system she installed. (Among the grievances expressed by Mr. Wald and Mr. Kosman, the former fund officials, however, were problems with the computer system, according to the inspector general's report.)
Repeated attempts over the last week to reach Ms. Ossipoff were unsuccessful. There was no response to messages left at her house and with Mr. Petty.
In his memo to Mr. McQuade, Mr. Petty defended Ms. Ossipoff's salary as proper given her experience, responsibilities and hard work, and said that the fund's chief executive at the time was aware of their relationship.
He described Ms. Shaw as "an unusually reliable, experienced, favorably priced, first-rate supplier." He said he did not know at the time that Ms. Ossipoff had fabricated bids, an action he called "stupid and pointless in the extreme," but stressed that the work was performed at a fair price and that taxpayer money was not misused.
 
Road to Resignation
An Official's Visit Brings On an Exit
In various letters and documents, Mr. Petty repeatedly said that the inspector general's report found no evidence of wrongdoing. And he suggested that the Agency for International Development might be looking for problems at the fund to justify the agency's existence at a time when Congress is considering cutting its budget.
The inspector general's report said its findings had been discussed with prosecutors, who were described as saying that Federal criminal statutes had not been violated because the fund is not a Government agency. But the United States Attorney's office said recently that it had not reached a conclusion and that the matter remained open.
The development agency did not see the inspector general's report as an exoneration of Mr. Petty, Michael D. Sherwin, the agency's procurement executive, told the fund board's audit committee at a meeting in October. In a memo he prepared for agency files, Mr. Sherwin said that he explained to the directors that the inspector general did not make recommendations in its investigations and that that fact should not be taken to mean it believed there had been no wrongdoing.
"I went on to tell the committee that had these matters involved Federal employees, these employees would indeed be facing criminal indictments and immediate administrative action to remove them from their jobs," wrote Mr. Sherwin, who said he attended the meeting at the request of the White House.
He then told the committee that if it did not do something about Mr. Petty, the Government might close the fund, according to his memo.
Mr. Petty, who has denied all wrongdoing, could not be reached for a specific response to Mr. Sherwin's memo.
In an interview, Mr. Sherwin said that he appeared before the committee, a highly unusual action in the fund program, because of "the nexis of the relationship of the woman doing the phony bids, the woman who got the job and the chairman." While such links might be acceptable on Wall Street, he added, "these were things we could not tolerate."
After Mr. Sherwin left the committee meeting, Mr. Petty agreed to resign, although he did not do so for another month.
 
Change of Command
Longtime Ally Steps Into Post
The board's new chairman, Mr. McQuade, did not press for the resignation. Mr. McQuade, a former Assistant Secretary of State who recently left Prudential Mutual Fund Management, joined the board at Mr. Petty's request. The two have been friends "since we were Young Turks on Wall Street," Mr. McQuade said, adding that he was "much more sympathetic to John than some people are; after all, he gave of his life to build the fund and was not getting paid for it."
Shortly after Mr. Petty left, Mr. Fichera, his chief critic, was voted off the board and Mr. Rubin quit.
Mr. McQuade said that Mr. Fichera's dismissal had nothing to do with Mr. Petty's departure; rather, he said, it was because of a personality conflict. But both Mr. Fichera and Mr. Rubin said the dismissal was an attempt to direct blame for the fund's problems toward the very person who was trying to fix them.
As a result of all this turmoil, the fund's future is unclear, although the Clinton Administration seems likely to recommend changes and may try to merge the fund with a more successful fund or close it down. A lawyer for the fund's audit committee, Robert C. Odle of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, said that the issues raised in the inspector general's report were "examples of the fund's serious corporate-governance problems." He said other funds would be able to avoid such problems by separating the chairman and chief executive functions, as the State Department recently suggested.
Nonetheless, the debacle at the Czech and Slovak fund calls into question the autonomy of the funds as a whole, and the power that is vested in their boards.
"The funds should move more into being government-type things or pure private sector -- to inject some accountability," Mr. Rubin said. As it is, he added, "they are neither fish nor fowl."

HEADLINE: GOVERNORS RAISE HOPES FOR ENDING BUDGET DEADLOCK

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The nation's governors endorsed bipartisan proposals today for overhauling the Federal Medicaid and welfare programs, prompting optimistic talk of breaking the monthslong impasse over balancing the Federal budget. But the proposals also drew questions from the White House and Congress and criticism from advocates for the poor.
President Clinton, Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, and Speaker Newt Gingrich praised the governors' ideas -- adopted unanimously at the winter meeting of the National Governors' Association here -- as steps in the right direction. Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich promised prompt hearings on the proposals, which seek a middle ground between the White House wishes for guaranteed benefits and the Republicans' insistence on more autonomy for the states. 
 But the White House raised several objections to the specifics of the proposals; Congressional Republicans said it was still unclear whether the President was prepared to negotiate in good faith, and advocates for the poor said they would vigorously contest limits on benefits in the welfare proposals that, they said, could hurt the needy. [Article, page 14.]
Moreover, senior White House officials made it clear that they saw no possibility of serious negotiations with Congress until after the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary later this month sorted out the Republican Presidential field, and Mr. Dole's prospects, a bit more.
Still, in a speech to the governors this morning, Mr. Clinton said their idea of preserving a Federal guarantee of medical benefits for needy people, and of broad new flexibility for states to administer such programs, had "contributed immeasurably" to resolving disputes between the White House and Congress. He made similar comments about the governors' proposals for overhauling welfare.
Mr. Dole praised the governors as "honest brokers" and added, "We're prepared to act, and we believe the President will be prepared to act, too." Mr. Gingrich promised prompt hearings on the proposals. His spokesman, Tony Blankley, described the Speaker as "ecstatic" at the governors' efforts.
Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican who heads the governors' association, described the Medicaid proposal as "the break that they're looking for."
Mr. Dole said this afternoon that the Senate would move quickly to consider the governors' recommendations in hearings conducted by the Senate Finance Committee.
"I think they've done an outstanding job," he told reporters. "And we believe it puts a lot of good pressure on Congress and President Clinton to come together on the rest of the balanced-budget package."
Indeed, the governors' recommendations carry some moral and political weight, not only because they come from a diverse group but also because the governors are the public officials most immediately concerned with delivering the health and welfare services at stake.
Their proposals sought to reconcile the tensions between the states' growing insistence that they have more freedom and flexibility to administer such programs and their concern for protecting their residents and their own budgets from fluctuations in the economy.
Broadly put, the Administration and many Congressional Democrats want to maintain Federal guarantees of, and supervision over, assistance to poor people in the Medicaid and welfare programs, while Congressional Republicans want to turn money over to the states in lump sums to distribute as the states see fit.
The governors' proposals, and the carefully supportive but noncommittal reaction to them, showed both the extent and the limits of their effort to reconcile such conflicting demands.
"It's more evidence that there's momentum out there for a deal," said a senior White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity. "But while the candidates are trooping through the frozen snows of Iowa and New Hampshire, the prospects for a deal are frozen, too."
The White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said that among the Administration's concerns about the Medicaid proposal was just what standards would be set for a nationally guaranteed package of medical benefits and how to set eligibility guidelines to preserve benefits for all those currently entitled to them -- the elderly, the disabled, children and pregnant women.
And while the White House praised one major aspect of the governors' proposal on welfare -- the call for more money for child care -- and commended Senator Dole for embracing it, Mr. McCurry raised questions about other aspects of the plan. In particular, he said it called for guaranteeing that states maintain their welfare efforts at only 75 percent of current levels, not the 80 percent that the President has previously suggested was the minimum he would accept.
Mr. Clinton, who once headed the governors' association as Governor of Arkansas, was more effusive than his spokesman, calling the governors' proposal on Medicaid "a very impressive accomplishment." And he singled out Mr. Dole for praise, saying he had shown a "genuine spirit of cooperation."
The Kansas Senator was equally magnanimous, though he could not resist a gentle dig at the President.
"Now the biggest parlor game in Washington, besides trying to figure out who wrote 'Primary Colors,' is trying to decide whether or not President Clinton wants a real balanced-budget agreement," Mr. Dole said, referring to the new, anonymously written novel about the 1992 Clinton campaign.
"I think he does," the Senator continued. "Maybe I'm wrong, but I'm willing to take him at his word. We spent 50 hours together in different meetings -- most time I've ever spent at the White house. I hope to be there longer later."
It has long been clear that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole would be willing to cut a deal, if not for the objections of more conservative House Republicans led by Mr. Gingrich. White House officials said they were surprised and pleased that Mr. Dole, a front-runner in the 1996 Republican Presidential race, had not struck a more partisan note in his speech.
White House aides also said they took it as a given that the Senator's ability to force a compromise with the House side would be enhanced, or diminished, depending on his showing in the Iowa and New Hampshire contests.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Human Resource Subcommittee, said that panel would conduct the House hearings on the governors' recommendations. But in announcing this, he fired off one of the few partisan shots of the day.
"The President has vetoed two welfare bills and we have become frustrated with his inaction on this issue," Mr. Archer said, adding that with the governors' proposal, "welfare reform is back on track in spite of the President's obstinateness."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Truth and Shades of It as Dole and Forbes Fight On

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 6

 BODY:
The Presidential candidates have mostly withdrawn from New Hampshire this week to concentrate on the battle for Iowa. But on television here, the warring commercials of Senator Bob Dole and Steve Forbes are more pervasive than ever.
Late last week, the Dole campaign began broadcasting a commercial in which Gov. Stephen Merrill of New Hampshire, standing outdoors, dressed casually and looking straight at the camera declares: "Steve Forbes's income tax plan increases the deficit and raises our taxes. The typical New Hampshire household will pay $2,000 more in taxes. And we lose our property tax deduction and mortgage interest deduction." 
 The commercial had two main purposes: to call attention to the endorsement of Mr. Dole by the Governor, probably the most popular politician in New Hampshire, and to raise doubts about Mr. Forbes's flat-tax proposal, the issue that has unexpectedly propelled the publishing executive out of the pack and into a close race with Mr. Dole.
Mr. Forbes responded this week with two advertisements in which an off-screen male voice essentially calls Mr. Dole a liar. One begins, "Bob Dole is misleading homeowners about Steve Forbes's flat tax and the mortgage deduction." The other begins, "The Concord Monitor reports Bob Dole is running a negative ad, with Steve Merrill in it, that is not accurate."
The Forbes commercials offer numbers on screen illustrating how the "average" home-owning family would see its Federal income tax cut under Mr. Forbes's plan for a flat tax of 17 percent, no deductions and personal exemptions of $13,000 for adults and $5,000 for children.
Campaigning in Iowa, Mr. Forbes challenged Mr. Dole to a debate on the flat tax. Mr. Dole declined but said Governor Merrill would be happy to debate Mr. Forbes. Mr. Forbes declined.
Then the Dole campaign released a new television spot. It labels as false and misleading a Forbes commercial that accuses the Senator of voting to "tax our Social Security benefits." The Dole commercial then goes on to reproach Mr. Forbes as planning to end Social Security and supporting forced retirement at 65.
The truth, according to Internal Revenue Service figures from tax returns in 1993, is that the Forbes flat-tax plan would probably lower the income taxes of homeowners with modest incomes. Those figures are for the last year for which complete data are available.
A rough calculation shows that a home-owning family of two adults and two children with an income, all in wages, of $45,000 and taking the average deductions such families claimed nationwide in 1993 for mortgage interest, property taxes and charitable contributions (the only deductions that most New Hampshire families that own homes can claim) would owe about $3,900 in income taxes under the existing law and about $1,500 under the Forbes plan.
But Mr. Dole is on solid ground when he maintains that the Forbes plan would increase the Federal budget deficit. The Treasury Department has estimated that a flat tax would result in a loss of revenue that would raise the deficit by $200 billion a year. Private forecasters using conventional computer models of the economy mostly agree with that estimate. Most economists believe that it would take a flat tax of 25 percent to increase the Treasury's revenue. And even at that rate, the four-person family earning $45,000 would owe only $2,250 in income taxes.
The Forbes commercial accusing Mr. Dole of voting to increase taxes on Social Security benefits is only partly true. The Senator did vote for legislation that, among many other provisions, would have raised taxes on Social Security benefits of upper-income retirees.
The Forbes campaign acknowledges that Mr. Forbes settled out of court an age-discrimination suit filed by a former secretary. But it denies that Mr. Forbes wants to end Social Security or favors forced retirement at age 65.

HEADLINE: Governors' Welfare Plan Seeks to Close Gap on Bill

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The welfare legislation endorsed today by the nation's governors would give states vast new power to design their own cash assistance programs and to devise ways of moving poor people from welfare to work.
The governors proposed giving each state a lump sum of Federal money to run its own welfare program. Like Congress and President Clinton, the governors would impose a five-year limit on payment of Federal welfare benefits to any family. 
 But under the governors' proposal, low-income people would still be entitled to food stamps if they met Federal eligibility criteria, and there would be no statutory limit on the cost of the food-stamp program, which is financed entirely by the Federal Government.
The governors supported most of the welfare bill that President Clinton vetoed last month, but they recommended numerous changes in the bill to address his concerns. For example, they suggested adding money for child care, rewarding states that find jobs for welfare recipients and increasing the size of a contingency fund for states with high unemployment.
Nevertheless, the proposals drew criticism from some advocates for the poor. Mr. Clinton thus finds himself once again in a ticklish political position, trying to show voters that he can "end welfare as we know it" without alienating an important bloc of supporters.
At its winter meeting here, the National Governors' Association also formally approved a policy statement on Medicaid that was informally endorsed on Monday. The proposal would give state officials new authority to design and operate health programs for poor people, but the Federal Government would still guarantee coverage for certain groups of people and certain benefits.
In a speech to the governors today, Mr. Clinton said their proposals would help break a deadlock between the Administration and Congress on welfare and Medicaid.
"I believe we're going to pass welfare reform legislation," Mr. Clinton said, telling the governors: "You have contributed immeasurably to helping us to resolve the impasse over Medicaid. You have contributed to the impulse to move to genuine welfare reform."
While he commended the governors for their effort, Mr. Clinton said he had a few reservations about their proposals. Administration officials later amplified those concerns. Democratic advocates for children and the poor were even more negative.
Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, a longtime friend of Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, criticized the governors' welfare proposal on the ground that it would not preserve a Federal guarantee of assistance for needy children. She said it would "leave many children poorer, hungrier, sicker and at greater risk of abuse and neglect."
Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a frequent adviser to Democrats in Congress, expressed alarm.
"The governors are a special-interest group, trying to maximize Federal aid and increase their ability to withdraw state money from welfare and Medicaid," he said. "Their proposal is, in many key areas, harsher than the Senate-passed welfare bill, which would have added more than a million children to the ranks of the poor."
House Republicans, rejecting such criticism, said they were delighted with the proposals and would try to pass legislation doing what the governors want.
"I hope the President won't derail it this time," said Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., a Florida Republican who heads the Ways and Means subcommittee responsible for welfare legislation. Another Republican said the governors' welfare proposal merited a grade of "8 or 9 on a 10-point scale, with 10 being everything the Republicans want."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, said he welcomed the proposals. "I think that the governors have done an excellent job of holding on to the principles that the Democratic Party represents in both welfare and Medicaid reform," Mr. Gephardt said. But he cautioned that "the devil is in the details."
The governors' broad conceptual agreements could come apart as Congress specifies the details needed to write legislation. Members of Congress said they had no idea what the governors' proposals would cost. Governors said the proposals would save money, but the Congressional Budget Office will not be able to estimate the savings until the proposals are reduced to legislation.
Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican who heads the governors' association, said, "This is a very fragile package, very, very fragile."
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader and a Republican candidate for President, said the governors' agreement "puts a lot of pressure on the leadership in Congress and the President of the United States, a good kind of pressure."
In a speech to the governors, Mr. Dole said, "The fact that you've come together ought to be an inspiration to us," and he predicted that it would be "a big, big plus in our efforts to get a bipartisan agreement" in Congress.
The governors said Congress should increase the money available for child care, adding $4 billion to the $18 billion that would be provided under the welfare bill in the next seven years. They would offer bonuses to states that exceed Federal goals for putting welfare recipients to work. The governors took no position on whether Congress should restrict welfare, food stamps and other types of assistance for legal immigrants who have yet to become citizens.
Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, a Democrat, said: "The welfare policy had problems, in my view, but I'm a team player. I was not trying to throw my body in front of it. Government is the art of compromise."
Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, both Republicans, said the policies endorsed by the governors would be immensely helpful to their states.
Medicaid is financed jointly by the Federal Government and the states. One of the changes recommended by the governors would significantly reduce the fiscal burden of Medicaid on states like New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, where per-capita income is relatively high.
Under current law, the Federal Government pays 50 percent of Medicaid costs in these states. Under the governors' proposal, the Federal share would be increased to 60 percent, so the states would be responsible for no more than 40 percent.
In her budget message to the New Jersey Legislature last week, Mrs. Whitman offered numerous proposals to move people from welfare to work. But many are subject to Federal approval. Under the policy recommended by the governors' association, New Jersey could make those changes by itself, without seeking permission from the Government.
Under the governors' proposal, state Medicaid programs would be required to guarantee certain services, like physician and hospital care, laboratory tests and X-rays. But the proposal said states should have "complete flexibility in defining the amount, duration and scope of services." Officials at the Department of Health and Human Services said that as a result, states could restrict benefits so severely that the guarantee of Medicaid coverage would become virtually meaningless.
The governors' proposal would guarantee Medicaid for poor children through the age of 12. Stan Dorn, director of the health division at the Children's Defense Fund, said the governors' proposal would also repeal a 1990 law that eventually guarantees Medicaid coverage for poor children from age 13 through 18. This change, he said, would deny Medicaid to three million children who would otherwise be entitled to Medicaid in 2002.

Thompson of Wisconsin, chairman of the governors' association, shook hands with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, at left. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;
U.N. Chief Urges Reducing U.S. Dues

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said today that he favored reducing the United States contributions to the United Nations budget from 25 percent to 15 or 20 percent.
He said a reduction would lessen the dependence of the United Nations on Washington and "better reflect the fact that this organization is indeed the instrument of all nations." 
 The United States now owes the United Nations at least $1.5 billion, and Washington's failure to pay has contributed significantly to the most serious financial crisis ever faced by the organization.
European nations stepped up their criticism of the United States today. After the Secretary General's speech, Francesco Paolo Fulci, Italy's representative, spoke for the European Union when he said that "the organization should get serious about imposing penalties on members who are consistently late and in major arrears."
American officials do not want the assessment cut below 20 percent because of concerns about a lessening of Washington's influence.

HEADLINE: We Can't Afford Voodoo 2

BYLINE: By Herbert Stein; Herbert Stein, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, was chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers under Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The experienced Republican Presidential candidates are amazed at the surge of Steve Forbes. They shouldn't be. They prepared the way for Steve Forbes. Indeed, they made him inevitable. 
 At least since the time of Andrew Mellon, the idea that taxes are evil has been forefront in the Republican creed. Ronald Reagan refined the creed: Taxes are not only evil; they are also unnecessary. In the post-World War II era, the party's platform has had two main planks -- anti-Communism and anti-taxes. With the collapse of the Soviet Union, the platform is down to one plank.
Of course, responsible Republican officials could not live by their own ideology. Once in Washington, they had to recognize that taxation is a legitimate and necessary function of government. So, President Dwight Eisenhower found himself repeatedly resisting calls for tax reduction. In 1969 President Richard Nixon resisted a drive for a big tax cut led by Senator Albert Gore Sr., a Democrat and father of the current Vice President.
President George "Read My Lips" Bush agreed to a tax increase in 1990. Bob Dole, as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, took the lead in raising taxes in 1982. And every other veteran Republican Senator has agreed to a tax increase or resisted a cut.
This is now a problem for Republican candidates who have held office. They want to show their adherence to the Republican anti-tax creed. But their own records, and their appreciation of the realities of the budget, keep them for doing so unreservedly. So the way is clear for a candidate uncontaminated by prior contact with the Federal budget, who can sing that old sweet song, "Let Me Cut Your Taxes, I Just Love Your Vote." That gives us Steve Forbes and the flat tax.
Of course, the term "flat tax" is a diversion. What it means is "low tax." No one is trudging through New Hampshire trying to sell a 25 percent flat tax. It has to be a 17 percent flat tax or some other impossibly low number because the flat tax is terribly unflat in its impact on different people, depending on whether they have home mortgages or employer-provided health benefits, and so forth
To be attractive, the flat tax has to be low enough so that even those most disadvantaged by it get something. Such a low rate would lose a lot of revenue, but that doesn't bother Mr. Forbes, because he hasn't yet encountered the Federal budget. That is presumably what he means when he boasts of not being a Washington insider.
 Thus cutting taxes serves all purposes in the Forbes campaign. You want 4 percent economic growth? Cut taxes! You want 4 1/2 percent interest rates? Cut taxes!
You want foreign policy? Cutting taxes will make America such a model society that the Serbs, Croats and Bosnians will stop shooting one another and emulate us. You want anti-crime policy? Cut taxes on legal income and you will eliminate the incentive to engage in illegal activity. You want fewer single mothers? Eliminate the tax code's marriage penalty.
The "insider" candidates find it hard to deal with this. They can't say that the Forbes tax rate is much too low. There is no such thing in the Republican campaign lexicon -- or in the Democratic one either -- as a tax rate that is too low.
The political mythology that cutting taxes is the sure road to electoral success is an indication of how few politicians know history. After the Republican 80th Congress cut taxes in 1948, Harry Truman won an election that he wasn't supposed to win. After the Republican 83rd Congress cut taxes in 1954, Democrats took control of the House for 40 years.
Yes, there was one politically successful tax cutter: Ronald Reagan. Mr. Forbes's friends like to compare him to Mr. Reagan. But there are critical differences. For one thing, Mr. Reagan had spontaneous charm. Also, Mr. Reagan had two big issues on which to base his 1980 campaign -- Communism and inflation -- and he later deal with both successfully. And he even went on to raise taxes by his second year in office.
The country faces an entirely different fiscal situation today than in 1980. Then the Federal debt was 26.8 percent of the gross domestic product, only slightly above its postwar low. The ratio today is more than 50 percent, and without a radical change it will likely exceed 100 percent in the next generation. We could afford Ronald Reagan once. We cannot afford him again.
Meanwhile, I'm cool. As far as I can figure it out, the Forbes flat tax would save me a lot money.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Priorities at the Port Authority

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has declared war against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for shortchanging New York City and favoring the interests of New Jersey. The Port Authority is a great regional resource, but unfortunately many of the Mayor's complaints make sense.
Mr. Giuliani's list of examples of the Authority's alleged favoritism to New Jersey is impressively long. Newark International Airport, for example, has a nifty new arrivals building while Kennedy Airport is still saddled with old, depressing and inadequate facilities that make visitors from abroad feel they are arriving steerage class. 
 Thanks to Port Authority subsidies, mass-transit systems that serve New Jersey commuters, from the PATH service to the Port Authority Bus Terminal, cost less than similar services in the rest of the region. In the same vein, the George Washington Bridge toll is $4 for a two-way ride, compared with $6 for the Triborough Bridge on the other side of Manhattan. Mr. Giuliani complains bitterly about shrinking payments from the city's airport leases, which dropped from $84 million to $3 million over a four-year period.
Mr. Giuliani contends that the Authority has cheated New York City out of $400 million in revenue from leases on the city's airports. He complains about "Hollywood accounting" and the fact that the Authority does not give the city a share of the $3-per-passenger facilities tax. The city is suing to get the money back. The issue will ultimately be decided in the courts or by arbitration.
Whatever favoritism may exist, the Port Authority is run by a board of directors equally divided between New York and New Jersey appointees. If the agency has been shortchanging New York City, it has been with both Governors' support. But New York has wasted its influence on trivial or short-sighted purposes. Gov. Mario Cuomo plundered Port Authority resources to balance his last budget, by getting the Authority to "buy" a parking lot at Aqueduct racetrack from the state. Gov. George Pataki insisted on appointing the executive director, and then used that power to make a weak but politically well-connected choice -- George Marlin, a favorite with the New York Conservative Party.
Right now, the Mayor should be pressing the Authority to complete Kennedy Airport's far-from-finished renovations. J.F.K. desperately needs a better international arrivals building, better transportation between terminals and a long-term solution to the problem of getting passengers to the airport. The Port Authority says it is moving on these projects. But it might be moving faster if it were not spending a disproportionate amount of its resources on the $186-million-a-year PATH subsidy.
The PATH train between Manhattan and New Jersey is a critical prop to the regional economy, like the subways and commuter railroads. But there is no reason the Port Authority should use its money to keep New Jersey commuter costs lower than those for city residents or workers from Long Island or Westchester County. If the Port Authority wants to demonstrate its evenhandedness, it can start by raising PATH fares from $1 to $1.50.
Mr. Giuliani can badger the Port Authority further by lobbying for expansion of the bridge capacity between Staten Island and New Jersey, and for serious thinking about rail freight delivery from the airports. He might even remind the Authority that it was formed in the 1920's to build a rail freight tunnel under the Hudson, a job not yet done.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Revolt of the Wannabes

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
As a barometer of global affairs, the annual Davos World Economic Forum is as good an indicator as you can find. The meeting brings together top industrialists and political figures from every corner of the world. Each year, one or two individuals stand out as trend-setters. One year it was Nelson Mandela, then Shimon Peres and Yasir Arafat, then Russian reformers. And that is why this year's Davos Forum was so interesting. Because this year the star -- the man everyone wanted to interview -- was a Communist: Gennadi Zyuganov, head of Russia's resurgent Communist Party.
Think about that. The Davos Forum is the ultimate capitalist convention. It is an annual celebration of globalization -- that loose combination of free-trade agreements, the Internet and the integration of financial markets that is erasing borders and uniting the world into a single, lucrative, but brutally competitive, marketplace. And who is the star but this dinosaur from the Jurassic period of the cold war. How come? 
 It is because the business and political leaders here seem to intuitively understand that Mr. Zyuganov is the cutting edge of a new global trend -- the backlash against global integration and free trade arrangements, which have created many winners but also many losers. The losers are now asserting themselves, whether it is labor unions in France, Pat Buchanan supporters in America or pensioners in Russia.
The Economics Minister of a leading developing country confided to me that his Government was desperate to become part of this new global marketplace. He and his colleagues at the top understand that in order to survive economically and attract foreign investment they have to open up their markets and upgrade their telecommunications, airports and commercial laws. But, he added, "Half the time I am dealing with bureaucrats who don't understand this new game, and half the time I am dealing with workers who are not prepared to compete. We will join in, but it is going to be very painful for some of our people. The cost will be a lot more social unrest and fanaticism. We all have our Zyuganovs."
Another sign of the times was the fact that the day the Davos conference opened, The Herald Tribune ran an essay by Klaus Schwab and Claude Smadja, respectively the founder and managing director of the Davos Forum. It was entitled: "Start Taking the Backlash Against Globalization Seriously." Messrs. Schwab and Smadja are two of the most renowned advocates of global trade and integration. Their essay is the equivalent of the presidents of Ford, G.M. and Chrysler writing an article in the 1960's entitled: "Start Taking Ralph Nader Seriously."
Messrs. Schwab and Smadja wrote that: "Economic globalization has entered a critical phase. A mounting backlash against its effects, especially in the industrial democracies, is threatening a very disruptive impact on economic activity and social stability in many countries. The mood in these democracies is one of helplessness and anxiety, which helps explain the rise of a new brand of populist politicians. This can easily turn into revolt."
It is now clear, they added, that global integration and free trade are not necessarily win-win propositions. Technological advances and productivity increases at corporations don't automatically translate into more jobs at higher wages. Unless countries can help their people adjust to this new world, globalization is going to become synonymous with "a brakeless train wreaking havoc."
When I asked him what prompted him to write the essay, Mr. Schwab said: "In the 19th century people thought the machine was going to destroy their life as they knew it, and today many people think that globalization is going to destroy their life as they know it. We have gotten accustomed to the idea that globalization will inevitably succeed. But I am not so sure anymore. Those of us who believe in globalization need to be more pro-active."
He's right. And the successful governments will be those able to design the right formula of worker training programs, tax policies that create jobs and preserve resources, population controls and sustainable social safety nets to deal with globalization. The good news is that many world leaders are beginning to understand this challenge. The bad news is that no one has found the formula yet.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: No Salvation From the Governors

 BODY:
The nation's governors voted unanimously at their conference yesterday for reforms of welfare and Medicaid that are harsher toward the poor in key respects than anything Congress has passed or that the Republicans privately negotiated with President Clinton in their ill-fated budget talks. This unfortunate outcome is the price for achieving the governors' primary goal of protecting state treasuries. What they did not achieve is a proposal that would guarantee essential security for the impoverished. A civilized, wealthy society should do no less.
On Medicaid, the governors said their plan would split the difference between turning the health insurance program over to the states to run, as the G.O.P. wants, and preserving the existing entitlement that poor families have to medical coverage. But the entitlement has shriveled. The governors' plan would guarantee undefined medical benefits to a diminished group of recipients. 
Under current law, families receiving Federal welfare assistance automatically qualify for Medicaid. But under the governors' plan, states would not have to cover adults or children over age 12, no matter how poor. Worse, the loosely worded requirement would allow states to skimp on hospital and other benefits, making an entitlement of questionable value even for those eligible.
The governors propose giving themselves plenty of room to reduce state Medicaid funds. Gov. George Pataki of New York, for example, would "win" the right to reduce state contributions by 20 percent without sacrificing any Federal money. Nationwide, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities estimates that states could cut their own spending on Medicaid by about $200 billion over seven years under the plan. The governors did improve the Congressional plan in one respect by agreeing to spend more Federal money in states whose Medicaid rolls rise. But whether the formula would truly protect states from soaring Medicaid enrollments is unclear.
The governors' welfare proposal rips away the Federal guarantee of additional money for states experiencing rising welfare rolls, as the President unwisely invited the Republicans to do. It puts a five-year cap on benefits even for adults who can find no job. The proposal would also allow states to make huge cuts -- up to 30 percent -- in the money they spend on welfare. The Federal Government would have little ability to force states to treat their poor residents fairly.
Nor would the plan provide enough money for states to maintain cash and other assistance while also putting recipients to work. The governors would make unacceptable cuts in food stamps and, borrowing the worst planks from the Congressional plan, would allow states to opt out of the Federal food stamp program and cut off childless adults after four months who cannot find work. If that happens, Americans -- who might, under the plan, be losing cash assistance and medical insurance -- would no longer be guaranteed a minimal, federally defined food benefit.
Many Americans held out hope that the bipartisan National Governors' Association would succeed in welfare and Medicaid reforms where Congress and the President miserably failed. But the governors proved parochial. They made sure that Federal law would let them do pretty much as they please when taking care of the poor. That might be a terrific solution for those who believe that states, left alone, would have the will and ability to act generously. But several governors, including Mr. Pataki, are already planning to slice welfare benefits. Over the past two decades, many states have allowed benefits to wither under the force of inflation.
It is not that state legislatures or governors are mean-spirited. States are simply the wrong place to set benefit levels for the poor. They are under tremendous pressure to balance budgets and cannot do so if they take care of the poor in ways that attract more poor families and repel taxpaying families and corporations. The governors say it is unfair to think they would shortchange the poor. The plan they passed overwhelmingly says the opposite.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Big Dawg Barking Up Wrong Tree

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
IN the formal chamber of the august House Judiciary Committee Tuesday, a beefy man in a brown football jersey, wearing orange shoes and a dog collar took his seat, placing on the witness table before him a big orange bone and a dog-faced hat.
This was John Thompson, a k a Big Dawg because he is the founder of the Cleveland Browns' rooting section in Cleveland Stadium known as th' Dawg Pound. He is one of those who, among other things, on cold Sunday afternoons barks at opponents. 
 On Tuesday, Big Dawg No. 1 appeared out of his customary canine element to testify as, he said, "basically a nonelected representative of the Cleveland Browns' fans" on just how important a sports franchise is, and the grief specifically it would cause the fans of the Cleveland community if Art Modell, the owner of the Browns' football team, is allowed to carry out his plans to move the team to Baltimore.
"I'm just one fan," Thompson, a season-ticket holder for 18 years, said emotionally. "There are hundreds of thousands of N.F.L. fans across the country that have the same investments that I do and also the same feelings."
In fact, the only financial investments Thompson has in the team are his Browns jersey and the dawg accouterments that accompanied him into the halls of Congress. There is a substantial emotional investment by many fans into their local teams, to be sure, and it is a meaningful point.
But aver all, Thompson's major investment is his romanticism for the team that in actuality should be named the Modell Browns. It is clear that they are not Cleveland's, since Modell could have moved them to Shanghai if he had wanted to -- whenever he wanted to -- and no amount of growling by Big Dawg could have changed it.
The same is true for the Steinbrenner Yankees, the Mara-Tisch Giants, the Paramount Knicks and Rangers. As well, of course, the O'Malley Dodgers.
Now the lawmakers are looking into a proposal by the National Football League to give it an antitrust exemption so it could prevent a franchise from just up and leaving a community, as Houston will, to Nashville; as the two Los Angeles teams recently did, to St. Louis and Oakland; as the Seattle team is threatening to do, to L.A.
The N.F.L., which will ta'e up the Browns' proposed move at an owners meeting in Chicago today and tomorrow, shouldn't have it. Why should the Government intervene in a private entertainment business? It is highly doubtful, for example, that it would put its foot down if Hollywood studios decided to move to Cleveland. And from a purely economic standpoint, such a move would be of greater financial loss to a community because of the jobs it provides.
"When the Dodgers left Brooklyn," said Neil Sullivan, professor of public administration at Baruch College, and author of "The Dodgers Move West," "the economy of Brooklyn did not collapse. No more than the economy of the South Bronx revived when the Yankees stayed to renovate Yankee Stadium with $120 million of New York City taxpayers' money. The kinds of jobs lost by the departure of a ball club -- ushers, vendors, and so forth -- may hurt a relatively few families, and that should not be minimized, but those kind of jobs do not determine the economic future of a community the size of Brooklyn or the Bronx."
It hurts to have a sports franchise, which one has grown up with, move. It is a symbol, a totem, in many ways of the community. But it is often little more than t'at. In fact, many of the people who lament the leave-taking, say, of the Dodgers, had themselves left Brooklyn for the suburbs, in some cases even before the ball club did.
Flabby politicians often buckle to the extortion demands of sports franchise owners. But when referendums are put to the public to ask if they want to pay for stadium improvements which, naturally, include the building of luxury boxes for the rich, they have often said no. Twice voters in San Francisco and twice in San Jose rejected recent referendums to build new ball parks.
Now George Steinbrenner is seeking more than $600 million for a new ball park in the area. What if that money was put into the schools, the police and fire departments, the housing and the transportation system of the South Bronx?
That would go a longer way toward making the area "major league" than gilding Steinbrenner's luxury boxes.
All big cities suffer similar living problems. Cleveland included. And bread ought to come before circuses, even for Big Dawgs.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Who's Losing Russia?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
The lights are going out all over Russia. Because believers in democracy -- not a majority, but a plurality backed by a free press -- are split into sullen factions, they may deliver Russia back to Communist or some other form of tyranny.
The enemy of reform is its hero of yesteryear. Because Boris Yeltsin and his Kremlin clique fear personal punishment from left or right should they lose power, they are making it impossible for the center to hold. 
 Yeltsin maintains the pretense of reform but has given it a bad name. His need to hold protective office prevents real reformers from presenting a single candidate against the Communists and fascists.
Western governments foolishly abet this division of the democrats by trying to boost Yeltsin's chances of clinging to power. Publicly, we support the $9 billion loan to Russia by the I.M.F., to be construed as a vote of confidence in Yeltsin -- though many Russians believe the money will be diverted to armaments and add to inflation.
Privately, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany passed along to Washington a Kremlin request that statements calling for NATO expansion to Poland be downplayed through June, to save Yeltsin embarrassment after he announces next week.
Such overt and covert propping up of the sclerotic regime is foolish. Just as Western governments' taking sides in Russia's election would backfire, aiding the Reds and browns, we should not intervene by encouraging Yeltsin to hang on, thereby dividing the democrats.
But individual Westerners -- from investors to pundits -- should not hesitate to urge Russian reformers to cut the squabbling and get their act together.
The name of the presidential game is to get into the two-man runoff. One finalist is likely to be the Communist Gennadi Zyuganov. The other could be Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the nationalist wild man; Gen. Aleksandr Lebed, nationalist but not wild, still popular though his party failed in parliamentary elections; Yeltsin, or Grigory Yavlinsky, the only reformer to win a base in Parliament.
Many of the other reformers are sore at Yavlinsky because he rejected unity last year. His strategy was to dissociate himself from the way that Yeltsin's economic aides -- Yegor Gaidar, Boris Fyodorov and the privatizer Anatoly Chubais, fired last week -- botched the transition to a market economy. Yavlinsky could truthfully say "I told you so," and avoid the Yeltsin taint. By going it alone, he survived politically, while voters rejected the others.
Now they're in deep sulk because Yavlinsky is the only reformers' game in town. Gaidar is muttering about supporting Yeltsin's Prime Minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin, who's not even in the race, and Chubais dreamily wishes Yavlinsky would abandon hope and support Yeltsin because "otherwise the Communists will win and Grisha [Yavlinsky] will be in prison along with me."
That dog-in-the-manger attitude is understandable but unrealistic. The parliamentary election centered on economics; the presidential will decide between freedom and tyranny.
In the runoff, Yeltsin is sure he could beat Zhirinovsky, which explains why he is surreptitiously helping his campaign now; But Yeltsin would likely lose to the Communist Zyuganov. Yeltsin might not even make it to the runoff; even if he did, and dramatically changed his mind on Chechnya and won in an upset, his election would spell doom for free-market democracy.
That leaves Yavlinsky. Yes, he's a long shot, but so is everybody else. If democratic reformers quietly united, that would push him into the high teens, within striking distance of the 25 percent or so needed for the runoff, and a sure bet if Yeltsin steps aside or falls ill again. There is talk in Moscow of a reformers' coalition with Lebed, who is anti-Communist and anti-Yeltsin, and might find attractive the Defense Ministry and later a reconstituted vice presidency.
The Communist vote, mainly pensioners and former apparatchiks, is solid but far from a majority; if the runoff posed a plain choice between Communist past and democratic future, the democrat could surprise.
But nothing is possible without reformist unity. That might persuade Boris Yeltsin -- the man now "losing Russia" -- to once again play the patriot and stop splitting the movement he betrayed.

HEADLINE: Yale Clerical Workers Strike as Talks Stall

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Clerical workers at Yale University went on strike this morning, setting up picket lines that led many professors to hold classes off campus in churches, movie theaters and private homes.
The walkout came less than a month after graduate teaching assistants abandoned a job action involving the withholding of students' grades. They had begun the action in an attempt to win recognition for their union, but they did not succeed. 
 Union leaders said that nearly 2,000 workers, who handle much of the paperwork on campus, had set a one-month deadline for the first phase of the strike. If the contract dispute is not resolved in that time, they said, maintenance, dining hall and custodial workers will follow. All belong to locals of the Federation of University Employees. The average salary of the clerical workers is $25,000 a year; the other workers are paid an average of $30,000.
The unions are seeking raises, better pension benefits and an end to subcontracting with nonunion labor, but their major concern is job security.
"People don't go on strike for a quarter-an-hour raise," Deborah Chernoff, a union spokeswoman, said. "They feel their livelihood is being threatened."
The unions today offered to submit the dispute to binding arbitration, but university negotiators refused.
For its part, the university, which has been running an operating deficit for five years, is seeking changes in the contract to help hold down costs by means of what a spokesman, Gary Fryer, calls "greater freedom to manage its work force." That might entail the hiring of outside workers and the creation of a two-tier pay scale so that new employees would earn less and have less costly benefits than present staff members.
Student opinion about the strike was mixed. Ramzi Zein, a fifth-year economics student, said: "I fully sympathize with the strikers. What they're doing is necessary to keep the administration in check."
Other students seemed indifferent. Kevin Shertzer, a junior majoring in history, said: "It's like the O. J. Simpson trial. You hear so much about it, you turn your ears off."
Craig Yacks, a sophomore majoring in American Studies, spoke for many students when he said, "As long as it doesn't affect me, I'm not interested."
Yale has a long history of labor disputes. Although the last two contracts were settled amicably, in 1984 a 10-week strike closed campus dining halls, and in 1977, the university endured a 13-week labor dispute. There were also walkouts in 1971 and 1974.
Ms. Chernoff charged that Yale was "more interested in the bottom line than in living up to its lofty ideals."
But Mr. Fryer contended that union demands for improved benefits were farfetched since Yale already provides "the most generous benefits package" of any competing university in the country, including free health insurance and up to $8,400 a year in scholarship aid per child for the children of workers.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
California propositions are antilawyer, and no joke.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
MANY people talk of cutting lawyers down to size. The Alliance to Revitalize California has a plan to do it.
This unusual coalition of politics-shy Silicon Valley executives and seasoned consumer advocates has declared war on civil litigation they consider excessive. Should the three propositions they managed to place on California's March 26 ballot pass, thousands of lawyers may be looking for new jobs. 
 Of the three initiatives, the one that has galvanized support from Intel, Intuit, Seagate, Symantec and Cypress Semiconductor is Proposition 201 -- "shareholder litigation reform" aimed at curtailing class-action suits that end in greenmail for plaintiffs' lawyers. But Proposition 202, the "lawyer contingent fee limitation" prohibiting lawyers from taking more than 15 percent of an easily negotiated settlement, would affect more people. And Proposition 200, "pure no-fault auto insurance," would radically alter the legal landscape.
Indeed, the no-fault initiative, which would virtually eliminate litigation over auto accidents, is so revolutionary that it deserves a closer look. "We've finally found a way to bullet-proof auto insurance from the greed of the trial lawyers," argues Jeffrey O'Connell, a professor of law at the University of Virginia who has spent much of his career promoting no-fault.
The logic is simple: when someone is injured in a car accident it is costly to assign blame, and the contest creates uncertainty for those injured. With no-fault, insurers simply pay for the medical care and lost income of their own customers.
But no-fault has never fully delivered on its promise to slash litigation because plaintiffs' lawyers have managed to write loopholes into state laws. Where injuries exceed a threshold, usually set by the cost of medical treatment, the injured party can sue for "pain and suffering" as for economic losses. And in states without no-fault, practically anything goes: 20 cents of the auto insurance premium dollar in California ends up in lawyers' pockets.
Proposition 200 would bar suits, except when drunken driving is a factor. The standard policy would provide $1 million in coverage against economic losses. Drivers who want the option of collecting for pain and suffering could insure themselves, much the way they can now buy coverage for uninsured motorists.
The Rand Corporation estimates that pure no-fault costs half as much as current auto liability insurance. Since collision and theft losses would not be affected, the savings on premiums in California would average about 25 percent.
Part of the savings would come from reduced fraud: 99 injury claims are made for every 100 auto accidents in Los Angeles -- triple the national average. As important, says Andrew Tobias, a financial writer and liberal crusader who helped write the initiative, Proposition 200 would sharply improve the odds of receiving compensation. "Who are you going to sue," Mr. Tobias asks, if you are injured by an uninsured driver (28 percent of all motorists in California), or if you injure yourself (16 percent of accidents)? Pedestrians, by the way, would automatically get $1 million coverage from an insurance pool.
The lawyers will not be pushovers. Last year they persuaded the Governor of Hawaii, a former trial lawyer, to veto pure no-fault legislation that would have required insurers to lower liability premiums by 45 percent. And they are not watching from the sidelines in California. In November the Consumer Attorneys of California, a trade association, warned members that "your future as a lawyer is at stake" and sought $99 contributions for its political action committee since only gifts "over $100 are a matter of public record."
More surprising -- and more ominous from the prospective of the sponsors -- consumer organizations are divided on the initiative. Bill Westenmeyer, director of the group that drafted the proposition that rolled back auto insurance premiums in California in 1988, is on the board of the Alliance. So is Mike Johnson, formerly on the staff of Public Citizen, Ralph Nader's lobbying group.
But Mr. Nader opposes no-fault, arguing that it deprives Americans of their right to a day in court. And his long shadow has apparently influenced the view of others. Consumers Union, which for a quarter-century has supported less radical no-fault, is fighting Proposition 200. "The notion that somebody could run a red light, wipe out a family and not pay would lead to frontier justice," argues Harry Snyder of Consumers Union.
Mr. Tobias acknowledges the emotional power of the day-in-court argument, but wonders why the best has become such a potent enemy of the good. He says that Rand found that the most seriously injured -- those with economic losses exceeding $100,000 -- now get an average of just 9 percent in compensation. "Californians would be better protected than they are today, and still save a bundle," he concludes.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Sears Shows Strength in 4th-Quarter Earnings Amid Slowness in Retailing

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
In a quarter expected to be dismal for retailers, Sears, Roebuck & Company proved to be an exception yesterday, reporting a strong improvment in fourth-quarter results.
For the quarter that ended Dec. 30, Sears earned $455 million, or $1.13 a share, down 33.6 percent from $685 million, or $1.74 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. 
 But the quarter a year ago included gains of $134 million from the spinoff of Allstate Insurance and the sale of the Homart Development Company and $195 million from the early repayment of debt. Without those gains, earnings from continuing operations rose 28 percent, from $356 million, or 90 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
The results were slightly higher than estimates of $1.11 a share, according to a survey of analysts by First Call. And the results were especially strong, analysts said, given that the holiday shopping season was one of the worst in 25 years, depressing the profits at most other retailers.
"You'd be hard pressed to find anybody that grew earnings at this rate in the retail industry," said Philip Abbenhaus, an analyst with Stifel Nicolaus & Company in St. Louis.
Shares of Sears surged $1.625 yesterday, to $44.25, on the New Stock Exchange
Sears said sales rose 7 percent, to $10.85 billion from $10.19 billion. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 5.8 percent.
Sales at its 800 Sears stores were strong in both the hard lines, such as home electronics and exercise equipment, and the soft lines, including apparel and cosmetics. Sears said sales were also strong in its 1,200 stores outside of malls, which include Homelife furniture and Sears hardware.
Sears's strong sales and earnings come as other retailers have struggled to gain sales from consumers worried about their job security and the economy. Still, Sears posted a healthy 6.8 percent increase in December's same-store sales.
"Sears was one of the few that had a good Christmas," said Joseph Ronning, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman in New York.
Its January same-store sales, which will be reported today, are expected to rise about 2 percent, dragged down by severe winter weather throughout the month. Even that small increase is better than what is expected for many of its competitors.
Analysts credited Sears's recent successes to a revamping by the chairman and chief executive, Arthur Martinez, who joined the retailer three years ago and took his current post in August.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Japan Trade and German Report Help Dollar vs. Yen and Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday on the strength of improved trade numbers with Japan and a newspaper report that the German Government was about to report higher unemployment figures.
The dollar's rise against the Japanese yen came on the back of a United States report that showed the trade deficit with Japan dropped in November to its lowest level since May 1993. Figures issued in Japan earlier in the day showed its overall trade surplus narrowed last year. 
 Traders pushed the dollar higher against the German mark on new speculation that Germany would have to lower interest rates to spur its economy. Lower rates devalue a country's assets and currency.
"The fears about Germany not easing have been almost completely unwound because of the unemployment report," said John Rothfield, an international economist at the Chicago office of Nationsbanc-CRT.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar was trading at 1.4770 marks, compared with 1.4710 marks on Tuesday. It finished at 106.10 yen, up from 105.20 yen the day before. The British pound slipped to $1.5368 from $1.5415.
The dollar began its rise against the yen as the Japanese Government announced that its trade surplus in goods and services fell 15 percent in 1995, the second straight annual decline. Later, the Commerce Department reported that the United States deficit with Japan had dropped.
That led traders to realize that the United States trade imbalance with Japan, a sore point between the two countries, "would not be with us forever," Mr. Rothfield said.
The improved trade numbers were seen as a sign of encouragement that Japanese policy to weaken the yen by cutting the trade imbalance was working.
In Germany, a newspaper reported that the Government would announce today that unemployment jumped to 10.8 percent in January, from 9.9 percent in December.
The numbers show "that the German economy really stopped in the second half of last year," Mr. Rothfield of Nationsbank-CRT said. The dollar will benefit, he said, now that the Bundesbank "has a vested interest for the dollar to go higher," particularly through continued interest rate cuts.
