HEADLINE: Belgrade Journal;
Scathing 'Conscience' of Balkans Spares No One

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia

 BODY:
During the Balkan war, most artists and writers in what was once Yugoslavia used their talents to glorify the ideologies that fuel violence or have found themselves silenced.
But amid the cacophony there has been one artist with enough stature in all six republics of the former Yugoslavia to continue to ridicule the nationalism and triumphalism that comes out of Belgrade, Zagreb and Sarajevo. 
 Dusan Kovacevic, a quiet, reclusive figure, was Yugoslavia's best-known playwright and screenwriter before the war. One of his plays, "The Professional," which has been running in Belgrade since 1989, was staged by Circle Repertory Company in New York last year and his film "Underground" won the Palme d'Or at the 1995 Cannes Film Festival. Within the former Yugoslavia his movies have achieved cult status. And the often cynical new generation, which has paid in blood for the nationalist dreams of its leaders, recites lines from his work like mantras.
"Don't let them kill you until we've won," taken from the play "Radovan III," is, like dozens of other lines, part of the vocabulary here.
"He has become our conscience," said Boba Durovic, a leading Belgrade theater director, "although there are a lot of people who would rather not listen."
Mr. Kovacevic sat on the edge of a couch, smoking a cigarette, in a small coffee shop in downtown Belgrade recently. He rarely appears in public, remaining at home with his wife, who is a lawyer, and two children.
"Look across the whole of the former Yugoslavia," he said sadly, "and all you see are works that glorify the nationalist ideologies that have crept up. There has been a terrible corruption of the arts. It reminds me of the Communist rule under Tito. We filmed some 800 movies in the old Yugoslavia after the end of World War II and about 500 of them were about the war. Not a single one was any good. We made stupid movies for 50 years.
"It is happening all over again, only now we have six states producing them. War is a great opportunity for mediocre writers and artists. Art cannot be motivated by hate."
Mr. Kovacevic, a 47-year-old Serb, began exploring the violent and self-destructive nature of his society long before it burst onto the world's television screens four years ago. "Radovan III," for example, focuses on a character who is so obsessed with the destruction of his enemies that he ultimately destroys himself.
In "The Professional," his 12th play, he strikes this familiar theme. The two main characters are divided by age, ideology, ethnicity and social circumstances. Teya was a dissident who is now flourishing with the collapse of Communism. Luke, a former secret policeman who spied on Teya, has had to deal with the destruction of a world that gave him meaning. He now drives a cab. The two are drawn together by their past relationship, although the men have changed roles. The oppressed has become the oppressor, and the new power structure is as corrupt and immoral as the old.
Like Louis-Ferdinand Celine and Edward Albee, Mr. Kovacevic insists on plumbing the depths of human despair and depravity with black humor. It is humor, he says, that best points out the incongruity of a people living in economic and political decline but clutching at fantastic myths of past glory and achievement.
He rarely raises political themes directly, writing instead about the intimate relationships between individuals.
"The war that never ends is the war between the parent and the child, the father and the son," he said. "The only solution is love and compassion. In our families we have fought too often over ideologies. Private wars have led to real wars. This is our fate."
Mr. Kovacevic is fascinated with the powerful criminal underworld that has risen from the wreckage of Communism across Eastern Europe and in Russia. He is now working on a play about the gangsters who he says control the theaters, along with nearly everything else, in Serbia. He describes Belgrade as "like Chicago in the days of Al Capone."
"In Belgrade we have a better class of criminal than we do artist," he said. "We suffer from primitive capitalism and this means we also suffer from primitive art. It all reminds me of Woody Allen's 'Bullets Over Broadway,' where petty mobsters have been handed the control of everything from our factories to our cultural life."
"Power has not changed that much," he went on. "The old Communist bosses are now the new capitalist managers. These old bosses just work for Mafia dons instead of the party."
Although he is a practicing member of the Eastern Orthodox Church, he has a deep distrust of authority. And he worries that Serbs, Croats and Muslims in the former Yugoslavia have embraced a pattern of self-destruction that, if left unexamined, will lead again to bloodshed. He says the NATO-led troops deployed to separate the rival factions in Bosnia will have to stay 20 years if they want to prevent another war.
"The main theme of all of my work is the insecurity of the individual before the system," he said. "It does not matter what the system is called, what ideology it embraces, the distortion done to the individual, the violence carried out by the system against the individual, is always the same and so is the result."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Serbian writer Dusan Kovacevic, seen in his Belgrade home, is one artist with enough stature in all six republics of the former Yugoslavia to ridicule the ideologies that have fed the violence there. (Ivan Milutinovic for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: North Korea Tells Groups To Halt Drive For Flood Aid

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Retreating from a landmark policy decision to seek international assistance, North Korea has told foreign relief agencies not to organize new appeals for flood victims who by some accounts are on the verge of famine.
Relief officials in New York, Geneva and elsewhere say they believe that conditions in the North Korean countryside remain desperate. But they have set aside plans for new appeals, while hoping that North Korea will reconsider. 
 North Korea's Foreign Ministry blamed army leaders in part for the change in policy, the relief officials said. Deputy Foreign Minister Choe Su Hon reportedly explained that some military leaders had opposed the policy decision, made last year, to seek outside help, and that these critics had capitalized on the problems that arose in the attempt to open the country.
The request for aid last year was an extraordinary step for North Korea, and an acknowledgement of its economic problems. The appeal was widely regarded as a milestone in the effort to ease North Korea's isolation in international affairs.
It is unclear whether the decision marks a complete reversal of policy, or something much milder, and the North Korean Government has not clarified its position.
"We just have to wait and see," said Simon Missiri, deputy director of the Asia-Pacific Department of the International Federation of the Red Cross in Geneva. "One way or another, aid has to come. Otherwise, there will be a big crisis for sure."
A United Nations official in New York said, "They haven't completely closed the door." North Korean diplomats at the United Nations in New York and Geneva did not rule out resuming aid later in the year.
The North Korean Foreign Ministry suggested to the aid organizations, however, that if they do not now have assistance in the pipeline, they might as well go home.
If the change in policy proves to be a lasting one, it is likely to lead to a further increase in nervousness along the heavily-armed border between North and South Korea. Tension is already higher this winter, partly because North Korea moved some fighters and bombers closer to the frontier. Any sign that North Korea is retreating into greater isolation or that its army is gaining influence will add to fears in the south.
The first hint of the latest development came on Friday in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang. Mr. Choe addressed the heads of a half-dozen relief groups, reportedly going out of his way to express gratitude for the aid. But he noted that North Korea has said that although last year's floods caused $5 billion damage, the United Nations opened a $15 million appeal and raised only $5 million.
In an unusual acknowledgment of splits within the North Korean Government -- and one of several references to the army -- Mr. Choe reportedly said that the decision to ask for aid had been a very difficult one, achieved over military objections. He said that problems also had been seized upon by forces both within North Korea, which he identified as the army, and outside the country, by which he apparently meant South Korea.
Mr. Choe emphasized that North Korea would continue to accept aid already in the works -- including, although he did not mention it, a $2 million package from Washington.
Washington agreed to give the assistance to North Korea, with which it does not have diplomatic relations, after recent consultations with Japan and South Korea. Both are irritated that North Korea seemed ungrateful for food assistance sent last year, and said that they would not give further aid.
The significance of Mr. Choe's references to military hard-liners, which echo similar comments made by other officials, is unclear. Many experts believe that the army may indeed be taking a tougher line, but Foreign Ministry officials would not mention the split unless they had approval from those same hard-liners in the military leadership.
Thus it may be that the Government is in part using a good cop-bad cop approach as a way of explaining its twists and turns of policy, officials and scholars say.
Over the past year, North Korea has been unusually accommodating to relief agencies, allowing them unprecedented access to rural areas and to information. Based on what their staff members have seen, the agencies are unanimous in saying that the shortage of food is extremely serious and that North Korea risks a major famine later this year.
The latest reports indicate that for the first time schools have no heat or electricity this winter, and that because of sub-freezing temperatures, schools were closed throughout the country for January. Schools have reopened, but are still unheated and attendance is said to be down 20 to 30 percent because of sickness.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues End Day Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday, as the market showed its disappointment with a sale of new 10-year notes.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 13/32 , to 10924/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.15 percent, from 6.12 percent on Tuesday 
 The sale of the 10-year notes was the second leg of the Treasury's three-part, $44.5 billion quarterly refunding. Although the $14 billion offering was sold near expectations, bids at the auction were a little softer than expected and retail interest was thin.
The average yield at auction for the 10-year note was 5.649 percent, down from 5.9 percent in November and the lowest yield on record.
"Typically one out of three auctions goes poorly, said Doug Burtnick, a managing analyst at Technical Data, a market research and analysis firm in Boston, "and it seems that the 10's were the refunding's sacrificial lamb."
As a result, market participants said yesterday that they expected that securities dealers might have to make additional yield concessions for today's auction of $12 billion in new 30-year bonds.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the long bond was being offered at a price to yield 6.09 percent, up about three-hundredths of a percentage point from the previous trading day.
Gary Thayer, senior economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, said while yields were at historic lows, they were not as attactive to investors as they would like.
He said that while the auction of 10-year notes was not a disaster, the soft demand raised concern in the market.
In addition to the long bond, the Treasury plans to sell $8 billion in seven-day cash management bills.
Bond prices received some support yesterday from the third consecutive decline in gold prices, whose recent rally had troubled the Treasury market over the last week. Surging gold prices are typically an indicator of inflationary pressures, and while supply and demand factors had been behind the metal's rally, the rise still disturbed many market participants. Yesterday, gold for April delivery fell $3.20, to $411.40 an ounce at the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, its largest one-day drop since Nov. 22.
Economic news is sparse this week, and the only reports out yesterday were the November trade deficit report, which showed the nation's trade gap narrowing by 13.5 percent.
Imports fell seven-tenths of 1 percent and exports rose nine-tenths of 1 percent. The trade deficit with Japan shrank to $4.13 billion, lowest since $3.7 billion in May 1993.
Consumer credit for December came in near expectations, economists said, with borrowing rising by $7.9 billion but at a slower pace.
Today, the market will get a look at initial weekly jobless claims for the period ended Jan. 27. Analysts expect the numbers to be off slightly to 385,000, from 388,000.
